('20', 0, 1, 2, 38) 1. CONGRESS REPORT ON THE PUNJAB DISORDERS 1
('20', 0, 2, 3, 83) CHAPTER I
('20', 0, 3, 4, 93) THE PUNJAB
('20', 0, 4, 5, 104) (HISTORICAL AND GEOGRAPHICAL) Historically the Punjab may be considered the most important province of India.
('20', 0, 4, 6, 214) It was here that the Aryas of Vedic times first made their home.
('20', 0, 4, 7, 279) It was here that the hymns of the Rig Veda were first chanted.
('20', 0, 4, 8, 342) It was to this province, at the great University of Taxila, that seekers after knowledge flocked from various parts of the world.
('20', 0, 4, 9, 472) It was in this province that the Pandus and the Kurus, the great heroes of the Mahabharata, fought out their great battles.
('20', 0, 4, 10, 596) It was here that Osiris, King of Egypt, first touched Indian soil and Semiramis, Queen of Assyria, who at the head of her vast armies tried her fortune for the dominion of India, suffered a crushing defeat.
('20', 0, 4, 11, 803) The Scythians and Tartars and Persians had to measure swords with the sons of the Punjab in their attempts to penetrate into India.
('20', 0, 4, 12, 935) It was in this province that Alexander the Great, though victorious, for the first time met a foe, under King Porus, who shattered his dream of a world wide dominion.
('20', 0, 5, 13, 1102) 1 Authorship of this Report, the full title of which reads Report of the Commis sioners oppointed by the Punjab Sub committee of the Indian National Congress, and which was published on March 25, 1920, has been attributed to Gandhiji on the basis of the following evidence : (I)”The responsibility of organizing the work of the Committee devolved on me, and as the privilege of conducting the inquiry in the largest number of places fell to my lot, I got a rare opportunity.
('20', 0, 5, 14, 1577) The task of drafting the report of this Committee was also entrusted to me.
('20', 0, 5, 15, 1653) This reprot, prepared as it was solely with a view to bringing out the truth and nothing but the truth, will enable the reader to see.
('20', 0, 5, 16, 1788) .” An Autobiography, Part V, Ch. XXXV.
('20', 0, 5, 17, 1827) (ii) a.”Whole day spent in discussing Gandhi’s draft Report.” The Story of My Life by M. R. Jayakar, Vol. I, p.
('20', 0, 5, 18, 1939) 322. b.”The Report was drawn up by Gandhi, with assistance from me.” Ibid.
('20', 0, 5, 19, 2014) c.”Gandhi made the first draft of the Report in a quiet little room.” Ibid.
('20', 0, 5, 20, 2090) d.”By that time, Das, Motilal and Tyabji had dropped out, and Gandhi and myself worked hard on the publication of the Report.”.
('20', 0, 5, 21, 2218) (iii) Letters produced in this volume which Gandhiji wrote to Jayakar during March 1920. The Report was published in two volumes, Volume I consisting of the Report and Volume II consisting of Evidence.
('20', 0, 5, 22, 2420) Here, only Volume I has been reproduced.
('20', 1, 0, 1, 2461) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('20', 1, 1, 2, 2501) The Punjab proper is the land watered by the five rivers, the Sutlej, the Beas, the Ravi, the Chenab and the Jhelum, from which it derives its name.
('20', 1, 1, 3, 2650) It is situated in the north west of India, and is bounded on the north by a portion of the Himalayas and Kashmir, on the west by the Indus, on the south by Sind and Rajputana, and on the east by the river Jamna.
('20', 1, 2, 4, 2862) The present area of the Punjab is 135, 773 square miles, out of which a little less than 100,000 square miles is directly under British rule, the rest being ruled by Indian princes and chiefs.
('20', 1, 2, 5, 3055) The population in 1911 was slightly less than 20 millions.
('20', 1, 2, 6, 3114) The province used to be much larger before, but in 1901 it was partitioned and a new province, now called the North West Frontier Province, was carved out of it.
('20', 1, 2, 7, 3276) Another slice was taken off in 1912, when the Capital of the British Indian Empire was shifted to Delhi, and the city of Delhi and a part of the surrounding territory were constituted into a distinct province.
('20', 1, 2, 8, 3486) The Punjab is inhabited mostly by Hindus, Mohammedans and Sikhs.
('20', 1, 2, 9, 3551) The Sikhs have their home in the Punjab and number about 3 1 2 million.
('20', 1, 2, 10, 3623) The chief occupation of the people is agriculture, but other industries are making headway and a considerable number of factories worked by steam have sprung up in various towns of the Punjab.
('20', 1, 3, 11, 3816) The Punjab supplies the flower of the British Indian Army.
('20', 1, 3, 12, 3875) During the late War 1 the contribution of the Punjab to the army was the largest of all provinces of India.
('20', 1, 4, 13, 3983) Among the fighting classes the Sikhs hold the foremost place and Rajputs and Jats come next.
('20', 1, 4, 14, 4076) The Rajputs and Jats of the western and southern parts are mostly Mussulmans and those of the eastern and northern parts are Hindus.
('20', 1, 4, 15, 4209) The Jats of the Central Punjab are mostly Sikhs.
('20', 1, 4, 16, 4258) We give in Sir Michael O’Dwyer’s 2 own words the Punjab’s war contribution in men.
('20', 1, 4, 17, 4341) Speaking on the 7th April last, Sir Michael O’Dwyer said :
('20', 1, 5, 18, 4400) I have spoken so often about the War and the Punjab’s share in it during the last year that I need say but little today.
('20', 1, 5, 19, 4521) We started the War with 100,000 men in the Army.
('20', 1, 6, 20, 4570) 1 World War I, 1914 18 2 Lt.
('20', 1, 6, 21, 4599)  Governor of the Punjab, 1913 19
('20', 2, 0, 1, 4632) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 3
('20', 2, 1, 2, 4670) In 1917, I was able to tell you that in the first 2 1 2 years of the War we had
('20', 2, 2, 3, 4750) raised 124,000 combatants.
('20', 2, 2, 4, 4777) In the next year we raised over 127,000 and a year ago the total was over a quarter of a million.
('20', 2, 2, 5, 4875) We were then in the most critical stage of the War and in response to His Majesty’s August Message and the Premier’s appeal, I asked the province to raise another 200,000 men including 180,000 fighting men within a year.
('20', 2, 2, 6, 5096) Many people thought that was an extravagant demand.
('20', 2, 2, 7, 5148) Those people did not know the spirit of the Punjab.
('20', 2, 2, 8, 5200) April and May 1918 were the harvest months and we advisedly did not push recruiting.
('20', 2, 2, 9, 5285) But 21,000 men were enrolled.
('20', 2, 3, 10, 5315) From June to September the recruiting campaign was carried on everywhere with great enthusiasm, and in those four months 78,000 men or over 19,500 per month joined the colours.
('20', 2, 3, 11, 5492) In October, owing to the influenza epidemic, the number dropped to 14,426 and in November, when we were about to make a fresh effort, our enemies collapsed and hostilities came to an end, and the number fell to 6,313, but in six months, from June to November, we had raised 99,000 men, or half of the total promised, and in the eight months, April to November, our total was 121,000 men, including 1,00,000 combatants.
('20', 2, 3, 12, 5911) If the need had continued, we should have completed our quota of 200,000. As it is, we can claim to have raised about 360,000 combatants during the four years of War, or more than half the total raised in the Indian Empire, excluding, of course, the splendid contribution from our gallant neighbours and allies in Nepal.
('20', 2, 4, 13, 6232) The distribution of the 355,000 combatants by main religions and tribes is roughly as follows :
('20', 2, 5, 14, 6328) MOHAMMEDANS 1,20,00
('20', 2, 6, 15, 6348) Pathans
('20', 2, 7, 16, 6356) Mohammedans from North & Central
('20', 2, 8, 17, 6389) Punjab, commonly known as
('20', 2, 9, 18, 6415) Punjabi Mohammedans
('20', 2, 10, 19, 6435) Mohammedans from South Punjab
('20', 2, 11, 20, 6465) Kashmiris
('20', 2, 12, 21, 6475) Other Mohammedans
('20', 2, 14, 22, 6493) 1,36,000
('20', 2, 18, 23, 6502) SIKHS 90,000
('20', 2, 19, 24, 6515) HINDUS 90,000
('20', 3, 0, 1, 6529) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('20', 3, 1, 2, 6569) Jats 30,000
('20', 3, 2, 3, 6581) Dogras 24,000
('20', 3, 3, 4, 6595) Other Rajputs 10,000
('20', 3, 4, 5, 6616) Ahirs 10,000
('20', 3, 5, 6, 6629) Gujars 6,000
('20', 3, 6, 7, 6642) Gaur Brahmins 5,000

('20', 3, 9, 10, 6704) The Mohammedans forming 5/9th of the population, gave 48 per cent of
('20', 3, 10, 11, 6773) the recruits, Hindus with 3/9th of the population, furnished 1 4 th, while the
('20', 3, 11, 12, 6852) Sikhs, though only 1/9th of the population, also furnished 1 4 th.
('20', 3, 12, 13, 6919) As I said last year the fighting men were drawn almost exclusively, and the non combatants mainly, from the rural population, both for Army and even in the Indian Defence Force; the townsfolk made but a slight response to the call for men, though they helped generously in the War Loan.
('20', 3, 12, 14, 7206) But most of the rural Hindus did splendidly in recruiting and their proportionate recruitment, though much below of the Sikhs, is nearly equal to that of the Punjabi Mohammedans.
('20', 3, 12, 15, 7385) The administration of the Punjab is carried on by a Lieutenant Governor, who has a Legislative Council under him—the members of which are partly elected and partly nominated.
('20', 3, 13, 16, 7560) The capital of the Punjab is and has always been at Lahore, which is a big town with a population of about 250,000, situated at a distance of about 1,200 miles from Calcutta, 300 miles from Delhi, 784 miles from Karachi, and 1,162 miles from Bombay.
('20', 3, 13, 17, 7810) The province is divided into 5 divisions under Commissioners, comprising 28 Districts under Deputy Commissioners or Collectors, viz., Ambala Division comprising the eastern part of the Punjab including Simla, the summer headquarters of the Government of India; Jullundur, including the mountainous and sub mountainous parts; Lahore, the central parts; Rawalpindi, the north western; and Multan, the western part of the Punjab.
('20', 3, 14, 18, 8237) CHAPTER II
('20', 3, 15, 19, 8248) SIR MICHAEL O’DWYER’S ADMINISTRATION
('20', 3, 16, 20, 8285) Gentlemen, I have often been criticized for dwelling on the achievements
('20', 4, 0, 1, 8358) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 5
('20', 4, 1, 2, 8396) of the Punjab in season and out of season.
('20', 4, 1, 3, 8439) But my pride in the province is based on no narrow parochial spirit.
('20', 4, 1, 4, 8508) I have spent 15 years away from it, during which I have seen many other parts of India.
('20', 4, 1, 5, 8596) I might indeed say, much have I seen and known, cities, men and manners, climates, councils, governments.
('20', 4, 1, 6, 8702) But nowhere did I find the same qualities as the Punjab can show, from the prince’s palace down to the peasant’s hut.
('20', 4, 1, 7, 8820) I found I could meet the Punjabi, whatever his class or condition, as man to man without suspicion or mistrust.
('20', 4, 1, 8, 8932) I found him, in the mass, loyal but not subservient, brave but not boastful, enterprising but not visionary, progressive but not pursuing false ideals, or mistaking the shadow for the substance.
('20', 4, 1, 9, 9127) These are the qualities which have made the Punjab among the provinces of India ‘not least but honoured of them all’, and these are the qualities which, combined with the moral courage that will be so essential in the times before you, will keep the Punjab in the vanguard of progress and prosperity.
('20', 4, 1, 10, 9428) This is what Sir M. O’Dwyer said in a public speech made on the 7th April, the day after the universal hartal in India and three days before the firing on unarmed people at Amritsar and Lahore and the murders and arson in Amritsar.
('20', 4, 1, 11, 9660) The quotation is from the speech he delivered at his last meeting in the Council prior to his then intended departure.
('20', 4, 1, 12, 9779) But the same speech also contains the following :
('20', 4, 2, 13, 9829) The Government of this province is and will remain determined that public order, which was maintained so successfully during the time of war, shall not be disturbed in the time of peace.
('20', 4, 2, 14, 10016) Action has, therefore, already been taken under the Defence of India Act 1 against certain individuals at Lahore and Amritsar, who, whatever their motives, were openly endeavouring to rouse public feeling against the Government.
('20', 4, 2, 15, 10245) The British Government, which has crushed foreign foes and quelled internal rebellion, could afford to despise these agitators, but it has a duty of protection to the young and the ignorant, whom they may incite to mischief and crime, while themselves standing aside.
('20', 4, 2, 16, 10513) I, therefore, take this opportunity of warning all, who are connected with political movements in the province, that they will be held responsible for the proper conduct of meetings which they organize, for the language used at and the consequences that follow such meetings.
('20', 4, 2, 17, 10789) Subject to these provisions the Government has no desire to restrict, in any way, the right of public meetings; but it is a matter of common knowledge that those who organize such meetings, even with quite legitimate objects, often lack moral courage or authority to restrain some of the more violent speakers.
('20', 4, 2, 18, 11100) It is also, I fear, only
('20', 4, 3, 19, 11125) 1 Passed in 1915 as an”essential war measure”
('20', 5, 0, 1, 11171) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('20', 5, 1, 2, 11211) too true that owing to the wild, reckless language which a handful of noisy agitators habitually indulge in, sober and reasonable men, with regard for their izzat 1, shrink from attending such meetings.
('20', 5, 1, 3, 11414) Restraining influen ces are,
('20', 5, 2, 4, 11443) therefore, either absent or are not exercised.
('20', 5, 2, 5, 11490) Hence the necessity for my warning, which is addressed to the Press as well as to the platform.
('20', 5, 2, 6, 11586) I would ask, in all seriousness, is this the calm and reasonable atmosphere which is needed to prepare the way for constitutional reforms?
('20', 5, 2, 7, 11725) It certainly is not, and those who are creating that unhealthy atmosphere are the deadliest enemies of the cause of re form, which they propose to champion.
('20', 5, 2, 8, 11882) Fortunately, their influence does not cor respond to the noise they make.
('20', 5, 2, 9, 11956) They do not speak with the voice of the Punjab.
('20', 5, 2, 10, 12004) He then expatiated on the inoffensive nature of the Rowlatt Act 2
('20', 5, 3, 11, 12070) and said about it what was not true, namely, that it conferred on the police no powers of arbitrary arrest, search or interference.
('20', 5, 3, 12, 12202) Everyone who has read the Rowlatt Act knows that it does contain such powers, and that it is because it contains such powers that it was so strongly objected to by the people.
('20', 5, 3, 13, 12378) Sir Michael, however, was not satisfied with his fanciful description of the Rowlatt Act.
('20', 5, 3, 14, 12468) He wanted to show what he felt about the great demonstration of the 6th April, which for thousands upon thousands was of a semi religious character because of the fast.
('20', 5, 3, 15, 12637) He laughed at it in this manner :
('20', 5, 4, 16, 12671) The recent puerile demonstrations against the Rowlatt Act in both Lahore and Amritsar would be ludicrous if they did not indicate how easily the ignorant and the credulous people, not one in a thousand of whom knows anything of the measure, can be misled.
('20', 5, 4, 17, 12927) Those who want only to mislead them incur a serious responsibility.
('20', 5, 4, 18, 12995) I would remind them of President Lincoln’s famous saying :”You can, if you are very clever and very unscrupulous, mislead all people for some time and some people for all time, but you cannot mislead all people for all time.” Those who appeal to ignorance rather than to reason have a day of reckoning in store for them.
('20', 5, 5, 19, 13316) No other Head of Government in India laughed at the people on the 7th of April.
('20', 5, 5, 20, 13396) Everyone but Sir M. O’Dwyer realized more or less the meaning of the 6th of April, but Sir Michael’s one desire was to provide”a day of reckoning” for those, who he thought, were
('20', 5, 6, 21, 13575) 1 Prestige, honour 2 Passed in the third week of March 1919 as a temporary measure intended to deal with the situation arising out of the expiry of the Defence of India Act and investing local governments with arbitrary powers to arrest and detain persons believed to be connected with certain offences threatening public safety
('20', 6, 0, 1, 13904) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 7
('20', 6, 1, 2, 13942) appealing to passion or ignorance rather than to reason.
('20', 6, 1, 3, 13999) It is not without considerable pain, that it will be our duty to show in the following pages, how it was Sir Michael who almost invariably appealed to passion and ignorance rather than to reason, and how serious a responsibility he incurred in misleading both the people and his superiors.
('20', 6, 1, 4, 14289) It will be our painful duty to show also the meaning he attached to the phrase” day of reckoning”.
('20', 6, 1, 5, 14388) He had occasion to speak again on the 10th.
('20', 6, 1, 6, 14432) He spoke in the evening after he had learnt what had happened at Amritsar and Lahore.
('20', 6, 1, 7, 14518) He spoke to the representatives of the martial races of the Punjab, who had met at the Montgomery Hall to present him with an address.
('20', 6, 1, 8, 14653) We give the speech in full as reported by the Associated Press :
('20', 6, 2, 9, 14718) I am glad to think that the excitement of this evening has not preven ted us from meeting here tonight.
('20', 6, 2, 10, 14822) I am proud to meet, in this unique gathering, so many representatives of the great martial races, Mohammedan, Sikh, and Hindu of the Punjab, who, though differing in origin, religion and social customs, are united to one another and to the British Government by two bonds of steel, the bonds of loyalty and valour.
('20', 6, 3, 11, 15137) You realize the difficulties of the administration and the necessity of
('20', 6, 4, 12, 15209) taking measures to prevent peaceful and orderly progress being disturbed by
('20', 6, 5, 13, 15285) disorder and anarchy.
('20', 6, 5, 14, 15307) You have seen within the last few weeks how a law
('20', 6, 6, 15, 15357) passed to safeguard the lives and property of the people against such outbursts
('20', 6, 7, 16, 15437) of anarchy and revolution—a law that is only to be brought into operation if,
('20', 6, 8, 17, 15515) unfortunately, those conditions should arise—has by the persistent falsehood
('20', 6, 9, 18, 15592) and misrepresentation of a small but noisy class been made to appear as a
('20', 6, 10, 19, 15666) deadly weapon aimed at the people, whom it is intended to protect in
('20', 6, 11, 20, 15735) situations of great emergency.
('20', 6, 11, 21, 15766) Those of you who have studied that law know
('20', 6, 12, 22, 15810) how baseless that agitation is.
('20', 6, 12, 23, 15842) You can gather something of the motives of
('20', 6, 13, 24, 15885) those behind that agitation from what took place a few days ago at Multan,
('20', 6, 14, 25, 15960) when the Rowlatt Bill agitation was made a pretext for offering an insult to
('20', 6, 15, 26, 16037) gallant Punjabi Mohammedans, Sikhs and Gurkhas, that had returned from the
('20', 6, 16, 27, 16112) front after fighting the battles of India, and these insulters had, as we know,
('20', 6, 17, 28, 16192) no martial spirit themselves and no appreciation for the valour and loyalty of
('20', 6, 18, 29, 16271) those who had been safeguarding their hearths and homes.
('20', 6, 18, 30, 16328) Their object is to
('20', 6, 19, 31, 16347) attack Government and insult those who are true to their salt.
('20', 6, 19, 32, 16410) Loyal men must
('20', 6, 20, 33, 16425) and will oppose their evil designs.
('20', 6, 20, 34, 16461) I would, therefore, ask you to explain the
('20', 6, 21, 35, 16504) motives and policy of Government, as shown in that law, to those within your
('20', 7, 0, 1, 16581) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('20', 7, 1, 2, 16621) influence, and to expose the campaign of falsehood that is being carried on in
('20', 7, 2, 3, 16700) certain quarters in order to mislead the ignorant and credulous masses and the
('20', 7, 3, 4, 16779) scum of the bazaars of the towns and to incite them to crime and disorder.
('20', 7, 4, 5, 16854) The promoters of the agitation began by announcing a policy of socalled passive resistance.
('20', 7, 4, 6, 16946) What form has that taken?
('20', 7, 4, 7, 16972) You heard what happened at Multan on Saturday.
('20', 7, 4, 8, 17019) At Lahore and Amritsar on Sunday coercion and intimidation were used to law abiding citizens, and in Bombay they have begun openly to defy the law.
('20', 7, 4, 9, 17167) This movement, unless promptly checked, will bring about disorder and bloodshed.
('20', 7, 4, 10, 17248) It has already done so at Amritsar and Lahore and will endanger the lives and property of law abiding citizens.
('20', 7, 4, 11, 17360) Government looks to you and to all loyal citizens, whatever their political views, to join with it in openly denouncing this dangerous agitation and bringing it to a speedy close.
('20', 7, 4, 12, 17540) Your co operation with Government in this and similar matters will be as valued and as much appreciated as your memorable war services.
('20', 7, 5, 13, 17676) The situation is for the moment critical, and prompt action on your part and that of Government is required.
('20', 7, 5, 14, 17785) Government will do its duty without hesitation, and will support you in doing yours.
('20', 7, 5, 15, 17870) Government will enforce the law, and if that leads to bloodshed, the responsibility is with those who make others break the laws.
('20', 7, 5, 16, 18000) This is my last word of counsel, and I know you will take prompt action on it and enable me to restore public order before I leave the province.
('20', 7, 5, 17, 18145) The trouble, though serious, is not widespread and, with your help, will soon be dispelled.
('20', 7, 6, 18, 18237) It will be a proud memory to me that in time of war or of internal trouble, I never appealed to the martial races of the Punjab in vain.
('20', 7, 6, 19, 18374) I am confident that by your action and that of the loyal and sturdy men you represent, you will, within the next few weeks, establish a further claim to my gratitude and to the consideration of Government.
('20', 7, 6, 20, 18580) I must now say good bye.
('20', 7, 6, 21, 18605) In leaving the province I shall carry away recollections of what you have done.
('20', 7, 6, 22, 18685) I shall not forget you, nor your work, nor your interest.
('20', 7, 6, 23, 18743) We have copied this speech in full, as it shows at a glance Sir Michael O’Dwyer’s mentality.
('20', 7, 6, 24, 18836) It was given to the martial races of the Punjab.
('20', 7, 6, 25, 18885) He has not hesitated to incite them against the people.
('20', 7, 6, 26, 18941) He has distorted facts, as for instance regarding the conduct of the people of Multan against the soldiers.
('20', 7, 6, 27, 19049) We have investigated the incident and we have found that no insult was offered to the soldiers who passed through Multan.
('20', 7, 6, 28, 19171) He has wilfully misrepresented the scope of the Rowlatt Act to his audience and then threatened the people with punishment, practically for taking part in political agitation.
('20', 8, 0, 1, 19347) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 9
('20', 8, 1, 2, 19385) We now propose to give a brief outline of Sir Michael O’Dwyer’s administration, showing how he estranged every class from him, and how he tried to reduce the influence of the educated classes over the masses.
('20', 8, 1, 3, 19594) He had considerable experience of the Punjab before he was appointed Lieutenant Governor, to which post he was called in 1913. He signalized his rule by contemptuous references to proposals for reforms.
('20', 8, 1, 4, 19797) He said in reply to an address of welcome a few weeks after his appointment :
('20', 8, 2, 5, 19875) During the short time I have held charge of this province, I have received many excellent and well meant suggestions, as to how I should carry on the administration, what I should do to meet the aspirations of the people, to further the movement towards self government, towards the separation of executive and judicial functions, and in regard to other matters of state policy.
('20', 8, 2, 6, 20254) Abstract speculations of this nature have their interest and value, though they would gain in value, if in addition to enforcing the duties of the administration, some stress were laid on the elementary duties of the people as citizens and subjects.
('20', 8, 2, 7, 20504) I should have welcomed and I shall welcome any practical suggestion, as to how Government can discharge more efficiently its primary obligation to secure life and property, and how the people can be aroused to a sense of duty towards the community.
('20', 8, 2, 8, 20753) All other questions of policy are, in my opinion, subsidiary to these two and should stand over till these obligations are adequately discharged.
('20', 8, 2, 9, 20899) He thus gave notice to his hearers that those reforms which they held to be vital for the progress of the country were”abstract specula tions” and that he expected his hearers to help him in securing life and property and awakening a sense of duty to the community.
('20', 8, 2, 10, 21165) One would have thought that life and property had become fairly secure, and that this securiy was claimed to be the proudest achievement of British Rule, and that the yearning for the reforms mentioned by his audience did show a sense of duty to the community.
('20', 8, 2, 11, 21426) In the same speech he addressed a homily to the vernacular Press.
('20', 8, 2, 12, 21492) It was followed by action under the Press Act.
('20', 8, 2, 13, 21539) Security was demanded from several vernacular newspapers; the security already deposited was forfeited in some cases.
('20', 8, 2, 14, 21657) A month later in his very first speech, as President of the local Legislative Council, he gave to the Press a second warning :
('20', 8, 3, 15, 21784) If the action already taken does not have the desired effect, Government will deal with the offenders as with any other individuals that break the law by promoting disorder or disaffection, and will employ all the means the law places at its disposal, and of these the taking and forfeiture of the security are the least.
('20', 9, 0, 1, 22106) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('20', 9, 1, 2, 22147) This warning was followed by a more stringent policy regarding the Press, although he himself in the same speech, referring to the peace that was prevalent in the province, said :
('20', 9, 2, 3, 22327) The great results already achieved are due to the mutual confidence and intimate association of the administration and the people, which have always been a marked feature in this province.
('20', 9, 2, 4, 22516) He had occasion, six months later, of expressing his views regard ing a proposal that an executive council be established in the province.
('20', 9, 2, 5, 22655) To this very innocent proposal he thus replied on the 13th April, 1914 :
('20', 9, 3, 6, 22728) The proposal had come upon him rather as a surprise.
('20', 9, 3, 7, 22781) The people of the province had from the start been habituated to regard the Lieutenant Governor as the sole head of, and in the last degree responsible for, the administration of the province.
('20', 9, 3, 8, 22974) The province had progressed and prospered under that system in a manner which can stand comparison with any other province or presidency, and that the matter could come within the range of practical politics only if it could be shown that the present administration of the province suffers from certain defects, and that the addition of an executive council would remove those defects.
('20', 9, 3, 9, 23360) He then insulted those who had come to honour him, by quoting : ‘For forms of Government let fools contend’.
('20', 9, 3, 10, 23469) Five months later the War broke out and the Punjabis had a fairly full experience of the working of the Defence of India Act, in the passing of which he had no small share.
('20', 9, 3, 11, 23642) What share he had and what powers he wanted, so as to supersede the ordinary procedure and safeguards of law, may be seen from the following recommendations of his, which were subsequently adopted by the Imperial Government.
('20', 9, 3, 12, 23867) We take them from the Sedition Committee’s Report, page 151 :
('20', 9, 4, 13, 23929) The Lieutenant Governor considered that”it is most undesirable at the present time to allow trials of any of these revolutionaries or other sedition mongers who have been or may be arrested in the commission of crime or while endeavouring to stir up trouble, to be protracted by the ingenuity of counsel, and drawn out to inordinate length by the committal and appeal procedure, which the Criminal Law provides.” His Honour, therefore, submitted for approval a draft ordinance which provided, subject to the sanction of the local government for its application in these cases : (a) for the elimination of committal procedure in the case of offences of a political or quasi political nature; (b) for the elimination of appeal in such cases; (c) for the taking of security from persons of the class affected by a more rapid
('20', 10, 0, 1, 24751) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 11
('20', 10, 1, 2, 24790) procedure than that prescribed by the ordinary law; (d) for the prompt punishment of village officers and the fining of villagers colluding with and harbouring revolutionary criminals.
('20', 10, 1, 3, 24975) He abused the powers given to him by the Defence of India Act by prohibiting the entry into the province of Messrs Tilak and Pal 1. He interned hundreds of local men with little or no cause.
('20', 10, 1, 4, 25166) He gagged the vernacular Press, prevented the nationalist papers edited outside the Punjab from circulating in the province, as, for instance, New India, Amrita Bazar Patrika, Independent.
('20', 10, 1, 5, 25355) He prohibited the circulation even of pre censored vernacular papers and brought about a state of things whereby it became practically impossible for the people of the province to have a free interchange of independent views, or a free ventilation of their grievances in the public Press, and then, having prevented free speech and free writing, allowed myself to think, and gave outsiders to understand that the people of the Punjab were the happiest under his rule.
('20', 10, 2, 6, 25823) Not only did he abuse emergency legislation for the purpose of throttling political aspirations, but he abused his position as a ruler by summoning public men, using threats and giving them warnings.
('20', 10, 2, 7, 26023) Lala Duni Chand, who has an unbroken record of public service, had personal experience of this part of Sir M. O’Dwyer’s administration.
('20', 10, 2, 8, 26159) This is what he says in his statement given to us by him :
('20', 10, 3, 9, 26218) As a secretary of the Indian Association I had to call public meetings, and after the issue of the notices I was called either by the Chief Secretary to Government or the Commissioner of Lahore to see him, and they always put such obstacles in my way of holding public meetings that many persons in my place would have done anything but held public meetings in Lahore.
('20', 10, 3, 10, 26587) The Chief Secretary and the Commissioner told me more than once, presumably on behalf of Sir Michael O’Dwyer, whom to invite and whom not to invite as speakers from outside the province.
('20', 10, 4, 11, 26774) Not only this but when some of the members of the Provincial Legislative Council attended the last Provincial Conference at Lahore, these gentlemen were called by the Chief Secretary, and were taken to task in such a way that they would not have the courage to attend other public meetings in the Bradlaugh Hall.

('20', 10, 4, 13, 27102) 553.) 2

('20', 11, 0, 1, 27364) 12 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('20', 11, 1, 2, 27405) In 1917, nineteen members of the Imperial Legislative Council signed their famous memorandum, setting forth their proposals for reforms.
('20', 11, 1, 3, 27542) 1 A meeting was held to approve of the scheme.
('20', 11, 1, 4, 27589) Four of the signatories to the notice of the meeting were Punjab men.
('20', 11, 1, 5, 27659) He sent for them and administered to them a severe rebuke for having dared to think for themselves and to sign the notice.
('20', 11, 1, 6, 27782) Then followed the Congress League Scheme, and he tried his best to wean the Punjab from it, and lost no opportunity of belittling the effort to bring about a hearty union between Hindus and Mohammedans.
('20', 11, 1, 7, 27985) He dared to confound the issue by comparing the Home Rule movement, led by Mrs. Besant and Mr. Tilak, whose goal was attainment of self government within the Empire by constitutional and peaceful means, with the Ghadar 2 revolutionists, whose goal was frankly to sever the British connection by violent means, and with the mad people of the South West Punjab, who desolated many a home by harbouring chimerical views of establishing an Islamic Kingdom through German aid.
('20', 11, 1, 8, 28457) He put down the Ghadar movement in a merciless manner, and, we fear, not without inflicting injustice on hundreds of innocent men.
('20', 11, 1, 9, 28588) He affected to consider the pillage of defenceless homes in the South West Punjab in 1915 by treating the pillage, in the early stage, as mere grain riots, and took energetic measures only when his hands were absolutely forced and when he saw that these depredations became so serious that they might even jeopardize the work of recruiting.
('20', 11, 1, 10, 28929) On the 13th of September, 1917, a resolution was moved by the Hon’ble Mr. Muhammad Shafi 3, asking that the legislative and administrative system in the Punjab be assimilated to that of the province of Bihar and Orissa.
('20', 11, 1, 11, 29149) There was no opposition to this mild resolution from any quarter.
('20', 11, 1, 12, 29215) Sir M. O’Dwyer himself rose to speak in its favour, but, to the amazement of everybody, he packed into a single speech as much irrelevancy and vilification of educated classes
('20', 11, 2, 13, 29391) which is not reproduced here; statement and page numbers and appendices, quoted in brackets in such cases, refer to that volume.
('20', 11, 2, 14, 29520) 1 The proposals were based on the idea of Dominion Self government.
('20', 11, 2, 15, 29588) 2 The Ghadar Party, a revolutionary organization, was started in 1911 in California by Har Dayal, editor of Ghadar.
('20', 11, 2, 16, 29704) Through his paper and party he won over many immigrants from the Punjab to his revolutionary programme.
('20', 11, 2, 17, 29808) These immigrants, working through their relations, were able to spread disaffection in the Indian Army, and when forced to return to India, they carried on anti British activities.
('20', 11, 2, 18, 29989) 3 Member, Imperial Legislative Council; became member of the Viceroy’s Executive Council in 1920
('20', 12, 0, 1, 30086) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 13
('20', 12, 1, 2, 30125) as he possibly could, till at last the Hon’ble Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya, who could brook it no longer, interrupted his speech and called for an apology, which at the instance of the Viceroy he had to tender.
('20', 12, 1, 3, 30336) His Excellency the Viceroy felt called upon to dissociate himself from Sir Michael’s views.
('20', 12, 1, 4, 30428) We would give a few extracts from that speech of Sir Michael’s :
('20', 12, 2, 5, 30493) Speaking of my own province, while I would welcome a speedy progress, I must say that those conditions (meaning the three conditions set forth by Mill as indispensable for self government) are not likely to be fulfilled for many a long day.
('20', 12, 2, 6, 30734) He observed again :
('20', 12, 3, 7, 30754) We should be glad if those who are so fond of basing political claims on the loyalty of India and the sacrifices of the Indians and the sacrifices of the Indian Army, which is mainly a Punjab army, would show their loyalty to the King Emperor and their sympathy for the province, which is bearing the burden of sacrifice, not by words, however eloquent, but in some practical form, for instance, by active help in the recruiting campaign in other provinces.
('20', 12, 3, 8, 31212) The following is another passage from the same speech to show Sir Michael’s utter want of appreciation of the educated classes :
('20', 12, 4, 9, 31341) In these days when we are in danger of being deafened by political harangues and of being blinded by the shower of political manifestos, it is well occasionally to return to mother earth to clear up our minds of shams and illusions, and to ask ourselves what will all this noise and talk do for the man on the soil, the man behind the plough, the man whose life is a long drawn question between a crop and a crop.
('20', 12, 4, 10, 31755) The implications of the speech are obvious.
('20', 12, 4, 11, 31799) It was for this affront to educated classes that he was made to apologize.
('20', 12, 4, 12, 31874) The meaning of an apology in ordinary English is that when a man apologizes for his speech or action he does not repeat it.
('20', 12, 4, 13, 31998) Not so Sir Michael.
('20', 12, 4, 14, 32018) On October 30th the same year—nearly a month after the apology—he practically went back upon it in the following words :
('20', 12, 5, 15, 32139) In a speech last month in the Imperial Council I described the signal services of the Punjab in this War with an emphasis, which some people considered excessive, as it involved a comparison with other provinces and their action during the War.
('20', 12, 5, 16, 32384) I still adhere to my argument that the loyal services of the Punjab in providing men, money and materials for the Empire stand out pre eminent, and establish a special claim on the consideration of the Government.
('20', 12, 5, 17, 32598) I also reaffirm my contention that the services of the martial
('20', 13, 0, 1, 32661) 14 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('20', 13, 1, 2, 32702) classes, on whom the burden of sacrifice has fallen, are receiving and should continue to receive prior recognition from Government, and that as the so called political concessions will be of less benefit to them than to other classes, we have to look around for forms of recognition and reward which they regard as suitable and desirable.
('20', 13, 1, 3, 33042) In this revised version we see not only a repetition of the offence but a repetition in an aggravated form.
('20', 13, 1, 4, 33150) He returns to the topic by way of complaint and gives a colouring to facts in order to prove—what nobody has denied—that the war services of the Punjab were singularly great.
('20', 13, 1, 5, 33325) He isolates the martial classes from the others, insults the former by imputing to them want of political ambition, and tries to wean them from association with the others by holding out prospects of special recognition.
('20', 13, 1, 6, 33546) His contempt of the educated classes and his inclination to withhold political power from them are easily traceable in the extract we have quoted.
('20', 13, 1, 7, 33693) But nothing perhaps shows more clearly his dislike of the educated classes than his memorandum on the question of constitu tional reforms, published together with the Government of India’s despatch of March 5th, 1919, Describing the demands made by the educated classes for the whole of India, he says :
('20', 13, 2, 8, 33997) If it is clear that the demands emanate not from the mass of the people, whose interests are at stake, but from a small and not quite disinterested minority, naturally enough eager for power and place, we must, if we are faithful to our trust, place the interests of the silent masses before the clamour of the politicians, however troublesome and insistent.
('20', 13, 2, 9, 34356) Here I may quote Burke’s warning :”Because half a dozen grasshoppers under a fern make the field ring with their importunate cries, while thousands of great cattle, who repose beneath the shadow of the British oak, chew their cud and are silent, pray do not imagine that those who make the noise are the only inhabitants of the field.” We need hardly comment upon the deadly insult implied in the quotation.
('20', 13, 2, 10, 34764) He then goes on, in the same writing, in total disregard of facts, to show that the educated classes have nothing in common with the masses, and that the latter are beginning to disown the educated leaders.
('20', 13, 2, 11, 34971) He belittles the efforts regarding Home Rule made by Mrs. Besant, Mr. Tilak, Mr. Jinnah, Hon’ble Pandit Malaviya and the Raja of Mahmudabad.
('20', 13, 2, 12, 35112) He exaggerates out of all proportion the non Brahmin classes’ movement, reduces the All India Muslim League to an unimportant body, deplores the awakening of the Punjab in spite
('20', 14, 0, 1, 35290) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 15
('20', 14, 1, 2, 35329) of his prohibitive orders against Messrs Tilak and Pal, and then he says gratuitously that the advancement to be considered should be”not of the political classes alone but of the Indian people”, and winds up this portion of his memorandum by saying :
('20', 14, 2, 3, 35581) I have felt it necessary to emphasize this principle because I can find no adequate recognition of it in the Government of India proposals.
('20', 14, 2, 4, 35721) Perhaps it is taken for granted.
('20', 14, 2, 5, 35754) But an obligation so solemn should not be kept in the background; and in its absence the proposals read as if the only question to be considered is how to satisfy the aspirations of a certain proportion of the educated classes.
('20', 14, 2, 6, 35982) The latter, no doubt, claim to represent the masses, but perhaps after what has come to light in the last few months, it is hardly necessary to expose the hollowness of the claim.
('20', 14, 2, 7, 36162) Apply any practical test— the prevention of religious riots, the composing of sectional differences, the raising of recruits for the combatant army or the defence force—when any of these questions is to the fore, the politician usually retires into the background.
('20', 14, 2, 8, 36427) His influence for good is generally nil, but he can and sometimes does add to the trouble by injudicious or malicious interference.
('20', 14, 3, 9, 36559) It is often stated as an argument for self government, that there are no religious riots in Native States.
('20', 14, 3, 10, 36666) For this there are many reasons, but a leading one is that the professional politician does not exist there, or, if he does, is not allowed to interfere.
('20', 14, 3, 11, 36820) The one recent and serious religious disturbance that I am aware of in Native States—between Sunnis and Shias in Bhopal—was fomented largely by the interference of a Mohammedan lawyer from Bombay anxious to advertise himself.
('20', 14, 3, 12, 37046) In the Punjab, though sectarian feeling often runs very high, it rarely leads to riot or bloodshed, because the local authorities know on whom to depend to compose matters.
('20', 14, 3, 13, 37219) Those are not politicians but quiet men of local influence.
('20', 14, 3, 14, 37279) Here we have Sir Michael O’Dwyer seeking to prove of the whole of India that the political classes are a useless body for all practical purposes.
('20', 14, 4, 15, 37425) So much for Sir Michael and the educated classes.
('20', 14, 4, 16, 37475) But though he claimed to regard the others with affection, he estranged them from him and his Government by his methods of recruitment and collection of war contributions.
('20', 14, 4, 17, 37647) It is not, however, without considerable hesitation that we feel bound to deal with this matter.
('20', 14, 4, 18, 37744) We realize the necessity that existed during the War for a vigorous campaign of recruiting and collection of monetary contributions.
('20', 14, 4, 19, 37877) We realize, too, that if India claims, as she does, equal partnership with the other members of the Empire, she must bear her full share of the Empire’s burden.
('20', 15, 0, 1, 38038) 16 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('20', 15, 1, 2, 38079) would, therefore, if we could, have avoided any reference to the methods adopted for collecting contributions in men and money.
('20', 15, 1, 3, 38207) But in understanding and appreciating the sudden response of the classes and the masses to the proposal for hartal, and then, in the Punjab, the unexpected exhibition of mob fury, it is necessary to go into the causes that contributed to the remarkable demonstration and in the Punjab to the manifestation of violence.
('20', 15, 1, 4, 38526) For we consider that no amount of misrepresentation about the Rowlatt Act, assuming that there was any, can possibly account for the response of the masses, and the participation of a number of people in violence.
('20', 15, 1, 5, 38740) Nor can any sense of duty towards the Empire be allowed to disregard the sacredness of individual liberty or to ignore cruelty or compulsion, secretly or openly but illegally practised.
('20', 15, 1, 6, 38926) The evidence that we have collected and the judicial records that we have read conclusively prove that the methods adopted for securing recruits and donations or loans travelled far beyond the line of moral or social pressure; nor were these methods unknown to Sir Michael O’Dwyer.
('20', 15, 1, 7, 39208) Indeed conscription was openly talked of, suggested and advocated, and we cannot help saying that open conscription would have been infinitely better than the so called voluntarism, which was in effect worse than conscription, because the voluntarism pressed only the weakest and permitted the strong to go scot free.
('20', 15, 1, 8, 39526) Let us glance at the actuality.
('20', 15, 1, 9, 39558) Sir Michael said at a meeting on the 4th of May, 1918, just after the Delhi programme had been settled :”200,000 men for the regular army, voluntarism if possible, cons cription if necessary.” Colonel Popham Young, speaking at the same meeting, said :
('20', 15, 2, 10, 39810) When deciding how to apportion the effort it is inevitable that many must be guided, must even be compelled.
('20', 15, 2, 11, 39919) We shall continue to work on the lines of voluntarism.
('20', 15, 2, 12, 39974) We shall fix quotas for each district, tahsil or village with reference to the material which is available, and shall in the great majority of cases obtain the number of men we require without resort to compulsion.
('20', 15, 2, 13, 40189) But in order to be fair to those who come forward at the call of duty, we must forthwith be armed with authority.
('20', 15, 2, 14, 40303) We must be able to say that when there has been a failure on the part of the people to choose their champions for the areas, Government will step in and make the choice for them.
('20', 15, 2, 15, 40482) At the same meeting Sir Michael O’Dwyer himself said as follows :
('20', 16, 0, 1, 40548) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 17
('20', 16, 1, 2, 40587) Before I leave the subject of recruitment I must say a few words about conscription.
('20', 16, 1, 3, 40672) No one, of course, dreams of conscripting the whole of India’s manhood for the half million combatants required; and if we can do without conscription in any form no one will be better pleased than I. But, splendid as has been the volunteer response of the Punjab hitherto, we must face the fact that the strain has been severe, that the burden has not been evenly distributed, and that the tribes and localities which have done their duty are not a little resentful against those who have not.
('20', 16, 1, 4, 41167) The land owning classes feel that they are paying the main burden of the War both in purse and in person, and that there are other classes who pay little or nothing in either form.
('20', 16, 1, 5, 41348) Inequality of burdens as between classes is always a legitimate grievance.
('20', 16, 1, 6, 41423) It becomes more acute as the need of men becomes more insistent and the call for men more imperative.
('20', 16, 2, 7, 41525) The contingency of failure of the voluntary system in certain areas is there and it would be cowardice not to face it.
('20', 16, 2, 8, 41644) We have given our pledge, and we must take measures in time to secure its fulfilment.

('20', 16, 2, 12, 42320) But, gentlemen, the machinery cannot be set in motion at once.
('20', 16, 2, 13, 42383) The men are wanted immediately.
('20', 16, 2, 14, 42415) What, therefore, appears necessary is that Government should take power to enforce the quotas allotted to provinces, and that all the necessary preparations should be made in advance on the distinct understanding that the measure will not be applied if the quotas are forthcoming on voluntary basis.
('20', 16, 3, 15, 42715) A circular was issued by the Punjab Government making suggestions for obtaining contributions which could only be given effect to by using more than normal pressure.

('20', 19, 3, 7, 49236) into the village and hear if any objections were taken to the selection of the recruits.
('20', 19, 3, 8, 49325) It was his practice to ask a family of 3 or 4 brothers to provide one or two recruits for the army.
('20', 19, 3, 9, 49425) He also secured some deserters from the neighbourhood of Gurna, who were sent under escort to the recruiting officer.

('20', 19, 4, 13, 49789) The president of the Special Tribunal made the following remarks in his notes :
('20', 19, 5, 14, 49869) Nadir Hussain Shah was overzealous and wanting in tact to influence a wild people unused to join the army.
('20', 19, 5, 15, 49976) The people had no traditions to back them.
('20', 19, 5, 16, 50019) On the 6th February, the Patwari prepared the lists of Bakh Lurhkan.

('20', 24, 2, 8, 61990) CHAPTER III
('20', 24, 3, 9, 62002) THE ROWLATT BILLS
('20', 24, 4, 10, 62020) The foregoing chapter makes it sufficiently clear that the people of the Punjab were subjected to a variety of pinpricks by the local administration, and that, by its studied contempt for them, it had made it well nigh impossible for the natural leaders of the people—the educated classes—to control the populace.
('20', 24, 4, 11, 62334) It was in this atmosphere that the Rowlatt Bills came upon the Punjab.
('20', 24, 5, 12, 62405) It is common ground that at the time these two Bills were published, 1 there was little or no revolutionary crime in India.
('20', 24, 5, 13, 62529) Indeed, for years it had ceased to affect any part of India other than Bengal and the Punjab.
('20', 24, 5, 14, 62623) In Bengal the party of violence came into being when discontent over the partition of Bengal grew to white heat.
('20', 24, 5, 15, 62736) In the Punjab it was due to the various measures of the local government, which deeply dissatisfied the people, and it became serious owing to the gross ill treatment of the proud Sikh settlers of Canada.
('20', 24, 5, 16, 62941) They infected some local men, too, with their discontent, and the forcible interference with the returned immigrants, ex Komagata Maru 2,brought it to a head.
('20', 24, 5, 17, 63100) The causes of violence in each case were
('20', 24, 6, 18, 63141) 1 In February 1919 2 In 1914, several hundred Punjabis sailed for Canada as emigrants.
('20', 24, 6, 19, 63228) They were, however, not allowed to land by the Canadian Government.
('20', 24, 6, 20, 63296) They returned by s.s.
('20', 24, 6, 21, 63318) Komagata Maru to India where they landed as prisoners and were kept in camp at Budge Budge, near Calcutta, under armed guard pending removal to their
('20', 25, 0, 1, 63468) 26 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('20', 25, 1, 2, 63509) well defined and, in our opinion, avoidable and remediable.
('20', 25, 1, 3, 63569) Anyway, violence, both in the Punjab and in Bengal, was brought under complete check, as the Government contend, under the powers taken by them in virtue of the Defence of India Act.
('20', 25, 2, 4, 63752) This Act was passed as an emergency measure to cope with revolutionary outbreaks that were feared during the War.
('20', 25, 2, 5, 63866) It is possible to understand the use of such powers when all available fighting material had been removed from India to the battlefields of France and Mesopotamia, and when India’s internal peace had to depend largely upon the loyalty and the peace loving nature of the people.
('20', 25, 2, 6, 64144) Extraordinary powers taken by the Executive, like Martial Law, enable one policeman to do the work of perhaps four, but this is done at the cost of the liberty of the subject, by depriving him of all the wholesome checks which regulate police procedure.
('20', 25, 2, 7, 64398) When, therefore, the hostilities ceased, the people had looked forward to the repeal of the Defence of India Act.
('20', 25, 2, 8, 64512) They had done so the more because, in spite of the declarations made by the Government that the measure would be used only in case of real necessity and never for the purpose of stifling political agitation or hindering the movements of public men, it was used for the purpose of restraining political freedom.
('20', 25, 2, 9, 64823) To mention no other case it was used in order to intern Mrs. Besant and her associates, 1 because they represented in its intense form the Indian Home Rule movement.
('20', 25, 2, 10, 64989) In it, there never was any suspicion of violence entertained even by her worst enemies.
('20', 25, 2, 11, 65077) The public had, therefore, grown thoroughly distrustful of the Government, and had hoped that in view of India’s unique war record, and the declaration 2 of August 1917 foreshadowing reforms leading to responsible government, that Act would be repealed and that the people would have respite from the unwelcome attentions of the Secret Service Department.
('20', 25, 3, 12, 65433) They were therefore taken by surprise when the two Bills were sprung upon them.
('20', 25, 3, 13, 65513) The Viceregal speech ushering in the Bills added
('20', 25, 4, 14, 65562) province and internment there.
('20', 25, 4, 15, 65593) Exasperated by continued ill treatment, they broke into revolt.
('20', 25, 4, 16, 65657) 1 Annie Besant and her associates, Arundale and Wadia, were interned on June 10, 1917. 2 Made by Montagu on August 10, 1917, shortly after assuming office as Secretary of State for India
('20', 26, 0, 1, 65844) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 27
('20', 26, 1, 2, 65883) to the disquiet, as it seemed to show that the Bills were designed to answer the fears of the British element in the Civil Service regarding its safety under the reforms.

('20', 27, 1, 2, 68066) not exist at the time they were made, it is not easy to understand them.
('20', 27, 1, 3, 68139) We know the argument that without the Defence of India Act or its substitute, non eruption of violence could not be guaranteed.
('20', 27, 1, 4, 68267) This argument involves two assumptions—first, that repressive legislation is necessary not merely to suppress crime of a revolutionary character, but that it remains under check only during the continuance of such legislation.
('20', 27, 1, 5, 68494) Second, that there were yet men at large who are or were suspected to be revolutionaries.
('20', 27, 2, 6, 68584) The first assumption betrays bankruptcy of statesmanship and a confession of failure; the second, if true, betrays hopeless inefficiency.
('20', 27, 2, 7, 68722) The fact is that the demand for repressive legislation means disincli nation to yield to the will of the people; in other words, government of them against their will.
('20', 27, 2, 8, 68890) The point was clearly brought out by the Hon’ble Mr. Sastri in his memorable speech 1 on the introduction of the Rowlatt Bill.
('20', 27, 2, 9, 69017) He said that even though political amelioration did not satisfy the confirmed anarchist, it, and not repression, was the only true way of securing peace, and proceeded to say :
('20', 27, 3, 10, 69194) Because the anarchist is in this unfortunate condition of mental derangement, are we to say, since these people are not going to be satisfied by political concessions, we will not think of them; we will only apply the rule of law to them?
('20', 27, 3, 11, 69433) That is not the way I think that sound statesmanship should go about the business.
('20', 27, 3, 12, 69516) We should offer them satisfying measures of political emancipation.
('20', 27, 3, 13, 69584) But after all it is not these anarchists that have to be satisfied.
('20', 27, 3, 14, 69652) It is general atmosphere which feeds anarchy that we have got no cure, and when the anarchist finds that he gets no sympathy anywhere, that he cannot propagate his wicked doctrine in a soil where there is contentment and political prosperity, he will naturally die, even if the long arm of the law does not get at him.
('20', 27, 3, 15, 69971) The Hon’ble Mr. Sastri’s remarks on the suggestion that the innocent need not fear the admittedly repressive character of the measure, are also worthy of note.

('20', 28, 1, 2, 70613) Criminal Investigation Department.

('20', 28, 1, 4, 70723) Men like me would not be considered innocent.
('20', 28, 1, 5, 70769) The innocent then is he who forswears politics, who takes no part in the public movements of the times, who retires into his house, mumbles his prayers, pays his taxes, and salaams all the government officials all round.

('20', 28, 1, 17, 72426) You ought not to lay them by the heels and punish them in ways that will shock the sense of justice; in ways that will make the innocent feel that there is no law in the land; in ways that will make honest, virtuous and public spirited work impossible.
('20', 28, 1, 18, 72679) The price even for the extinction of wickedness that is demanded then is far too high.
('20', 28, 1, 19, 72766) Much better that a few rascals should walk abroad than that the honest man should be obliged for fear of the law of the land to remain shut up in his house, to refrain from the activities which it is in his nature to indulge in, to abstain from all political and public work merely because there is a dreadful law in the land.
