('20', 130, 1, 18, 324416) It was not the work of a crowd, nor, so far as we can see, of anybody from Akalgarh.
('20', 130, 1, 19, 324501) The theory suggested to us was that the wire cutting was done by those who were coming back from the Wazirabad Baisakhi fair, Akalgarh being 23 miles from Wazirabad.
('20', 130, 1, 20, 324667) On the 22nd of April, however, the Deputy Commissioner came, stopped at the canal bridge and sent for the gentry of the town.
('20', 130, 1, 21, 324793) He required them to repair the road leading to the dak bungalow, and ordered that it must be repaired quickly by the town people in such a manner that his motor could have an easy passage.
('20', 130, 1, 22, 324982) Nearly Rs. 2,000, therefore, were collected from the people, and the road extending over a mile was compulsorily fitted for the passage of the Deputy Commissioner’s motor.
('20', 130, 1, 23, 325154) The whole of the amount was raised in a

('20', 131, 1, 2, 325236) single day from the small town.
('20', 131, 1, 3, 325268) Not only, therefore, was the levy illegal and objectionable on principle, but it was also unconscionably heavy for a place so poor as Akalgarh.
('20', 131, 1, 4, 325412) Then followed, as at Gujranwala and Wazirabad, the arrests of the leading people.
('20', 131, 1, 5, 325494) A batch of 30 accused was tried, 20 of whom were acqui tted, 2 lads of 15 years of age were sentenced to simple imprisonment for one day, 6 were convicted and the case against 2 was withdrawn.

('20', 132, 3, 11, 328700) RAMNAGAR
('20', 132, 4, 12, 328709) Ramnagar is no bigger than Akalgarh.

('20', 132, 5, 17, 328991) No damage is reported to have been done at Ramnagar, but it is alleged that an effigy of His Majesty was burnt on the 15th April, and the ashes thrown into the river.
('20', 132, 5, 18, 329158) We have enquired into this allegation with the closest attention.
('20', 132, 5, 19, 329224) Several hundred witnesses were examined by us.
('20', 132, 5, 20, 329271) And though the evidence thus collected was convincing and conclusive to repudiate the charge, it was decided to invite the public in the openest manner to give us any information to the contrary that they might possess.
('20', 132, 5, 21, 329491) A public meeting was, therefore, held on the 30th November, 1919, in the open at Ramnagar, at which those who believed that the King’s effigy had been burnt or had information on it, were invited to make either a public or a private statement, but not a single witness came forward to state that there ever was any such insult offered to His Majesty.
('20', 132, 5, 22, 329842) We are satisfied that it was entirely a manufactured charge.
('20', 132, 5, 23, 329903) The statements, collected by us, will show that up to the 23rd April no mention was ever made of this matter by any of the police officers.

('20', 133, 1, 5, 330475) The alleged leader in the affair, although he was available, was not arrested before the 9th of May.

('20', 135, 1, 2, 335163) HAFIZABAD Hafizabad is 15 miles from Akalgarh on the Wazirabad Lyallpur railway line, and is a fairly large trade centre.

('20', 136, 3, 5, 337828) First of all, 6 men, all of whom were respectable people, were arrested and handcuffed.

('20', 136, 3, 7, 338004) After the lapse of a month and a half, charges were framed against them.
('20', 136, 3, 8, 338077) In order to get up false prosecution witnesses, the people were subjected to corporal punishment; filthy and abusive language was used against them in the bazaar.
('20', 136, 3, 9, 338240) They were severely treated and the police subjected respectable men to all sorts of hardships and indignities.
('20', 136, 3, 10, 338351) Telegrams were sent to His Excellency the Viceroy and the Lieutenant Governor, Punjab, about false prosecution witnesses.
('20', 136, 3, 11, 338473) But no attention was paid nor any enquiry held.
('20', 136, 3, 12, 338521) When it became known to the Colonel that such telegrams were being sent, they were censored and refused.
('20', 136, 3, 13, 338626) The Summary Court Martial disposed of all the Hafizabad cases in the course of one single day.
('20', 136, 3, 14, 338721) The accused in the Hafizabad cases included big landowners, raises,
('20', 136, 4, 15, 338789) bankers, lawyers and other respectable people, and were marched through the streets and were deliberately humiliated.
('20', 136, 4, 16, 338907) (Statement 388, p.
('20', 136, 4, 17, 338926) 517.) Lala Rup Chand Chopra gives a graphic account of the energetic measures taken by Colonel O’Brein regarding the recruiting, and then regarding the prosecutions under Martial Law.
('20', 136, 4, 18, 339110) Not finding things to his satisfaction, i.
('20', 136, 4, 19, 339153) e., many people not having been arrested up to the 30th April, Colonel O’Brien is said to have removed some of the old officials and put in men of his own choice.
('20', 136, 4, 20, 339316) On the evening of the 30th April, a proclamation by beat of drum was issued to the effect that every turban wearer was to present himself the next morning in front of the Tahsil, and if anybody absented, he would be shot.
('20', 136, 4, 21, 339538) He adds that during the new regime, people were made to sit all day long in the open, and the process was repeated from day to day.
('20', 136, 4, 22, 339670) (Statement 390.) The same order as at other places was issued regarding school children.
('20', 136, 4, 23, 339759) Some British soldiers helped themselves to various articles from shopkeepers, without making any payment.
('20', 136, 4, 24, 339865) The witness went with Mr. Andrews to the Inspector’s house on the 20th October, and a case of extortion was brought to his notice on the part of the punitive police, with the result that two constables had to be dismissed and a havildar degraded.

('20', 137, 1, 3, 340476) (Statement 390.)
('20', 137, 2, 4, 340493) Lala Beli Ram Kapur was arrested and locked up with 23 others in a room measuring 12 by 15, the same room having to be used by all of them for natural purposes also.

('20', 137, 2, 6, 340722) (Statement 405, p.
('20', 137, 3, 7, 340741) Sardar Mewa Singh, a retired head clerk in the Forest Depart ment, describes the cruelty of the recruiting methods.
('20', 137, 3, 8, 340857) He describes his own arrest as follows :
('20', 137, 4, 9, 340898) On the 21st of April, I was arrested without a warrant.
('20', 137, 4, 10, 340954) On the 22nd, warrants were drawn and the signature of the District Magistrate obtained.
('20', 137, 4, 11, 341042) I was placed for two days in the Hafizabad lock up, which was very dirty.
('20', 137, 4, 12, 341116) 23 men were packed up there in a single room.
('20', 137, 4, 13, 341162) It could hardly accommodate four persons.
('20', 137, 4, 14, 341204) We were put to fearful discomforts, not being allowed even to ease ourselves, when we felt the necessity.
('20', 137, 4, 15, 341310) Two of us were taken out at a time in handcuffs.
('20', 137, 4, 16, 341359) At times we had to pass stools in the lock up.
('20', 137, 4, 17, 341406) On the 23rd of April, 1919, we were removed to the Gujranwala District Jail.
('20', 137, 4, 18, 341483) All the 23 persons were bound by the same chain.
('20', 137, 4, 19, 341532) Handcuffs were put on the hands of everybody.
('20', 137, 4, 20, 341578) We were taken there under strict surveillance and a guard of armed military police.
('20', 137, 4, 21, 341662) We were not allowed to answer a call of nature, or to drink water on the way.
('20', 137, 4, 22, 341740) The treatment accorded to us by the menial staff was intolerable.
('20', 137, 4, 23, 341806) On the 23rd of May, 1919, we were again taken back to Hafizabad for identification.
('20', 137, 4, 24, 341890) I cannot express the horrible treatment that was meted out to us by the police on our way to Hafizabad.
('20', 137, 4, 25, 341994) Some seven or eight men were allowed their own food by the Superintendent, Jail, Gujranwala.
('20', 137, 4, 26, 342087) When we were taken out from the Gujranwala Jail in handcuffs, the Jailor asked the Sub Inspector of Police to allow us to take our meals which were ready, but the latter refused to allow us to do so.
('20', 137, 4, 27, 342287) We had thus to fast for the whole day.
('20', 137, 4, 28, 342326) We were brought down to Lahore on the 29th May.
('20', 137, 4, 29, 342374) The papers were shown to the Public Prosecutor, who sent this case back, considering our offence to be slight.
('20', 137, 4, 30, 342485) On the evening of 4th June, Mr. Wace called on us to put in a list of defence witnesses.
('20', 137, 4, 31, 342574) In spite of our repeated requests we were not informed of the charges against us, nor were we given the names of the prosecution witnesses.
('20', 137, 4, 32, 342714) The date for the hearing was fixed for 7th June, which left us a very short time to prepare our defence.
('20', 137, 4, 33, 342819) We could not inform our relatives, nor engage the services of lawyers.
('20', 137, 4, 34, 342890) One of my defence witnesses, Dr. Umrek Singh, Assistant Surgeon, was at Simla.
('20', 137, 4, 35, 342969) He was not called.
('20', 137, 4, 36, 342988) In cross examination, Dr. Daulat Ram admitted that he was on bad terms with me.
('20', 137, 4, 37, 343068) Other prosecution witnesses appeared out of fear of the police.
('20', 138, 0, 1, 343132) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 139
('20', 138, 1, 2, 343172) My defence witnesses, who are all respectable gentlemen, had deposed that I had been confined to bed on account of some trouble in the eyes, and could not have left my house.
('20', 138, 1, 3, 343347) I am more than 60 years of age.
('20', 138, 1, 4, 343379) I have never taken any part in any political meetings.
('20', 138, 1, 5, 343434) Mr. Wace, after consultation with Colonel O’Brien, the Deputy Commissioner, fined me Rs. 500. My petition for mercy still remains undealt with.
('20', 138, 1, 6, 343578) This is all due to the mischief of the police who had won over a few badmashes (hooligans) to support them.
('20', 138, 1, 7, 343686) Thus all the occurrences took place on the same day, at the very place.
('20', 138, 1, 8, 343758) The disturbances continued for two days, the 14th and the 15th.
('20', 138, 1, 9, 343822) On the former, the police did not try at all to check the activities of the people, rather, they abetted them.
('20', 138, 1, 10, 343933) On the latter day, the disturbances were quelled by simply firing a few blank cartridges and without the help of any additional police or military from outside.
('20', 138, 1, 11, 344094) Had the police done their duty on the first day, these things would never have happened at all.
('20', 138, 1, 12, 344190) The damage done to the buildings at Hafizabad might have amounted to a few rupees.

('20', 138, 1, 14, 344347) The people have to bear the expenses of the punitive police, and this is a source of great trouble to the poor subjects of His Majesty.
('20', 138, 1, 15, 344483) (Statement 389.) Lala Ram Sahai, Head Master, Anglo Sanskrit School, was also among those who were arrested.

('20', 138, 1, 18, 344672) He was taken to the Gujranwala jail and brought back to Hafizabad after a fortnight.
('20', 138, 1, 19, 344757) He says :
('20', 138, 2, 20, 344767) Here pressure was brought to bear upon me to become a prosecution witness.
('20', 138, 2, 21, 344842) The Inspector of Police used no physical force, but he employed moral pressure of every kind.
('20', 138, 2, 22, 344936) He first praised me as an educated man and then alarmed me that I might be hanged and all my property confiscated, or that I might be transported for life.
('20', 138, 2, 23, 345092) First, I told him that I did not like to play the traitor, and he advanced try [sic] arguments as to how it was no treason to tell the truth.
('20', 138, 3, 24, 345234) then consulted my father and the religious instructor of the school and decided that I must tell the truth and nothing but the truth.

('20', 139, 1, 4, 346342) No question was put to me about violence in the Court.
('20', 139, 2, 5, 346397) On 21st May, 1919, we were again brought back to Hafizabad.

('20', 139, 6, 21, 348108) The indignities and the inde cency, as described by the witness, during the confinement, mostly wrongful, to which cultured or well brought up men had been subjected, betray the degradation to which the officials had sunk in their desire to suppress agitation.
('20', 139, 7, 22, 348369) SANGLA HILL
('20', 139, 8, 23, 348381) Sangla Hill is a comparatively modern place.
('20', 139, 8, 24, 348426) It is a railway station, 62 miles from Lahore, situated on the Lahore Lyallpur branch.
('20', 139, 8, 25, 348513) It has a population of about 4,000 people.
('20', 139, 8, 26, 348556) It was on the 12th April that a hartal was observed owing to Mr. Gandhi’s arrest.
('20', 140, 0, 1, 348638) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 141
('20', 140, 1, 2, 348678) According to Mr. Bosworth Smith 1,
('20', 140, 2, 3, 348713) The effect of the meeting in connection with the hartal was not at once evident.
('20', 140, 2, 4, 348794) On the 13th, the Baisakhi fair passed off fairly quietly.
('20', 140, 3, 5, 348852) 15th, telegraph wires were cut between Sangla and Salanwala.
('20', 140, 3, 6, 348913) On the 16th, a Sikh with some other Sikhs, assisted by a large mob from the town, forcibly released a military prisoner at Sangla station.
('20', 140, 3, 7, 349052) He was an Indian prisoner.
('20', 140, 3, 8, 349079) On the evening of that day (15th), some men made a murderous attack on Mr. Wells, a telegraph inspector.
('20', 140, 3, 9, 349184) This account is altogether exaggerated.
('20', 140, 3, 10, 349224) The testimony produced before us shows clearly that the Sikh who forcibly released a military prisoner had run amok, and there was no crowd behind him.
('20', 140, 3, 11, 349376) It was an individual affair.
('20', 140, 3, 12, 349405) There was no murderous attack on Mr. Wells on the 15th or any other day, and he was not seriously injured.
('20', 140, 3, 13, 349512) It is perfectly clear from the evidence in our possession that the people of Sangla were in no way implicated in any attack on anybody, or in any damage to property.
('20', 140, 3, 14, 349678) But Martial Law was, all the same, proclaimed on the 19th April.
('20', 140, 3, 15, 349743) The Deputy Commissioner visited Sangla and did nothing at the time, except to warn the people against repeating the hartal.
('20', 140, 3, 16, 349867) On the 22nd, however, an officer with British soldiers arrived, arrested 11 leaders and after a few hours’ detention released them.
('20', 140, 3, 17, 349999) Arrests, however, were commenced on the 26th April.
('20', 140, 3, 18, 350051) The arrested people were released on the 29th.
('20', 140, 3, 19, 350098) But on the 12th May, a military demonstration was held and shots were fired from the hill, evidently with a view to overawe the people.
('20', 140, 3, 20, 350234) Captain Ewing of the mobile column stated before Lord Hunter’s Committee that they had “a demonstration with a machine gun and Lewis gun firing before a large number of people”.
('20', 140, 3, 21, 350412) On the same day, 13 leaders were again arrested, handcuffed and marched under humiliating circumstances.
('20', 140, 3, 22, 350517) On the 13th May, 64 further arrests were made.
('20', 140, 3, 23, 350564) They were bound with their own turbans, a most disgraceful procedure, and marched off to the police station.
('20', 140, 3, 24, 350673) A roll call of inhabitants was taken daily for some days.
('20', 140, 3, 25, 350731) On the 14th, 47 other arrests were made, and on the 18th, Mr. Bosworth Smith told the people under arrest that if they paid a fine of Rs. 50,000, they would all be released.
('20', 140, 3, 26, 350905) Mr. Bosworth Smith admits that he wanted to levy a fine of Rs. 50,000 on the Sangla people, but denies that he made it a condition of release.
('20', 140, 3, 27, 351048) All the same, the fact stands that, on the 19th May, 116 persons out of 124, all told, were released, the contention on the part of the people being that

('20', 144, 1, 6, 359115) (Statement
('20', 144, 3, 7, 359126) Moman is a railway station, 6 miles from Sangla on the Lahore side.
('20', 144, 3, 8, 359194) There is no doubt that a party proceeded to this station from the surrounding villages and burnt and looted it, a procedure for which there was no provocation whatsoever, and which was an act of pure wanton destruction.
('20', 144, 3, 9, 359414) It is not certain whether the people from the surrounding villages burnt the station, or whether it was a party of outsiders.
('20', 144, 3, 10, 359540) In any case, the high handed mea sures taken by the authorities by way of reprisals were totally uncalled for.

('20', 144, 4, 12, 359891) MANIANWALA AND NEIGHBOURING PLACES
('20', 144, 5, 13, 359926) This is a village hardly containing a population of 500 men, and it is one of the villages near the railway station, Dhaban Singh.
('20', 144, 5, 14, 360057) This station was burnt and looted by the people from the surrounding villages on the 16th April, 1919. The villagers had heard exaggerated reports of what had happened at Amritsar, which evidently excited them to this act of incendiarism; and as one of the witnesses states, what began as an act of vengeance ended as one of loot on the part of evil doers.
('20', 144, 6, 15, 360414) But, bad as the action of some of the villagers was, the reparation exacted by the authorities was heartless, and passed the bounds of decency.
('20', 144, 6, 16, 360558) On the 19th April, a troop train arrived at the Dhaban Singh station.
('20', 144, 6, 17, 360628) Guns were pointed towards Manianwala; some soldiers alighted from the train and proceeded to the village, shooting as they went.
('20', 144, 6, 18, 360757) One man at least was shot dead, others were wounded.
('20', 144, 6, 19, 360810) One at least was maimed for life and rendered unfit for work.
('20', 144, 6, 20, 360872) There seems to have been no warrant for this shooting.
('20', 144, 6, 21, 360927) Women fled from their houses on hearing the shots, including those who were about to be mothers.
('20', 145, 0, 1, 361024) 146 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('20', 145, 1, 2, 361066) Sardar Atar Singh, a Lambardar of thirty years’ standing, and founder of the village, narrowly escaped death.
('20', 145, 1, 3, 361176) His house was searched, cupboards were broken open, and cash and other things removed.
('20', 145, 1, 4, 361263) Atar Singh is said to be 115 years old.
('20', 145, 1, 5, 361303) He is certainly over 100 and can hardly move about, and passes his days seated on a bedstead.
('20', 145, 1, 6, 361397) He and Inder Singh were arrested; he, being unable to walk, was put on a horse.
('20', 145, 1, 7, 361477) They were both taken to the station, and confined in an iron wagon which served as an improvised lock up.
('20', 145, 1, 8, 361583) There, they were detained for some days.
('20', 145, 1, 9, 361624) This wagon, being made of iron, without any lining, was natu rally unbearable during the hot days of April, and in this way, several other villagers had to pass their days often without food and water.

We have dwelt upon these incidents at some length, and we consider that an officer who is capable of behaving in the manner Mr. Bosworth Smith seems to have, is totally unfit to occupy a post of any responsibility in a civilized Government or to wear His Majesty’s uniform.
('20', 146, 4, 16, 365505) The other statements in connection with the incident at Manianwala show how over eighty villagers were arrested and sub jected to the greatest inconvenience, how the villagers were obliged to pay for meals which the Government was bound to supply them whilst they were in detention, and how they were pressed under a vareity of threats to give false evidence, how flogging was administered, how Mr. Bosworth Smith conducted his trials, and how on the kind of evidence described in the statements, villagers were tried before the Martial Law Commission, and some of them trans ported for life.

('20', 147, 0, 1, 366241) 148 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('20', 147, 1, 2, 366283) atone for the grave injustice done to the villagers, the majority at least of whom appear to have been utterly innocent.
('20', 147, 1, 3, 366404) A punitive police has been imposed on the villagers, and a heavy indemnity was levied upon them by Mr. Bosworth Smith, which was subsequently reduced.
('20', 147, 1, 4, 366555) We cannot close this brief review of the barbarities of Manianwala without mentioning that Mr. C. F. Andrews personally visited the place 1 on behalf of the Congress Sub committee, and he brought evidence supporting the statements about the inhuman treatment described above.
('20', 147, 2, 5, 366831) NAWAN PIND (CHAK NO.
('20', 147, 3, 6, 366852) This again is a very small village, smaller even than Manian wala, in the Tahsil Khangah Dogran.
('20', 147, 3, 7, 366949) This is also near the railway station, Dhaban Singh, and, therefore, came in for practically the same treatment as Manianwala, except that the women folk seemed to have escaped the disgraceful treatment that was meted out to their less fortunate sisters of Manianwala.
('20', 147, 3, 8, 367218) That some villagers might have taken part in the burning of the Dhaban Singh station is quite likely, but there can be no justification for the cruel and vindictive punishment of a whole village, and yet the selection we have made out of nearly 40 witnesses, all speaking about similar or the same incidents, shows that the same treatment was meted out to the residents of Nawan Pind as to those of Manianwala.
('20', 147, 4, 9, 367629) Khushal Singh states that the day following the burning of the railway station, the inhabitants of the surrounding villages, including Nawan Pind, had gathered on the railway station.

('20', 149, 4, 8, 371976) The parties are now appealing against their conviction on the following grounds :
('20', 149, 5, 9, 372058) (a) They were not present that day at the railway station, and offered to produce several witnesses to prove an alibi.

('20', 149, 9, 15, 372731) (d) This statement has been made to me by the youngest brother of the accused, Jagat Singh, a boy of 18, whom I know well and who has been my pupil for four years in this College and School.
('20', 149, 9, 16, 372922) Of Jagat Singh’s personal loyalty I have no doubt whatever.
('20', 149, 9, 17, 372982) I am in a position to know what Jagat Singh’s feelings are, and a suggestion that Jagat Singh was a politician of anti British tendency would be regarded here as ludicrous; also the fact that these brothers who support the boy sent him here suggests that they are loyal; for it is usually the loyal Sikhs who send the sons from afar to an institution which is supposed to have the special favour of the Sircar.
('20', 149, 10, 18, 373393) made enquiries among the railway coolies, many of whom know the two convicted brothers, and their universal opinion is that the brothers are perfectly innocent, and the case has been got up against them by their enemies.
('20', 149, 11, 19, 373614) (e) The point which seems to vitiate the evidence against the men is that

('20', 152, 1, 2, 378439) CHUHARKANA
('20', 152, 2, 3, 378450) This is an important mandi, viz., a market place visited by hundreds of men from the neighbouring villages, who bring their stock to the market.
('20', 152, 2, 4, 378595) The village of Chuharkana lies about a mile and a half from the mandi.
('20', 152, 2, 5, 378666) The station Chuharkana is near the mandi.
('20', 152, 2, 6, 378708) The hartal was observed on the 12th April.
('20', 152, 2, 7, 378751) A public meeting announcing it was held on the previous day, in which all, including the municipal councillors, took part.
('20', 152, 2, 8, 378874) Nothing happened up to the 14th.
('20', 152, 2, 9, 378907) By the 15th, however, the news from Amritsar and Lahore had become common property, and people were much agitated.
('20', 152, 2, 10, 379022) Some people, living at the mandi, and others from the villages who were at the mandi, proceeded to the railway station, and in broad daylight, took implements from the railway gang, damaged the line and burnt the station.
('20', 152, 3, 11, 379244) This was followed by the arrival of the military, and machine guns, with an armoured train.
('20', 152, 3, 12, 379336) There was considerable indiscriminate shooting.
('20', 152, 3, 13, 379384) Rai Sahib Sri Ram Sud has sought, in his evidence before the Hunter Committee, to justify the shooting, but the whole of the evidence in our possession contradicts his statement.
('20', 152, 3, 14, 379563) Indeed, he seems to be condemned out of his own mouth.
('20', 152, 3, 15, 379618) It should also be remembered that the shooting took place before the proclamation of Martial Law.
('20', 152, 3, 16, 379716) Now, R. S. Sri Ram Sud is a Sub Divisional Officer of many years’ standing; he has served in the district since August 1918; he, therefore, knew the people.
('20', 152, 3, 17, 379873) He made himself principally responsible for the firing and, when he was cornered by Pandit Jagat Narain, he said that his authority was derived from the Criminal Procedure Code.
('20', 152, 3, 18, 380051) In answer to Sir Chimanlal, who enquired on what he came to the conclusion that he should fire, he said, “Because we already came to know that the mob had already collected there, and there was reliable information of it.” Again he says : “I had already heard that the people of Chuharkana were rushing to the market to loot.” “Therefore, without any further enquiry, you began to fire?” asked Sir Chimanlal.
('20', 152, 3, 19, 380460) “Yes, we determined to open fire,” was the answer.
('20', 152, 3, 20, 380511) He was then asked : “Your idea was that you wanted to strike terror.” He replied, “Well, if necessary.
('20', 152, 3, 21, 380614) And we found it necessary.” “And after that firing, you proceeded further to the station?” asked Sir Chimanlal.
('20', 152, 3, 22, 380726) “Yes,” was the reply.
('20', 152, 3, 23, 380748) The Rai Sahib then described the movements of the people.
('20', 152, 4, 24, 380806) Q. What do you mean by moving?
('20', 152, 4, 25, 380837) They were not committing any
('20', 153, 0, 1, 380866) 154 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('20', 153, 1, 2, 380908) mischief?
('20', 153, 2, 3, 380918) A. No, not at that time.
('20', 153, 2, 4, 380943) People were coming out and going into the village.
('20', 153, 3, 5, 380994) Q. You do not know what their object was in coming out and going into the village?
('20', 153, 4, 6, 381077) A. Well, their object was to attack the armoured train.
('20', 153, 5, 7, 381133) Q. From a distance, how did you know that they were collecting to attack the armoured train?
('20', 153, 6, 8, 381226) A. Unfortunately, I cannot illuminate things which are in my brain.

('20', 153, 9, 13, 381562) Q. With what object you cannot say?

('20', 154, 0, 1, 382979) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 155
('20', 154, 1, 2, 383019) Thus, whilst we will not go so far as to say that firing before Martial Law could not be justified, we believe that the firing referred to by the Sub Divisional Officer was hasty, premature, indiscriminate and due to panic or over zeal.
('20', 154, 1, 3, 383256) To strike terror was no part of the officer’s business.
('20', 154, 1, 4, 383312) It is a sign not of strength but of weakness, not a vindication of justice but a perpetration of injustice.
('20', 154, 1, 5, 383420) A guilty conscience alone resorts to terrorism.
('20', 154, 1, 6, 383468) We admit that the incendiarism, the looting and the wire cutting were all bad, unwarranted and disgraceful, and that the culprits deserved condign punishment.
('20', 154, 1, 7, 383627) But nothing that the people did could possibly justify the random firing that was resorted to and that resulted in the loss of innocent lives and permanent injury to several innocent people, and the other barbarous measures that were taken, in order to “terrorize” a whole people.
('20', 154, 2, 8, 383908) The other measures were more or less the same everywhere.
('20', 154, 2, 9, 383966) The evidence about looting by the soldiers is stronger and more voluminous for Chuharkana than elsewhere.
('20', 154, 2, 10, 384072) Cattle were forcibly seized and milked for the soldiers.
('20', 154, 2, 11, 384129) Goats, utensils, eatables were taken away even in the absence of the owners.
('20', 154, 2, 12, 384206) It is difficult to estimate the material loss that the people must have suffered during the Martial Law regime.

('20', 158, 14, 24, 394060) (Statement 480.)
('20', 158, 15, 25, 394077) SHEIKHUPURA
('20', 158, 16, 26, 394089) Sheikhupura is a historic place, 25 miles from Lahore, and the last place to be noticed in the Gujranwala district.
('20', 158, 16, 27, 394205) It derives its name from the pet name of the Emperor Jehangir, and it was the residence of Rani Nakain of Maharaja Ranjit Singh.
('20', 158, 16, 28, 394334) It has a population of about 2,500 people.
('20', 158, 16, 29, 394377) Sheikhupura observed a hartal on the 6th of April.
('20', 158, 16, 30, 394428) It was spon taneous and complete, in spite of the interference by the Sub Ins pector of Police with the people.
('20', 158, 16, 31, 394540) There was a meeting in the evening, where, as admitted by the officials, temperate speeches were made.
('20', 158, 16, 32, 394643) The Sub Divisional Officer, Rai Sahib [Sri] Ram Sud, unsuccessfully attempted to stop the meeting by summoning the pleaders and using threatening language towards them.
('20', 158, 16, 33, 394812) Then, up to the 13th, there was
('20', 159, 0, 1, 394844) 160 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('20', 159, 1, 2, 394886) perfect peace.
('20', 159, 1, 3, 394901) The news of Amritsar and Lahore, however, had its effect upon Sheikhupura’s population, and the morning of the 14th saw another spontaneous and complete hartal, when too, there was no untoward incident.
('20', 159, 1, 4, 395104) It has been alleged that a baker’s shop was forcibly closed that day and that the baker was assaulted.
('20', 159, 1, 5, 395207) The statement is denied, in spite of a conviction registered by the so called Summary Court.
('20', 159, 1, 6, 395300) During the night, however, some telegraph and signal wires were cut by unknown persons, very pro bably from Sheikhupura.
('20', 159, 2, 7, 395421) In any case, the trouble did not arise out of the hartal, but all the same Martial Law was proclaimed on the 19th, and everything that has been narrated of the other places happened in Sheikhupura also.
('20', 159, 2, 8, 395624) The pleaders came in for special attention.
('20', 159, 2, 9, 395668) They were subjected to special humiliation; they were arrested and detained for 40 days and finally discharged without a trial and without being told why they had been arrested.
('20', 159, 2, 10, 395846) A special feature in Sheikhupura was that the whole of the male population, over the age of ten years, was made to sweep a large area of land, 1 just in order to humiliate the people.
('20', 159, 2, 11, 396030) They were also made to attend, from early morning till evening, for 7 days for the purpose of the so called investigation.
('20', 159, 2, 12, 396153) Schoolboys had to attend, as in other places also.
('20', 159, 3, 13, 396204) A 60 year old respected Lambardar of 38 years’ standing and a retired Inspector of Police 2, was arrested simply because his sons were not in Sheikhupura when they were wanted.
('20', 159, 3, 14, 396381) His property was confiscated and his tenants prohibited from cutting the crops.
('20', 159, 4, 15, 396461) The soldiers and the police freely helped themselves to the goods of the people.
('20', 159, 4, 16, 396542) The usual pressure was applied for extorting evidence and the trials resulted in the same miscarriage of justice as elsewhere.
('20', 159, 4, 17, 396669) But, unlike the other places, Mr. Bosworth Smith reported the pleaders to the High Court with a view to their being deprived of the right of practising.
('20', 159, 4, 18, 396822) Out of nearly 70 statements, we have selected about 30 for presentation, which support all the statements made above.

('20', 160, 1, 2, 397112) Sardar Boota Singh, B.A., LL.B., was a member of the District War League, who had assisted in recruiting and had received a certi ficate for his services.
('20', 160, 1, 3, 397267) He says that he took no part in either hartal, being engaged elsewhere on both the days.

('20', 160, 2, 5, 397391) No mob was seen collected in any place, no demonstrations were made anywhere and nothing unusual was done by the people.

('20', 160, 2, 7, 397605) [He adds:]
('20', 160, 3, 8, 397616) All of us were put in charge of some 25 soldiers, who carried loaded guns with fixed bayonets.
('20', 160, 3, 9, 397711) We were made to parade the city in this condition and were more than once made to sit upon filthy ground in the presence of our co villagers.
('20', 160, 3, 10, 397853) After making a full display of our humiliating condition for about an hour, we were marched double speed towards an armoured train.
('20', 160, 3, 11, 397985) I was abused, jeered at and beaten with a stick on account of my not keeping pace with the others owing to my ill health.
('20', 160, 3, 12, 398107) The prisoners were taken to Lahore, the journey occupying two hours.
('20', 160, 3, 13, 398176) Their repeated requests to be allowed to answer nature's call were refused by the guard, and no food was supplied to them till late in the evening.
('20', 160, 3, 14, 398324) [He continues:]
('20', 160, 4, 15, 398340) From the railway station, we were taken to the Central Jail Lahore, where we were handcuffed and taken to solitary cells.
('20', 160, 4, 16, 398462) For 40 days we were thus detained, thereby suffering the greatest possible discomfort and hardship.
('20', 160, 4, 17, 398562) As if all this was not enough, further humiliation was heaped upon them, even as they were discharged; for they were taken handcuffed to Sheikhupura, marched to the police station and then to the Naib Tahsildar's house in the town, evidently in order to mock them, and it was there that they were finally discharged.

('20', 161, 3, 9, 400388) It was totally unfit for habitation, as it had been used previously as a latrine, and was reeking with foul smell.
('20', 161, 3, 10, 400503) They were made to leave their turbans and shoes outside the lock up.
('20', 161, 3, 11, 400572) Gauhar Singh, being a Sikh, protested against the removal of the turban, and wanted to keep his spectacles on, as he could not see without them on account of his age.
('20', 161, 3, 12, 400739) His protests were disregarded.
('20', 161, 3, 13, 400770) He was dismissed from his lambardari without his being informed of it, and his appeal to the higher authority was also dismissed without his being heard.
('20', 161, 3, 14, 400924) (Statement 485.) Gosain Maya Ram, also B.A., LL.B., says that the arrests took place early in the morning:
('20', 161, 4, 15, 401031) We were not properly clad.

('20', 161, 4, 17, 401178) Our request to have our clothes brought was met with a curt refusal and a frown.

('20', 162, 1, 2, 402246) This witness relates an interesting conversation he had with the Sub Divisional Officer, who tried to warn him first, and then the other pleaders, from going to the meeting of the 6th April, and when he succeeded in showing that there was nothing wrong about the meeting and nothing inconsistent with the pleaders' licences to go to the meeting, the appeal was made on personal grounds, to which the Gosain weakly yielded.
('20', 162, 1, 3, 402669) Then the Sub Divisional Officer sent for other pleaders and told them that the Gosain had promised not to join the meeting.

('20', 162, 2, 6, 403056) (Statement 484.) Sardar Pritam Singh, Pleader, who happened not to be arrested, witnessed the ushering in of Martial Law, which was proclaimed in the evening of the 19th April.
('20', 162, 2, 7, 403233) He thus described it:
('20', 162, 3, 8, 403255) This proclamation was read by the Sub Divisional Officer, Rai Sahib Sri Ram himself, and after the reading was over, the people were told by him that he had been invested with powers to shoot them, in case they repeated the hartal a second time.
('20', 162, 3, 9, 403501) On this occasion, he made a thrust at the chins of several old respectable people with the end of his stick.
('20', 162, 3, 10, 403610) He then describes the machine gun demonstration referred to before the Hunter Committee:
('20', 162, 4, 11, 403699) About the end of April, a moving column of British and Indian soldiers made a demonstration of the strength of the Sirkar (Government) with a number of machine guns and motor cars mounted with guns.
('20', 162, 4, 12, 403898) Several iron pieces were placed against a mound, facing the machine guns.
('20', 162, 4, 13, 403972) After the machine guns had been worked, and the iron pieces pierced with gun fire, they were shown to the people, who had been made to see the tamasha by the order of the authorities.
('20', 162, 4, 14, 404156) They were told that those persons would be made the targets of these very machines, if they rebelled against the Sirkar again.
('20', 162, 4, 15, 404283) This show of power was, however, preceded by the reading of a proclamation, issued by the Lieutenant Governor, wherein he had advised the people to co operate with the Government in bringing about normal conditions.
('20', 162, 4, 16, 404499) This demonstration of power, side by side with an appeal for co operation, seems to be an incompatible mixture.
('20', 162, 4, 17, 404611) There was another demonstration, on or about the 7th May, of a different character, this time intended not merely to terrorize, but also to humiliate.
('20', 162, 4, 18, 404762) We again give it in the language of the same witness:

('20', 163, 1, 2, 404858) He gathered together in the sun all the people of the place including, among others, pleaders who had not been arrested.
('20', 163, 1, 3, 404979) The pleaders were separated from the rest and made to stand in two rows, the front row consisting of those who had not joined the meeting of the 6th April, and the back row consisting of those who had joined that meeting but without taking any active part in it.
('20', 163, 1, 4, 405242) Mr. Bosworth Smith then began his speech, and he took the Indian pleaders as his text.
('20', 163, 1, 5, 405329) He said among other things, that the pleaders of India were a low class of people (kamin), who agitated against the Sirkar and made the innocent
('20', 163, 2, 6, 405474) zemindars their tools.

('20', 163, 3, 10, 405872) After he had done with the pleaders, Mr. Bosworth Smith made Sardar Gauhar Singh, a retired Inspector of Police, parade before the people, barefooted and handcuffed, in the sun.

('20', 163, 4, 12, 406165) had been sent to jail for their misdeeds.
('20', 163, 4, 13, 406207) The Government would forfeit [sic ] his pension and deport him to Burma.
('20', 163, 4, 14, 406280) He then advised the people generally.
('20', 163, 4, 15, 406318) He said that they were all suar log (swine) and gandi makkhi (contemptible flies).
('20', 163, 4, 16, 406401) He actually spat on the ground, saying kala log (black men ) ganda log (contemptible people), sab ek rang ka (all of one colour), inasmuch as they had rebelled against the Sirkar by the closing of their shops.
('20', 163, 4, 17, 406611) He told them that they never should listen to the pleaders, who always cheated them, but go for advice to their Lambardars, Zaildars, Tahsildars and Deputies.
('20', 163, 4, 18, 406770) (Statement 503.) Here we have a special insult offered to the pleaders, an attempt to wean the people from those whom they considered their friends, the studied degradation of a respected Inspector of Police, because of the supposed misdeeds of his sons, and a vulgar abuse of the whole of his audience, and all this by an officer who was in charge of the district, and who was sent to restore order, and to punish the evil doers.
('20', 163, 4, 19, 407201) The case of Gauhar Singh shows to what extent the officials went in relentlessly persecuting innocent people.
('20', 163, 4, 20, 407311) Sardar Gauhar Singh and his family have practically been ruined, and in bringing ruin to these men, the officer who especially interested himself in them did not hesitate to resort to questionable means.

('20', 164, 2, 4, 407780) Accordingly, on the 19th of April , 1919, my father was arrested and sent to the Lahore Central Jail, without being guilty of any crime, but he was released that very day.
('20', 164, 2, 5, 407952) What happened to us at Sheikhupura that day is beyond description.

Before closing our review of the events of Sheikhupura during April, it is necessary to glance at a portion of the evidence given by Colonel O'Brien, Mr. Bosworth Smith, Rai Sahib Shri Ram Sud, who show the animus that they brought to bear upon their work.
('20', 165, 1, 5, 411072) It will be remembered that Colonel O'Brien justified the arrests without warrants, of people in general, on the strength of powers given to the Commissio ners under the Defence of India Act.
('20', 165, 1, 6, 411263) The ordinary common sense view of the section, which we have already quoted, would be that the Commissioners did not include Deputy Commi ssioners; where powers have been given to Deputy Commissioners, they have been specifically mentioned.
('20', 165, 1, 7, 411504) However, as far as Sheikhu pura pleaders were concerned, Col.
('20', 165, 1, 8, 411566) O'Brien shifted the ground by saying that they were arrested for organizing hartal.
('20', 165, 1, 9, 411650) Mr. Bosworth Smith, who was never before in Sheikhupura and, therefore, had never seen the pleaders before, has not only condemned them as a class without cause, but had the effrontery to report them to the High Court.
('20', 165, 1, 10, 411869) Rai Sahib Shri Ram Sud has admitted that he had a ground of complaint that one of the pleaders was (a) “a subscriber to The Tribune”, (b) “was seen bareheaded with another pleader on the day of hartal”, and (c) “as the president of the meeting, after the 6th April, he got letters of regret from some of the pleaders”; while another was (a) “a subscriber to the Moslem Herald”, (b) “was seen at the home of another pleader”, and (c) “had written a letter to the president of the meeting, regretting his inability to attend it ”.
('20', 165, 1, 11, 412398) We have not dealt with the summary trials in any detail nor with extortion.
('20', 165, 1, 12, 412474) The evidence on both these points is to be found in the Sheikhupura statements in a full measure.
('20', 165, 1, 13, 412572) The summary trials were a farce.
('20', 165, 1, 14, 412605) The evidence on extortion is most damaging.
('20', 165, 2, 15, 412649) LYALLPUR
('20', 165, 3, 16, 412658) Lyallpur is the headquarters of the Lyallpur district.
('20', 165, 3, 17, 412713) It is a new town containing a population of over 15,000. It is one of the largest depots for the exportation of wheat in the province.
('20', 165, 3, 18, 412848) There was a
('20', 166, 0, 1, 412860) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 167
('20', 166, 1, 2, 412900) spontaneous and complete hartal on the 6th April, and there was a public meeting also, at which resolutions were passed and carefully prepared, written out speeches, moderate in tone, were delivered.
('20', 166, 1, 3, 413100) The meeting was held after due consultation with the authorities.
('20', 166, 1, 4, 413166) Nothing happened up to the 12th.
('20', 166, 1, 5, 413199) But, by that time, the news of the arrests of Mr. Gandhi, Dr. Kitchlew and Dr. Satyapal had arrived and also about the firing at Lahore And Amritsar.
('20', 166, 1, 6, 413349) This brought about another spontaneous hartal.
('20', 166, 1, 7, 413396) The leaders tried to avoid it, but they were not able to control the feelings of the people.
('20', 166, 1, 8, 413489) They, however, rendered to the authorities great assistance in observing peace.
('20', 166, 1, 9, 413569) Rumours about the alleged firing on the Golden Temple had considerably disturbed the Sikh population specially, and the hartal was prolonged.
('20', 166, 1, 10, 413711) But, through the tact and vigilance of the leaders, the hartal was broken up on the 15th.
('20', 166, 1, 11, 413801) There was no disturbance whatsoever in the town.
('20', 166, 1, 12, 413850) Wires were cut near Lyallpur, but there was no connection between the wire cutting and the hartal or any person in Lyallpur.
('20', 166, 1, 13, 413975) Bundles of bhusa (chaff), stacked at the station, were burnt.
('20', 166, 1, 14, 414037) This was considered to be the work of incendiaries.
('20', 166, 1, 15, 414089) Innocent people were arrested and put to a lot of trouble in this connection, but upon a claim made on behalf of the Secretary of State for compensation a full enquiry was held and the magistrate dismissed the claim, and found that the burning of bhusa was not the work of incendiaries.
('20', 166, 1, 16, 414376) Unfortunately, the enquiry was held too late for the protection of the innocent people.
('20', 166, 1, 17, 414464) We have annexed the judgment to the statements recorded by us.
('20', 166, 1, 18, 414527) The magistrate says:
('20', 166, 2, 19, 414548) The bhusa appears to have gone on fire between 8.15 p.m.
('20', 166, 2, 20, 414605) and 8.45
('20', 166, 3, 21, 414614) The fire was noticed by the picket at about 8.40. The night was dark, there was strong wind blowing from the direction of the factory at the time.
('20', 166, 3, 22, 414761) This wind later developed into a dust storm of great violence.
('20', 166, 4, 23, 414824) The stack or rather pyramid of bales which was nearest to the factories had taken fire.
('20', 166, 4, 24, 414912) the fire had begun on the side nearest to the factories.
('20', 166, 4, 25, 414969) The sirki
('20', 166, 5, 26, 414979) covering or roof over the bales had caught fire.
('20', 166, 5, 27, 415028) The fire communicated itself to the bales at once.
('20', 166, 5, 28, 415079) The chaukidar of the bhusa stacks was absent at the
('20', 166, 6, 29, 415131) The store keeper or the officer in charge of baling operations arrived shortly after the fire had begun.
('20', 166, 6, 30, 415236) I reached the spot with cavalry very shortly after the fire had begun.
('20', 166, 6, 31, 415307) A few people from the factories, a few members of the municipal staff and the store keeper alluded to above were the only persons on the spot when I arrived.
('20', 166, 6, 32, 415465) There was no information of any crowd having visited the stacks or of any single person having been seen near the stacks.
('20', 166, 6, 33, 415587) The absence of the chaukidar seems to have been due to laziness and not to have
('20', 167, 0, 1, 415667) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 168
('20', 167, 1, 2, 415709) been arranged or premeditated.
('20', 167, 1, 3, 415740) Neither patrol nor picket saw anything suspicious in the vicinity of the goods yard.
('20', 167, 1, 4, 415825) The subsequent dust storm and the covering of the ground by footprints of the helpers who tried to prevent the fire spreading to other stacks prevented all possibility of evidence.
('20', 167, 2, 5, 416006) A very exhaustive police enquiry was made; no trace of anything bearing on the burning of the bhusa came out.
('20', 167, 2, 6, 416116) There were some approvers in the Lyallpur cases, who were associates of and in the secrets of those who were convicted in the Lyallpur disorders.
('20', 167, 2, 7, 416262) None of these however had any information to give in regard to the burning of the bhusa, which does not seem to have formed part of the plans of their associates.
('20', 167, 3, 8, 416425) There was a strong suspicion at the time that this was the work of an incendiary, because,
('20', 167, 4, 9, 416516) 1. similar acts had occurred elsewhere in connection with the disorders;
('20', 167, 5, 10, 416589) 2. a plot to burn bhusa had been alleged to have existed at Toba Tek Singh;
('20', 167, 6, 11, 416665) 3. of the fact that goods had been removed from the goods yard the day before.
('20', 167, 7, 12, 416744) The police enquiry, however, has failed to connect the burning of this bhusa with the act of any incendiary or with any riot or rioters.
('20', 167, 7, 13, 416881) Those convicted in jail in Lyallpur disorder were questioned by me.
('20', 167, 7, 14, 416949) They have now, after conviction, no object in concealing what they knew, and have given information on a number of other points, but none of them have any information to give about the bhusa .
('20', 167, 8, 15, 417142) I have examined the theory of whether it was the act of some villager or villagers, but no clue has been obtained .
('20', 167, 9, 16, 417258) Four factories were working on the day in question.
('20', 167, 9, 17, 417310) One of them was in close proximity to the stacks.
('20', 167, 9, 18, 417360) During the winter months no fires were caused to the bhusa by factories working ; but since April, there have been a number of fires in piles of open cotton in factory yards, due to cinders from chimneys, etc.
('20', 167, 9, 19, 417570) It is possible, though not likely on account of the distance, that this may have been the cause of the bhusa fire.
('20', 167, 10, 20, 417685) I have been unable to find anything, except suspicion, to point to this injury having arisen from riot and unlawful assembly within the area.
('20', 167, 11, 21, 417827) I am unable, therefore, to make the assessment contemplated in Section 15 A (2) (c) of the police Act.
('20', 167, 11, 22, 417930) Incidentally, the magistrate has remarked:
('20', 167, 12, 23, 417973) There were no riots or disturbances at Lyallpur that day; though shops were shut, no disorder or unlawful assemblies were noticed in the town itself (Statement 517 A.) So much was Lyallpur free from violent tendencies that Mr. B. W. Smith, Superintendent of Police, in giving his evidence before the
('20', 168, 0, 1, 418273) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 169

('20', 169, 1, 3, 421079) (Statement 517.) Lala Amir Chand 1 arrived at Lyallpur on domestic business on the 13th April.
('20', 169, 1, 4, 421174) He had arrived from Calcutta at Lahore on the 5th April.

('20', 169, 1, 13, 422162) He concludes:

('20', 169, 2, 15, 422261) (Statement 524.) Sardar Sant Singh, Vakil, gives a graphic description of the trial of the pleaders and others.
('20', 169, 2, 16, 422373) He shows how at every step they were obstructed in their defence, and delay was caused, during which time they were kept under detention, and although the case was not finished when Martial Law ceased to exist, they were convicted.

('20', 174, 2, 3, 433196) We have now reviewed, in the briefest manner possible, the events of April last in the five districts, in which Martial Law was proclaimed, viz, Amritsar, Lahore, Gujranwala, Lyallpur and Gujrat.
('20', 174, 2, 4, 433392) In spite of our desire to do full justice to the tragedy in the Punjab, for it was nothing less, we have been unable to do so.
('20', 174, 2, 5, 433519) It is not possible for us to condense into the compass of a brief review the story of persecution, corruption and disregard of human feelings that is revealed in the evidence we are presenting to the public.
('20', 174, 2, 6, 433727) We have endeavoured to hold the scales evenly.
('20', 174, 2, 7, 433774) We have endeavoured to make every allowance for the exceptional circumstances in which the officers suddenly found themselves placed.
('20', 174, 2, 8, 433908) Yet, we have come to the conclusion that the measures taken by the authorities to suppress what have been termed disorders were far in excess of the requirements.
('20', 174, 2, 9, 434071) What was the nature of the disorders, and how did they arise?
('20', 174, 2, 10, 434133) These disorders consisted in incendiarism in isolated places; murders of innocent Europeans; cutting of telegraph wires; burning, in an indifferent manner, of one or two small bridges; and derailment in one or two places.
('20', 174, 2, 11, 434355) It is admitted that they were not universal, that the armed population remained unaffected, took no part, directly or indirectly, in the disorders; that the vast masses of the peasantry took no part in violence; that the population, even according to the official testimony, alleged to have been concerned in the disorders, was only 4 1 2 lcs out of 2 crores, the total population of the Punjab.
('20', 174, 2, 12, 434751) According to the evidence in our possession, the only places where violence did take place were Amritsar, Kasur, Gujranwala, Wazirabad, Nizamabad, Hafizabad, Moman, Dhaban Singh, Chuharkana, Khem Karn, Patti and Malakwal, containing a population of about 2 1 4 lacs.
('20', 174, 2, 13, 435018) But it has to be
('20', 174, 3, 14, 435035) remembered that of this population of 2 1 4 lacs, it is clear from the evidence both before us and the Hunter Committee and that obtainable from the records of the several trials, that only a very small fraction could have taken an actual part in the alleged disorders.
('20', 174, 3, 15, 435305) The European lives lost were four.
('20', 174, 3, 16, 435340) We cannot too strongly condemn this action of the mob.
('20', 174, 4, 17, 435395) But how did a people, generally peaceful, find it in them to burn public property and commit murders?
('20', 174, 4, 18, 435497) We have attempted to give the answer.
('20', 174, 4, 19, 435535) Sir Michael O'Dwyer put an undue strain upon the proverbial patience of the people.
('20', 174, 4, 20, 435619) By his vilification of the educated classes, by his methods of recruiting and collecting the War Loan and other
('20', 175, 0, 1, 435731) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 176
('20', 175, 1, 2, 435773) funds, by his suppression of the public Press, he had caused immense irritation among the people.
('20', 175, 1, 3, 435871) His utterly unjustifiable deportation of Mr. Gandhi and Drs.
('20', 175, 1, 4, 435932) Kitchlew and Satyapal lighted the material he had made inflammable.
('20', 175, 1, 5, 436000) Being defeated in his attempt to prevent the peaceful demonstration of the 6th April against the Rowlatt legislation, he thought he would make one supreme effort to crush the spirit of the people, struggling to find a free and disciplined expression.
('20', 175, 1, 6, 436251) He mistook this healthy plant for a poisonous weed to be rooted out by every means; and he resorted to the madness of the deportations just mentioned.
('20', 175, 1, 7, 436402) It would still perhaps have been well if he had issued peremptory orders to his subordinates not to be free with their rifles.
('20', 175, 1, 8, 436529) But it was impossible for him to be temperate and furious at the same time.
('20', 175, 1, 9, 436605) The unwise firing at Amritsar strained the temper of the people to the breaking point.
('20', 175, 1, 10, 436692) The crowd became mad, and, in its fury, committed arson, murder and pillage, and spent its fury in three hours.
('20', 175, 1, 11, 436804) The other places, mentioned by us, caught the infection from and copied Amritsar, we are, however, thankful to be able to say, without any further destruction of life except at Kasur.
('20', 175, 1, 12, 436988) Was this a state of rebellion or waging of war?
('20', 175, 1, 13, 437036) Was this a state beyond the power of the civil authority, taking assistance, if necessary, from the military to cope with?
('20', 175, 1, 14, 437159) Was it a state necessitating supers ession of law?
('20', 175, 1, 15, 437210) We have answered the question in dealing with each place separately, and the cumulative effect of the whole examination strengt hens the conclusion that, so far as the published evidence before the Hunter Committee and the evidence in our possession shows, there was no necessity whatsoever for the promulgation of Martial Law.
('20', 175, 1, 16, 437538) The secret evidence led before Lord Hunter’s Committee will have to be extraordinarily clear and overwhelming to establish a case for Martial Law.
('20', 175, 1, 17, 437685) The theory of rebellion or war completely broke down before the Hunter Committee.
('20', 175, 1, 18, 437767) There was no proof of organization outside the Punjab and behind the so called conspiracy.
('20', 175, 1, 19, 437858) On the contrary, Col.
('20', 175, 1, 20, 437880) O’Brien—one of Sir Michael’s trusted lieutenants—had to admit that he had no evidence to support the theory of rebellion, that it was mere guess work and that his arrest of the leaders of Gujranwala, too, was based on mere table talk.
('20', 175, 1, 21, 438115) He admitted that he had nothing to connect the leaders directly with violence, but that he wanted to hold them responsible if there was any violence at all in Gujranwala.
('20', 175, 1, 22, 438286) The other witnesses fared no better.
('20', 175, 1, 23, 438323) They only betrayed their own incapacity for assessing the values of acts and events.
('20', 176, 0, 1, 438408) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 177
('20', 176, 1, 2, 438448) The fact is it was necessary for Sir Michael’s theory that the Rowlatt agitation was mischievous, to establish a widespread conspiracy.
('20', 176, 1, 3, 438584) The wish was father to the thought, and he saw, and he made others see that in every speech of the leaders there was sedition, in every hartal a conspiracy, and in every Hindu Mohammedan fraternization a menace to British rule.
('20', 176, 1, 4, 438812) No wonder the conspiracy theory broke down.
('20', 176, 1, 5, 438856) And if Martial Law was unjustified, much more so was its prolongation for nearly two months.
('20', 176, 1, 6, 438949) The measures taken under it were such as to disgrace any government, calling itself civilized.
('20', 176, 1, 7, 439044) Its inauguration was heralded by the massacre of the innocents of Jallianwala Bagh.
('20', 176, 1, 8, 439128) The tone of frightfulness set up by General Dyer was approved by Sir Michael O’Dwyer during the two dark months that followed.
('20', 176, 1, 9, 439255) If our figures are correct, and we hold them to be so, nearly 1,200 lives were lost, at least 3,600 men wounded, and some permanently disabled.
('20', 176, 1, 10, 439399) The vengeance taken was out of all proportion to the wrong done by the people—wrong moreover, which was initiated under grave provocation.
('20', 176, 1, 11, 439538) The slow torture administered to the survivors during the Martial Law period, we have sufficiently described.
('20', 176, 1, 12, 439648) We can only hope that the reve lations presented by us will make a repetition of the atrocities impossible.
('20', 176, 2, 13, 439756) CHAPTER VI
('20', 176, 3, 14, 439767) CONCLUSION
('20', 176, 4, 15, 439778) We have now dealt with the five districts in which Martial Law was proclaimed.
('20', 176, 4, 16, 439857) We have dealt with Sir M. O'Dwyer’s regime, and we have endeavoured to examine the Rowlatt Act and the satyagraha movement.
('20', 176, 4, 17, 439981) We desire to state that we have endeavoured to keep ourselves to the facts before us, and not based our conclusions on anything outside the evidence, printed separately, supplemented by the evidence given before Lord Hunter’s Committee and the record of the Martial Law Tribunals.
('20', 176, 4, 18, 440262) We have been obliged in places to use strong language, but we have used every adjective with due deliberation.
('20', 176, 4, 19, 440373) If anything, we have understated the case against the Punjab Government.
('20', 176, 4, 20, 440446) We recognize that we have no right to exact an impossible standard of correctness from the Government.
('20', 176, 4, 21, 440549) In times of excitement and difficulty, any officer is prone to make mistakes, in spite of the best intentions in the
('20', 177, 0, 1, 440666) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 178
('20', 177, 1, 2, 440708) We recognize, too, that when the country is on the eve of important changes introduced in the administration, and the Sovereign has made an appeal to the officials and the people for co operation we should say nothing that may be calculated to retard the progress.
('20', 177, 2, 3, 440973) But we feel that it is not possible to ignore acts of atrocious injustice on a wholesale scale by responsible officers, as it would not be possible, no matter how bright the future might be, to ignore the criminal acts of the people.
('20', 177, 2, 4, 441207) In our opinion, it is more necessary now than ever before that the official wrong should be purged as well as the people’s.
('20', 177, 2, 5, 441331) The task of working the Reforms and making India realize her goal in the quickest time possible would be well nigh impossible if both the people and the officials did not approach it with clean hands and clean minds.
('20', 177, 2, 6, 441548) If, therefore, we recommend that officials who have erred should be brought to justice, we do so not in a vindictive spirit, but in order that the administration of the country may become purified of corruption and injustice.
('20', 177, 2, 7, 441774) Whilst, therefore, we believe that the mob excesses in Amritsar and elsewhere were wrong and deserving of condemnation, we are equally sure that the popular misdeeds have been more than punished by the action of the authorities.
('20', 177, 3, 8, 442003) We believe that had Mr. Gandhi not been arrested whilst he was on his way to Delhi and the Punjab, and had Drs.
('20', 177, 3, 9, 442115) Kitchlew and Satyapal not been arrested and deported, innocent English lives would have been saved,and valuable property, including Christian churches, not destroyed.
('20', 177, 3, 10, 442282) These two acts of the Punjab Government were uncalled for, and served like matches applied to material rendered inflammable by previous processes.
('20', 177, 4, 11, 442429) In examining, in detail, the events in the different districts of the Punjab, we have refrained from saying anything regarding the Government of India.
('20', 177, 4, 12, 442581) It is impossible, however, to ignore or slur over the inaction, if not the active participation, of the Central Government in the offi cial action.
('20', 177, 4, 13, 442729) His Excellency the Viceroy never took the trouble of examining the people’s case.
('20', 177, 4, 14, 442811) He ignored telegrams and letters from individuals and public bodies.
('20', 177, 4, 15, 442880) He endorsed the action of the Punjab Government without inquiry.
('20', 177, 4, 16, 442945) He clothed the officials with indemnity in indecent haste.
('20', 177, 4, 17, 443004) He never went to the Punjab to make personal inquiry, even after the occurrences.
('20', 177, 4, 18, 443086) He ought to have known, at least in May, everything that the various official witnesses have admitted, and yet he failed to inform the public or the Imperial
('20', 178, 0, 1, 443244) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 179
('20', 178, 1, 2, 443284) Government of the full nature of the Jallianwala Bagh massacre, or the subsequent acts done under Martial Law.
('20', 178, 1, 3, 443395) He became a party to preventing even a noble and well known English Christian of unimpeachable veracity in the person of Mr. C. F. Andrews from proceeding to the Punjab, 1 whilst he was on his way, not to inflame passions, but simply to find out the truth.
('20', 178, 1, 4, 443652) He allowed Mr. Thompson, the Chief Secretary to the Punjab Government, to indulge in distortion of facts and insult the Hon’ble Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya, whose statements, made in the Council 2 , have almost all been now proved to be true out of the mouths of the official witnesses themselves.
('20', 178, 1, 5, 443950) He expressed such a callous indifference to popular feelings and betrayed such criminal want of imagination, that he would not postpone the death sentences pronounced by the Martial Law Tribunals, except after he was forced to do so by the Secretary of State for India.
('20', 178, 1, 6, 444220) He seems to have closed his heart against further light by shutting out questions by a responsible member of the Council like the Hon’ble Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya.
('20', 178, 1, 7, 444387) He would not visit the Punjab for local inquiry.
('20', 178, 1, 8, 444436) We refrain from criticizing his attitude over the Rowlatt agitation.
('20', 178, 1, 9, 444505) But a sense of public safety forbids us to ignore His Excellency’s inability to appreciate and deal with the situation in April.
('20', 178, 1, 10, 444634) Whilst, therefore, we do not think His Excellency was wilfully neglectful of the interests of those who were entrusted to his charge by His Majesty, we regret to say that His Excellency Lord Chelmsford proved himself incapable of holding the high office to which he was called, and we are of opinion that His Excellency should be recalled.
('20', 178, 2, 11, 444974) We summarize below our other conclusions: 1. The people of the Punjab were incensed against Sir M. O’Dwyer’s administration by reason of his studied contempt and distrust of the educated classes and by reason of the cruel and compulsory methods, adopted during the War, for obtaining recruits and monetary contributions and by his suppression of public opinion by gagging the local Press and shutting out nationalist newspapers from outside the Punjab.
('20', 178, 2, 12, 445427) 2. The Rowlatt agitation disturbed the public mind and shook public confidence in the goodwill of the Government.
('20', 178, 2, 13, 445541) This was
('20', 178, 3, 14, 445550) 1 Andrews, while on his way to Lahore, was taken out of the train at Amritsar railway station, detained there for several hours and finally sent back out of the Punjab.
('20', 178, 3, 15, 445719) 2 Imperial Legislative Council

('20', 179, 1, 2, 445792) shared by the Punjab in a fuller measure perhaps than elsewhere, because of the use made by Sir M. O’Dwyer of the Defence of India Act for purposes of stifling public movements.
('20', 179, 1, 3, 445970) 3. The satyagraha movement, and the hartal which was designed as a precursor of it, whilst they vitalized the whole country into activity, saved it from more awful and more wide spread calamities, by restraining the violent tendencies and passions of the people.

('20', 179, 1, 5, 446413) 5. There was no conspiracy to overthrow the Government in the Punjab.

('20', 179, 1, 8, 446675) 7. The mob violence which began at Amritsar was directly due to the firing at the railway over bridge, and the sight of the dead and wounded at a time when the excitement had reached white heat.
('20', 179, 1, 9, 446870) 8. Whatever the cause of provocation, the mob excesses are deeply to be regretted and condemned.

('20', 179, 1, 11, 447089) 10. In each case, Martial Law was proclaimed after order had been completely restored.
('20', 179, 1, 12, 447176) 11. Even if it be held that the introduction of Martial Law was a State necessity, it was unduly prolonged.
('20', 179, 1, 13, 447284) 12. Most of the measures taken under Martial Law, in all the five districts, were unnecessary, cruel, oppressive and in utter disregard of the feelings of the people affected by them.
('20', 179, 1, 14, 447468) 13. In Lahore, Akalgarh, Ramnagar, Gujrat, Jalalpur Jattan, Lyallpur and Sheikhupura, there were no mob excesses at all worthy of the name.
('20', 179, 1, 15, 447608) 14. The Jallianwala Bagh massacre was a calculated piece of inhumanity towards utterly innocent and unarmed men, including children, and unparallelled for its ferocity in the history of modern British administration.
('20', 179, 1, 16, 447825) 15. The Martial Law Tribunals and the Summary Courts were made the means of harassing innocent people, and resulted in abortion of justice on a wide scale, and under the name of justice caused moral and material sufferings to hundreds of men and women.

('20', 180, 1, 2, 448118) 16. The crawling order and other fancy punishments were unworthy of a civilized administration, and were symptomatic of the moral degradation of their inventors.
('20', 180, 1, 3, 448280) 17. ('20', 186, 1, 2, 459252) 7. NOTES
('20', 186, 2, 3, 459261) RABINDRANATH TAGORE'S VISIT Information has been received that Sir Rabindranath Tagore, the poet, is to spend a week in Gujarat.
('20', 186, 2, 4, 459390) We shall profit best from his presence if we give him peace and learn from him the things we should.
('20', 186, 2, 5, 459491) He does not like too many functions.
('20', 186, 2, 6, 459528) He keeps indifferent health.
('20', 186, 2, 7, 459557) Perfect silence is essential at the meetings which he is to attend.
('20', 186, 2, 8, 459625) He dislikes people shouting.
('20', 186, 2, 9, 459654) We believe that, if we bear these restrictions in mind, he will be able to visit Surat and Broach.
('20', 186, 2, 10, 459753) How can we honour him best?
('20', 186, 2, 11, 459781) By helping his enterprise financially.
('20', 186, 2, 12, 459820) He is deeply attached to his Santiniketan Ashram and the School 1 it runs.
('20', 186, 2, 13, 459895) The Ashram was founded by his father 2 and the School by himself.
('20', 186, 2, 14, 459961) He meets the expenses for these from donations received.
('20', 186, 2, 15, 460018) He has used his own money, too, for these enterprises of his.
('20', 186, 2, 16, 460080) When he toured Madras last year, he received donations for Santiniketan from every place that he visited.
('20', 186, 2, 17, 460186) We think it will create an excellent impression if something like that happens in Gujarat too.
('20', 186, 2, 18, 460281) We hope this will be borne in mind at every place he visits.
('20', 186, 2, 19, 460342) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 28 3 1920

('20', 187, 5, 14, 462193) 9. MEANING OF “BANDHU”
('20', 187, 6, 15, 462216) [Before March 30, 1920] 1
('20', 187, 7, 16, 462242) I had praised Shrimati Sarladevi's article, “Bandhu”, 2 appearing in the issue of 29th February and asked the readers to read it several times over.
('20', 187, 7, 17, 462391) Thereupon, some of them wrote to me to say that they had gone through the article and reflected over it but had failed to make out its meaning.
('20', 187, 7, 18, 462535) They have requested me to explain the meaning myself.
('20', 187, 7, 19, 462589) I could not reply immediately, being busy with my numerous activities.
('20', 187, 7, 20, 462660) Now that I have some peace in Sinhgadh, I have read the article three times and give here the meaning as I understand it.
('20', 187, 7, 21, 462782) The first part of the article was written several years ago when she was living in Bolpur 3. I saw her in her disconsolate state when her husband was in jail 4. I saw that nothing would give her peace.
('20', 187, 7, 22, 462984) The consolation which a friend could give in such circumstances, I tried to, but I could see that this brought no peace to her mind.
('20', 187, 7, 23, 463117) She was
('20', 187, 8, 24, 463125) 1 The article was obviously written at Sinhgadh, where Gandhiji stayed from March 26 to March 30. 2 Literally, brother 3 Probably at Santiniketan 4 In 1919
('20', 188, 0, 1, 463281) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 189
('20', 188, 1, 2, 463321) suffering, I saw, as a woman separated from her husband does.
('20', 188, 1, 3, 463383) When I spoke about the release of prisoners, trying to guess when one could expect them to be out, I found that I could engage her attention.
('20', 188, 1, 4, 463525) It was while she was in this frame of mind that I once requested her to write something for Navajivan or Young India.
('20', 188, 1, 5, 463643) She hesitated, putting me off with the remark: “Ideas will just not come.” One day she observed : “Long ago I wrote something which, in Bengali, would be considered good.
('20', 188, 1, 6, 463814) If you agree, I will complete it, and you may have it translated if you wish.
('20', 188, 1, 7, 463892) I should have the right to send the Bengali to some other journal.” I agreed.
('20', 188, 1, 8, 463970) ‘One does not look a gift horse in the mouth’ is a saying in English.
('20', 188, 1, 9, 464040) Moreover, my aim was to see that she had something to occupy her.
('20', 188, 1, 10, 464106) It is easy to explain the meaning now.
('20', 188, 1, 11, 464145) There is a saying among us that “Time is invincible.” Time has also been described as an enemy.
('20', 188, 1, 12, 464241) This same Time takes for us the form of a bandhu when we are not plunged in the grief of separation or lost in the midst of pleasures, and gives us peace.
('20', 188, 1, 13, 464396) This was the peace which was Sarladevi's when she lived in the woods.
('20', 188, 1, 14, 464466) And so, Time, like a bandhu, tells us at early dawn: “Now be seated here and dive deep into your mind for a while.” And again, when we have done our duty for the hour, is it any wonder that the Time bird should smile at us with a face lit up with joy?
('20', 188, 1, 15, 464718) In the afternoon, no doubt, drowsiness comes upon us but the Brother Time cautions us to look outside, to observe the fields there and see that they are quiet, but not asleep.“What aspirations and hopes, what music and beauty shine through!” By thus overcoming laziness, we have had the peace of the noon too.
('20', 188, 1, 16, 465028) And now comes twilight.
('20', 188, 1, 17, 465052) Well, the Bird says: “Enough!
('20', 188, 1, 18, 465082) Now sit quietly in one spot and do nothing.” What else is there to do?
('20', 188, 1, 19, 465153) For one who goes over the day's work with a tranquil mind at twilight and thanks God for a day well spent, what else is there to do at that hour?
('20', 188, 1, 20, 465299) Passing the day thus, Sarladevi found that Time was a bandhu.
('20', 188, 1, 21, 465361) Here starts the second part.
('20', 188, 1, 22, 465390) Who is to live in the house— she or the furniture?
('20', 188, 1, 23, 465441) “We have left the woods and come to a city.
('20', 188, 1, 24, 465485) Cupboards all around and tables and chairs.” “A little bit of sky framed” in a small window—this is all that remained as a visible symbol of the Formless.

('20', 189, 0, 1, 465887) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 190
('20', 189, 1, 2, 465929) is an enemy—it is not peace.
('20', 189, 1, 3, 465958) And so Sarladevi asks, doubtfully, whether Time is always a bandhu or one only when the heart is ready to receive him as such.
('20', 189, 1, 4, 466085) “As we can have no real contact with a bandhu unless we make the mind free, so this bandhu perhaps does not like coming to us in the midst of all this uncontrolled rushing about for material things?” Of course, he does not.
('20', 189, 1, 5, 466309) Happiness comes only where there is self control.
('20', 189, 1, 6, 466359) Lack of self control is a sign that one is not at peace with oneself.

('20', 189, 1, 8, 466545) Is it the perfection inside me?
('20', 189, 1, 9, 466577) One who is perfect inside needs no external bandhu to complete that perfection.” If at all one does, the author proceeds to show what kind of a bandhu he must be.
('20', 189, 1, 10, 466740) Time being no longer ours, whom should we seek?
('20', 189, 1, 11, 466788) Ponder ing over this, she remembered the Bhagavad Gita.

('20', 189, 1, 13, 466913) Only in Rama can the weak find strength.
('20', 189, 1, 14, 466954) When there is no living creature to console one in separation and lighten the grief, the grief stricken one calls on Rama.
('20', 189, 1, 15, 467077) So long as the elephant could struggle against the crocodile, he did not remember God; 1 but, when his lord ship was exhausted, he began to call on the servant of servants.
