('20', 190, 4, 11, 468651) 11. THE SATYAGRAHA WEEK
('20', 190, 5, 12, 468675) First and foremost in the programme for the holy National Week I put fasting and prayer.
('20', 190, 5, 13, 468764) I have said enough to emphasize the necessity of both these for the unfoldment of our national life.
('20', 190, 5, 14, 468865) I speak of these from personal experience.
('20', 190, 5, 15, 468908) But, writing to a friend on this very matter of prayer, I came across a beautiful thing from Tennyson which I present to the readers of Young India, if perchance I might convert them to a definite belief in the efficacy of prayer.
('20', 190, 5, 16, 469139) Here is the gem:
('20', 190, 6, 17, 469156) More things are wrought by prayer Than this world dreams of.
('20', 190, 6, 18, 469217) Wherefore let they voice Rise like a fountain for me night and day.
('20', 190, 6, 19, 469285) For what are men better than sheep or goats That nourish a blind life within the brain, If, knowing God, they lift not hands of prayer Both for themselves and those who call them friend?
('20', 190, 6, 20, 469472) For so the whole round earth is every way Bound by gold chains about the feet of God.
('20', 190, 6, 21, 469558) Throughout my wanderings in India, I have had the privilege of mixing with men of all creeds, of mixing with thousands of women, hundreds upon hundreds of students.
('20', 190, 6, 22, 469723) I have discussed with them national problems with a passion which I am unable to describe.
('20', 190, 7, 23, 469814) 1 On March 25, 1920 2 Gandhiji could go back to Sinhgadh only on April 29.
('20', 191, 0, 1, 469889) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 192
('20', 191, 1, 2, 469931) have found that we have not yet reached a conscious recognition of our national state.
('20', 191, 1, 3, 470018) We have not had the discipline necessary for a realization of that state and I venture to say that there is nothing so powerful as fasting and prayer that would give us the requisite discipline, spirit of self sacrifice, humility and resoluteness of will without which there can be no real progress.
('20', 191, 1, 4, 470318) I hope therefore that millions throughout India will open the Satyagraha Week with sincere fasting and prayer.
('20', 191, 2, 5, 470429) I do not wish, during this weak, to emphasize the civil resistance part of satyagraha.
('20', 191, 2, 6, 470516) I would like us to contemplate truth and non violence, and to appreciate their invincibility.
('20', 191, 2, 7, 470610) Indeed, if all of us regulate our lives by this eternal law of satya and ahimsa, there will be no occasion for civil or other resistance.
('20', 191, 2, 8, 470748) Civil resistance comes into play when only a small body of men endeavour to follow truth in the face of opposition.
('20', 191, 2, 9, 470864) It is difficult to know what is truth, when to defend it to the point of civil resistance and how to avoid error in the shape of violence in one's pursuit after truth.
('20', 191, 2, 10, 471032) There may well be differences of opinion as to the advisability of preaching civil resistance as a creed during a week devoted to national uplift, in which one seeks the co operation of all without distinction of party, class or creed.
('20', 191, 3, 11, 471268) Beyond the prayer and fasting on the 6th and the 13th we have the collection for the Jallianwala Bagh Memorial.
('20', 191, 3, 12, 471380) 1 I trust that complete organization would be set up in every province, in every district, and every town or village.
('20', 191, 4, 13, 471498) The third part of the activity is represented by three meetings during the week all over India at the stated times, whereat I have suggested the passing of certain resolutions, viz., on the Rowlatt Act which gave rise to the satyagraha movement, the Khilafat question which by Hindu association cements Hindu Muslim unity, and what may be called the Jallianwala Bagh resolution, to be passed on the 13th April, calling upon the Government to take such measures as may be necessary to prevent a repetition of the tragedies that were witnessed during Martial Law regime and which were opened even before the inauguration of Martial Law by the unlawful massacre of the 13th.
('20', 191, 4, 14, 472170) I suggest the following resolutions for acceptance:

('20', 197, 1, 2, 482957) 15. APPEAL FOR JALLIANWALA BAGH MEMORIAL FUND 1
('20', 197, 2, 3, 483005) BOMBAY, April 6, 1920 I trust that Bombay will respond in its own generous manner to the Punjab Memorial.
('20', 197, 2, 4, 483111) It is a national monument.
('20', 197, 2, 5, 483138) I have said repeatedly that it is in no sense anti British.
('20', 197, 2, 6, 483198) We should be unfit to call ourselves a nation if we did not treasure the memory of those innocent men who fell on the fateful 13th of April, 1919. I hope that Englishmen will see their way to subscribe to the Memorial.
('20', 197, 2, 7, 483417) Their co operation will be a demonstration of the non racial character of the Memorial.
('20', 197, 2, 8, 483505) Moreover, it stands independent of any finding, adverse or otherwise, of the Hunter Committee.
('20', 197, 2, 9, 483600) It has been officially admitted that the men killed were innocent.
('20', 197, 2, 10, 483667) Nothing that the Hunter Committee may find can possibly free India from the obligation to nationalize the plot in which innocent blood flowed in such profusion and to erect on it a national memorial that shall preserve the memory of the dead and shall yet be free from any poison or hatred.
('20', 197, 3, 11, 483958) M. K. GANDHI The Bombay Chronicle, 7 4 1920
('20', 197, 4, 12, 484002) 16. SPEECH AT NATIONAL WEEK MEETING, BOMBAY
('20', 197, 5, 13, 484046) April 6, 1920
('20', 197, 6, 14, 484060) In connection with the National Week, a public meeting of the citizens of Bombay was held under the joint auspices of the Presidency Association, the Provincial Congress Committee, the Bombay branches of the Home Rule League, and the National Union, at the open space near the French Bridge, Bombay, yesterday.
('20', 197, 6, 15, 484371) Among those present, besides the President, were Mr. M. K. Gandhi, Mrs. Annie Besant, Mr. M.A. Jinnah, .
('20', 197, 7, 16, 484476) the Hon'ble Sir Dinshah M. Petit was elected to the chair.
('20', 197, 8, 17, 484535) The following is an authentic summary of Mr. Gandhi's speech .
('20', 197, 8, 18, 484598) in seconding the resolution moved by the Hon'ble V. J. Patel urging the repeal of the Rowlatt Act.
('20', 197, 8, 19, 484697) Mr. Gandhi said he hoped that at least during the Satyagraha Week, if not for
('20', 197, 9, 20, 484775) 1 Released as a letter to the Press
('20', 198, 0, 1, 484811) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 199
('20', 198, 1, 2, 484851) always, the meetings would be conducted on the same principles as they were done during the satyagraha campaign.
('20', 198, 1, 3, 484964) The principles were that there should be no signs or sounds of approval or disapproval of the speakers' remarks but that they should be listened to in perfect silence and with respect.
('20', 198, 1, 4, 485149) Mr. Gandhi felt that if this rule was observed the audience would be able to follow clearly the views that might be expounded by the various speakers.
('20', 198, 1, 5, 485300) He called this the Satyagraha Week but he hoped that no one in the audience would be frightened by the word.
('20', 198, 1, 6, 485409) He fully realized his responsibility as he knew that he was addressing a meeting called under the auspices of the Bombay Presidency Association which was a non satyagraha body.
('20', 198, 1, 7, 485586) He spoke about the Satyagraha Week without hesitation because he was neither emphasizing nor offering civil resistance for acceptance.
('20', 198, 1, 8, 485721) He wanted to emphasize the necessity for truthfulness in speech and in deed and of non violence in their relentless pursuit of Truth.
('20', 198, 1, 9, 485855) Mr. Patel who had preceded him had said that resolutions were of no use.
('20', 198, 1, 10, 485928) He agreed with Mr. Patel to a certain extent.
('20', 198, 1, 11, 485974) But there were resolutions and resolutions.
('20', 198, 1, 12, 486018) Theirs was not a resolution of despair but of confidence.
('20', 198, 1, 13, 486076) It was not so much addressed to Government as it was a prayer addressed to the Almightly.
('20', 198, 1, 14, 486166) He as a believer in fasting and praying made bold to say that if they had Truth on their side and a prayerful heart com bined with determination to sacrifice themselves they could not but achieve success.
('20', 198, 1, 15, 486371) Their resolution was moreover an invitation to Government to do their duty.
('20', 198, 1, 16, 486447) The Congress had offered co operation 1 on the Reforms in so far as that co operation spelt national uplift.
('20', 198, 1, 17, 486556) It was an act of nobility on the part of the Congress when it offered co operation in spite of the Rowlatt Act remaining on the statute book as a weapon that could be used by Government at any moment to repress the people or their activities.
('20', 198, 1, 18, 486799) The resolution was an invitation to Government to respond to that nobility by removing the Rowlatt Act even before the Reformed Assembly met 2 .
('20', 198, 1, 19, 486944) Mr. Patel had also pointed out the difficulty of carrying a repealing measure in the event of Government not repealing the Rowlatt Act before the Reformed Assembly met.
('20', 198, 1, 20, 487113) He very properly urged that the Viceroy had merely to certify that a particular measure would endanger the peace of the land to stop its progress.
('20', 198, 1, 21, 487260) But he (Mr. Gandhi) felt that there were other ways of combating any such untoward result if the Government failed in its duty.
('20', 198, 1, 22, 487388) He had no doubt about the Act being repealed during the first session of the Reformed Assembly.
('20', 198, 1, 23, 487484) But even if that new Assembly failed to do its duty he assured the meeting that so long as there was a handful of satyagrahis left alive, there would be no peace in the land until that Act was repealed before its statutory period.
('20', 198, 2, 24, 487715) Therefore he seconded the resolution, not in despair but in all confidence, and recommended it to the audience as a token of the fixed resolve of the people of India to secure the repeal of that obnoxious measure which had cost such suffering for so many people.
('20', 198, 3, 25, 487978) The Bombay Chronicle, 7 4 1920 & 8 4 1920
('20', 198, 4, 26, 488020) 1 At its Amritsar session held in December 1919 2 Elections to the Central Legislative Assembly under the Reforms Act of 1919 were to be held in November 1920.
('20', 199, 0, 1, 488180) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 200
('20', 199, 1, 2, 488222) 17. THE PUNJAB SENTENCES The Commissioners appointed by the Congress Punjab Sub committee have in their report accused His Excellency the Viceroy of criminal want of imagination.
('20', 199, 1, 3, 488401) His Excellency's refusal to commute two death sentences out of five is a fine illustration of the accusation.
('20', 199, 1, 4, 488511) The rejection of the appeal 1 by the Privy Council no more proves the guilt of the condemned than their innocence could have been proved by quashing the proceedings before the Martial Law Tribunal.
('20', 199, 1, 5, 488709) Moreover, these cases clearly come under the Royal Proclamation 2 in accordance with its interpretation by the Punjab Government.
('20', 199, 1, 6, 488839) The murders in Amritsar were not due to any private quarrel between the murderers and their victims.
('20', 199, 1, 7, 488940) The offence, grave though it was, was purely political and committed under excitement.
('20', 199, 1, 8, 489027) More than full reparation has been taken for the murders and arson.
('20', 199, 1, 9, 489095) In the circumstances common sense dictates reduction of the death sentences.
('20', 199, 1, 10, 489172) The popular belief favours the view that the condemned men are innocent and have not had a fair trial.
('20', 199, 1, 11, 489275) The execution has been so long delayed that hanging at this stage would give a rude shock to Indian society.
('20', 199, 1, 12, 489384) Any Viceroy with imagination would have at once announced commutation of the death sentences—not so Lord Chelmsford.
('20', 199, 1, 13, 489501) In his estimation, evidently, the demands of justice will not be satisfied if at least some of the condemned men are not han ged.
('20', 199, 1, 14, 489631) Public feeling with him counts for nothing.
('20', 199, 1, 15, 489675) We shall still hope that either the Viceroy or Mr. Montagu will commute the death sentences.
('20', 199, 1, 16, 489768) But if the Government will grievously err, if they carry out the sentences, the people will equally err if they give way to anger or grief over the hanging if it has unfortunately to take place.
('20', 199, 1, 17, 489963) Before we become a nation possessing an effective voice in the councils of nations, we must be prepared to contemplate with equanimity, not a thousand murders of innocent men and women but many thousands before we attain a status in the world that shall not be surpassed by any nation.
('20', 199, 1, 18, 490249) We hope therefore that all concerned will take rather than lose heart and treat hanging as an ordinary affair of life.
('20', 199, 1, 19, 490368) (Since the above was in type, we have received the cruel news.
('20', 199, 1, 20, 490431) At last H. E. the Viceroy has mercilessly given the rude shock to Indian society.
('20', 199, 1, 21, 490513) It is now for the latter to take heart in spite of the unkindest cut.—Editor, Young India.) Young India, 7 4 1920

('20', 200, 2, 7, 491049) It breathes the loftiest sentiments.
('20', 200, 2, 8, 491086) Every line of it is proof of the religious spirit pervading his effort.
('20', 200, 2, 9, 491158) It is worthy of the Poet and the occasion.
('20', 200, 2, 10, 491201) His reference to Calcutta as the product of modern civilizaton is a fine token of his innate courtesy and humility.

('20', 200, 2, 13, 491501) He performed his task with consummate skill by describing the condition of Calcutta.

('20', 201, 6, 29, 494186) April 9, 1920
('20', 201, 7, 30, 494200) In connection with the National Week, a public meeting of the citizens of Bombay was held under the auspices of the Central Khilafat Committee of India, on the open space near the French Bridge, Bombay, last night.
('20', 201, 7, 31, 494415) Mr. Mia Mahomed Haji Jan Mohomed Chhotani 4 presided.
('20', 201, 8, 32, 494469) 1 Self 2 Wife of Mahadev Desai 3 Gandhiji reached Sinhgadh on April 29. 4 A nationalist Muslim leader of Bombay 5 The report in The Times of India, 10 4 1920 adds that the proceedings were in vernacular.
('20', 202, 0, 1, 494673) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 203
('20', 202, 1, 2, 494713) Mr. M. K. Gandhi moved the following resolution: This meeting of the Hindus, Mohammedans and others, the inhabitants of Bombay, trusts that the Khilafat question will be solved consistent[ly] with the just demand of the Mohammedans of India and with the solemn pledges of His Majesty's Ministers and this meeting records its opinion that in the event of adverse decision being arrived at, it will be the duty of every Indian to withdraw co operation from the Government until the pledges are fulfilled and Muslim sentiment conciliated.
('20', 202, 2, 3, 495249) Mr. Gandhi said they had met there that night not exclusively in connec tion with the question of the Khilafat, but rather to look back on what had happened in India during the last twelve months.
('20', 202, 2, 4, 495446) The two events that stood out most prominent among others were the inauguration of swadeshi and the laying of the foundation of genuine Hindu Muslim unity.
('20', 202, 2, 5, 495602) The first was started in April and the latter became an accomplished fact when Hindu and Muslim blood mingled together in Jallianwala Bagh.
('20', 202, 2, 6, 495742) Since then, that unity had gone on increasing.
('20', 202, 2, 7, 495789) He appealed to the Hindus to sympathize with and support their Mohammedan brethren in the Khilafat question and thus cement that unity for good.
('20', 202, 2, 8, 495934) Muslim hearts were sore, as they had never before been sore, over the threatened dismemberment of the Turkish Empire and over the question of Khilafat.
('20', 202, 2, 9, 496086) If the Hindus failed to sympathize with the Mohammedans on the present occasion the great opportunity of cementing the unity would go, never perhaps to recur.
('20', 202, 3, 10, 496245) Proceeding, Mr. Gandhi said he had never blindly supported a cause and would never so support one.
('20', 202, 3, 11, 496344) He asked them to support the Mohammedans because he felt that the Muslim cause was just.
('20', 202, 3, 12, 496433) He had read the report of what happened at the interview 1 between the Prime Minister and the Khilafat Deputation, and he found there was no demand urged by the Deputation that was not just.
('20', 202, 3, 13, 496624) Now what they naturally expected in the Prime Minister of the British Empire was that he should adhere to the solemn promises he had made whilst the War was on, regarding the Turkish question.
('20', 202, 3, 14, 496817) What the Muslims of India wanted was that the status quo ante bellum should be maintained as far as possible regarding Turkey.
('20', 202, 3, 15, 496944) They desired, among other things, that Constantinople and Turkey in Europe should remain in Turkish hands, and that there should be Turkish suzerainty over the Jazirat ul Arab.
('20', 202, 3, 16, 497121) 2 As to those parts of Turkey which had a majority of non Muslim population, the European powers might ask for whatever guarantees they liked from Turkey for the protection of the non Muslim races provided those guarantees were not prejudicial to the position of the Sultan.
('20', 202, 3, 17, 497396) If the Arabs, who were Muslims, wanted self government they might have it but there should be the suzerainty of the Sultan over them.
('20', 202, 3, 18, 497530) When they in India asked
('20', 202, 4, 19, 497555) 1 On March 17, 1920 2 The holy places of Hedjaj.
('20', 202, 4, 20, 497604) The Government of India affirmed on March 29, 1920, that the holy places of Hedjaj would remain under independent Muslim control.

('20', 203, 1, 2, 497776) 21. TWO LETTERS
('20', 203, 2, 3, 497792) I have received two thought provoking letters.
('20', 203, 2, 4, 497839) One of them is by a well educated, pure minded sister.
('20', 203, 2, 5, 497894) The second is from an English friend, a prominent Christian gentlemen of England.
('20', 203, 2, 6, 497976) The sister writes 1:
('20', 203, 3, 7, 497997) These remarks are evidence of the purity of the sister’s heart.
('20', 203, 3, 8, 498061) She is perfectly right in saying that it is a great sin to disfigure or tear out the King’s picture.
('20', 203, 3, 9, 498162) If children learn such discourtesy and rudeness in their tender age, they will never grow fit to serve the people.
('20', 203, 3, 10, 498277) A little reflection will be enough to show that in insulting the Emperor we but insult ourselves and, trying to throw dust at the sun, we only throw it in our own eyes.
('20', 203, 3, 11, 498446) We may not like the British administration, but the Emperor is not responsible for it.
('20', 203, 3, 12, 498533) He does not even know what happens in his Empire.
('20', 203, 3, 13, 498583) It is not his duty, he does not have the means, to keep himself so informed.
('20', 203, 3, 14, 498660) How is he to blame, then?
('20', 203, 3, 15, 498686) Even if the blame is his, how will he be better by our tearing out his picture?
('20', 203, 3, 16, 498766) The important thing, however, is that unworthy thoughts should not make their appearance in children’s minds at all.
('20', 203, 3, 17, 498883) They should be innocent.
('20', 203, 3, 18, 498908) The mind should be innocent for the entire period of one’s student life.
('20', 203, 3, 19, 498981) Attachments and aversions should have no place in that period.
('20', 203, 3, 20, 499044) Even if, however, we cannot attain such a high state, we may certainly keep ourselves free from rudeness, discour tesy and thoughtlessness.
('20', 203, 3, 21, 499184) I don’t think Navajivan is read by many children.
('20', 203, 3, 22, 499234) I would therefore urge the parents to ask the children to read this article and see that they correct their wrong habit.
('20', 203, 3, 23, 499355) Teachers also can do this.
('20', 203, 3, 24, 499382) The second point in the letter of this sister is about the people’s bad habit of using foul words.
('20', 203, 3, 25, 499481) The habit is so widespread that I think it will be difficult to remedy it.
('20', 203, 3, 26, 499556) I have tried to do my bit to correct this bad habit, but I must admit that it was with the utmost difficulty that I could do so among my clients and others I am in contact with.
('20', 203, 3, 27, 499734) It is an almost incurable disease.
('20', 203, 3, 28, 499769) I remember what my clients often told me, that such words dropped out of their mouth without their meaning to use them.
('20', 203, 3, 29, 499889) However difficult the task, we must succeed in it.
('20', 203, 3, 30, 499940) It does not even require our arguing with people, nor is it a matter on which
('20', 203, 4, 31, 500018) 1 This letter, not reproduced here, complained about school children tearing out and disfiguring pictures of King Emperor George V in their books and about the widespread use of foul language among workers.
('20', 204, 0, 1, 500225) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 205
('20', 204, 1, 2, 500265) people have strong feelings.
('20', 204, 1, 3, 500294) It is only a matter of getting rid of a bad habit of long standing, so long indeed that the people cannot even see anything wrong in it.
('20', 204, 1, 4, 500431) Many of the readers of Navajivan will feel that this article cannot be for them; for they never use foul words.
('20', 204, 1, 5, 500543) If however, they pay attention to the language they employ, they will discover that even they use the word salo 1. We must constitute ourselves censors to keep watch over one another and, noting offensive words in the language, make a deliberate effort to get rid of them.
('20', 204, 1, 6, 500816) If every time we hear a person using some bad word we politely request him to refrain from doing so, some improvement can be brought about.

('20', 206, 3, 7, 504704) 24. SPEECH AT NATIONAL WEEK MEETING, BOMBAY
('20', 206, 4, 8, 504748) April 13, 1920
('20', 206, 5, 9, 504763) In connection with the National Week, a public meeting under the auspices of
('20', 206, 6, 10, 504840) the Bombay Branch of the Home Rule League, and the National Union, was held on
('20', 206, 7, 11, 504919) the open space near the French Bridge, Bombay, last night, Mr. M. A. Jinnah
('20', 206, 8, 12, 504995) presiding.
('20', 206, 9, 13, 505006) Mr. M. K. Gandhi moved the following resolution : 1
('20', 206, 10, 14, 505058) This meeting of the citizens of Bombay is of opinion that whilst mob excesses at Amritsar, although committed after grave provocation, were worthy of condemnation, the deliberate and calculated massacre without warning by General Dyer of innocent, unarmed and otherwise defenceless men at Jallianwala Bagh was an unexampled act of barbarity and hopes that the Government of India and the Imperial Government will take such steps as to render impossible a repetition of such barbarity and other similar barbarities committed by responsible officers in the Punjab during the period of the Martial Law administration and hopes that recommendations made by the Punjab Sub committee of the Indian National Congress will be carried out in their entirety.
('20', 206, 11, 15, 505807) Mr. Gandhi said they had heard Dr. Tagore’s message, and he could say that the acts of barbarity perpetrated by some officials in the Punjab could not have been condemned in more scathing terms than those used by the great poet.
('20', 206, 11, 16, 506036) He entirely agreed with the Chairman that the acts committed by General Dyer were unworthy of a soldier and were such as would befit only a coward.
('20', 206, 11, 17, 506184) Proceeding, Mr. Gandhi said they asked Government to adopt such measures as would render impossible a repetition of the barbarities committed in the Punjab, and to adopt in their entirety the recommendations made by the Sub committee of the Congress.
('20', 206, 11, 18, 506435) The main
('20', 206, 12, 19, 506444) 1 Before Gandhiji moved the resolution, C. F. Andrews read out a message from Rabindranath Tagore condemning the Jallianwala Bagh massacre.
('20', 207, 0, 1, 506584) 208 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('20', 207, 1, 2, 506626) recommendation with which they were concerned was that under no circumstances in future should Sir Michael O’Dwyer and General Dyer be given responsible positions either in India or in any other part of the British Empire.
('20', 207, 1, 3, 506849) It was their minimum demand that these officials should be displaced.
('20', 207, 1, 4, 506919) They admitted that some people in the Punjab committed bad deeds which deserved to be condemned but the deeds perpetrated by some Government officials were worse still.
('20', 207, 1, 5, 507088) They could never forget what happened at the Jallianwala Bagh.
('20', 207, 1, 6, 507151) They could never forget the memory of the innocent people who died there.
('20', 207, 1, 7, 507225) He was glad that the people of Bombay had contributed Rs. 3,25,000 to the memorial, though he must say he felt a little bit disappointed that it was not quite what he had expected from Bombay.
('20', 207, 1, 8, 507418) Continuing, Mr. Gandhi said they could not forget, till life lasted, the memory of the Jallianwala Bagh victims.
('20', 207, 1, 9, 507531) He entertained no thoughts of vengeance, because vengeance was the resort of the coward.
('20', 207, 1, 10, 507620) But they could never forget the memory of the dead.

('20', 211, 2, 3, 513745) THE ASHRAM, April 17 [1920] 2
('20', 211, 3, 4, 513775) MY DEAR FRIEND, Will you forgive me for not writing to you all these long days?
('20', 211, 3, 5, 513855) Not a day has passed but I have longed to write to you a love letter.
('20', 211, 3, 6, 513925) But the pressure of work has prevented me from so doing.
('20', 211, 3, 7, 513982) I pleaded with Sarladevi to write to you on my behalf but she said nothing but a letter in my own writing would do.
('20', 211, 3, 8, 514098) And so the weary days have gone on.
('20', 211, 3, 9, 514134) I hope however that you received my message through Rehana.
('20', 211, 3, 10, 514194) What a wonderful girl she is.
('20', 211, 3, 11, 514224) Indeed the Tagores and the Tayabjis are the rarities for India and they are her friends.
('20', 211, 3, 12, 514313) And it is my good fortune that I tumble upon them wherever I go.
('20', 211, 3, 13, 514378) But I am not going to be satisfied until I get the girlies and Mrs. Abbas to do some spinning for me.
('20', 211, 3, 14, 514480) You will blame me I know.
('20', 211, 3, 15, 514506) Well, you can easily remedy the evil by sending one of the girls here to learn the art.
('20', 211, 3, 16, 514594) If, however, that is impossible I must send you a teacher from here.
('20', 211, 3, 17, 514663) Please tell me what you will have me to do.
('20', 211, 3, 18, 514707) And now for your health.
('20', 211, 3, 19, 514732) Rehana told me that you still kept indifferent health.
('20', 211, 3, 20, 514787) You worry too much.
('20', 211, 3, 21, 514807) I should burrrr 3 away all worry and trust myself and the world to God.
('20', 211, 3, 22, 514879) We are less than ants in the scheme of the universe.
('20', 211, 3, 23, 514932) All therefore that is given to us to do is to try our best without attaching ourselves to results.
('20', 211, 3, 24, 515031) And this applies as much to indisposition of the body as of the Punjab.
('20', 211, 3, 25, 515103) In the one case you consult a doctor and sing; in the other you write a conscientious report and sing till you receive further orders.
('20', 211, 3, 26, 515238) And now love to you all.
('20', 211, 3, 27, 515263) A big post awaits me.
('20', 211, 3, 28, 515285) “Cheer boys, cheer; no more of idle sorrow” is a hymn I learnt as a schoolboy.
('20', 211, 3, 29, 515364) It abides with me today.
('20', 211, 3, 30, 515389) Yours sincerely,
('20', 211, 4, 31, 515406) M. K. GANDHI

('20', 212, 1, 2, 515920) 31. THE KHILAFAT
('20', 212, 2, 3, 515937) I commented last week on a letter from a learned sister.
('20', 212, 2, 4, 515994) I also referred in that article to a letter from an English friend.
('20', 212, 2, 5, 516062) He writes to this effect.”I am surprised that you take interest in the Khilafat issue.
('20', 212, 2, 6, 516149) I helped you on the South Africa question.
('20', 212, 2, 7, 516192) I believed you to be a well wisher of the British and to be a wise and honest man.
('20', 212, 2, 8, 516275) But now you want to unite the Hindus and the Muslims against the British, taking the side of Turkey.
('20', 212, 2, 9, 516376) I have lived in Armenia and know what oppression the [Turkish] Muslims have practised.
('20', 212, 2, 10, 516463) I doubt your bona fides but, before hearing from you that what I see in newspapers is correct, I shall form no conclusions against you.” The letter from the learned sister was prompted by love and so she did not doubt my bona fides.
('20', 212, 2, 11, 516696) In the letter from the English friend, despite the friendly tone, my bona fides is in doubt.
('20', 212, 2, 12, 516789) Both, of course, question whether my efforts will have happy results.
('20', 212, 2, 13, 516859) They are not the only ones to have this doubt.
('20', 212, 2, 14, 516906) Other friends have felt the same way.
('20', 212, 2, 15, 516944) I think it is impossible, when resisting injustice, wholly to prevent ill will against the wrongdoer.
('20', 212, 2, 16, 517046) There is no doubt either, that a man who cherishes hatred harms himself through it.
('20', 212, 2, 17, 517130) No one is perfect, of course, and, therefore, the man who cherishes hatred deserves our compassion, for he wishes the world to forgive him his errors but, refusing to forgive the world its errors, he has rendered himself unworthy of being forgiven.
('20', 212, 2, 18, 517379) However, having long been given to anger and hatred, we cannot keep away these enemies even if we wish.
('20', 212, 2, 19, 517483) What then should we do?
('20', 212, 2, 20, 517507) Should we refrain from opposing injustice, lest someone should oppose the wrongdoer?
('20', 212, 2, 21, 517592) This is what happens among relations and friends.
('20', 212, 2, 22, 517642) We want the mistakes of our relatives to be buried.
('20', 212, 2, 23, 517694) In my view, if hatred is harmful so is misplaced love.
('20', 212, 2, 24, 517749) There will be no harm done if mistakes by our relations are also exposed; there may be some good, on the contrary.
('20', 212, 2, 25, 517864) The first step towards undoing a wrong is to recognize it as such and feel ashamed of it.
('20', 212, 2, 26, 517954) It cannot be recognized fully if it is covered up and the person who has done the wrong abandons all shame, grows defiant and sinks ever deeper in the pit of error.
('20', 212, 2, 27, 518119) Just as, in the case of a boil on the body, there is nothing for it but to cut it open, so also there is no way but to bring a mistake to light.
('20', 212, 2, 28, 518264) Neither of the two letters above suggests that injustice may not be resisted.
('20', 212, 2, 29, 518342) It is with the method of resistance that they quarrel.
('20', 213, 0, 1, 518397) 214 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('20', 213, 1, 2, 518439) my method, resistance to injustice is taken to the length of parting company with the wrongdoer, be he one’s father, if he does not change.
('20', 213, 1, 3, 518579) If we do not, we become a party to the injustice.
('20', 213, 1, 4, 518629) It is my personal experience that even if resistance to injustice is taken to the point of leaving the wrongdoer, it does not detract a bit from one’s love for him.
('20', 213, 1, 5, 518794) Injustice is a great wrong.
('20', 213, 1, 6, 518822) It is a test of one’s love whether one can love a friend despite his error.
('20', 213, 1, 7, 518898) There is no great merit in returning good for good.
('20', 213, 1, 8, 518950) As we learn from Shamal Bhatt 1, the enlightened man is one who returns good for evil.
('20', 213, 1, 9, 519037) The Gita teaches us to look alike on friend and foe.
('20', 213, 1, 10, 519090) There is, thus, only one royal road before us.
('20', 213, 1, 11, 519137) We should think long and much before deciding that a particular act is unjust or wrong.
('20', 213, 1, 12, 519225) We should not be too ready to come to conclusions against any man who may appear to have acted unjustly.
('20', 213, 1, 13, 519330) But, judge the matter how carefully we will, if we find that a wrong has been done we should fight it to the end.
('20', 213, 1, 14, 519444) At the same time, if we discover that we were in error in believing that a wrong had been done, we should be ready to admit our error that very moment and apologize for it.
('20', 213, 1, 15, 519617) This method which I am demonstrating before India and in the cause of which I engage my friends, is a new experiment.
('20', 213, 1, 16, 519735) It may have shortcomings; I see some.
('20', 213, 1, 17, 519773) I never lay claim to perfection.
('20', 213, 1, 18, 519806) But it is my conviction that this is the only right path.
('20', 213, 1, 19, 519864) India can save herself along that path alone.
('20', 213, 1, 20, 519910) I am convinced that on the Khilafat issue the Muslims are in the right.
('20', 213, 1, 21, 519982) The moment I see their error I will stop helping them.
('20', 213, 1, 22, 520037) I do not say that they are free from hatred but I am sure that, joining my love with their hatred, I can diminish the intensity of that hatred.
('20', 213, 1, 23, 520181) I also believe that, if my method is followed by a large number, their hatred can be counteracted altogether.
('20', 213, 1, 24, 520291) Those who are full of hatred will in any case fight injustice, and exercise no restraint in doing so.
('20', 213, 1, 25, 520393) The man who is free from hatred has also no choice but to fight.
('20', 213, 1, 26, 520458) The wrongdoer, of course, is full of hatred.
('20', 213, 1, 27, 520503) His victim, when he acts, acts in hatred.
('20', 213, 1, 28, 520545) The only question is what the man without hatred should do.
('20', 213, 1, 29, 520605) The answer to this is not always easy to find.
('20', 213, 1, 30, 520652) A man grows through moral dilemmas.
('20', 213, 1, 31, 520688) One rises only by falling again and again.
('20', 213, 1, 32, 520731) Our duty is to remain alert, lest we make a mistake.
('20', 213, 1, 33, 520784) To do nothing because of such fear is cowardice.
('20', 213, 1, 34, 520833) Despite, therefore, the danger of our making mistakes, wherever we find injustice we should resist it
('20', 213, 2, 35, 520935) 1 A Gujarati poet of the eighteenth century

('20', 216, 4, 11, 524732) 35. SPEECH AT MEETING OF MILL HANDS, AHMEDABAD 2
('20', 216, 5, 12, 524781) April 18, 1920 This is the second anniversary of the peaceful triumph of justice.
('20', 216, 5, 13, 524863) 3 I call it a victory both for the mill owners and the mill hands.
('20', 216, 5, 14, 524930) I call this a victory of justice because the demand of the mill hands was just and the means adopted by them to secure acceptance were pure.
('20', 216, 5, 15, 525071) I should not wish victory for the mill hands by unjust means.

('20', 220, 1, 3, 534092) Development of the moral faculty means that of the religious sense.
('20', 220, 1, 4, 534160) The world does not quarrel with those who have a true faith in God and who understand the true nature of religion.
('20', 220, 1, 5, 534275) And if it does such men turn away the wrath of their adversaries by their gentleness.

('20', 220, 1, 7, 534441) But it means knowledge of one’s self and knowledge of God, and just as a person does not become a weaver unless he knows the art of weaving so does he fail to know himself unless he complies with certain rules.
('20', 220, 1, 8, 534652) Chief amongst these are three that are of universal observance.
('20', 220, 1, 9, 534716) The first is observance of truth.
('20', 220, 1, 10, 534750) He who does not know what it is to speak the truth is, like a false coin, valueless.
('20', 220, 1, 11, 534835) The second is not to injure others.
('20', 220, 1, 12, 534871) He who injures others, is jealous of others, is not fit to live in the world.
('20', 220, 1, 13, 534949) For the world is at war with him and he has to live in perpetual fear of the world.
('20', 220, 1, 14, 535033) We all are bound by the tie of love.
('20', 220, 1, 15, 535070) There is in everything a centripetal force without which nothing could have existed.
('20', 220, 1, 16, 535155) Scientists tell us that without the presence of the cohesive force amongst the atoms that comprise this globe of ours it would crumble to pieces and we would cease to exist, and even as there is cohesive force in blind matter so much must there be in all things animate and the name for that cohesive force among animate beings is Love.
('20', 220, 1, 17, 535492) We notice it between father and son, between brother and sister, friend and friend.
('20', 220, 1, 18, 535576) But we have to learn to use that force among all that lives, and in the use of it consists our knowledge of God.
('20', 220, 1, 19, 535689) Where there is love there is life; hatred leads to destruction.
('20', 220, 1, 20, 535753) I hope that Anasuyabehn will help you to learn this great law of love and I ask you, if you recognize her love towards you, to reciprocate it by feeling in your own persons that same love towards the whole of humanity.
('20', 220, 1, 21, 535972) The third rule is that we have to conquer our passions.
('20', 220, 1, 22, 536028) It is called brahmacharya in Sanskrit.
('20', 220, 1, 23, 536067) I do not use it here merely in its accepted narrow sense.
('20', 220, 1, 24, 536125) He is not a brahmachari, who, although he may be a celebate or may be living a chaste life as a married man, otherwise gives himself up to a variety of indulgences.
('20', 220, 1, 25, 536290) He alone is capable of knowing himself who brings under complete subjection all his passions.
('20', 220, 1, 26, 536384) He who exercises self restraint in its widest sense is also a brahmachari—a man of faith, a true Hindu or a true Mohammedan.
('20', 220, 2, 27, 536509) It is a breach of brahmacharya to hear questionable language or obscene songs.
('20', 220, 2, 28, 536588) It is licentiousness of the tongue to utter foul abuse instead of reciting the name of God, and so with the other senses.
('20', 220, 2, 29, 536710) He alone can be considered the true man who having subjected his

('20', 221, 1, 2, 536817) passions becomes perfectly self restrained.
('20', 221, 1, 3, 536861) We are like a rider who cannot keep his horse under control and is quickly brought down.
('20', 221, 1, 4, 536950) But one who drawing in the reins keeps the animal under subjection stands a fair chance of reaching his destination.
('20', 221, 1, 5, 537067) Even so does a man who can control his passions make for the goal.

('20', 221, 1, 15, 538122) But if that be not the object to be achieved, it would be a sin to attempt and get better wages and reduce the hours of labour.
('20', 221, 1, 16, 538250) May God grant you Anasuyabai the power to achieve the end.

('20', 225, 0, 1, 543748) 226 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('20', 225, 1, 2, 543790) 41. NOTES 1
('20', 225, 2, 3, 543802) COMMUNAL REPRESENTATION
('20', 225, 3, 4, 543826) We have absurdities enough in India in communal represen tation being demanded by other small groups because the principle has been conceded in the case of Mohammedans.
('20', 225, 3, 5, 543995) 2 But when the cry for communal representation comes from Indians in Burma, the absurdity becomes criminal.
('20', 225, 3, 6, 544103) We understand some Indians of Ran goon have pleaded for communal representation in the Burmese Council to be formed under the Reforms.
('20', 225, 3, 7, 544238) We do hope that the demand will be withdrawn before mischief is done.
('20', 225, 3, 8, 544308) The Burman will have every right to resent any such separate treatment of Indian settlers there.
('20', 225, 3, 9, 544405) We are in Burma as guests of the Burmese for their and our mutual good, not for the exploitation of the former.
('20', 225, 3, 10, 544517) Their welfare should be our first consideration.
('20', 225, 3, 11, 544566) As a friend correctly points out, the Indian demand would be like Gujaratis or Marwaris claiming communal repre sentation for themselves in the Bengal Council.
('20', 225, 3, 12, 544726) Surely, Indians of Burma would have a right to enter the Burmese Council, only if they by force of ability and service can command the Burmese vote.
('20', 225, 3, 13, 544875) We, who desire that nobody should set up claims in India which are against our interests, are bound to guard against desiring rights in Burma in conflict with the interests of the Burmans.
('20', 225, 3, 14, 545064) And yet that is precisely what lies at the bottom of this demand for communal representation by Indian settlers.
('20', 225, 3, 15, 545177) We, therefore, trust that wiser counsels will prevail and that we shall hear no more of communal representation for Indians in Burma.
('20', 225, 4, 16, 545311) MR. HORNIMAN’S DEPORTATION
('20', 225, 5, 17, 545338) 26th April will be the anniversary of Mr. Horniman’s deportation.

('20', 226, 3, 20, 547720) 42. SWADESHI
('20', 226, 4, 21, 547733) The National Week closed on Tuesday the 13th.
('20', 226, 4, 22, 547779) It was in every way a remarkable demonstration of Hindu Muslim unity, the determination to secure repeal of the Rowlatt Act and the satyagraha spirit.
('20', 226, 4, 23, 547930) The speeches delivered were sober and more to the point than before.
('20', 226, 4, 24, 547999) There was no disorderliness at any of the meetings of which we have received reports.
('20', 226, 4, 25, 548085) What however about swadeshi?
('20', 226, 4, 26, 548114) Was swadeshi too not a product
('20', 227, 0, 1, 548145) 228 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('20', 227, 1, 2, 548187) of the satyagraha spirit and activity?
('20', 227, 1, 3, 548226) It undoubtedly was.
('20', 227, 1, 4, 548246) But swadeshi work is the most constructive of all.
('20', 227, 1, 5, 548297) It does not lend itself to speeches so much as to solid action.
('20', 227, 1, 6, 548361) It is not possible to save fifty crores of rupees annually by speeches or demonstrations.
('20', 227, 1, 7, 548451) It involves much more than the severing of this annual drain.
('20', 227, 1, 8, 548513) It involves the honour of Indian womanhood.
('20', 227, 1, 9, 548557) Everyone who has any connection with the mill industry knows that the women working in the mills are exposed to temptations and risks to which they ought not to be exposed.
('20', 227, 1, 10, 548730) Many women for want of home employment accept road repair labour.
('20', 227, 1, 11, 548796) And only those who know what this labour is, understand the risks the women run.
('20', 227, 1, 12, 548877) Give them the spinning wheel and no woman need ever seek any other employment than sitting at the spinning wheel.
('20', 227, 1, 13, 548991) Swadeshi means even distribution of wealth from an occupation next in importance only to agriculture.
('20', 227, 1, 14, 549093) It supplements agriculture and therefore automatically assists materially to solve the problem of our growing poverty.
('20', 227, 1, 15, 549212) Thus swadeshi is our veritable Kamadhenu 1 supply ing all our wants and solving many of our difficult problems.
('20', 227, 1, 16, 549324) And an occupation which saves our honour and provides our livelihood becomes a religious duty.
('20', 227, 2, 17, 549419) How can the great consummation be achieved?
('20', 227, 2, 18, 549463) The answer is simple.
('20', 227, 2, 19, 549485) Those who realize the importance of the problem must set about working in one or all of the following directions :
('20', 227, 3, 20, 549600) 1. Learn spinning yourself whether man or woman.
('20', 227, 3, 21, 549649) Charge for the labour if you need money, or make a gift of at least one hour’s labour to the nation daily.
('20', 227, 3, 22, 549756) 2. Learn weaving yourself whether for recreation or for maintenance.
('20', 227, 3, 23, 549825) 3. Make improvements in the present handlooms and the spinning wheels, and if you are rich, pay for them to those who would make them.
('20', 227, 3, 24, 549960) 4. Take the swadeshi vow and patronize the cloth that is both hand spun and hand woven.
('20', 227, 4, 25, 550048) 5. Introduce such cloth among your friends and believe that there is more art and humanity in khadi whose yarn has been prepared by your poor sisters.
('20', 227, 4, 26, 550199) 6. If you are a mother, you will give a clean and national culture to your children and make them wear clothes made out of
('20', 227, 5, 27, 550322) 1 A mythical cow that gave whatever one asked of her
('20', 228, 0, 1, 550375) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 229
('20', 228, 1, 2, 550415) beautiful khadi which is available to millions and which can be most easily produced.
('20', 228, 1, 3, 550501) Swadeshi then means the creation of a most perfect organization in which every part work in perfect harmony with every other.
('20', 228, 1, 4, 550627) If we succeed in bringing into being such an organization, not only is success of swadeshi assured, but real swaraj comes to us as a matter of course.
('20', 228, 2, 5, 550778) Young India, 21 4 1920

('20', 228, 4, 7, 550820) The prejudice against Indian settlers outside India is showing itself in a variety of ways.
('20', 228, 4, 8, 550912) Under the impudent suggestion of sedition the Fiji Government has deported Mr. Manilal Doctor 1 who with his brave and cultured wife 2 has been rendering assistance to the poor indentured Indians of Fiji in a variety of ways.
('20', 228, 4, 9, 551138) The whole trouble has arisen over the strike of the labourers in Fiji.
('20', 228, 4, 10, 551209) Indentures have been cancelled, 3 but the spirit of slavery is by no means dead.
('20', 228, 4, 11, 551290) We do not know genesis of the strike; we do not know that the strikers have done no wrong.
('20', 228, 4, 12, 551381) But we do know what is behind when a charge of sedition is brought against the strikers and their friends.
('20', 228, 4, 13, 551488) The readers must remember that the Government that has scented sedition in the recent upheaval in Fiji is the Government that had the hardihood to libel Mr. Andrews’ character.
('20', 228, 4, 14, 551665) What can be the meaning of sedition in connec tion with the Fiji strikers and Mr. Manilal Doctor?
('20', 228, 4, 15, 551763) Did they and he want to seize the reins of government?
('20', 228, 4, 16, 551818) Did they want any power in that country?
('20', 228, 4, 17, 551859) They struck for elementary freedom.
('20', 228, 4, 18, 551895) And it is a prosti tution of terms to use the word sedition in such connection.
('20', 228, 4, 19, 551975) The strikers may have been over hasty.
('20', 228, 4, 20, 552014) Mr. Manilal Doctor may have misled them.
('20', 228, 4, 21, 552055) If his advice bordered on the criminal, he should have been tried.
('20', 228, 4, 22, 552122) The information in our possession goes to show that he has been strictly constitutional.
('20', 228, 4, 23, 552211) Our point, however, is that it is an abuse of power for the Fiji Government to have deported Mr. Manilal Doctor without a trial.
('20', 228, 4, 24, 552340) It is wrong in principle to deprive a person of

('20', 229, 3, 27, 554544) 44. THE CAUSE OF THE VERNACULARS
('20', 229, 4, 28, 554577) To anyone who watched the proceedings of the recent Sahitya
('20', 229, 5, 29, 554637) 1 The Commission of Enquiry which sat from March 1920 to July 1920. It was appointed by the Union Government of South Africa to enquire into the question of Asiatics trading and holding land in several provinces of South Africa.
('20', 230, 0, 1, 554866) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 231
('20', 230, 1, 2, 554906) Sammelans 1 it must be clear that our national awakening is not con fined to politics alone.
('20', 230, 1, 3, 554999) The enthusiasm displayed at these gatherings indicated a happy change.
('20', 230, 1, 4, 555070) We are giving in thought their proper place to the vernaculars in our national life.
('20', 230, 1, 5, 555155) Raja Ram Mohan Ray’s 2
('20', 230, 2, 6, 555178) prophecy that India will one day be an English speaking country, has not today many stars in its favour.
('20', 230, 2, 7, 555283) The great reformer’s spirit, how ever, still haunts some.
('20', 230, 2, 8, 555341) A number of our eminent men hastily generalize in favour of English as the national medium.
('20', 230, 2, 9, 555433) The present status of English as a court language weighs with them unduly.
('20', 230, 2, 10, 555508) They fail to see that the present status of English is no credit to us and that it is not conducive to the growth of a true democratic spirit.
('20', 230, 2, 11, 555651) That crores of men should learn a foreign tongue for the convenience of a few hundreds of officials is the height of absurdity.
('20', 230, 2, 12, 555779) An instance is often cited from our past history to prove the necessity of a lingua franca to strengthen the Central Government of the country.
('20', 230, 2, 13, 555923) Nobody disputes the necessity of a common medium.
('20', 230, 2, 14, 555973) But it cannot be English.
('20', 230, 2, 15, 555999) The officials have to recognize the vernaculars.
('20', 230, 2, 16, 556048) The second consideration that appeals to the Anglicists is India’s position in the Empire.
('20', 230, 2, 17, 556139) The argument, put in plain words, amounts to asking 31crores of Indians to accept English as their common language for the sake of the other parts of the Empire whose population is not more than 12 crores.
('20', 230, 3, 18, 556345) The first fact that ought to receive consideration from every student of this problem is that after a century and a half of British rule English has failed to take the place of a lingua franca of India.
('20', 230, 3, 19, 556548) A kind of broken English, no doubt, does seem to have succeeded in this respect in our cities.
('20', 230, 3, 20, 556643) But this fact can only dazzle those who profess to study our national problems in big cities like Bombay and Calcutta.
('20', 230, 3, 21, 556762) And what is their population after all?
('20', 230, 3, 22, 556802) It is only 2.2 per cent of the total population of India.
('20', 230, 3, 23, 556860) The second fact that the Anglicists ignore is that a very large majority of our vernaculars are akin to one another, and as a result of this, Hindi as a lingua franca suits all the provinces except the Madras Presidency.
('20', 230, 3, 24, 557081) In view of this advantage in favour of Hindi and in view of our present national consciousness how can we accept English as our lingua franca?
('20', 230, 4, 25, 557224) The solution of this problem will decide the fate of the vernacu lars.
('20', 230, 4, 26, 557295) In our educational system English is suffered to have an unna 
('20', 230, 5, 27, 557358) 1 Literary conferences 2 Raja Ram Mohan Roy (1772 1833); socio religious reformer of Bengal; the pioner of English education in India
('20', 231, 0, 1, 557492) 232 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('20', 231, 1, 2, 557534) tural dominance over vernaculars.
('20', 231, 1, 3, 557568) The extreme Anglicists hold that English should be used as the medium of instruction”at the earliest age possible”.
('20', 231, 1, 4, 557684) This argument is based on the fact that children in a foreign country pick up the language of the country without diffi culty at an early age.
('20', 231, 1, 5, 557827) Refuting this argument the Calcutta University Commission say :
('20', 231, 2, 6, 557891) Whereas in a foreign country a child is surrounded by others who speak the language of the country, in a class room he is sorrounded by others who, with the exception of the teacher, are as ignorant as himself of the new medium; it is a class of one person teaching many, not of many teaching one; and it is only by experiment that class room methods can be worked out successfully.
('20', 231, 2, 7, 558274) The”educational economy”, as an advantage of vernaculari zing our educational system, has received recognition at the hands of the Commission.
('20', 231, 2, 8, 558417) We have pointed out, in our issue of February 11, that the recommendations of the Calcutta University Commission in this connection are a further step.
('20', 231, 2, 9, 558569) The next logical step after this is recommending the use of vernaculars as the medium in our univer sities also.
('20', 231, 2, 10, 558682) The Sadler Commission have made the matriculation stage as a halting place between the use of vernaculars as the medium of instruction in secondary schools and their use in the college depart ment.
('20', 231, 2, 11, 558880) They have suggested as their own opinion a bilingual system for the future.
('20', 231, 2, 12, 558956) But they also say :
('20', 231, 3, 13, 558976) We do not wish to prejudge the future.
('20', 231, 3, 14, 559015) It is not for us to predict whether the natural desire to use Bengali to the utmost will eventually outweigh the immense advantages of being able to use a medium common not only to the educated classes throughout India, but to more peoples than any other, and giving access in effect to the literature and the scientific records of the world.
('20', 231, 3, 15, 559358) Though in view of the evidence submitted to them the Commissioners could not be persuaded to lay down a policy for the future in favour of vernacularizing university education also, it is equally true that they could not find anything in the evidence which supported the Anglicists or the bilinguists.
('20', 231, 3, 16, 559660) Thus, though the replies to the Commissioners’ questions do not in themselves decide the future, they do
('20', 231, 4, 17, 559765) reveal a strong movement in favour of the immediate introduction of Bengali fo
('20', 231, 5, 18, 559844) r some University purposes, and of its ultimate introduction for others, a movement of which there was little sign in the debate in the Imperial Legislative Council of 1915. If we study the Commissioners’ analysis of the replies, we can
('20', 232, 0, 1, 560081) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 233
('20', 232, 1, 2, 560121) more fully appreciate their remark.
('20', 232, 1, 3, 560157) The question put to the witnesses was :”Do you hold English should be used as the medium of instruction and examination at every stage above matriculation in the university course?’
('20', 232, 2, 4, 560339) The replies are analysed as follows :
('20', 232, 3, 5, 560377) (i) 129 are positively in the affirmative; (ii) 29 are in the affirmative, with slight reservations; (iii) 68 are in favour of a joint use of English and the vernacular either side by side in the same institution, or in parallel institutions; (iv) 33 replies suggest the gradual replacement of English by the vernacular as the object to be aimed at; (v) 37 are in the negative; and
('20', 232, 4, 6, 560759) (vi) 9 are insusceptible of classification.
('20', 232, 5, 7, 560803) So, 155 replies are in favour of the English medium and nearly 138 are not against using the vernacular medium sooner or later.
('20', 232, 5, 8, 560931) This propor tion is certainly encouraging to the vernacularists.
('20', 232, 5, 9, 560996) Besides, even among those that favour the English medium there is not an inconsiderable section of witnesses who advise the foreign medium, because there is no provision for proper and sufficient text books for different subjects.
('20', 232, 5, 10, 561227) This school of educationists is not against the vernacular medium on principle.
('20', 232, 5, 11, 561307) They do not like us to get into water till we have learnt swimming.
('20', 232, 5, 12, 561375) Of a similar sort but more decisive is the evidence of the remaining witnesses that stand for the English medium.
('20', 232, 5, 13, 561489) This latter evidence has stamped the vernaculars as unfit ever to serve the purpose of the medium of instruction.
('20', 232, 5, 14, 561603) These witnesses betray an ignorance of the history of our vernaculars.
('20', 232, 5, 15, 561674) There was a time when Sanskrit was the sole medium for Hindu philosophy.
('20', 232, 5, 16, 561747) But a few enthusiastic scholars enriched their vernaculars with a decent store of philosophic literature and brought Hindu philosophy within the reach of the masses.
('20', 232, 5, 17, 561913) Can we not with our present ideas of organization do for our vernaculars in the sphere of science what once those vernacular scholars did in the sphere of philosophy?
('20', 232, 5, 18, 562080) As against the diffidence of these witnesses, the vernacularists can cite the example of Japan.

('20', 232, 5, 20, 562185) W. E. S. Holland, Principal of St. Paul’s Cathedral College, Calcutta, in his evidence, writes :
('20', 232, 6, 21, 562282) Japan by use of the vernacular, has built up an educational system that commands the respect of the West.
('20', 233, 0, 1, 562388) 234 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('20', 233, 1, 2, 562430) The evidence of Babu Ramananda Chatterjee, the editor of the Modern Review, is even more convincing.
('20', 233, 1, 3, 562531) He says :
('20', 233, 2, 4, 562541) The use of the vernaculars in all grades of university education is indispen sably necessary.
('20', 233, 2, 5, 562635) All objections have force only temporarily, for the most highly developed modern languages and literatures were at first no better than Bengali.
('20', 233, 2, 6, 562780) In their case development was obtained by use; and it will be obtained in our case, too, in the same way.
('20', 233, 2, 7, 562886) Thus we find that though the evidence before Dr. Sadler’s Commis sion is not today in favour of vernacularizing university education, it does hold high hopes for the future of the cause of the vernacular medium.
('20', 233, 2, 8, 563098) Time was when the vernacularists’ cause was looked upon with distrust.
('20', 233, 2, 9, 563169) There is now not only no distrust but confidence has taken its place.

('20', 233, 2, 12, 563419) Their progress is being keenly watched by many.
('20', 233, 2, 13, 563467) Their success will, as Jus tice Sir Abdul Rahim says, make the solution of the problem of the vernaculars easier.
('20', 233, 2, 14, 563581) At the last convocation of the Hindu University, the Hon.

('20', 233, 2, 17, 563843) The present distribution of provinces is another factor which has done no less an injury than any other to the cause of the vernaculars.
('20', 233, 2, 18, 563980) The redistribution of provinces on a linguistic basis will be followed by a rearrangement of universities.
('20', 233, 2, 19, 564087) We have shown above the three allied spheres of work for the cause of vernaculars.
('20', 233, 2, 20, 564170) And it is evident that unless we advance this cause, we shall not be able to remove the growing intellectual and cul tural gulf between our men and women and between the classes and the masses.
('20', 233, 2, 21, 564364) It is also equally certain that the vernacular medium alone can stimulate originality in thought in the largest number of persons.

('20', 234, 4, 6, 564883) 46. LETTER TO J. L. MAFFEY SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, April 24, 1920 DEAR MR. MAFFEY, I thank you for your prompt telegram in reply to mine 3 about the proposed Khilafat mission.
('20', 234, 4, 7, 565065) Although I cannot possibly grumble at the reply, I feel the responsibility so much that I had not the heart to proceed with the mission without the fullest approval of the Viceroy.
('20', 234, 4, 8, 565246) What I mean is that no matter how strong and stubborn may be my opposition to Government actions or measures, I am anxious to have my conduct regarded as above suspicion and as that of a friend.
('20', 234, 4, 9, 565441) I have no desire to go to England, for I feel that I can work most effectively in India rather than in England.
('20', 234, 4, 10, 565553) But I have a vague feeling that I owe it to the Imperial Government and to the British public to tell them what a broken pledge on the Khilafat question is likely to mean.
('20', 234, 4, 11, 565725) But I cannot do it without the assistance of the authorities.
('20', 234, 4, 12, 565787) I was therefore disinclined to go unless the Mahomedan friends wanted me to, in spite of my failure to get an unequivocal approval of my mission from the Viceroy.
('20', 234, 4, 13, 565950) I have now sent the enclosed cablegram 4 to Mr. Montagu and await his reply.
('20', 234, 4, 14, 566027) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI From a microfilm: Lord Chelmsford Papers.

('20', 235, 1, 2, 566434) 47. USES OF KHADI
('20', 235, 2, 3, 566452) The movement for swadeshi is slowly gathering momentum, though it is not progressing well enough to satisfy me.The Satyagraha Week saw a good awakening among the people and the swadeshi movement has also gained correspondingly.
('20', 235, 2, 4, 566680) Muslims have now started taking greater interest in it.
('20', 235, 2, 5, 566736) There is a new spirit among them.
('20', 235, 2, 6, 566770) For them swadeshi means boycott.
('20', 235, 2, 7, 566803) I have stated my view that boycott will not serve our purpose; even then, to the extent that boycott implies swadeshi, it is bound to produce some good.

('20', 243, 1, 2, 585539) 51. TO READERS
('20', 243, 2, 3, 585554) Only recently we changed the size of Navajivan and revised the price of a copy in Bombay and Ahmedabad.

('20', 243, 2, 14, 586567) For those who are managing the paper, this experiment of running a journal without advertisements is quite new.

('20', 244, 2, 3, 587966) HOME RULE LEAGUE
('20', 244, 3, 4, 587983) It is a distinct departure from the even tenor of my life for me to belong to an organization that is purely and frankly political.
('20', 244, 3, 5, 588115) But after careful deliberation and consultation with friends I have joined the All India Home Rule League and accepted the office of its President.
('20', 244, 3, 6, 588263) 1 Some friends whom I consulted told me that I should not join any political organization and that if I did, I would lose the position of splendid isolation I enjoy at present.
('20', 244, 3, 7, 588440) I confess that this caution had considerable weight with me.
('20', 244, 3, 8, 588501) At the same time I felt that if I was accepted by the League as I was, I should be wrong in not identifying myself with an organization that I could utilize for the advancement of the causes in which I had specialized and of the methods which experience has shown me are attended with quicker and better results than those that are usually adopted.
('20', 244, 3, 9, 588850) Before joining the League, I endeavoured to ascertain the opinion of those who were outside the Presidency and with whom I had not the privilege to come in such close contact as with co workers in the Bombay Presidency.
('20', 244, 4, 10, 589070) The causes referred to by me are swadeshi, Hindu Moslem unity with special reference to Khilafat, the acceptance of Hindustani as the lingua franca and a linguistic redistribution of the Provinces.
('20', 244, 4, 11, 589268) I would engage the League, if I can carry the members with me, in these activities so that they occupy the largest part of the nation’s time and attention.
('20', 244, 5, 12, 589424) I freely confess that reforms take a secondary place in my scheme of national reorganization.
('20', 244, 5, 13, 589518) For I feel that the activities chosen by me, if they could but absorb national energy, would bring about all the reforms that the most ardent extremists can ever desire, and so far as the desirability of full self government at the earliest possible moment is concerned I yield to none in my desire to hasten our progress.
('20', 244, 5, 14, 589841) And it is because I feel that the progress towards self government can be best accelerated by developing the activities I have mentioned that I keep them in the forefront of the national programme.
('20', 244, 5, 15, 590039) I shall not treat the All India Home Rule League as a party organization in any sense of the term.
('20', 244, 5, 16, 590138) I belong to no party and I
('20', 244, 6, 17, 590165) 1 This was on April 28, 1920.

('20', 245, 1, 2, 590237) wish to belong to none hereafter.
('20', 245, 1, 3, 590271) I am aware that the constitution of the League requires it to help the Congress, 1 but I do not consider the Congress as a party organization, even as the British Parliament, though it contains all parties and has one party or other dominating it from time to time, is not a party organization.
('20', 245, 1, 4, 590566) I shall venture to hope that all parties will cherish the Congress as a national organization providing a platform for all parties to appeal to the nation with a view to moulding its policy and I would endeavour to so mould the policy of the League as to make the Congress retain its non party national character.
('20', 245, 2, 5, 590880) This brings me to methods.
('20', 245, 2, 6, 590907) I believe that it is possible to introduce uncompromising truth and honesty in the political life of the country.

('20', 247, 1, 5, 595611) On the Khilafat question I refuse to be a party to a broken pledge.

('20', 248, 3, 5, 598405) 54. NON CO OPERATION
('20', 248, 4, 6, 598426) A writer in The Times of India, the editor of that wonderful daily and Mrs. Besant have all in their own manner condemned non co operation conceived in connection with the Khilafat movement.
('20', 248, 4, 7, 598617) All the three writings naturally discuss many side issues which I shall omit for the time being.
('20', 248, 4, 8, 598714) I propose to answer two serious objections raised by the writers.
('20', 248, 4, 9, 598780) The sobriety with which they are stated entitles them to a greater consideration than if they had been given in violent language.
('20', 248, 4, 10, 598910) In non co operation, the writers think, it would be difficult if not impossible to avoid violence.
('20', 248, 4, 11, 599009) Indeed violence, The Times of India editorial says, has already commenced in that ostracism has been resorted to in Calcutta And Delhi.
('20', 248, 4, 12, 599145) Now I fear that ostracism to a certain extent is impossible to avoid.
('20', 248, 4, 13, 599215) I remember in South Africa in the initial stages of the passive resistance campaign those who had fallen away were ostracized.
('20', 248, 4, 14, 599342) Ostracism is violent or peaceful according to the manner in which it is practised.
('20', 248, 4, 15, 599425) A congregation may well refuse to recite prayers after a priest who prizes his title above his honour.
('20', 248, 4, 16, 599528) But the ostracism will become violent if the individual life of a person is made unbearable by insults, innuendoes or abuse.
('20', 248, 4, 17, 599653) The real danger of violence lies in the people resorting to non co operation becoming impatient and revengeful.
('20', 248, 4, 18, 599765) This may happen, if, for instance, payment of taxes is suddenly withdrawn or if pressure is put upon soldiers to lay down their arms.
('20', 248, 4, 19, 599899) I however do not fear any evil consequences, for the simple reason that every responsible Mohammedan understands that non co operation to be successful must be totally unattended with violence.
('20', 248, 4, 20, 600093) The other objection raised is that those who may give up their service may have to starve.
('20', 248, 4, 21, 600184) That is just a possibility but a remote one, for the committee will certainly make due provision for those who may suddenly find themselves out of employment.
('20', 248, 4, 22, 600343) I propose however to examine the whole of the difficult question much more
('20', 249, 0, 1, 600418) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 250
('20', 249, 1, 2, 600460) fully in a future issue and hope to show that if Indian Mohammedan feeling is to be respected, there is nothing left but non co operation if the decision arrived at is adverse.
('20', 249, 2, 3, 600637) Young India, 28 4 1920
('20', 249, 3, 4, 600660) 55. THE USES OF KHADDAR
('20', 249, 4, 5, 600684) While the swadeshi movement is going forward by leaps and bounds and Mohammedans are taking it up as enthusiastically as Hindus, it is well to consider the best method of promoting swadeshi.
('20', 249, 4, 6, 600875) The veriest tyro in swadeshi knows that we do not manufacture enough cloth to supply our wants.
('20', 249, 4, 7, 600971) If therefore we merely use mill made cloth, we simply deprive the poor of what they need, or at least increase the price of mill made cloth.
('20', 249, 4, 8, 601112) The only way therefore to encourage swadeshi is to manufacture more cloth.
('20', 249, 4, 9, 601187) Mills cannot grow like mushrooms.
('20', 249, 4, 10, 601221) We must, therefore, fall back upon hand woven and hand spun yarn.
('20', 249, 4, 11, 601287) Yarn has never perhaps been so dear as it is today and mills are making fabulous profits out of yarn.
('20', 249, 4, 12, 601389) He, therefore, who hand spins a yard of yarn, helps its production and cheapens its price.
('20', 249, 4, 13, 601480) How to spin yarn and weave cloth is then the question.
('20', 249, 4, 14, 601535) I know from personal experience that it is possible to flood the market with hand spun yarn and hand woven cloth if the standard cloth comes to be recognized as fit for wear.
('20', 249, 4, 15, 601710) This cloth is called khaddar in Upper India.
('20', 249, 4, 16, 601755) It is called khadi in the Bombay Presidency.
('20', 249, 4, 17, 601800) Thanks to Sarladevi 1, she has shown that it is possible to make even saris out of khaddar.
('20', 249, 4, 18, 601892) She thought that she could best express herself during the National Week by wearing khaddar sari and khaddar blouse.
('20', 249, 4, 19, 602009) And she did it.
('20', 249, 4, 20, 602025) She attended parties in her khaddar sari.
('20', 249, 4, 21, 602067) Friends thought it was impossible.
('20', 249, 4, 22, 602102) They thought a woman who had never worn anything but the finest silk or the finest Dacca muslin could not possibly bear the weight of heavy khaddar.
('20', 249, 4, 23, 602251) She falsified all fears and was no less active or less elegant in her khaddar sari than in her finished silk saris.”If you do not feel awkward in that sari of yours, you may go anywhere and to any party and you will find it would be well with you.” It was with some such words that her great uncle, Sir Rabindranath Tagore, blessed her when he saw her in her khaddar sari.
('20', 249, 4, 24, 602624) I relate this sacred incident in order to show that two of the most artistic people of India found nothing inartistic in khaddar.
('20', 249, 4, 25, 602754) This is the cloth I venture to
('20', 249, 5, 26, 602785) 1 Sarladevi Chowdhrani
('20', 250, 0, 1, 602808) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 251
('20', 250, 1, 2, 602848) introduce to the cultured families of India, for on its use hangs the immediate success of the swadeshi movement during its infant stage.
('20', 250, 1, 3, 602986) To me khaddar is any day more artistic than the finest Dacca muslin, for its association.
('20', 250, 1, 4, 603076) Khaddar supports today those who were starving.
('20', 250, 1, 5, 603124) It supports women who have been reclaimed from a life of shame or women who, because they would not go out for work, remained idle and quarrelled among themselves for want of occupation.
('20', 250, 1, 6, 603311) Khaddar therefore has a soul about it.
('20', 250, 1, 7, 603350) It has an individuality about it.
('20', 250, 1, 8, 603384) The wearer is able to trace all the processes of its manufacture to the respective manufacturers.
('20', 250, 1, 9, 603482) If our tastes were not debased, we would prefer khaddar to sticky calico even during the summer season.
('20', 250, 1, 10, 603586) Let those who are now using it certify, if they will, to the truth of my statement.
('20', 250, 1, 11, 603670) This khaddar is now being stocked at the Satyagraha Ashram.
('20', 250, 1, 12, 603730) And I have accumulated a stock which is beyond the capacity of the space at my disposal.
('20', 250, 1, 13, 603819) I therefore ask the readers of Young India to come to the rescue by introducing khaddar in their own homes.
('20', 250, 1, 14, 603927) Needless to say that the Ashram makes no profits from it.
('20', 250, 1, 15, 603985) Any margin left is devoted to recouping the loss incurred in the initial stages or in reducing the price of khaddar received from districts where the cost is heavier than elsewhere, for the cost is not the same all over.
('20', 250, 1, 16, 604206) In inducing weavers to take to their original occupation, I am obliged to pay enough to support them and for the present.
('20', 250, 1, 17, 604328) Khaddar can be used for making underwear, even if one is disinclined to use it for the outer costume.
('20', 250, 1, 18, 604430) But even if one is not inclined to use it for personal wear, it can be used for making caps, towels, wipers, tea cloths, satchels, bed sheets, bedding, holdalls, carpet pieces, cushions, covers for furniture etc.
('20', 250, 1, 19, 604643) I am having it dyed Turkey red in swadeshi dye.
('20', 250, 1, 20, 604691) It then becomes more durable and looks less dirty when it is used for carpets or mattress making or upholstering.
('20', 250, 1, 21, 604805) I would advise those who wish to support this industry of the poor and the neglected to send for the khaddar by corresponding with the Manager, Khaddar Department, Satyagraha Ashram, Sabarmati.

('20', 252, 1, 2, 606589) 57. PRESS STATEMENT ON THE TURKISH TREATY 1
('20', 252, 2, 3, 606633) The cablegram regarding the decision of the Conference 2 at San Remo, is most disquieting.
('20', 252, 2, 4, 606724) The decision is bound to greatly disturb the Mohammedan mind.
('20', 252, 2, 5, 606786) I hope, however, that the Mohammedan leaders will neither be disheartened nor give way to anger.
('20', 252, 2, 6, 606883) The issues involved are tremendous.
('20', 252, 2, 7, 606919) The greatest self restraint is, therefore, absolutely necessary.
('20', 252, 2, 8, 606984) Non co operation is, I remain convinced, the only remedy enabling India to give disciplined expression to the deep wound that is being made into her very heart.
('20', 252, 2, 9, 607145) The way to be trodden is, I know, weary and full of thorns, but I am certain that it is possible to wrench justice from an alliance that prides itself on its brute force.
('20', 252, 2, 10, 607316) I know that the temptation to answer violence with violence is almost irresistible, yet I feel certain that the slightest violence done by us will not only return to us with mad fury, but will dash to pieces the present hope of Islam, whereas the completely peaceful withdrawal of co operation must inevitably result in a revision of any arrangement that the Powers might make regarding Turkey.
('20', 252, 2, 11, 607711) And that can be demonstrated to be unjust and a breach of the solemn promises made by His Majesty’s Ministers.
('20', 252, 2, 12, 607822) To those who distrust non co operation, I can only say, in all humility : ‘You will accelerate the eruption of violence, if you succeed in defeating the scheme of non co operation and cannot replace it by some definite course of strong action, which must be more than a mere protest, so much more, that resort to it must bring about this desired end.’ The Bombay Chronicle, 29 4 1920

('20', 255, 3, 9, 611643) The doctor [told me that I] was too pulled down to attempt walking up.
('20', 255, 3, 10, 611714) I in my infatuity thought I could do it.

('20', 259, 2, 3, 618365) SINHGADH, April 30 [1920] 2
('20', 259, 3, 4, 618393) BHAISHRI MANGALDAS, I have your letter.
('20', 259, 3, 5, 618433) It was three in the afternoon when I got it and I am writing this reply immediately.
('20', 259, 3, 6, 618518) Even so, I do not think it will reach you on the 1st.
('20', 259, 3, 7, 618572) I think your suspicion of Ambalal bhai 3 is unjustified.
('20', 259, 3, 8, 618629) I told you even that I had agreed with Ambalal bhai on certain rates.
('20', 259, 3, 9, 618699) I did not go further into the matter be cause I thought you knew why I had gone to his place.
('20', 259, 3, 10, 618793) There was nothing in my talk with him which I need have kept back from you, nor did I consider it improper to enter into negotiations with him after I had informed you.
('20', 259, 3, 11, 618962) I negotiated with the mills which agreed to do so.
('20', 259, 3, 12, 619013) I thought it advisable to restrict the scope of the strike, and I still think that way.
('20', 259, 3, 13, 619101) How may I convince you that I have not the least desire to have things my own way in all matters?
('20', 259, 3, 14, 619199) I exert myself to the utmost to see that justice prevails.
('20', 259, 3, 15, 619258) More often than not, the line I take up is based on pure justice and, as justice always prevails, the people in their simplicity are led to believe that I try to have my own way in all things.
('20', 259, 3, 16, 619451) When they come to know me better they see that I have no such desire, for I want neither money nor honour.
('20', 259, 3, 17, 619558) I had had enough of wealth and gave up its pursuit.
('20', 259, 3, 18, 619610) God meets all my needs through friends.
('20', 259, 3, 19, 619650) Honour I receive in over flowing measure from my conscience so that no room is left for receiving more from others.
('20', 259, 3, 20, 619766) For what other reasons, then, should I feel tempted to have anything my own way?
('20', 259, 3, 21, 619847) There is a fundamental difference between our points of view and so there always remains some distance between our positions.
('20', 259, 3, 22, 619973) You believe that, as it is, the workers get more than enough and that they will not use well what they will now get [in addition].
('20', 259, 3, 23, 620104) I believe that they get very little at present.
('20', 259, 3, 24, 620152) I do not think either that even the
