('20', 264, 1, 2, 628582) 70. LETTER TO JAMSHEDJI NASARWANJI MEHTA 1
('20', 264, 2, 3, 628625) SINHGADH,
('20', 264, 3, 4, 628635) [May 1, 1920] 2
('20', 264, 4, 5, 628651) BHAISHRI JAMSHEDJI,
('20', 264, 5, 6, 628671) I welcome your letter.
('20', 264, 5, 7, 628694) I cannot possibly fail to understand you or your sentiments; nor can it be said that those who are opposed to the idea of non co operation are not friends of the Muslims.
('20', 264, 5, 8, 628865) There can well be a difference of opinion even among friends.
('20', 264, 6, 9, 628927) And now I shall answer your questions :
('20', 264, 7, 10, 628967) 1. It is true that the effect of non co operation will be to create opposite to the Government, but it has not been conceived in a spirit of retaliation and, therefore, the question what crime the Government has committed does not rise; though, of course, the latter has not done all it could have.
('20', 264, 7, 11, 629266) If the British Government fails to secure justice, the Indian Government can resign.
('20', 264, 7, 12, 629351) In a situation like this the Indian Government cannot rest content with a mere protest.
('20', 264, 7, 13, 629439) This is where it has failed and so the people are within their rights in withdrawing their co operation and thereby expressing their displeasure.
('20', 264, 7, 14, 629585) 2. We may not knowingly inflict pain on others.
('20', 264, 7, 15, 629633) Nevertheless, if in consequence of some unavoidable act of ours anyone suffers, we cannot be held responsible.
('20', 264, 7, 16, 629744) I have always the right to resign from Government service and, if the Government feels unhappy because of my resignation, I am guilty of no violence towards it.
('20', 264, 7, 17, 629905) I may be living in my father’s house and incidentally serving him in many ways, but I may quit the house and stop co operating with him when I see him doing an injustice and that would certainly hurt him; even then, my duty would be to leave the house.
('20', 264, 7, 18, 630158) My father would have invited that suffering on himself.
('20', 264, 7, 19, 630214) If we do not act in this manner, the oppressors all the world over get a charter of freedom to persist in their evil ways.
('20', 264, 7, 20, 630337) 3. Thus you will see that if we can organize non co operation without indulging in violence we have every right to do so; it is in fact our duty to do so.
('20', 264, 8, 21, 630492) 1 A Parsi business man and public worker of Karachi 2 The letter was in reply to one from Jamshedji Mehta dated April 24, 1920. The source assigns this letter to may 19, which is evidently an error, Gandhiji was in Sinhgadh only till May .
('20', 264, 8, 22, 630732) Probably “19” was a misprint for “1”.
('20', 265, 0, 1, 630770) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 266
('20', 265, 1, 2, 630812) 4. Shaukat Ali’s speech 1 has not alarmed me, for I think I understand what he means.
('20', 265, 1, 3, 630898) I do admit that all the Muslims do not view non co operation in the same light that I do.
('20', 265, 1, 4, 630988) But there is a clear understanding with them that there can be no violence side by side with non co operation.
('20', 265, 1, 5, 631099) Besides, though Muslims may adopt non co operation in a spirit of retaliation, we can produce a happy result from it and save ourselves from an outbreak of violence.
('20', 265, 1, 6, 631265) All good actions, by whatever feelings prompted, yield some fruit.
('20', 265, 1, 7, 631332) The man who follows truth or exercises self restraint out of fear or shame will yet reap the outward benefit of doing so; such is the power of good actions.
('20', 265, 1, 8, 631489) Many others must have sincerely felt the same doubt which you have and hence I am sending your letter and my reply for publication in the Navajivan.

('20', 265, 2, 10, 631708) 71. WHY I HAVE JOINED THE HOME RULE LEAGUE
('20', 265, 3, 11, 631751) TO MEMBERS OF THE HOME RULE LEAGUE Though much pressed before now by friends to join the All India Home Rule League, I could not bring myself to do so.
('20', 265, 3, 12, 631903) One reason for this was that I could not, and still do not, take interest in politics merely as such.
('20', 265, 3, 13, 632005) But this time there was pressure of a different kind.
('20', 265, 3, 14, 632059) When I was first asked, my views were not so well known as they are now.
('20', 265, 3, 15, 632132) Besides, unlike as on previous occasions I found it impossible to remain silent during the last Congress 2. I saw that I must place before the people my views on some of the issues.
('20', 265, 3, 16, 632314) I was quite active at the Congress, and I do not regret the fact.
('20', 265, 3, 17, 632380) I was tempted to join the Home Rule League.
('20', 265, 3, 18, 632424) I wrote to friends outside the Bombay Presidency and consulted them.
('20', 265, 3, 19, 632493) I told them that, if I joined the Home Rule League, it would be in the hope of being to
('20', 265, 4, 20, 632581) 1 At Madras, as president of the Khilafat Conference, on April 17. In his letter to Gandhiji, Jamshedji Mehta had complained that Shaukat Ali’s loose interpretation of “non co operation” and “non violence” was rather alarming.
('20', 265, 4, 21, 632808) 2 The Amritsar Session of December 1919
('20', 266, 0, 1, 632848) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 267
('20', 266, 1, 2, 632888) put my ideas and methods into practice.
('20', 266, 1, 3, 632928) Most of the friends approved of my ideas and also of my intention of joining the League.
('20', 266, 1, 4, 633017) Some others approved of my ideas but expressed the fear that, by joining the League, I would sacrifice my freedom and my independent position.
('20', 266, 1, 5, 633160) This fear had considerable weight with me.
('20', 266, 1, 6, 633203) But I decided that, when they were admitting me to the League in full knowledge of my views, I would be able to preserve my freedom; I saw, moreover, that I would gain a platform for propagating my ideas.
('20', 266, 1, 7, 633408) It is with this hope that I have joined the League.
('20', 266, 1, 8, 633460) I think that the key to the speediest achievement of swaraj lies in swadeshi, Hindu Muslim unity and the spread of Hindi as the national language.
('20', 266, 1, 9, 633607) Hence I will try to interest the League in these activites.
('20', 266, 1, 10, 633667) India’s economic emancipation and moral regeneration can only be achieved through swadeshi.
('20', 266, 1, 11, 633759) I would, therefore, exact a promise from every candidate for election to the Legislative Assembly that he would not be afraid to levy a tariff on foreign goods to any extent necessary for protecting Indian industry.
('20', 266, 1, 12, 633975) So long as there is no unity between Hindus and Muslims, I think swaraj will remain a mere dream.
('20', 266, 1, 13, 634073) I should like, therefore, to extend all help to the Muslims in their fight on the Khilafat issue and thus win them over for ever.
('20', 266, 1, 14, 634203) I shall, therefore, try to engage every member of the League in Khilafat work.
('20', 266, 1, 15, 634282) We are to work with the millions and influence them.
('20', 266, 1, 16, 634335) I will, therefore, try and see that I, and others as well, use for our work, both inside and outside the League, the respective regional languages in each region and the national language, that is to say, Hindustani, on the national plane.
('20', 266, 1, 17, 634575) I would have every member of a leigislature give the assurance that he would try to use, and see that others used, the respective regional languages in the [provincial] legislatures and the national language in the Central Legislature.
('20', 266, 1, 18, 634811) This idea carries with it another.
('20', 266, 1, 19, 634846) To ensure speedy attention to people’s needs and development of every component part of the nation, I will strive to bring about a linguistic division of India and try to induce the League to take up this cause.
('20', 266, 1, 20, 635058) I will exert myself to get separate provinces for the Telugu, Sindhi, Marathi, Oriya and Gujarati speaking peoples and will do all I can to use the League to plan the means, and induce others to plan them, for the full development of each.
('20', 266, 1, 21, 635298) If I succeed in engaging the League in these activities, I shall
('20', 267, 0, 1, 635363) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 268
('20', 267, 1, 2, 635405) feel confident of our being able to achieve swaraj at an early date.
('20', 267, 1, 3, 635474) Looking at the matter from this point of view, I would put less value on the Reforms than on these other things.
('20', 267, 1, 4, 635587) I do not mean to say that the Reforms are of no consequence.
('20', 267, 1, 5, 635648) But I am not prepared to give them more importance than they deserve.
('20', 267, 1, 6, 635718) Even if we were to have all power in our hands today, so long as we do not understand swadeshi or value Hindu Muslim unity or retain the delusion that English may serve as the langu age of administration, I see that the Reforms could be used to deprive us of our freedom.
('20', 267, 1, 7, 635990) They are but a means, not an end in themselves.
('20', 267, 1, 8, 636038) Swadeshi and the other things are both means and ends at once.
('20', 267, 2, 9, 636101) I am of the view, besides, that my method of work yields better results, and quicker.
('20', 267, 2, 10, 636187) This method consists in firm adherence to truth in all that we do, putting the fullest trust in truth and fearing no one in following truth as we know it.
('20', 267, 2, 11, 636342) Acceptance of this principle brings about such a revolution in our life that we become self reliant that very instant.
('20', 267, 2, 12, 636461) Instead of depending on others, we learn forthwith to depend on our selves.
('20', 267, 2, 13, 636537) I wish, therefore, to work hard for the introduction of this principle of satyagraha in the activities of the League.
('20', 267, 2, 14, 636655) I have no intention of drawing it into civil disobedience.
('20', 267, 2, 15, 636714) The idea has not spread widely, and it seems to me that the country has not yet understood the spirit of civil disobedience.
('20', 267, 2, 16, 636839) I wish, therefore, that no member should be alarmed because of my views about disobeying laws.
('20', 267, 3, 17, 636934) I shall seek other opportunities of elaborating my ideas before members of the League.
('20', 267, 3, 18, 637021) Meanwhile, I invite comments from every member on the views set forth above.
('20', 267, 3, 19, 637098) I also hope that all of them will express an opinion on the rightness or otherwise of my step.

('20', 268, 1, 2, 637269) 72. NON CO OPERATION
('20', 268, 2, 3, 637290) Now that the idea of non co operation is making an impact, I feel the need for an easily intelligible [Gujarati] equivalent for it as I felt for”passive resistance”.
('20', 268, 2, 4, 637456) Asahakar immediately occurs to me, but I request the help of readers for finding a better term.
('20', 268, 2, 5, 637552) The learned Mrs. Besant has passed strong strictures against non co operation, 1 and so have a correspondent in The Times of India and its Editor.
('20', 268, 2, 6, 637699) Mrs. Besant’s services to India have been so invaluable, her in dustry so great and her love for India so fine a thing that I cannot but hesitate to criticize her statements or express my difference with her.
('20', 268, 2, 7, 637908) I have always, however, accepted the principle that we can differ, respect fully, even from those whom we look upon as our elders, and that gives me courage on this occasion as well to express my dissent from her.
('20', 268, 2, 8, 638122) With all three of them the great fear is that non co operation is bound to lead to violence.
('20', 268, 2, 9, 638215) We certainly cannot claim that violence will never occur but, having taken all precautions against its occurrence, we must, I feel, go ahead with our programme.
('20', 268, 2, 10, 638376) If we know that those who want to resort to violence are only waiting for non co operation to start, we should certainly postpone it.
('20', 268, 2, 11, 638510) According to me, the success of the Muslims’ cause lies in their preventing the outbreak of violence.
('20', 268, 2, 12, 638612) They have realized this so well that violence is bound to be kept out.
('20', 268, 2, 13, 638683) They know that non co operation cannot proceed even for an hour along with violence.
('20', 268, 2, 14, 638768) Someone may ask whether it is ever possible to prevent violence from breaking out anywhere in India.
('20', 268, 2, 15, 638869) The reply to this is that an army is no longer an army if anything happens in it which was not in the plan; likewise, if we have become one, we must have the capacity to prevent accidents like outbreak of violence.
('20', 268, 2, 16, 639084) Before we have acquired such capacity, we shall commit errors and shall have to rectify them.
('20', 268, 2, 17, 639178) I admit all this but I know that the people must acquire this self discipline.
('20', 268, 2, 18, 639257) It seems to me that this is a great opportunity for doing so.
('20', 268, 2, 19, 639319) These writers have assumed, without any reason whatever, that the advocates of non co operation do not know their job.
('20', 268, 2, 20, 639438) The latter do not intend to climb to the last step of the staircase of non co 
('20', 268, 3, 21, 639517) 1 The policy of non co operation did not appeal to Annie Besant and she tried todissuade the Muslims from adopting it.
('20', 269, 0, 1, 639636) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 270
('20', 269, 1, 2, 639678) operation all in one jump.
('20', 269, 1, 3, 639705) If they proceed step by step, there will be very little fear of their falling.
('20', 269, 1, 4, 639784) There are risks, of course, in non co operation.
('20', 269, 1, 5, 639833) But there is no alternative left.
('20', 269, 1, 6, 639867) If the unjust settlement of the Khilafat issue is intoler able, there must be some way out.
('20', 269, 1, 7, 639959) If the people are not to have even this weapon of non co operation, violence will remain the only course for them and that is a remedy worse than the disease, for our aim is not to vent anger but to secure justice on the Khilafat issue.
('20', 269, 1, 8, 640196) Violence will not succeed in that; it seems to me, therefore, that there is no other weapon except non co operation.

('20', 269, 4, 11, 640349) 73. NOTES
('20', 269, 5, 12, 640359) THE JALLIANWALA BAGH MEMORIAL AND POPULAR AWAKENING If we wish to measure the increase in popular awakening during the last year, we can do so from the contributions being received from all quarters for the Jallianwala Bagh memorial.
('20', 269, 5, 13, 640593) From the list 1 given below, it will be seen that, wherever efforts have been made, even small villages have not lagged behind cities in offering their contributions.
('20', 269, 5, 14, 640760) We have received several letters informing us that in certain places even the poorest of the poor have contributed amounts equal to what they spend on some accustomed necessity of theirs; in some parts, the volunteers moved the whole day from place to place and from house to house, to collect funds.
('20', 269, 5, 15, 641061) The villages in which Mr. Mahadev Desai moved have, according to the information he sends us, a population of not more than a thousand each and yet in every village people contributing to the Memorial Fund belonged not only to the upper and educated classes, but also to the lower and illiterate classes; that is to say, there were contributors not only from Brahmins and Vanias 2
('20', 269, 6, 16, 641442) but also from goldsmiths, carpenters, smiths, oilmen and Kolis 3. In one village, the majority of the population was Muslim.
('20', 269, 6, 17, 641567) There are names of women, too.
('20', 269, 6, 18, 641598) Shri Mahadev Desai reports that, in collecting the
('20', 269, 7, 19, 641649) 1 Not reproduced here 2 The merchant class 3 Sturdy, sea faring Hindu agriculturists inhabiting the sea coast of Gujarat
('20', 270, 0, 1, 641770) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 271
('20', 270, 1, 2, 641810) amounts he did, he did not have to press anyone for contribution.
('20', 270, 1, 3, 641876) He would briefly explain to the people the reason for raising this Fund; in some places, he would show pictures of the Jallianwala Bagh, etc., in the report of the Congress Committee and explain what had happened, 1 and instantly, people would come with whatever they could afford.
('20', 270, 2, 4, 642158) A saying which a gentleman quoted humorously to Mr. Desai, in one of the villages he visited, is worth reporting here.
('20', 270, 2, 5, 642277) The gentleman remarked:”Well, friend, though the dubli 2 gathers only the kharmato, the havaldar 3 must have his trinket all right.
('20', 270, 2, 6, 642409) That is what it is, these days.
('20', 270, 2, 7, 642441) But this is a national cause, and so how can one refuse to pay?” There is a profound meaning in this saying; it brings out the condition of our peasantry in a most touching manner.
('20', 270, 2, 8, 642622) The word kharmato means the grain left over in some corners after the harvest has been removed from where it was gathered in the field.
('20', 270, 2, 9, 642758) With this explanation, the meaning of the saying will be clear.
('20', 270, 2, 10, 642822) The present condition of our peasantry is like that of the dubli picking up kharmato; even so, they give his trinket to the havaldar, and gladly— to a havaldar who is a worthy beggar, that is, a national worker.
('20', 270, 3, 11, 643034) From this fact, another inference may also be drawn, that it is easier to carry on national work in villages than in cities; it would, therefore, be natural to make a start with village swaraj and thence proceed to swaraj for the whole country.
('20', 270, 4, 12, 643279) [From Gujarati]

('20', 273, 1, 2, 647425) 76. LETTER TO B. KRIPALANI 1
('20', 273, 2, 3, 647454) May 2, 1920 I do believe your grandson 2 is doing better at the Ashram than he could do anywhere else.
('20', 273, 2, 4, 647557) If I did not believe that of any boy I would certainly not keep that boy in the Ashram.
('20', 273, 2, 5, 647645) In my opinion the Ashram education is such an all round education that a boy discharged from it is capable of earning more than he would be after a study elsewhere for the same number of years.
('20', 273, 2, 6, 647839) He acquires, that is to say, more confidence in himself.
('20', 273, 2, 7, 647896) But I do confess that boys at the Ashram are constantly taught to believe that education is meant for building character and not wealth.
('20', 273, 2, 8, 648033) Boys at the Ashram are constantly weaned from wealth hunger.
('20', 273, 2, 9, 648094) I would strongly advise you not to force Girdhari to any institution, but to keep him wherever he wishes to remain.
('20', 273, 2, 10, 648210) He is well able to choose for himself.

('20', 273, 4, 13, 648320) 77. LETTER TO LALCHAND
('20', 273, 5, 14, 648343) May 2, 1920
('20', 273, 6, 15, 648355) MY DEAR LALCHAND 3 , I have read all your notes in the Young India of the 28th April.
('20', 273, 6, 16, 648441) The first is quite good, the second is not bad, but it is weak and halting.
('20', 273, 6, 17, 648517) The matter of the third is good, but the manner of dealing with it is bad, the fourth is bad both in manner and matter—in matter because the Congress Deputation, you must know, is not going, and if you did not know you should have made certain.
('20', 273, 6, 18, 648762) It is bad in manner because the style is not that of Young India.
('20', 273, 6, 19, 648828) The fifth note is very good in matter, but you have hardly done justice to a case so important as that of the ill treatment of a lady.
('20', 273, 6, 20, 648963) My criticism is not meant to frighten you.
('20', 273, 6, 21, 649006) It is meant only to warn you to be more careful in future in your selection of subjects and manner of dealing with them.
('20', 273, 6, 22, 649127) Young India will not look faulty for want of a variety of subjects.
('20', 273, 6, 23, 649195) But it will certainly look paltry, if the subjects chosen do not show originality, accuracy of information, and strength in dealing with

('20', 277, 1, 2, 656137) 80. LETTER TO SWAMI SHRADDHANAND
('20', 277, 2, 3, 656170) May 2, 1920 DEAR BROTHER, I have your letter.
('20', 277, 2, 4, 656216) Government employees will be asked to give up jobs only when definite alternative plans have been made for their livelihood.
('20', 277, 2, 5, 656341) In this connection I am in consultation with Muslim brethren.
('20', 277, 2, 6, 656403) I have not advised anyone to leave the country, 1 nor can I do so.
('20', 277, 2, 7, 656470) Some of our Muslim brethren do no doubt intend to leave the country.
('20', 277, 2, 8, 656539) We cannot stop them, but I tell these people also that their leaving the country will not be of any avail.
('20', 277, 2, 9, 656646) If we leave the country as a step in satyagraha, we cannot think of bringing any pressure on the Government through it.
('20', 277, 2, 10, 656766) In my opinion the time for Hindus [sic] to leave India may come when there is a Hindu king and when the subjects, in collaboration with him, make the practice of Hindu religion compulsory.
('20', 277, 2, 11, 656955) If we now fail to non co operate with the Government I will understand this to signify that the religious spirit of the Muslims has weakened.
('20', 277, 2, 12, 657097) As everyone can see, this question of the Khilafat involves a great blow to Islam.
('20', 277, 2, 13, 657180) If at such a juncture Muslims are not prepared to make sacrifices in life and property, it can only mean that the religious spirit has become extinct in them.
('20', 277, 2, 14, 657339) I would not be surprised if such a disaster should come to pass for, travelling round the world, I have witnessed the power of the age of Kali 2. The religious spirit is everywhere in decline and I find irreligion even in many things that are done in the name of religion.
('20', 277, 2, 15, 657612) If what I have written is not clear to you, please tell me.
('20', 277, 2, 16, 657672) I hope the work of the Gurukul 3 goes on nicely now.
('20', 277, 2, 17, 657725) I have been in this secluded spot 4 for the last four days.
('20', 277, 3, 18, 657785) MOHANDAS [From Hindi]

('20', 278, 1, 2, 658171) 81. LETTER TO SARLADEVI CHOWDHRANI May 3, 1920 MY DEAR SARALA, Finding Janaka exulting in the discovery that he was the changeless Brahma, Ashtavakra challenges his position in the 3rd chapter and says :
('20', 278, 3, 3, 658375) 1 Having known the atman to be in truth the Imperishable One without a second, how is it that you, enlightened about the atman and ever firm in mind, take pleasure in acquiring possessions?
('20', 278, 3, 4, 658565) Ashtavaktra Gita, III, 1 Just as, not knowing a sea shell, one covets it under the delusion that it is a piece of silver, so through ignorance of the atman one sees it as the delusive world of sense objects and takes pleasure in them.
('20', 278, 3, 5, 658800) III, 2 Having known yourself to be that One from Whom emanates this universe waves rise in an ocean, why do you run about like a weak, miserable wretch?
('20', 278, 3, 6, 658953) III, 3 Having learnt that the atman is the living spirit, absolute and unconditioned, supremely beautiful, if one remains attached to the gross pleasure of sense, one gets defiled.
('20', 278, 3, 7, 659134) III, 4 It is strange that even a wise one, knowing himself present in all creatures and all creatures present in himself, should be dominated by the sense of “I” and “Mine”.
('20', 278, 3, 8, 659308) III, 5 It is strange that even a man abiding in the Supreme Oneness and set on attaining moksha should get distraught with passion, yielding to its overmastering urge through experience of the pleasure it brings.
('20', 278, 3, 9, 659521) III, 6 It is strange that a man who knows for certain that the desire which has possessed him is an enemy of knowledge should yet long for pleasure even though extremely enfeebled and nearing death.
('20', 279, 0, 1, 659720) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 280
('20', 279, 1, 2, 659762) 1 The challenged Janaka, retaining the same exultant mood, replies in the fourth chapter :
('20', 279, 2, 3, 659853) 1 It is strange that a man unattached both to this world and the other, able to dicriminate between the transient and the eternal and aspiring after moksha, should be afraid of moksha itself.
('20', 279, 2, 4, 660045) III, 8 The steadfast man when consuming things which please, or when made to suffer, is neither happy nor angry, ever seeing the one atman every where.
('20', 279, 2, 5, 660197) III, 9 The high souled man, looking upon the ever active body of his as not his, how should such a one be affected by praise or blame?
('20', 279, 2, 6, 660332) III, 10 The man of steady intellect, who the entire universe as maya and is no more interested in its shows, how will he have fear even when death is near?
('20', 279, 2, 7, 660488) III, 11 The high souled one whose mind is free from desire even when things look hopeless, who, self realized, rests supremely content in himself, with whom may such a one be compared?
('20', 279, 2, 8, 660673) III, 12 The man of steady intellect who knows that all this, in very truth, is appearance and no more, will he feel drawn by one thing and repelled by another?
('20', 279, 2, 9, 660833) III, He who has inwardly renounced attachment, who is unaffected by the pairs of opposites and who hopes for nothing—to him chance brought things of enjoyment occasion neither happiness nor suffering.
('20', 279, 2, 10, 661034) III, 14
('20', 280, 0, 1, 661042) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 20 JULY, 1920 281
('20', 280, 2, 2, 661085) You will note that the verses in the fourth chapter are somewhat dangerous.
('20', 280, 2, 3, 661161) It is strong food for a delicate stomach.
('20', 280, 2, 4, 661203) All the chapters are not of equal length.
('20', 280, 2, 5, 661245) The third for instance has 14 verses and the fourth only six.

('20', 284, 1, 2, 670591) 83. THE DELHI NOTIFICATION AND PRESS ORDERS 1
('20', 284, 2, 3, 670637) The first repressive move in connection with the Khilafat movement has commenced at Delhi in the shape of a notification under the Seditious Meetings Act and a gradual muzzling of the Muslim Press.
('20', 284, 2, 4, 670835) We are not surprised at this.
('20', 284, 2, 5, 670865) We must expect the Government to anticipate every move of the Committee 2 and expect it to thwart the scheme of non co operation.
('20', 284, 2, 6, 670995) Nor can the Govern ment be blamed for it so long as it acts wisely and temperately.
('20', 284, 2, 7, 671079) But the people must be prepared for the Government even to lose its senses, become panicky and adopt insane measures.
('20', 284, 2, 8, 671197) O’Dwyerism may erupt anywhere any day.
('20', 284, 2, 9, 671236) The people must prepare for all contingencies.
('20', 284, 2, 10, 671283) The preparation is simple.
('20', 284, 2, 11, 671310) They must not lose their heads on any account whatsoever.
('20', 284, 2, 12, 671368) They must not be angry.
('20', 284, 2, 13, 671392) They must not play into the hands of mischief makers and answer Government madness with madness.
('20', 284, 2, 14, 671489) No one should act on his own responsibility.
('20', 284, 2, 15, 671534) It should be remembered that civil disobedience is not to be offered, at any rate at this stage, in connection with the Khilafat movement.
('20', 284, 2, 16, 671673) Non co operation, too, has not yet commenced.
('20', 284, 2, 17, 671719) Every Government order must be strictly obeyed, all rules and laws faithfully carried out.
('20', 284, 2, 18, 671810) Then and then only is non co operation likely to succeed.
('20', 284, 2, 19, 671868) All the laws of war are applicable to this great struggle.
('20', 284, 2, 20, 671927) An army moves silently, calmly and deliberately.
('20', 284, 2, 21, 671976) No unit acts on its own responsibility.
('20', 284, 2, 22, 672016) Discipline is the watchword of success.
('20', 284, 2, 23, 672056) So must it be with the Khilafat army of peace.
('20', 284, 2, 24, 672103) Its strokes will be sure and certain only when there is no violence in the face of the greatest provocation.
('20', 284, 2, 25, 672212) The Government is not bound by any rule of non violence.
('20', 284, 2, 26, 672269) Indeed, the last resort of a Government is violence.
('20', 284, 2, 27, 672322) The leaders must be prepared for prosecutions, internments, imprisonment, etc.

('20', 284, 2, 29, 672444) Then, when we have proved ourselves by going through the process of purification, will victory come, not till then.

('20', 285, 1, 2, 672862) 84. HOW TO WORK NON CO OPERATION
('20', 285, 2, 3, 672895) Perhaps the best way of answering the fears and criticism as to non co operation is to elaborate more fully the scheme of non co operation.
('20', 285, 2, 4, 673035) The critics seem to imagine that the organizers propose to give effect to the whole scheme at once.
('20', 285, 2, 5, 673135) The fact however is that the organizers have fixed definite, progressive four stages.
('20', 285, 2, 6, 673221) The first is the giving up of titles and resignation of honorary posts.
('20', 285, 2, 7, 673293) If there is no response or if the response received is not effective, recourse will be had to the second stage.
('20', 285, 2, 8, 673405) The second stage involves much previous arrange ment.
('20', 285, 2, 9, 673459) Certainly, not a single servant will be called out unless he is either capable of supporting himself and his dependents or the Khilafat Committee is able to bear the burden.
('20', 285, 2, 10, 673633) All the classes of servants will not be called out at once and never will any pressure be put upon a single servant to withdraw himself from the Government service.
('20', 285, 2, 11, 673798) Nor will a single private employee be touched for the simple reason that the movement is not anti English.
('20', 285, 2, 12, 673905) It is not even anti Government.
('20', 285, 2, 13, 673937) Co operation is to be withdrawn because the people must not be party to a wrong—a broken pledge—a violation of deep religious sentiment.
('20', 285, 2, 14, 674074) Naturally, the movement will receive a check, if there is any undue influence brought to bear upon any Government servant or if any violence is used or countenanced by any member of the Khilafat Committee.
('20', 285, 2, 15, 674280) The second stage must be entirely successful, if the response is at all on an adequate scale.
('20', 285, 2, 16, 674374) For no Government— much less the Indian Government—can subsist if the people cease to serve it.
('20', 285, 2, 17, 674470) The withdrawal therefore of the police and the military—that third stage—is a distant goal.
('20', 285, 2, 18, 674562) The organizers however wanted to be fair, just and above suspicion.
('20', 285, 2, 19, 674630) They did not want to keep back from the Government or the public a single step they had in contemplation even as a remote contin gency.
('20', 285, 2, 20, 674766) The fourth, i.e., suspension of taxes, is still more remote.
('20', 285, 2, 21, 674827) The organizers recognize that supension of general taxation is fraught with the greatest danger.
('20', 285, 2, 22, 674924) It is likely to bring a sensitive class in conflict with the police.
('20', 285, 2, 23, 674993) They are therefore not likely to embark upon it, unless they can do so with the assurance that there will be no violence offered by the people.
('20', 285, 2, 24, 675137) I admit as I have already done that non co operation is not unatt ended with risk, but the risk of supineness in the face of a grave issue is infinitely greater than the danger of violence ensuing from organizing non co operation.
('20', 285, 2, 25, 675368) To do nothing is to invite violence for a
('20', 286, 0, 1, 675410) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 287
('20', 286, 1, 2, 675450) certainty.
('20', 286, 1, 3, 675461) It is easy enough to pass resolutions or write articles condemning non co operation.
('20', 286, 1, 4, 675546) But it is no easy task to restrain the fury of a people incensed by a deep sense of wrong.
('20', 286, 1, 5, 675637) I urge those who talk or work against non co operation to descend from their chairs and go down to the people, learn their feelings and write, if they have the heart, against non co operation.
('20', 286, 1, 6, 675830) They will find, as I have found, that the only way to avoid violence is to enable them to give such expression to their feelings as to compel redress.
('20', 286, 1, 7, 675981) I have found nothing save non co operation.
('20', 286, 1, 8, 676025) It is logical and harmless.
('20', 286, 1, 9, 676053) It is the inherent right of a subject to refuse to assist a government that will not listen to him.
('20', 286, 2, 10, 676153) Non co operation as a voluntary movement can only succeed if the feeling is genuine and strong enough to make people suffer to the utmost.
('20', 286, 2, 11, 676292) If the religious sentiment of the Mohammedans is deeply hurt and if the Hindus entertain neighbourly regard towards their Muslim brethren, they will both count no cost too great for achieving the end.
('20', 286, 2, 12, 676493) Non co operation will not only be an effective remedy but will also be an effective test of the sincerity of the Muslim claim and the Hindu profession of friendship.
('20', 286, 3, 13, 676659) There is, however, one formidable argument urged by friends against my joining the Khilafat movement.
('20', 286, 3, 14, 676761) 1 They say that it ill becomes me, a friend of the English and an admirer of the British constitution, to join hands with those who are today filled with nothing but ill will against the English.
('20', 286, 3, 15, 676957) I am sorry to have to confess that the ordinary Mohammedan entertains today no affection for Englishmen.
('20', 286, 3, 16, 677062) He considers, not without some cause, that they have not played the game.
('20', 286, 3, 17, 677136) But if I am friendly towards Englishmen, I am no less so towards my countrymen, the Mohammedans.
('20', 286, 3, 18, 677233) And as such they have a greater claim upon my attention than Englishmen.
('20', 286, 3, 19, 677306) My personal religion however enables me to serve my countrymen without hurting Englishmen or for that matter anybody else.
('20', 286, 3, 20, 677429) What I am not prepared to do to my blood brother, I would not do to an Englishman.

('20', 286, 3, 22, 677554) But I would withdraw co operation from him if it became necessary, as I had withdrawn from my own brother 2 (now deceased) when it became necessary.
('20', 286, 3, 23, 677703) I serve the Empire

('20', 288, 1, 2, 680127) 85. REPRESSION IN DELHI
('20', 288, 2, 3, 680151) There was no reason to believe that the Khilafat movement would go on without the Government resorting to repression.
('20', 288, 2, 4, 680269) If anyone believed so, the notification 1 issued by the Delhi Government should open his eyes.
('20', 288, 2, 5, 680364) The notification forbids the holding of any meeting in Delhi Province for a period of three months without the prior permission of the Government.
('20', 288, 2, 6, 680511) This is but the beginning.
('20', 288, 2, 7, 680538) The Government would certainly not permit a movement like non co operation without trying to suppress it.
('20', 288, 2, 8, 680644) No government would, for that matter.
('20', 288, 2, 9, 680682) The movement is of such a nature that, if it succeeds, the administration would come to a standstill.
('20', 288, 2, 10, 680784) The Government is certain to take steps to prevent this.
('20', 288, 2, 11, 680841) It is through repression that the people will be tested.
('20', 288, 2, 12, 680898) If the Government were to remain quiet, non co operation would not have much effect.
('20', 288, 2, 13, 680983) Every State depends in the last resort on the pistol, that is, on the power it wields.
('20', 288, 2, 14, 681070) In this fight, however, the people’s weapon is their capacity for suffering.
('20', 288, 2, 15, 681147) If they pit their physical strength against the Government’s, they will lose.
('20', 288, 2, 16, 681225) The idea, therefore, of employing physical force simultaneously with non co operation will have to be given up altogether.
('20', 288, 2, 17, 681348) And so I hope that the people will remain peaceful despite any repressive measures the Government may take in Delhi or elsewhere.
('20', 288, 2, 18, 681478) Their success lies in doing so and going ahead with the programme.
('20', 288, 2, 19, 681545) It should be remembered that in this struggle the soul force of the Indian people is to be pitted against the brute force of the Allies.
('20', 288, 2, 20, 681682) If, in this, there is the slightest admixture of brute force by the people, even what is claimed as soul force will be looked upon as brute force or as weakness.
('20', 288, 2, 21, 681844) If the people want to succeed on the Khilafat question with the help of soul force, they should be ready to go to jail, to be deprived of their property and to resign from Government service.
('20', 288, 2, 22, 682036) This is certainly no movement aiming at easy success.
('20', 288, 2, 23, 682090) It also needs to be borne in mind that we have not so far introduced the element of civil disobedience in this struggle.
('20', 288, 2, 24, 682211) As I understand the matter, civil disobedience and non co operation do not go together.
('20', 288, 2, 25, 682299) Any ordinances, therefore, which the Government might

('20', 290, 1, 2, 684128) 86. ABDUCTIONS ON BORDER
('20', 290, 2, 3, 684153) There are certain wild tribes on the North West Frontier of India.
('20', 290, 2, 4, 684220) They are Muslims and live by carrying out raids and abducting people.
('20', 290, 2, 5, 684290) 1 Recently they abducted an English girl and set her free only when they received a ransom.
('20', 290, 2, 6, 684382) In like manner, they plunder Hindus in surrounding villages, abduct some and set them free when they are paid ransom.
('20', 290, 2, 7, 684500) They harass Muslims, too, in the same manner.
('20', 290, 2, 8, 684546) This is not, therefore, a case of Muslims plundering Hindus.
('20', 290, 2, 9, 684607) Nevertheless, some Hindus, on the strength of the happy spirit of Hindu Muslim unity which is in the air today, want that the Muslims, if they are sincere, should take steps to stop these raids.
('20', 290, 2, 10, 684802) I know that this is said in ignorance.
('20', 290, 2, 11, 684841) Indian Muslims have no influence whatever on the wild tribes on the border.
('20', 290, 2, 12, 684917) They themselves suffer from these raids, as I have pointed out.
('20', 290, 2, 13, 684981) Be that as it may, we must think out measures to stop this harassment.
('20', 290, 2, 14, 685052) Those who suffer from these raids and abductions should get help.
('20', 290, 2, 15, 685118) It is for the Government to provide it.
('20', 290, 2, 16, 685158) If it cannot ensure such protection, what happens to the mighty power of protection with which it is credited?
('20', 290, 2, 17, 685269) I have no illusions left about this power.
('20', 290, 2, 18, 685312) The Government is not as strong for preventing crime as it is for punishing the guilty after a crime has been committed.
('20', 290, 2, 19, 685433) The instances of Arar and Katarpur are quite fresh in our memory.
('20', 290, 2, 20, 685499) Personally, I would not blame the Government for this state of affairs.
('20', 290, 2, 21, 685571) As long as human nature remains what it is, crimes will continue.
('20', 290, 2, 22, 685637) The State succeeds in preventing them, more or less, to the extent that they can be prevented by fear of punishment.
('20', 290, 3, 23, 685754) The best remedy against this should be with the people them selves.
('20', 290, 3, 24, 685822) Be it on the border or elsewhere, the people should be capable of defending themselves.
('20', 290, 3, 25, 685910) If they do not have the capacity, they should cultivate it.
('20', 290, 3, 26, 685970) One method is to win over one’s neighbour by love, and the other is to stop him by fear.
('20', 290, 3, 27, 686059) Generally, a mixture of the two is employed.
('20', 290, 3, 28, 686104) People develop enough physical strength for self defence, and also try to cultivate friendly relations with the neighbours.
('20', 290, 3, 29, 686228) The inhabitants of the border villages can employ both these methods.
('20', 290, 4, 30, 686298) 1 During the period, 1919 20, no fewer than 611 raids took place in the Peshawar, Kohat, Bannu and Dera Ismail Khan districts.
('20', 290, 4, 31, 686425) They resulted in the killing of 298, the wounding of 392, and the kidnapping of 463 British subjects.
('20', 290, 4, 32, 686527) India in 1920.

('20', 291, 1, 2, 686584) They may prepare themselves to fight the raiders unitedly, and may also negotiate with them when there is peace.

('20', 291, 4, 13, 687597) 87. A HUMBLE SUGGESTION 1
('20', 291, 5, 14, 687623) I observe that many candidates have come forward for the choice of the would be electors for the reformed Councils.
('20', 291, 5, 15, 687739) 2 It must be granted that it is possible to render some service to the State by entering these Councils.
('20', 291, 5, 16, 687844) But it is my firm belief that many can serve the country better by remaining outside.

('20', 294, 1, 2, 694027) 89. CURSE OF WIDOWHOOD
('20', 294, 2, 3, 694050) Mr. Kanchanlal Khandwala’s letter is full of figures about widows.
('20', 294, 2, 4, 694117) Anyone’s heart will bleed to read them.
('20', 294, 2, 5, 694157) Impatient reformers will merely say that remarriage of widows is the only straight and simple remedy for this.
('20', 294, 2, 6, 694268) I cannot say so.
('20', 294, 2, 7, 694285) I too have a family of my own.
('20', 294, 2, 8, 694316) There are many widows in my family, but I can never bring myself to advise them to remarry and they will not think of doing so either.
('20', 294, 2, 9, 694451) The real remedy is for men to take a pledge not to remarry.
('20', 294, 2, 10, 694511) But there are other remedies, barring remarriage, which we do not adopt, or rather do not wish to adopt.
('20', 294, 2, 11, 694616) Here they are: 1. Child marriages should stop.
('20', 294, 2, 12, 694663) 2. No boy and girl should be betrothed till they are of an age to live together.
('20', 294, 2, 13, 694744) 3. Not only should a woman who has never lived with her husband be permitted to remarry, she should actually be encouraged to do so.
('20', 294, 2, 14, 694877) Such women should not be classed with widows.
('20', 294, 2, 15, 694923) 4. Those who became widows before the age of fifteen and who are still young should be free to remarry.
('20', 294, 2, 16, 695027) 5. Instead of being regarded as a sign of ill fortune, widowhood should be looked upon as a holy state and respected accordingly.
('20', 294, 2, 17, 695157) 6. The best arrangements should be made to educate widows and give them some occupation.
('20', 294, 2, 18, 695246) There is no doubt that, if these reforms are brought about, Hindu society would be rid of the evils arising from widowhood.
('20', 294, 2, 19, 695370) Every family and every community may adopt these reforms for themselves.
('20', 294, 2, 20, 695443) Many reforms are delayed because everyone waits for someone else to make a start.
('20', 294, 2, 21, 695525) It is a divine injunction that man should do a good deed the moment he sees it as such; about a sinful act, one should think, consult a fortune teller and take advice from thousands of people, and ultimately refrain from it.
('20', 294, 2, 22, 695750) We become guilty in the sight of God if we delay in the performance of a good deed.
('20', 294, 2, 23, 695834) But we act the opposite way.
('20', 294, 2, 24, 695863) We are not afraid of doing anything sinful, but, when it comes to doing good, we wait for conferences.
('20', 294, 2, 25, 695966) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 9 5 1920

('20', 295, 1, 2, 696044) 90. THREE OCCASIONS
('20', 295, 2, 3, 696064) A wedding having taken place in the Satyagraha Ashram, I could not help making a comparison between this wedding in the Ashram and the weddings outside.
('20', 295, 2, 4, 696217) I take the liberty to place before the reader some of my reflections on this.
('20', 295, 2, 5, 696295) Imam Saheb Abdul Kadir Bawazeer is an earnest Muslim of a noble family.
('20', 295, 2, 6, 696367) His father was the Muezzin in the Jumma Masjid in Bombay for several years.
('20', 295, 2, 7, 696443) The Imam Saheb has been with me for the past many years.
('20', 295, 2, 8, 696500) He was with me in jail, too.
('20', 295, 2, 9, 696529) After his experience of jail, he lost interest in business and came over with his family to stay with me in Phoenix.
('20', 295, 2, 10, 696646) Bodily labour was a rule in Phoenix.
('20', 295, 2, 11, 696683) The Imam Saheb had never done it, but started it there.
('20', 295, 2, 12, 696739) We used to bring out Indian Opinion and the Imam Saheb picked up the work of composing.
('20', 295, 2, 13, 696827) The Imam Saheb has two daughters.
('20', 295, 2, 14, 696861) He has lived with me as if he were my own brother and we have fully respected each other’s religion, so that we have never felt sorry that we belong to different religions.
('20', 295, 2, 15, 697034) We have felt nothing wrong in his doing his namaz and the Hindu following his own method of worship; on the contrary, we have believed that this is as it should be.
('20', 295, 3, 16, 697199) And now came the wedding of his eldest daughter, Fatima.
('20', 295, 3, 17, 697256) We held consultations.
('20', 295, 3, 18, 697279) Fatima, over twenty, is a wise girl.
('20', 295, 3, 19, 697316) After having consulted her and the Imam Saheb, we decided to have a wedding which would become the Ashram and our life of poverty.
('20', 295, 3, 20, 697447) We dropped the marriage procession, the band and all other pomp; we dropped even the feast.
('20', 295, 3, 21, 697539) That the students might realize the importance of their brahmacharya, they too were consulted and it was decided that they should not attend the marriage.
('20', 295, 3, 22, 697694) The relations of Imam Saheb and of the bridegroom, Bhai Syed Hussein Uraizee, and others connected with the Ashram, were invited to give their blessings.
('20', 295, 3, 23, 697848) They were offered home made sherbet and fruits and nuts.
('20', 295, 3, 24, 697905) As for illuminations, there was nothing except a hanging lamp.
('20', 295, 3, 25, 697968) The ceremony lasted two hours, of which half an hour was taken up by the maulood sharif or reading out in Arabic the life of the Prophet by way of an auspicious beginning.
('20', 295, 3, 26, 698140) This was followed by the

('20', 300, 2, 7, 705754) 94. LETTER TO SYED FAZLUR RAHMAN
('20', 300, 3, 8, 705787) THE ASHRAM, May 11, 1920
('20', 300, 4, 9, 705812) DEAR SYED FAZLUR RAHMAN, Technically it is the Government which is perpetrating the injustice against Turkey and thus violating Indian sentiment and therefore I cannot withdraw my support of its injustice by boycotting British goods.
('20', 300, 4, 10, 706046) Indeed I expect to gain British sympathy and by it compel the British Government to do the right thing.
('20', 300, 4, 11, 706150) I do not say that a successful boycott cannot achieve the end.
('20', 300, 4, 12, 706213) But it will be by way of punishment and not by way of duty [.] We are ourselves not to be party to an injustice.
('20', 300, 4, 13, 706326) My plan of non co operation today does not involve the withdrawal of servants from benevolent institutions but if a Government were wholly corrupt I would not hesitate to stop its activity by complete withdrawal of co operation.
('20', 300, 4, 14, 706555) I would refuse to have even useful service through a corrupt agency and when the activity of a completely unjust Government is brought to a standstill it is simultaneously replaced by another agency that will perform the useful services such as you mention.
('20', 300, 4, 15, 706813) But as yet I do not take that view of the British Government.

('20', 301, 1, 2, 707571) 95. DISTRESS IN ORISSA
('20', 301, 2, 3, 707594) Orissa, in spite of its enjoying the honour of having one of the great places of pilgrimage, viz., Jagannath Puri, appears to be a godforsaken country.
('20', 301, 2, 4, 707746) For, even whilst India is pulsating with a consciousness of national life, we know little of Orissa.
('20', 301, 2, 5, 707847) For most of us, it is a mere geographical expression.
('20', 301, 2, 6, 707901) Not being a centre of modern education it has not produced the modern type of workers and, therefore, nobody knows whether the people of Orissa are happy or unhappy.
('20', 301, 2, 7, 708067) For months past an Orissa friend has been trying to interest me in its problems.
('20', 301, 2, 8, 708148) He has for the last few weeks been telling me that there is practically a famine in the land.
('20', 301, 2, 9, 708242) In a little village containing 59 families, numbering all told 411 men and women, recently 11 infants, he says, died for want of nutrition.
('20', 301, 2, 10, 708382) Altogether 58 deaths have taken place owing to starvation, 61 have abandoned the village and those who are left are mere skin and bone.
('20', 301, 2, 11, 708518) They have neither food nor clothing.
('20', 301, 2, 12, 708555) Women being insufficiently clad will not leave their homes and some are living on grass and leaves!
('20', 301, 2, 13, 708655) I was not prepared to believe this terrible story.
('20', 301, 2, 14, 708706) I felt that before making a public appeal there should be some authentic information to be placed before the people.
('20', 301, 2, 15, 708823) I therefore approached the Servants of India Society for lending Mr. Amritlal Thakkar’s services.
('20', 301, 2, 16, 708921) His fitness for the work cannot be questioned, for he has qualified himself for it for years by such kind of investigations.
('20', 301, 2, 17, 709046) My request was readily granted and the following is the substance of what he has to say after a week’s stay in the Puri District of Orissa : I have been travelling in the villages for the last 8 days.
('20', 301, 2, 18, 709247) There are certainly famine conditions in Orissa.
('20', 301, 2, 19, 709296) Whilst I was in Jamshedpur, I believed that Orissa was one of the granaries of India because Balassore provides a vast quantity of rice.
('20', 301, 2, 20, 709433) But alas!
('20', 301, 2, 21, 709443) Today I find that the people of the affected district have to get their rice from Calcutta, Sambalpur, etc.
('20', 301, 2, 22, 709551) The country had a double visitation—famine and flood.
('20', 301, 2, 23, 709605) It is said that during the last six months over 1,500 people must have died of starvation.
('20', 301, 2, 24, 709696) I have already visited nearly 19 villages.
('20', 301, 2, 25, 709739) Of these 6 are said to have lost 40 inhabitants simply from starvation.
('20', 301, 2, 26, 709811) People are still dying.
('20', 301, 2, 27, 709835) An old man died in my very presence.
('20', 301, 2, 28, 709872) He was among those who had come for relief.
('20', 301, 2, 29, 709916) A co worker has just returned from a village telling me that he saw an old man who was dying of

('20', 302, 1, 2, 710052) starvation.
('20', 302, 1, 3, 710064) One stumbles upon children recently bereft of parents.

('20', 302, 1, 5, 710175) I have sent you the following telegram:
('20', 302, 2, 6, 710215) I have visited already 19 villages.
('20', 302, 2, 7, 710251) I am still travelling.

('20', 302, 4, 22, 711192) 96. NEITHER A SAINT NOR A POLITICIAN
('20', 302, 5, 23, 711229) A kind friend has sent me the following cutting from the April number of East and West :
('20', 302, 6, 24, 711318) Mr. Gandhi has the reputation of a saint but it seems that the politician in him often dominates his decisions.
('20', 302, 6, 25, 711430) He has been making great use of hartals and there can be no gainsaying that under his direction hartal is becoming a powerful political weapon for uniting the educated and the uneducated on a single question of the day.
('20', 302, 6, 26, 711650) The hartal is not without its disadvantages.
('20', 302, 6, 27, 711695) It is teaching direct action, and direct action, however potent, does not work for unity.
('20', 302, 6, 28, 711785) Is Mr. Gandhi quite sure that he is serving the highest behests of ahimsa, harmlessness?
('20', 302, 6, 29, 711874) His proposal to commemorate the shooting at Jallianwala Bagh is not likely to promote concord.
('20', 302, 6, 30, 711969) It is a tragic incident into which our Government was betrayed, but is the memory of its bitterness worth retaining?
('20', 302, 6, 31, 712086) Can we not commemorate the event by raising a temple of peace, to help the widows and orphans to bless the souls of those who died without knowing why?
('20', 302, 6, 32, 712238) The world is full of politicians and pettifoggers who, in the name of patriotism, poison the inner sweetness of man and, as a result, we have wars and feuds and such shameless slaughter as turned Jallianwala Bagh into a shambles.
('20', 302, 6, 33, 712468) Shall we not now try for a larger symbiosis such as Buddha and Christ preached, and bring the world to
('20', 303, 0, 1, 712571) 304 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('20', 303, 1, 2, 712613) breathe and prosper together?
('20', 303, 1, 3, 712643) Mr. Gandhi seemed destined to be the apostle of such a movement, but circumstances are forcing him to seek the way of raising resistances and group unities.
('20', 303, 1, 4, 712800) He may yet take up the larger mission of uniting the world.
('20', 303, 1, 5, 712860) I have given the whole of the quotation.
('20', 303, 1, 6, 712901) As a rule I do not notice criticism of me or my methods except when thereby I acknowledge a mistake or enforce still further the principles criticized.
('20', 303, 1, 7, 713053) I have a double reason for noticing the extract.
('20', 303, 1, 8, 713102) For, not only do I hope further to elucidate the principles I hold dear, but I want to show my regard for the author of the criticism whom I know and whom I have admired for many years for the singular beauty of his character.
('20', 303, 1, 9, 713329) The critic regrets to see in me a politician, whereas he expected me to be a saint.
('20', 303, 1, 10, 713413) Now I think that the word “saint” should be ruled out of present life.
('20', 303, 1, 11, 713484) It is too sacred a word to be lightly applied to anybody, much less to one like myself who claims only to be a humble searcher after truth, knows his limitations, makes mistakes, never hesitates to admit them when he makes them, and frankly confesses that he, like a scientist, is making experiments about some of ‘the eternal verities’ of life, but cannot even claim to be a scientist because he can show no tangible proof of scientific accuracy in his methods or such tangible results of his experiments as modern science demands.
('20', 303, 1, 12, 714017) But though by disclaiming sainthood I disappoint the critic’s expectations, I would have him to give up his regrets by answering him that the politician in me has never dominated a single decision of mine, and if I seem to take part in politics, it is only because politics encircle us today like the coil of a snake from which one cannot get out, no matter how much one tries.
('20', 303, 1, 13, 714395) I wish therefore to wrestle with the snake, as I have been doing, with more or less suc cess, consciously since 1894, unconsciously, as I have now discovered, ever since reaching the years of discretion.
('20', 303, 1, 14, 714599) Quite selfishly, as I wish to live in peace in the midst of a bellowing storm howling round me, I have been experime nting with myself and my friends by introducing religion into politics.
('20', 303, 1, 15, 714788) Let me explain what I mean by religion.
('20', 303, 1, 16, 714828) It is not the Hindu religion, which I certainly prize above all other religions, but the religion which transcends Hinduism, which changes one’s very nature, which binds one indissolubly to the truth within and which ever purifies.
('20', 303, 1, 17, 715060) It is the permanent element in human nature which counts no cost too great in order to find full expression and which leaves the soul utterly restless until it has found itself, known its Maker and appreciated the true correspondence between the Maker and itself.
('20', 303, 1, 18, 715324) It was in that religious spirit that I came upon hartal.
('20', 303, 1, 19, 715381) I wanted to
('20', 304, 0, 1, 715393) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 305
('20', 304, 1, 2, 715433) show that it is not a knowledge of letters that would give India consciousness of herself, or that would bind the educated together.
('20', 304, 1, 3, 715566) The hartal illuminated the whole of India as if by magic on the 6th of April, 1919. And had it not been for the interruption of the 10th of April, brought about by Satan whispering fear into the ears of a Government conscious of its own wrong and inciting to anger a people that were prepared for it by utter distrust of the Government, India would have risen to an unimaginable height.
('20', 304, 1, 4, 715953) The hartal had not only been taken up by the great masses of people in a truly religious spirit but it was intended to be a prelude to a series of direct actions.
('20', 304, 1, 5, 716116) But my critic deplores direct action.
('20', 304, 1, 6, 716154) For, he says, “it does not work for unity.” I join issue with him.
('20', 304, 1, 7, 716221) Never has anything been done on this earth without direct action.
('20', 304, 1, 8, 716287) I rejected the word “passive resistance”, because of its insufficiency and its being interpreted as a weapon of the weak.
('20', 304, 1, 9, 716409) It was direct action in South Africa which told and told so effectively that it converted General Smuts to sanity.
('20', 304, 1, 10, 716524) He was in 1906 the most relentless opponent of Indian aspirations.
('20', 304, 1, 11, 716591) In 1914 he took pride in doing tardy justice by removing from the statute book of the Union a disgraceful measure 1 which in 1909 he had told Lord Morley would be never removed, for he then said South Africa would never tolerate repeal of a measure which was twice passed 2 by the Transvaal Legislature.
('20', 304, 1, 12, 716895) But what is more, direct action sustained for eight years 3 left behind it not only no bitterness, but the very Indians who put up such a stubborn fight against General Smuts, ranged themselves round his banner in 1915 and fought under him in East Africa.
('20', 304, 1, 13, 717151) 4 It was direct action 5 in Champaran which removed an age long grievance.
('20', 304, 1, 14, 717226) A meek submission when one is chafing under a disability or a grievance which one would gladly see removed, not only does not make for unity, but makes the weak party acid, angry and prepares him for an opportunity to explode.
('20', 304, 1, 15, 717453) By allying myself with the weak party, by teaching him direct, firm, but harmless action, I make him feel strong and capable of defying the physical might.
('20', 304, 1, 16, 717609) He feels braced for the struggle, regains confidence in himself and knowing that the remedy lies with himself, ceases to harbour the spirit of revenge and learns to be satisfied with a redress of the wrong he is seeking to remedy.

('20', 306, 4, 7, 721481) 97. KHILAFAT
('20', 306, 5, 8, 721494) As I told you in my last letter I think Mr. Gandhi has made a serious mistake in the Khilafat business.
('20', 306, 5, 9, 721598) The Indian Mohammedans base their demand on the assertion that their religion requires the Turkish rule over Arabia; but when they have against them in this matter the Arabs themselves, it is impossible to regard the theory of the Indian Mohammedans as essential to Islam.

('20', 306, 5, 11, 721928) It is as if the German Roman Catholics made a demand in the name of Roman Catholics, with Rome and the Italians making a contrary demand.

('20', 306, 5, 14, 722592) We could not now stand by and see the Turks reconquer the Arabs (for the Arabs would certainly fight against them) without grossly betraying the Arabs to whom we have given pledges.
('20', 306, 5, 15, 722774) It is not true that the Arab hostility to the Turks was due simply to European suggestion.

('20', 309, 3, 8, 729488) 98. “IN PROCESS OF KEEPING”
('20', 309, 4, 9, 729516) The writer of “Current Topics” in The Times of India has attempted to challenge the statement made in my Khilafat article regarding ministerial pledges, and in doing so, cites Mr. Asquith’s Guild Hall speech of November 10, 1914. When I wrote the article, I had in mind Mr. Asquith’s speech.
('20', 309, 4, 10, 729808) I am sorry that he ever made that speech.
('20', 309, 4, 11, 729850) For, in my humble opinion, it betrayed, to say the least, a confusion of thought.
('20', 309, 4, 12, 729932) Could he think of the Turkish people as apart from the Ottoman Government?
('20', 309, 4, 13, 730007) And what is the meaning of the death knell of Ottoman Dominion in Europe and Asia if it be not the death knell of Turkish rule and therefore also of the Turkish people as a free and governing race?
('20', 309, 4, 14, 730205) Is it, again, true historically that the Turkish rule has always been a blight that “has withered some of the fairest regions of the earth”?
('20', 309, 4, 15, 730346) And what is the meaning of his statement that followed, viz., “Nothing is further from our thoughts than to imitate or encourage a crusade against their belief”?
('20', 309, 4, 16, 730508) If words have any meaning, the qualifications that Mr. Asquith introduced in his speech should have meant a scrupulous regard for Indian Muslim feeling.
('20', 309, 4, 17, 730661) And if that be the meaning of his speech, without anything further to support me I would claim that even Mr. Asquith’s assurance is in danger of being set at nought if the resolutions of the San Remo
('20', 309, 5, 18, 730861) 1 Made by the Allies, for example, with Russia, Italy and the Grand Sherif of Mecca in 1915
('20', 310, 0, 1, 730953) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 311
('20', 310, 1, 2, 730993) Conference 1 are to be crystallized into action.
('20', 310, 1, 3, 731042) But I base my remarks on a considered speech made by Mr. Asquith’s successor 2 two years later when things had assumed a more threatening shape than in 1914 and when the need for Indian help was much greater than in 1914. His pledge 3 would bear repetition till it is fulfilled.
('20', 310, 1, 4, 731321) He said : Nor are we fighting to deprive Turkey of its capital or of the rich and renowned lands of Asia Minor and Thrace which are predominantly Turkish in race..
('20', 310, 1, 5, 731485) We do not challenge the maintenance of the Turkish Empire in the homeland of the Turkish race with its capital at Constantinople.
('20', 310, 1, 6, 731615) If only every word of this pledge is fulfilled both in letter and in spirit, there would be little left for quarrelling about.
('20', 310, 1, 7, 731742) In so far as Mr. Asquith’s declaration can be considered hostile to the Indian Muslim claim, it is superseded by the later and more considered declaration of Mr. Lloyd George— a declaration made irrevocable by fulfilment of the consideration it expected, viz., the enlistment of the brave Mohammedan soldiery which fought in the very place which is now being partitioned in spite of the pledge.
('20', 310, 1, 8, 732137) But the writer of “Current Topics” says Mr. Lloyd George “is now in process of keeping his pledge”.
('20', 310, 1, 9, 732237) I hope he is right.
('20', 310, 1, 10, 732257) But what has already happened gives little ground for any such hope.
('20', 310, 1, 11, 732326) For, imprisonment or internment of the Khalifa in his own capital 4 will be not only a mockery of fulfilment but it would be adding injury to insult.
('20', 310, 1, 12, 732476) Either the Turkish Empire is to be maintained in the homelands of the Turkish race with its capital at Constantinople or it is not.
('20', 310, 1, 13, 732608) If it is, let the Indian Mohammedans feel the full glow of it, or if the Empire is to be broken up, let the mask of hypocrisy be lifted and India see the truth in its nakedness.
('20', 310, 1, 14, 732786) To join the Khilafat movement then means to join a movement to keep inviolate the pledge of a British minister.
('20', 310, 1, 15, 732898) Surely, such a movement is worth much greater sacrifice than may be involved in non co operation.

('20', 311, 2, 3, 733256) May 12, 1920
('20', 311, 3, 4, 733269) An urgent meeting of the All India Khilafat Committee was held 1 in Bombay on 12th May to deliberate finally on the non co operation movement .
('20', 311, 3, 5, 733413) the Central Committee has finally unanimously decided to adopt and work a full non co operation programme as recommended by the sub committee consisting of Messrs Chhotani, Gandhi, Abul Kalam Azad and Shaukat Ali.
('20', 311, 4, 6, 733627) Mahatma Gandhi in a clear, forcible speech again explained the non co operation movement.
('20', 311, 4, 7, 733717) Its success depended on the firmness and courage of Moslems.
('20', 311, 4, 8, 733778) Their Hindu brethren would willingly support Moslems but Moslems should take the lead.
('20', 311, 4, 9, 733865) Every effort should be made to impress on all that any violence under any provocation would fatally injure the cause, while joint action was in progress.
('20', 311, 4, 10, 734019) He assured all that his wife and children would gladly sacrifice their life and all for this sacred cause.
('20', 311, 5, 11, 734126) After solemn discussion and a speech from Mr. C. Rajagopalachari the resolution 2 was unanimously and most enthusiastically adopted, all standing and calling on God to witness their firm adhesion.

('20', 316, 7, 25, 744082) 105. THE KHILAFAT
('20', 316, 8, 26, 744100) A good many questions are being raised about the Khilafat.
('20', 316, 8, 27, 744159) There is plenty of discussion in the papers too about it.
('20', 316, 8, 28, 744217) Several people express the opinion that non co operation will lead to violence, and they ask how, if that happens, we shall profit from non co operation.
('20', 316, 8, 29, 744371) As in all great ventures, there is bound to be an element of risk in
('20', 316, 9, 30, 744440) 1 From the reference to the article “Mill owners and Workers of Ahmedabad”; vide “Mill Owners and Workers of Ahmedabad”, 16 5 1920. 2 ibid
('20', 316, 10, 31, 744579) 3 Esther Faering had left for Denmark on May 19, 1920. 4 Son of Saraladevi Chowdharani
('20', 317, 0, 1, 744666) 318 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('20', 317, 1, 2, 744708) non co operation.
('20', 317, 1, 3, 744726) Life is full of experiments and risks.
('20', 317, 1, 4, 744765) Not even moksha is to be obtained without our venturing for it.
('20', 317, 1, 5, 744829) Man, full of errors, can consider only this : ‘Is there a greater risk in doing this or in not doing it?
('20', 317, 1, 6, 744934) If there is less risk in doing it, is it unavoidable for other reasons as well?’
('20', 317, 2, 7, 745015) I am convinced that, had there been no move for non co operation, violence would long since have broken out.
('20', 317, 2, 8, 745124) It is non co operation which has prevented violence.
('20', 317, 2, 9, 745177) The Muslims are boiling over, but they have kept their patience in the belief that the Hindus are with them.
('20', 317, 2, 10, 745286) When they began to suspect that, despite all this, they might not get justice, they had to think.
('20', 317, 2, 11, 745384) What should they do now?
('20', 317, 2, 12, 745409) Some thought of violence.
('20', 317, 2, 13, 745435) Some considered the unworthy idea of boycott but they realized that, even if it was right, it was not feasible.
('20', 317, 2, 14, 745547) Meanwhile, at the very first conference 1 in Delhi, I suggested non co operation.
('20', 317, 2, 15, 745629) They hailed it with one voice.
('20', 317, 2, 16, 745660) I told them that non co operation would be possible only if they gave up the idea of violence.
('20', 317, 2, 17, 745755) Even if there was a single murder by any of us or at our instance, I would leave.
('20', 317, 2, 18, 745837) They agreed, and understood that non co operation was, in many respects, a more potent weapon than violence.
('20', 317, 2, 19, 745946) This idea of non co operation was then taken up and, today, it has spread everywhere; it is only because of this that we have peace in India.
('20', 317, 2, 20, 746088) I am quite convinced that, had the Muslims not fixed their eyes on non co operation, we would now be witnessing a miserable state of affairs in India.
('20', 317, 2, 21, 746239) I think the Government would have succeeded in suppressing violence, but it would have occurred all the same.
('20', 317, 2, 22, 746349) If it occurs even in spite of non co operation, the Government will be able to suppress it.
('20', 317, 2, 23, 746441) The only question is whether it would have occurred in the absence of non co operation.
('20', 317, 2, 24, 746529) The answer to this must be in the affirmative.
('20', 317, 3, 25, 746576) So, then, we have to consider whether non co operation is necessary on other grounds.
('20', 317, 3, 26, 746662) We cannot start it simply because violence has been prevented.
('20', 317, 3, 27, 746725) Many evil things are done in this world.
('20', 317, 3, 28, 746766) Steps to prevent them suggest themselves to us, but we do not feel bound to take them.
('20', 317, 3, 29, 746853) In many places in India itself people do cruel things.
('20', 317, 3, 30, 746908) If we could have our way we would prevent them, but we do not go to these places and try.
('20', 317, 3, 31, 746998) The thing is beyond our capacity.
('20', 317, 3, 32, 747032) Sometimes it does happen that we are in a position to prevent an evil by a lesser evil, but it does not therefore become our duty to commit the lesser evil.
('20', 317, 3, 33, 747189) Hence we shall have to consider non co operation from
('20', 317, 4, 34, 747243) 1 Held on November 23 and 24, 1919
('20', 318, 0, 1, 747278) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 319
('20', 318, 1, 2, 747318) two points of view.
('20', 318, 1, 3, 747338) Is it an objectionable weapon?
('20', 318, 1, 4, 747369) I have often replied to this, that it is not so, that, on the contrary, it is one’s religious duty to non co operate on certain occasions.
('20', 318, 1, 5, 747508) In fact, there is nothing wrong in non co operation itself.
('20', 318, 1, 6, 747568) We have then to consider whether or not we should use the weapon of non co operation on this occasion.
('20', 318, 1, 7, 747671) In other words, should the Hindus help the Muslims to this extent?
('20', 318, 1, 8, 747738) One and all admit that on the Khilafat issue the Muslims are in the right.
('20', 318, 1, 9, 747813) It is the evident duty of Hindus to be with the Muslims in their suffering.
('20', 318, 1, 10, 747889) The latter have no other weapon save non co operation.
('20', 318, 1, 11, 747944) Can the Hindus then stand aloof and keep neutral?
('20', 318, 1, 12, 747994) In my humble view, the Hindus are bound to join in non co operation.

('20', 318, 2, 14, 748100) 106. WHAT SHOULD THE VOTERS DO?
('20', 318, 3, 15, 748132) Many who had hitherto no concern with Council elections will be shortly called upon to vote for the reformed Councils.
('20', 318, 3, 16, 748251) The powers, too, of elected members will be found to have increased.
('20', 318, 3, 17, 748320) 2 This adds to the voters’ responsibility.
('20', 318, 3, 18, 748363) In all our cities the citizens have been exercising the municipal franchise.
('20', 318, 3, 19, 748440) And of these elections it cannot be said that the electors have always acquitted themselves in a wise manner.
('20', 318, 3, 20, 748550) Electors’ private relations with the candidates have often weighed with them more than the candidates’ qualifications.
('20', 318, 3, 21, 748669) It would be well if we set up a better standard for the elections to the Legislative Councils.
('20', 318, 3, 22, 748764) Only thus shall we be able to make the best use of the Councils.
('20', 318, 3, 23, 748829) I suggest also that voters should not identify themselves with any party or its quarrels.
('20', 318, 3, 24, 748919) They should consider candidates’ views and not their party.
('20', 318, 3, 25, 748979) Their character should weigh more even than their views.
('20', 318, 3, 26, 749036) A man of character will make himself worthy of any position he is given.
('20', 318, 3, 27, 749109) Even his mistakes will not much matter.
('20', 318, 3, 28, 749149) I consider it impossible for a man without character to do higher national service so that if I were a voter, from among the list I would first select men of character and then I would understand their views.
('20', 318, 3, 29, 749358) My questions to them would be : 1. Do you approve of the present swadeshi movement?
('20', 318, 4, 30, 749442) 1 This translation is reproduced from Young India, 9 6 1920.
('20', 318, 5, 31, 749503) 2 Under the Reforms Act of 1919
('20', 319, 0, 1, 749535) 320 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('20', 319, 1, 2, 749577) are you prepared to levy heavy import duties on foreign cloth?
('20', 319, 1, 3, 749640) Will you favour legislation for cheapening the materials and machinery required to produce swadeshi articles?
('20', 319, 2, 4, 749750) 2. Do you hold that all the affairs of a province should be conducted in its own vernacular and that the affairs of the nation should be conducted in Hindustani—a combination of Hindi and Urdu?
('20', 319, 2, 5, 749944) If you do, will you endeavour incessantly to introduce the use of the vernaculars in the administration of the respective provinces, and the national language in the Imperial administration?
('20', 319, 3, 6, 750135) 3. Do you hold that the present division of the provinces of India was made for administrative and political purposes and that no regard was paid to the people’s wishes?
('20', 319, 3, 7, 750305) And do you hold that this division has done much harm to the national growth?
('20', 319, 3, 8, 750383) If you think so, will you try to bring out a redistribution on a linguistic basis as early as possible?
('20', 319, 4, 9, 750487) 4. Do you hold that there is not the remotest likelihood of India’s regeneration without Hindu Muslim unity?
('20', 319, 4, 10, 750596) And if you think so, are you, if a Hindu, willing to help the Mussulmans in all legitimate ways in their trouble?
('20', 319, 5, 11, 750710) A satisfactory answer to them alone will entitle the candidates to my vote if I had one.
('20', 319, 5, 12, 750799) I suggest these questions because I regard them as of great importance.
('20', 319, 5, 13, 750871) If the electors do not see any significance in these questions, they may put others which they consider to be of greater importance for the upliftment of the nation.
('20', 319, 5, 14, 751037) If is not the particular questions that matter but the knowing of candidates’ views on national questions.
('20', 319, 5, 15, 751144) My attempt is to point out that we need an electorate which is impartial, independent and intelligent.
('20', 319, 5, 16, 751247) If the electors do not interest themselves in national affairs and remain unconcerned with what goes on in their midst, and if they elect men with whom they have private relations or whose aid they need for themselves, this state of things can do no good to the country; on the contrary, it will be harmful.
('20', 319, 5, 17, 751555) Now it remains to be considered what the electors should do if they do not receive a satisfactory answer to their questions or if they cannot find men of character.
('20', 319, 5, 18, 751720) It is an established custom with regard to elections that electors, if they do not find any candidate to their
('20', 320, 0, 1, 751831) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 321
('20', 320, 1, 2, 751871) liking, need not register their votes.
('20', 320, 1, 3, 751910) In such a case abstention amounts to an exercise of one’s vote.
('20', 320, 1, 4, 751974) Exception was taken to this procedure, that if good electors refuse to make their choice bad electors would make the worst choice.
('20', 320, 1, 5, 752105) This is to a certain extent true.
('20', 320, 1, 6, 752139) But suppose in a certain place, all candidates being drunkards, the better portion of the electorate abstain from voting and the candidates manage to secure votes from their kind, can they exercise any influence in the Councils?
('20', 320, 1, 7, 752368) No doubt their vote has its numerical value, but their views and speeches cannot influence the Council.
('20', 320, 1, 8, 752472) Moreover, an intelligent abstention has its own effect.
('20', 320, 1, 9, 752528) The electors having once failed to find a proper candidate will next time take steps to find out a suitable man and elect him, and by so doing they will raise the level of their own place.
('20', 320, 1, 10, 752717) In a growing nation people are able to understand the national affairs and they are expected to purify the political atmosphere they live in and to maintain its purity.
('20', 320, 1, 11, 752886) All enlightened and thoughtful voters will find that occasionally situations must arise when they will have to purposely refuse to register their votes.
('20', 320, 1, 12, 753039) I earnestly hope that on such occasions our electors will have courage to do so.
('20', 320, 1, 13, 753120) I hope that when they do exercise the vote they will give it to the best man no matter to which party he belongs.

('20', 320, 5, 17, 753295) The reader will be glad to know that the stock of khadi which had accumulated in the Satyagraha Ashram has been entirely sold out.

('20', 320, 5, 19, 753654) So, the centres which had been asked not to send any more khadi [to the Ashram] have now resumed its supply.
('20', 320, 5, 20, 753763) Those who want to buy khadi keep asking for samples and prices, but at present we are in no position to be definite about either.

('20', 321, 1, 2, 754044) hand spinning.
