('20', 322, 3, 4, 756480) 109. MILL OWNERS AND WORKERS OF AHMEDABAD
('20', 322, 4, 5, 756522) I had hoped that I would not have to write anything about the dispute between the mill owners and the workers.
('20', 322, 4, 6, 756633) 1 But, when thousands of people stop working, I feel that as a journalist I am in duty bound to bring this matter to the notice of readers.
('20', 322, 4, 7, 756773) There are problems of which a genuine solution is rendered more difficult by public discussion.
('20', 322, 4, 8, 756869) Even so, when a situation has become the subject of talk among people, it is the duty of the journalist to put the matter before the public in its true perspective.
('20', 322, 4, 9, 757034) This is so in regard to [the conflict between] the mill owners and workers.
('20', 322, 4, 10, 757110) There are more than fifty mills in Ahmedabad.
('20', 322, 4, 11, 757156) In these mills not less than fifty thousand workers are employed.
('20', 322, 4, 12, 757222) The workers of the throstle section of the spinning departments demanded from their employers a wage of Rs. 30 and ten hours’ work instead of twelve hours’ as at present.
('20', 322, 4, 13, 757393) They submitted these demands after much thinking.
('20', 322, 4, 14, 757443) There are other demands besides these which are not in dispute.
('20', 322, 4, 15, 757507) They are, for instance, that in mills where they are not getting clean water, arrange ments should be made to supply it to them, that lavatories, if not clean, should be improved, that separate lunch rooms should be provided where they do not exist at present.
('20', 322, 4, 16, 757768) These facilities ought to be provided as a matter of course.
('20', 322, 4, 17, 757829) It is a matter of shame that they have to be asked for.
('20', 322, 4, 18, 757885) What raised a serious dispute, however, was the demand for an increase in wages and decrease of working hours.
('20', 322, 4, 19, 757996) There were consultations between the representatives of mill owners and workers.
('20', 322, 4, 20, 758077) In this the object of both parties was to avert a strike.
('20', 322, 4, 21, 758135) This could happen only in two ways : either the workers remain ignorant and do not try to understand their rights or, though knowing them, forgo them; alternatively, in case of difference of
('20', 322, 5, 22, 758326) 1 On March 31, Gandhiji had written to the mill owners requesting them to grant certain concessions to the workers.
('20', 323, 0, 1, 758442) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 324
('20', 323, 1, 2, 758484) opinion between the two parties, they go to a third party for a decision.
('20', 323, 1, 3, 758558) If this latter course is followed, the workers should be able to act unitedly.
('20', 323, 1, 4, 758637) As the mill owners need some means, a body like their Association, to speak with one voice and in concert, the workers should also have a union to represent them.
('20', 323, 1, 5, 758800) With this end in view, an effort was made to organize workers’ unions and a start was made with the workers of the throstle section.
('20', 323, 1, 6, 758933) 1 Some unions were actually formed.
('20', 323, 1, 7, 758969) If these unions function well, acting with unity of purpose and speaking with one voice, their strength will increase very much indeed and, at the same time, the members will learn to be bound by their decisions whether these are to their liking or not.
('20', 323, 1, 8, 759223) The risk is that, with the establishment of unions, the workers’ strength will increase and may be misused.
('20', 323, 1, 9, 759331) The advantage would be that the members would learn to obey rules and exercise some self restraint.
('20', 323, 1, 10, 759431) Arbitrators can be appointed and disputes settled through them only if there are such unions.
('20', 323, 1, 11, 759525) Only when this practice has taken root will there be an end to strikes.
('20', 323, 1, 12, 759597) In this case, when the workers put forth their demands as above, some mill owners wanted to refer them straightway to arbitrators for their decision.
('20', 323, 1, 13, 759747) Shri Ambalal [Sarabhai] took the lead in this.
('20', 323, 1, 14, 759794) He felt that if disputes were resolved through arbitration, strikes could be averted and the industry could be saved losses.
('20', 323, 1, 15, 759919) And so he and others, who subscribed to his view, drew up a panchanama 2 and this was signed.
('20', 323, 1, 16, 760013) Shri Mangaldas was of the view that it would be better if there was nobody between the mill owners and the workers; that this in fact would be the most honourable thing for the two parties.
('20', 323, 1, 17, 760203) Any difference of opi nion between them they should settle between themselves.
('20', 323, 1, 18, 760282) He even tried to settle matters in this way.
('20', 323, 1, 19, 760327) His great fear is that the workers are grow ing insubordinate day by day and refuse to submit to discipline.
('20', 323, 1, 20, 760436) If this went on, the industry would suffer.
('20', 323, 1, 21, 760480) Hence the workers should have train ing in securing justice by direct negotiations with the employers.
('20', 323, 1, 22, 760583) He did solve some disputes in this way.
('20', 323, 1, 23, 760623) But, finally, he also accepted to some extent the principle of arbitration in regard to the workers of the throstle section.
('20', 323, 1, 24, 760748) It was decided that a joint award by him and myself would be accepted.
('20', 323, 1, 25, 760819) This notwithstanding, Shri Ambalal’s panchanama remained,
('20', 323, 2, 26, 760877) 1Vide”Speech at Meeting of Mill hands, Ahmedabad”, 25 2 1920.

('20', 324, 0, 1, 760986) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 325
('20', 324, 1, 2, 761026) but on the understanding that, if Mangaldas’s proposal led to an agreed decision, it should be accepted by Shri Ambalal’s party.
('20', 324, 1, 3, 761155) Shri Mangaldas and I could not reach agreement up to April 25. As Shri Ambalal was proceeding to England, he decided to finalize the rates of wages in so far as he was concerned and did so in consultation with the representatives of the workers.
('20', 324, 1, 4, 761401) Shri Mangaldas was informed about them.
('20', 324, 1, 5, 761441) Thereafter we started our consultation but could not come to an agreed decision.
('20', 324, 1, 6, 761522) As a result, except in the twelve mills of Shri Ambalal’s group, there was a strike from May 9. A compromise was possible if the workers accepted something less than the wages proposed by Shri Ambalal’s group.
('20', 324, 1, 7, 761732) This, however, they could not do, since they believed that even the wages accepted by Shri Ambalal’s group were not adequate.
('20', 324, 1, 8, 761858) At length, they agreed to entrust the matter to a single arbitrator for award.
('20', 324, 1, 9, 761937) But Shri Mangaldas and I could not name such an arbitrator acceptable to both of us and so a strike has started.
('20', 324, 1, 10, 762050) My only wish is that the workers should preserve complete peace despite the strike, that the mill owners, too, should take alm thought and do only what is right and proper.
('20', 324, 1, 11, 762223) I see no need, just now, to answer questions like these : whether or not the demands of the workers are justified, whether they have erred in doing what they have done, whether the decision of the Ambalal group to appoint arbitrators was proper, whether there was any principle at stake in Shri Mangaldas’s party fighting for a modification of rates by a small percentage, whether it was right of me to have associated myself with both panchas.
('20', 324, 1, 12, 762668) For the present, I think it would be better not to go deeply into disputed matters so that a favourable atmosphere might be created for ending the strike without untoward incidents and for the resumption of work by the mill hands.

('20', 324, 2, 14, 762936) 110. MORE THOUGHTS ABOUT WIDOWS
('20', 324, 3, 15, 762968) The ideal of widowhood is one of the glories of the Hindu religion.
('20', 324, 3, 16, 763036) If the vow of unswerving devotion to the husband has any meaning, it is that, once a woman has, with full knowledge, accepted and looked upon a man as her husband, even when he has died she should cherish his memory and rest in it, nay, find joy in it.
('20', 324, 3, 17, 763289) It is by living in this way that thousands of widows in India have become
('20', 325, 0, 1, 763363) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 326
('20', 325, 1, 2, 763405) sacred names worthy of remembrance in one’s morning prayers.
('20', 325, 1, 3, 763466) Only recently I had occasion to call on Ganga swarup 1 Ramabai Ranade 2 and saw her in her own room.
('20', 325, 1, 4, 763567) In the centre of the room, I saw a couch, with a portrait of the late Justice Ranade placed on it.
('20', 325, 1, 5, 763666) I understood its significance but to make sure I asked her why the portrait was kept there.
('20', 325, 1, 6, 763758) She replied :”Well, this was his couch; it was on this that he generally sat and so I have reserved it for his portrait.
('20', 325, 1, 7, 763879) I pass my day and also sleep at night under its shadow.” I was filled with joy to hear these holy words and I understood the glory of widowhood the better.
('20', 325, 1, 8, 764035) I know that chaste and devoted wives like Ramabai are to be found everywhere in India.
('20', 325, 1, 9, 764122) But where shall we find men with the ideal of devotion to one wife?
('20', 325, 1, 10, 764190) If there are none such, are the men merely to honour chaste and devoted wives and be satisfied with that; should they not honour such wives by themselves following with absolute firmness the ideal of devotion to one wife?
('20', 325, 1, 11, 764412) What can be better worship than emulation?
('20', 325, 1, 12, 764455) Where, on the contrary, there is not the slightest desire to emulate, what value is to be put upon mere lip worship?
('20', 325, 1, 13, 764572) I have been in India for five years and have gathered a good deal of experience of every aspect of Indian life.
('20', 325, 1, 14, 764684) I have seen many a young man generally considered to have good character and to all appearances bearing great love for his wife, getting engaged and marrying soon after the wife dies.
('20', 325, 1, 15, 764868) And this has pained me a great deal.
('20', 325, 1, 16, 764905) If we had not been slaves of certain customs, the very idea that a man who had lost his wife should, even before he has returned home from the cremation, think of remarriage would be harrowing.
('20', 325, 1, 17, 765099) Actually, the mother wishes to see her widowed son married again at the earliest.
('20', 325, 1, 18, 765181) Even the mother in law encourages her widowed son in law to get married and the son in law is not in the least embarrassed when so advised.
('20', 325, 1, 19, 765321) What is the meaning of such a man shedding tears [over his dead wife]?
('20', 325, 1, 20, 765392) What is the value of innumerable efforts such a man may make to perpetuate the memory of his former wife?
('20', 325, 1, 21, 765498) Again, how much value should the new wife attach to the love which he may shower on her?
('20', 325, 1, 22, 765587) How can such a life be considered as guided by thought?
('20', 325, 1, 23, 765643) I see nothing but wickedness in it and, as long as men do not mind being thus brazen faced, to praise widowhood seems to me sheer hypocrisy and the very height of selfishness on their part.
('20', 325, 2, 24, 765833) 1 Literally, in a state like Ganga’s.
('20', 325, 2, 25, 765871) According to the Mahabharata, the sacred river took human form and lived as wife of King Shantanu for some time.
('20', 325, 2, 26, 765984) Among Hindus, the term is prefixed to the name of a widow.
('20', 325, 3, 27, 766043) 2 Widow of Justice Mahadev Govind Ranade who died in 1901; a social reformer of Maharashtra
('20', 326, 0, 1, 766135) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 327
('20', 326, 1, 2, 766175) A man who has been a friend to his wife for some years, has shared her joy and sorrow, has enjoyed life with her, should he not observe mourning even as long as one does on the death of a mere friend?
('20', 326, 1, 3, 766376) Even in England, where widows can remarry, a woman of good family does not, maybe for fear of public opinion, venture to seek another man’s company for a period of one year.
('20', 326, 1, 4, 766550) The nobility of an Indian husband, however, does not last beyond the cremation ground and, at times, in the very precincts of the crematorium, even as the body of his holy wife is being consumed to ashes on the pyre, his relatives do not hesitate to propose to him remarriage and the widowed man feels no shame in lending his ear to such talk.
('20', 326, 1, 5, 766894) It is essential that India saves herself from this pitiable plight.
('20', 326, 1, 6, 766962) I see man’s selfishness, conscious or otherwise, even in the movement for encouraging widows to remarry.
('20', 326, 1, 7, 767067) By helping them to do so, men want to forget their own shame.
('20', 326, 1, 8, 767129) If men believe that widows really suffer, they can help the latter to forget that suffering by themselves following uncompromisingly the ideal of taking only one wife.
('20', 326, 1, 9, 767297) In such matters, public opinion has become so feeble that I have seen, all over India, educated men of noble families entering into ill matched unions or, on the death of their wife, remarrying immediately.
('20', 326, 1, 10, 767504) Whether or not men do their duty, why should the women not have their rights?
('20', 326, 1, 11, 767582) Women must have voting rights, by all means : but what will women, who do not understand what rights are or, if they understand them, do not have the strength to secure them, do with voting rights?
('20', 326, 1, 12, 767780) Let them have these rights, there is no harm in that; let them become members of legislatures in India; but the foremost duty of women is to save themselves from the intentional or unintentional tyranny of men and make India glorious and strong.
('20', 326, 1, 13, 768026) It is only when an ignorant woman is ready to sacrifice her equally ignorant daughter to the fire of a recent widower’s lust that the man, whose tears of grief on the loss of his wife have not yet dried, can think of remarrying.
('20', 326, 1, 14, 768255) For my part, I believe that it is women’s right, nay, it is a duty they owe to themselves, to their menfolk and to India, to bring about reforms of this kind.

('20', 329, 5, 10, 772284) 114. PRESS STATEMENT ON TURKISH PEACE TERMS
('20', 329, 6, 11, 772328) The Turkish terms 1 are admittedly a staggering blow to the Indian Mussulmans.
('20', 329, 6, 12, 772407) In spite of the claim made in the Government communique that the peace terms are a fulfilment of Mr. Lloyd George’s pledge of 5th January, 1918, it is in my opinion not a true fulfilment either of the letter or the spirit of the pledge.
('20', 329, 6, 13, 772644) However, what to do now is the question.
('20', 329, 6, 14, 772685) I hope that the Mohammedans will not lose self control nor give way to despair.
('20', 329, 6, 15, 772765) Given an adequate measure of intelligent self sacrifice, I have no doubt that it is possible to secure justice.
('20', 329, 6, 16, 772877) There is no sacred character about the peace terms.
('20', 329, 6, 17, 772929) They are capable of being revised.
('20', 329, 6, 18, 772964) The only question is whether the Mohammedans can exercise full self control and at the same time undergo considerable amount of self sacrifice.
('20', 329, 6, 19, 773108) Any outbreak of violence will, undoubtedly, spoil what is a good cause.
('20', 329, 6, 20, 773180) I am convinced that non co operation is the only effective remedy both for avoiding violence and for healing the wound inflicted on Mohammedan India.
('20', 329, 6, 21, 773330) If other Indians and Englishmen would make common cause with their Mussulman fellow subjects the task will be easy and it will ensure non violence in the land.
('20', 329, 6, 22, 773490) I trust that the Khilafat Committee will call immediately a joint conference of Hindus and Mohammedans to consider the steps to be taken with a view to concerted action being taken for securing a revision of the terms in consistence with the pledged word of British ministers and the known religious sentiment of Indian Mussulmans.
('20', 329, 6, 23, 773822) The Bombay Chronicle, 18 5 1920
('20', 329, 7, 24, 773854) 1Vide Appendix”Turkish Peace Terms”, before 3 6 1920.

('20', 331, 1, 2, 775553) 116. SWADESHI DAY BY DAY 1
('20', 331, 2, 3, 775580) Readers of Young India will be agreeably surprised to learn that the article 2 about khaddar has not only resulted in complete disposal of the stock that had accumulated at the Ashram, but it has evoked orders from Baluchistan, the Nilgiris, and even Aden.
('20', 331, 2, 4, 775837) This is as it should be.
('20', 331, 2, 5, 775862) The revival of the ancient cottage industry of India— hand spinning during leisure hours in their own homes by the millions of women, and hand weaving in similar circumstances by men—cannot but produce a silent yet effective revolution in this country and prevent an annual drain of crores of rupees which need never have left India and distribute the sav ings among the poor millions instead of concentrating them in the hands of a few capitalists.
('20', 331, 2, 6, 776312) This is not to say that we do not want capitalists in India.
('20', 331, 2, 7, 776373) They are there already.
('20', 331, 2, 8, 776397) They are able to take care of themselves.
('20', 331, 2, 9, 776439) It is the poor millions who need to be lifted up from grinding poverty and consequent degradation.
('20', 331, 2, 10, 776538) Nothing but a full revival of the hand spinning and the hand weaving industry can raise them effectively and speedily.
('20', 331, 2, 11, 776657) It is to be hoped therefore that the demand for khaddar being proved, its production will be stimulated in every nook and corner of India.
('20', 331, 3, 12, 776796) The most wonderful experience, however, of the popularity of swadeshi has been that of Shrimati Sarladevi Chowdhrani and Mrs. Mohani, the wife of that sincere and indefatigable worker, Maulana Hasrat Mohani.
('20', 331, 3, 13, 777004) Writing from Lahore whilst preparing to go to Bareilly, where she had to go to attend the Khilafat Conference 3 , the former says :
('20', 331, 4, 14, 777136) I have done my packing racked with conflicts as to what to take and what not to take with me—whether to wear khaddar dress there while addressing the audience or swadeshi silk, the point of which will not be so well understood— whether to take up the trunk or to wrap up the holdall with clothes inside the bedding—whether to be smart and fashionable as of old or to be simple and common only.
('20', 331, 4, 15, 777530) I have at last chosen to be the latter.
('20', 331, 4, 16, 777570) But it is taking time and trouble to assimilate the new method.
('20', 331, 5, 17, 777634) 1 This article has been identified as Gandhiji’s from the draft in his hand preserved in the Gandhi Smarak Nidhi.
('20', 331, 5, 18, 777748) 2 Vide ”The Uses of Khaddar”, 28 4 1920.
('20', 331, 6, 19, 777789) 3 Held on May 3, 1920
('20', 332, 0, 1, 777811) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 20 JULY, 1920 333
('20', 332, 1, 2, 777854) Writing after her experiences of Bareilly, she says :
('20', 332, 2, 3, 777908) Just coming back from visits to Mohammedan families.
('20', 332, 2, 4, 777961) There were two ladies— wife and sister in one place.
('20', 332, 2, 5, 778014) They took the vow for charkha and swadeshi.
('20', 332, 2, 6, 778058) In another place there were six ladies who all took the same vow.
('20', 332, 2, 7, 778124) It was a family of Cutchi Bohras 1, very rich and cultured, settled down here since the days of the Mutiny.
('20', 332, 2, 8, 778232) I find I can do the swadeshi and charkha propaganda to perfection in these provinces.
('20', 332, 2, 9, 778318) My swadeshi dress is having its effect.
('20', 332, 2, 10, 778358) At a meeting called in Bareilly by Mrs. Mohani, fifteen Mohammedan ladies took the swadeshi vow.
('20', 332, 2, 11, 778455) Speaking to the Bareilly divisional conference in Hindustani on a resolution on swadeshi, she laid stress upon the deep poverty of India and her two chief wants—food and raiment—and she said that if we did not know how to manage our own homes and could not make the two ends meet, we would be ill fitted to undertake the management of the national affairs.
('20', 332, 2, 12, 778812) It was remarkable, she added, that whilst the people were ready to listen to speeches which required from them no action and no sacrifice they were chary of attending meetings where they were told home truths and which drew their attention to their primary duty of attending to swadeshi at all costs.
('20', 332, 2, 13, 779113) She asked them to work in the spirit of the late Vidyasagar 2, who was not only not ashamed of but took pride in wearing throughout his life khaddar cloth.
('20', 332, 2, 14, 779269) She admitted that return to khaddar was difficult, but all upward move ments were so.
('20', 332, 2, 15, 779355) India would never be able to produce the beautiful cloth she did before, until she resolutely refused to use silks from China, Japan, France and elsewhere, and was content in the interval to wear cloth made out of coarse yarn that daughters of India were able to produce today.
('20', 332, 2, 16, 779633) Her poverty and her nakedness, too, left no option to those who realized the actual condition of the country.
('20', 332, 2, 17, 779743) She appealed to those on the platform to lead the way, emphasizing her admonition by quoting :
('20', 332, 4, 18, 779838) The Chowdharis 4 had not much time left to them to test the truth
('20', 332, 5, 19, 779904) 1 A Muslim community from Cutch, in Gujarat 2 Ishwarchandra Vidyasagar (1820 1901); Sanskrit scholar and social reformer of Bengal 3 What the eminent man does, others do.
('20', 332, 5, 20, 780075) The standard he sets up, the rest of the world follows.
('20', 332, 5, 21, 780131) Bhagavad Gita, III, 21. 4 Sarladevi and her husband

('20', 333, 1, 2, 780225) of the above remarks in their own home, for they had to prepare dresses for their eldest son whose marriage was to take place on the 14th instant.
('20', 333, 1, 3, 780372) Pandit Rambhuj Dutt Chowdhari writes :

('20', 333, 3, 8, 780589) 117. SOME QUESTIONS ANSWERED
('20', 333, 4, 9, 780618) I write to thank you for yours of the 7th instant and especially for your request that I should, after reading your writings in Young India on non co operation, give a full and frank criticism of them.
('20', 333, 4, 10, 780820) I know that your sole desire is to find out the truth and to act accordingly, and hence I venture to make the following remarks.
('20', 333, 4, 11, 780949) In the issue of May 5th you say that non co operation is”not even anti Government”.
('20', 333, 4, 12, 781033) 1 But surely to refuse to have anything to do with the Government to the extent of not serving it and of not paying its taxes is actually, if not theoretically, anti Government; and such a course must ultimately make all government impossible.
('20', 333, 4, 13, 781277) Again, you say,”It is the inherent right of a subject to refuse to assist a government that will not listen to him.” 2 Leaving aside the question of the ethical soundness of this proposition, may I ask which government, in the present case?
('20', 333, 4, 14, 781518) Has not the Indian Government done all it possibly can in the matter?
('20', 333, 4, 15, 781588) Then if its attempts to voice the request of India should fail, would it be fair and just to do anything against it?
('20', 333, 4, 16, 781705) Would not the proper course be non co operation with the Supreme Council of the Allies, including Great Britain, if it be found that the latter has failed properly to support the demand of the Indian Government and people?
('20', 333, 4, 17, 781928) It seems to me that in all your writings and speeches you forget that in the present question both Government and people are at one, and if they fail to get what they justly want, how does the question of non co operation arise?
('20', 333, 4, 18, 782157) Hindus and Englishmen and the Government are all at present”shouldering in a full hearted manner the burden the Mohammedans of India are carrying,” 3 etc., etc.
('20', 333, 4, 19, 782318) But supposing we fail of our object—what then?
('20', 333, 4, 20, 782365) Are we all to refuse to co operate and with whom?
('20', 333, 5, 21, 782415) Might I recommend the consideration of the following course of conduct?
('20', 333, 6, 22, 782487) 1.”Wait and see” what the actual terms of the Treaty with Turkey are.
('20', 333, 7, 23, 782557) 2. If they are not in accordance with the aspirations and recommendations of the Government and the people of India, then every legitimate effort should be made to have the terms revised.
('20', 333, 8, 24, 782745) 1Vide”How to Work Non co operation”, 5 5 1920. 2 ibid 3 ibid
('20', 334, 0, 1, 782806) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 335
('20', 334, 1, 2, 782846) 3. To the bitter end, co operate with a Government that co operates with us, and only when it refuses co operation, go in for non co operation.
('20', 334, 2, 3, 782990) So far I personally see no reason whatsoever for non co operation with the Indian Government, and till it fails to voice the needs and demands of India as a whole there can be no reason.
('20', 334, 2, 4, 783177) The Indian Government does sometimes make mistakes, but in the Khilafat matter it is sound and therefore deserves or ought to have the sympathetic and whole hearted co operation of every one in India.
('20', 334, 2, 5, 783378) I hope that you will kindly consider the above and perhaps you will be able to find time for a reply in Young India.
('20', 334, 3, 6, 783495) I gladly make room for the above letter and respond to the suggestion to give a public reply as no doubt the difficulty experienced by the English friend is experienced by many.
('20', 334, 3, 7, 783673) Causes are generally lost, not owing to the determined opposition of men who will not see the truth as they want to perpetuate an injustice but because they are able to enlist in their favour the allegiance of those who are anxious to understand a particular cause and take sides after mature judgment.
('20', 334, 3, 8, 783976) It is only by patient argument with such honest men that one is able to check oneself, correct one’s own errors of judgment and at times to wean them from their error and bring them over to one’s side.
('20', 334, 3, 9, 784178) This Khilafat question is specially difficult because there are so many side issues.
('20', 334, 3, 10, 784263) It is therefore no wonder that many have more or less difficulty in making up their minds.
('20', 334, 3, 11, 784354) It is further complicated because the painful necessity for some direct action has arisen in connection with it.
('20', 334, 3, 12, 784467) But whatever the difficulty, I am convinced that there is no question so important as this one if we want harmony and peace in India.
('20', 334, 4, 13, 784601) My friend objects to my statement that non co operation is not anti Government, because he considers that refusal to serve it and pay its taxes is actually anti Government.
('20', 334, 4, 14, 784774) I respectfully dissent from the view.
('20', 334, 4, 15, 784812) If a brother has fundamental differences with his brother, and association with the latter involves his partaking of what in his opinion is an injustice, I hold that it is brotherly duty to refrain from serving his brother and sharing his earnings with him.
('20', 334, 4, 16, 785070) This happens in everyday life.
('20', 334, 4, 17, 785101) Prahlad did not act against his father, when he declined to associate himself with the latter’s blasphemies.
('20', 334, 4, 18, 785210) Nor was Jesus anti Jewish when he declaimed against the Pharisees and the hypocrites, and would have none of them.
('20', 334, 4, 19, 785325) In such matters, is it not the intention that determines the character of a particular act?
('20', 334, 4, 20, 785417) It is hardly correct as
('20', 335, 0, 1, 785441) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 336
('20', 335, 1, 2, 785483) the friend suggests that withdrawal of association under general circumstances would make all government impossible.
('20', 335, 1, 3, 785600) But it is true that such withdrawal would make all injustice impossible.
('20', 335, 1, 4, 785673) My correspondent considers that the Government of India having done all it possibly could, non co operation could not be applicable to that Government.
('20', 335, 1, 5, 785825) In my opinion, whilst it is true that the Government of India has done a great deal, it has not done half as much as it might have done, and might even now do.
('20', 335, 1, 6, 785985) No government can absolve itself from further action beyond protesting, when it realizes that the people whom it represents feel as keenly as do lakhs of Indian Mussulmans in the Khilafat question.
('20', 335, 1, 7, 786183) No amount of sympathy with a starving man can possibly avail.
('20', 335, 1, 8, 786245) He must have bread or he dies, and what is wanted at that critical moment is some exertion to fetch the wherewithal to feed the dying man.
('20', 335, 1, 9, 786384) The Government of India can today head the agitation and ask, to the point of insistence, for full vindication of the pledged word of a British Minister.
('20', 335, 1, 10, 786538) Has the Government of India resigned by way of protest against the threatened, shameful betrayal of trust on the part of Mr. Lloyd George?
('20', 335, 1, 11, 786677) Why does the Government of India hide itself behind secret despatches?
('20', 335, 1, 12, 786748) At a less critical moment Lord Hardinge committed a constitutional indiscretion, 1 openly sympathized with the South African passive resistance movement and stemmed the surging tide of public indignation in India, though at the same time he incurred the wrath of the then South African Cabinet and some public men in Great Britain.
('20', 335, 1, 13, 787080) After all, the utmost that the Government of India has done is, on its own showing, to transmit and press the Mohammedan claim.
('20', 335, 1, 14, 787208) Was that not the least it could have done?
('20', 335, 1, 15, 787251) Could it have done anything less without covering itself with disgrace?
('20', 335, 1, 16, 787323) What Indian Mohammedans and the Indian public expect the Government of India to do at this critical juncture is not the least, but the utmost that it could do.
('20', 335, 1, 17, 787483) Viceroys have been known to tender resignations for much smaller causes.
('20', 335, 1, 18, 787556) Wounded pride brought forth not very long ago the resignation of a Lieutenant Governor.
('20', 335, 1, 19, 787644) On the Khilafat question, a sacred cause dear to the hearts of several million Mohammedans is in danger of being wounded.
('20', 335, 1, 20, 787766) I would therefore invite the English friend, and every Englishman in India, and every Hindu, be he moderate or extremist, to make common cause with the Mohammedans and thereby compel the Government of India to do its duty, and thereby
('20', 335, 2, 21, 788001) 1Vide”Lord Hardinge’s Speech”, 3 12 1913.
('20', 336, 0, 1, 788043) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 337
('20', 336, 1, 2, 788083) compel His Majesty’s Ministers to do theirs.
('20', 336, 1, 3, 788128) There has been much talk of violence ensuing from active non co operation.
('20', 336, 1, 4, 788203) I venture to suggest that the Mussulmans of India, if they had nothing in the shape of non co operation in view, would have long ago yielded to counsels of despair.
('20', 336, 1, 5, 788368) I admit that non co operation is not unattended with danger.
('20', 336, 1, 6, 788429) But violence is a certainty without, violence is only a possibility with, non co operation.
('20', 336, 1, 7, 788521) And it will be greater possibility if all the important men, English, Hindu and others of the country, discountenance it.
('20', 336, 2, 8, 788643) I think that the recommendation made by the friend is being literally followed by the Mohammedans.
('20', 336, 2, 9, 788742) Although they practically know the fate, they are waiting for the actual terms of the treaty with Turkey.
('20', 336, 2, 10, 788848) They are certainly going to try every means at their disposal to have the terms revised before beginning non co operation.
('20', 336, 2, 11, 788971) And there will certainly be no non co operation commenced so long as there is even hope of active co operation on the part of the Government of India with the Mohammedans, that is, co operation strong enough to secure a revision of the terms should they be found to be in conflict with the pledges of British statesmen.
('20', 336, 2, 12, 789291) But if all these things fail, can Mohammedans as men of honour who hold their religion dearer than lives do anything less than wash their hands clean of the guilt of British Ministers and the Government of India by refusing to co operate with them?
('20', 336, 2, 13, 789540) And can Hindus and Englishmen, if they value Mohammedan friendship, and if they admit the full justice of the Mohammedan claim, do otherwise than heartily support the Mohammedans by word and deed?
('20', 336, 3, 14, 789737) Young India, 19 5 1920
('20', 336, 4, 15, 789760) 118. PLEDGES BROKEN
('20', 336, 5, 16, 789780) After the foregoing 1 was printed the long expected peace terms regarding Turkey 2 were received.
('20', 336, 5, 17, 789878) In my humble opinion, they are humiliating to the Supreme Council 3, to the British Ministers, and if as a Hindu with deep reverence for Christianity I may say so, a denial of Christ’s teachings.
('20', 336, 5, 18, 790074) Turkey broken down and torn with dissensions within may submit to the arrogant disposal of herself, and Indian
('20', 336, 6, 19, 790185) 1Vide the preceding item.
('20', 336, 6, 20, 790211) 2Vide Appendix”Turkish Peace Terms”, before 3 6 1920.
('20', 336, 7, 21, 790265) 3 Of the Allies
('20', 337, 0, 1, 790281) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 338
('20', 337, 1, 2, 790323) Mohammedans may out of fear do likewise.
('20', 337, 1, 3, 790364) Hindus out of fear, apathy or want of appreciation of the situation, may refuse to help their Mohammedan brethren in their hour of peril.
('20', 337, 1, 4, 790502) The fact remains that a solemn promise of the Prime Minister of England has been wantonly broken.
('20', 337, 1, 5, 790600) I will say nothing about President Wilson’s fourteen points 1 , for they seem now to be entirely forgotten as a day’s wonder.
('20', 337, 1, 6, 790726) It is a matter of deep sorrow that the Government of India communique offers a defence of the terms, calls them a fulfilment of Mr. Lloyd George’s pledge of 5th January, 1918, and yet apologizes for their defective nature and appeals to the Mohammedans of India, as if to mock them, that they would accept the terms with quiet resignation.
('20', 337, 1, 7, 791066) The mask that veils the hypocrisy is too thin to deceive anybody.
('20', 337, 1, 8, 791132) It would have been dignified if the communique had boldly admitted Mr. Lloyd George’s mistake in having made the promise referred to.
('20', 337, 1, 9, 791266) As it is, the claim of fulfilment of the promise only adds to the irritation caused by its glaring breach.
('20', 337, 1, 10, 791373) What is the use of the Viceroy, saying,”The question of the Khilafat is one for the Mohammedans and Mohammedans only and that with their free choice in the matter Government have no desire to interfere,” while the Khalif’s dominions are ruthlessly dismembered, his control of the holy places of Islam shamelessly taken away from him and he himself reduced to utter impotence in his own palace which can no longer be called a palace but which can be more fitly described as a prison?
('20', 337, 1, 11, 791856) No wonder His Excellency fears that the peace includes”terms which must be painful to all Moslems”.
('20', 337, 1, 12, 791956) Why should he insult Muslim intelligence by sending the Mussulmans of India a message 2 of encouragement and sympathy?
('20', 337, 1, 13, 792075) Are they expected to find encouragement in the cruel recital of the arrogant terms or in a remembrance of ‘the splendid response’ made by them to the call of the King ‘in the day of the Empire’s need’?
('20', 337, 1, 14, 792277) It ill becomes His Excellency to talk of the triumph of those ideals of justice and humanity for which the Allies fought.
('20', 337, 1, 15, 792399) Indeed, the terms of the so called peace with Turkey, if they are to last, will be a monument of human arrogance and man made injustice.
('20', 337, 1, 16, 792536) To attempt to crush the spirit of a brave and gallant race, because it has lost in the fortunes of war, is a triumph not of humanity but a demonstration of inhumanity.
('20', 337, 2, 17, 792704) 1 Accepted by the Allies as the basis of peace on January 4, 1918 2 Published on May 14, 1920; vide Appendix”Viceroy’s Message to Muslims of India”, before 3 6 1920.
('20', 338, 0, 1, 792870) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 339
('20', 338, 1, 2, 792910) And if Turkey enjoyed the closest ties of friendship with Great Britain before the War, Great Britain has certainly made ample reparation for her mistake by having made the largest contribution to the humiliation of Turkey.
('20', 338, 1, 3, 793134) It is insufferable therefore when the Viceroy feels confident that with the conclusion of this new treaty that friendship will quickly take life again and a Turkey regenerate, full of hope and strength, will stand forth in the future, as in the past, a pillar of the Islamic faith.
('20', 338, 1, 4, 793416) The Viceregal message audaciously concludes,”This thought will, I trust, strengthen you to accept the peace terms with resignation, courage and fortitude and to keep your loyalty towards the Crown bright and untarnished as it has been for so many generations.” If Muslim loyalty remains untarnished it will certainly not be for want of effort on the part of the Government of India to put the heaviest strain upon it, but it will remain so because the Mohammedans realize their own strength—the strength in the knowledge that their cause is just and that they have got the power to vindicate justice in spite of the aberration suffered by Great Britain under a Prime Minister whom continued power has made as reckless in making promises as in breaking them.
('20', 338, 1, 5, 794174) Whilst therefore I admit that there is nothing either in the peace terms or in the Viceregal message covering them to inspire Mohammedans and Indians in general with confidence or hope, I venture to suggest that there is no cause for despair or anger.
('20', 338, 1, 6, 794426) Now is the time for Mohammedans to retain absolute self control, to unite their forces and, weak though they are, with firm faith in God to carry on the struggle with redoubled vigour till justice is done.
('20', 338, 1, 7, 794632) If India— both Hindu and Mohammedan—can act as one man and can withdraw her partnership in this crime against humanity which the peace terms represent, she will soon secure a revision of the treaty and give herself and the Empire at least, if not the world, a lasting peace.
('20', 338, 1, 8, 794907) There is no doubt that the struggle would be bitter, sharp and possibly prolonged, but it is worth all the sacrifice that it is likely to call forth.
('20', 338, 1, 9, 795057) Both the Mussulmans and the Hindus are on their trial.
('20', 338, 1, 10, 795112) Is the humiliation of the Khilafat a matter of concern to the former?
('20', 338, 1, 11, 795182) And if it is, are they prepared to exercise restraint, religiously refrain from violence and practise non co operation without counting the material loss it may entail upon the community?
('20', 338, 1, 12, 795370) Do the Hindus honestly feel for their Mohammedan brethren to the extent of sharing their sufferings to the fullest extent?
('20', 338, 1, 13, 795493) The answer to these questions, and not the peace terms, will finally decide the fate of the Khilafat.
('20', 338, 1, 14, 795595) Young India, 19 5 1920

('20', 343, 6, 21, 803344) 128. WHAT SHALL WE DO NOW?
('20', 343, 7, 22, 803371) The peace terms have been announced.
('20', 343, 7, 23, 803408) We understand the English term peace to mean the treaty which ends fighting.
('20', 343, 7, 24, 803485) But it also means quiet.
('20', 343, 7, 25, 803510) If the terms which are announced had been described as the terms of war, the description would have been truer to facts.
('20', 343, 7, 26, 803631) But, as was said in ridicule of the late Mr. Gladstone by an equally great man, the late Mr. Disraeli, language was invented not to express men’s thoughts but to conceal them.
('20', 343, 7, 27, 803807) That remark is perfectly applicable to the peace terms now announced.
('20', 343, 7, 28, 803877) To say that there is peace where one
('20', 343, 8, 29, 803914) 1 As noted by the addressee 2 In connection with the conference on the Khilafat issue to be held at Allahabad; vide”Telegram to Shaukat Ali”, 22 5 1920.
('20', 344, 0, 1, 804067) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 345
('20', 344, 1, 2, 804107) party forces the other to agree to something against its will, crushes it under its brute strength, is a grave offence against Satyanarayan 1 .
('20', 344, 2, 3, 804251) And yet the Supreme Council has framed such terms and sent them to Turkey.
('20', 344, 2, 4, 804326) It has, by doing so, disgraced the epithet it uses to describe itself.
('20', 344, 2, 5, 804397) For a council which ignores justice and, blinded by its strength, wishes to describe injustice as justice, to call itself supreme is to add insult to injury.
('20', 344, 2, 6, 804555) The peace terms may be said to have completely violated the pledges given by British Ministers.
('20', 344, 2, 7, 804651) The promise was to the effect that the Turkish Empire would be preserved intact in Asia and Europe, wherever there were communities of Turks.
('20', 344, 2, 8, 804793) But the Turkish Empire has been preserved only in name.
('20', 344, 2, 9, 804849) In fact, the Supreme Council has, as it were, imprisoned the Sultan in his own palace.
('20', 344, 2, 10, 804936) This amounts to torturing the Turks by constantly reminding them of their past glory.
('20', 344, 2, 11, 805022) There was hope that the holy places of Islam would remain under the control of the Khalifa.
('20', 344, 2, 12, 805114) Actually, he has been deprived of his suzerainty over these holy places as also over the peninsula which Muslims know as Jazirat ul Arab; in all this, there is not even a trace of justice or truth.
('20', 344, 2, 13, 805312) Its being described, nevertheless, as justice is the very limit of man’s pride and haughtiness, his reliance on brute strength.
('20', 344, 2, 14, 805440) If such one sided terms can be described as just, many things in the world which we usually know as injustice will have to be considered just.
('20', 344, 3, 15, 805583) And yet His Excellency the Viceroy, addressing the Muslims, 2
('20', 344, 4, 16, 805645) tells them that they should remain peaceful, that what now remains leaves room for hope and so they should take heart, rather than fall into despair.
('20', 344, 4, 17, 805795) They should remember [he says] the old friendship between England and Turkey, and now that the peace terms have brought about a reunion, they should cement the new friendship and help in creating a new and glorious Turkey.
('20', 344, 4, 18, 806018) These words of His Excellency are like branding again a man who has received burns.
('20', 344, 4, 19, 806102) What should one do in this difficult situation?
('20', 344, 4, 20, 806150) If the Muslims sit still, all that they have done during the last four years will be proved to have been hollow.
('20', 344, 4, 21, 806263) If the Muslims have no peace, Hindus can have none, and vice versa—such is the law of friendship.
('20', 344, 4, 22, 806361) If, losing our peace of mind in this way, we give way to anger and, getting excited, take to violence, we shall have lost the game.
('20', 344, 4, 23, 806493) If we refrain from
('20', 344, 5, 24, 806512) 1 God in the form of Truth 2 In his message of May 14, 1920; vide Appendix”Viceroy’s Message to Muslims of India”, before 3 6 1920.
('20', 345, 0, 1, 806644) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 346
('20', 345, 1, 2, 806686) violence, however, and show that we have the strength for self sacrifice, we need not at all conclude that we have lost the game.
('20', 345, 1, 3, 806816) The Muslims and the rest of the country need not at all be shocked that the peace terms have been finalized.
('20', 345, 1, 4, 806925) If India does her duty, these terms will certainly be revised.
('20', 345, 1, 5, 806988) There is no reason to doubt this.
('20', 345, 1, 6, 807022) To get these terms revised, India has only one thing at her disposal and that is non co operation.
('20', 345, 1, 7, 807121) Non co operation has now become a duty because, if we do not start it, India will have been party to this injustice.
('20', 345, 1, 8, 807238) The Bri tish Empire is alive only because of the co operation of all its subjects.
('20', 345, 1, 9, 807321) In everything it does, the Empire must have co operation, whether the co operation is given willingly or otherwise.
('20', 345, 1, 10, 807437) The chief manifestation of satyagraha is refusal to submit to compulsion.
('20', 345, 1, 11, 807511) Hence, wherever the people have even a little of satyagraha in them, they refuse to submit to compulsion and the rulers may manage such satyagrahi subjects by cajoling, that is, by pleasing them.
('20', 345, 1, 12, 807707) On this issue of the Khilafat, the people should not submit to force nor allow themselves to be won over by cajoling.
('20', 345, 1, 13, 807825) Hence, if the feelings of the Muslims have been really hurt, at any rate they cannot co operate with the Empire.
('20', 345, 1, 14, 807938) If the Muslims cannot, how can the Hindus?
('20', 345, 1, 15, 807981) A meeting of leading Hindus and Muslims is to be held shortly to consider when and how to start non co operation.
('20', 345, 1, 16, 808095) 1 If the decisions of this meeting are enthusiastically accepted by the people, we shall produce good from what seems evil today.
('20', 345, 1, 17, 808225) Meanwhile, the people should show the utmost patience and wait.
('20', 345, 1, 18, 808289) That will be tapascharya 2 for them.
('20', 345, 1, 19, 808326) This great issue, however, raises many secondary issues.
('20', 345, 1, 20, 808383) Some of these deserve attention.
('20', 345, 1, 21, 808416) People from a number of places have strongly urged on me the inadvisability of non co operation and the risks involved in it.
('20', 345, 1, 22, 808542) Hence, thinking that the answers I have given to some friends who have advised me deserve to be read by readers of Navajivan as well, I give here the substance of a letter from an English friend and of my reply to him.
('20', 345, 2, 23, 808761) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 23 5 1920

('20', 346, 0, 1, 809147) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 347
('20', 346, 1, 2, 809187) 129. IMPORTANCE OF KHADI
('20', 346, 2, 3, 809212) The reader will be glad to know that we have been receiving orders for khadi from all over India.
('20', 346, 2, 4, 809310) All the stocks of khadi have been sold out and orders are still pouring in.
('20', 346, 2, 5, 809386) But people should not understand from this that one should order no more khadi.
('20', 346, 2, 6, 809466) Because people had lost faith in it, the production of khadi has stopped but otherwise our position is so good that we can produce heaps and heaps of it.
('20', 346, 2, 7, 809620) Besides, though I want khadi to be sold, I place so high a value on it that I do not want anyone to order it, if it is actually not needed, just in order to reduce accumulated stocks.
('20', 346, 2, 8, 809804) Khadi made from hand spun yarn is sacred to me, so that such khadi is not to be thrown away.
('20', 346, 2, 9, 809897) Moreover, consumption of khadi with out real need will harm the country.
('20', 346, 2, 10, 809970) Khadi will have been wisely used when we start wearing it in place of the fine cloth or foreign or mill made cloth now used by us.
('20', 346, 2, 11, 810101) Only then shall we succeed in overcoming the shortage of cloth in India.
('20', 346, 2, 12, 810174) The rule, therefore, is that people who use a great variety of dresses should reduce their needs of cloth—so that the pressure on available cloth may be reduced and even in meeting their genuine needs they should use khadi wherever they can.
('20', 346, 2, 13, 810416) This will spare cloth for the people and the money spent over cloth will have been well used, for, instead of a few people earning it, it will be distributed among thousands.
('20', 346, 2, 14, 810591) It is not enough that we produce and consume; we should use our discretion in doing so.
('20', 346, 2, 15, 810679) Production—and the manner of consumption too—should be so organized as to benefit the maximum number of people.
('20', 346, 2, 16, 810791) This is the simple principle of economics.
('20', 346, 2, 17, 810834) People starve only where this is violated.
('20', 346, 2, 18, 810877) Hence a demand for khadi by itself will not please me.
('20', 346, 2, 19, 810932) I can see, though, from the type of people who order khadi that they wish to put it to good use.
('20', 346, 2, 20, 811029) We should also rejoice inasmuch as the demand for khadi is an expression of the love for the ideal of swadeshi.
('20', 346, 2, 21, 811141) Orders for khadi have been received from places like Baluchistan and the Nilgiri Hills and from far away Aden.
('20', 346, 3, 22, 811252) Perhaps we can derive still more satisfaction from the experience of Shrimati Saraladevi Chowdharani and the wife of the capable and extremely good natured Maulana Hasrat Mohani.
('20', 346, 3, 23, 811431) Saraladevi had an invitation to attend the Khilafat Conference at Bareilly.

('20', 347, 8, 16, 812852) Two circumstances militated against peace : that twelve mills were working and that the workers of the throstle department alone were on strike.

('20', 347, 8, 19, 813141) We cannot adequately congratulate the workers on this.

('20', 349, 2, 8, 817074) 131. MARRIAGE PROCESSIONS
('20', 349, 3, 9, 817100) I have received a letter on this subject from a highly educated lady.
('20', 349, 3, 10, 817170) Thinking the following part of the letter 1 to be important, I place it before readers.
('20', 349, 3, 11, 817258) My purpose in reproducing this letter is to see that people start thinking about the subject, which I took courage to discuss, and do something at any rate to carry out the suggestions.
('20', 349, 3, 12, 817444) On questions of reforms like these, so useful to the people, we cannot rest content with holding good views.
('20', 349, 3, 13, 817553) We should, rather, learn to abandon immediately any custom which we think to be injurious.
('20', 349, 3, 14, 817644) A number of people came to me from Baroda.
('20', 349, 3, 15, 817687) As this was a year of marriages among Patidars 2 and as the Gaekwar Government had prohibited the evil custom, prevalent among them, of marrying off even little boys and girls, these people had come to consult me on how to get the ban removed.
('20', 349, 3, 16, 817931) I told them that, if I had the powers of the Gaekwar Government, I would offer such satya graha against people marrying off boys and girls of tender age that they would not even be able to stay on in the State.
('20', 349, 3, 17, 818142) These friends understood my joke and not only did they give up the idea of securing my help but started discussing how this custom of child marriage, which had had so strong a hold
('20', 349, 4, 18, 818323) 1 Not translated here.
('20', 349, 4, 19, 818346) The correspondent endorsed Gandhiji’s criticism of marriage customs; vide”Three Occasions”, 9 5 1920.
('20', 349, 5, 20, 818448) 2 A community of Hindu agriculturists in Gujarat.
('20', 349, 5, 21, 818498) They used to arrange marriages only in certain auspicious years.
('20', 350, 0, 1, 818563) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 351
('20', 350, 1, 2, 818603) over the people, could be ended.
('20', 350, 1, 3, 818636) I told them that, if other communities have every year auspicious periods during which marriages can be celebrated, the shastras cannot be so wrong headed as to forbid this to Patidars.
('20', 350, 1, 4, 818822) In such matters, it should not be necessary even to seek advice.
('20', 350, 1, 5, 818887) Any individual who feels so inclined may refuse to marry off his daughter, and think himself free, like anyone else, to arrange the marriage in any year.
('20', 350, 1, 6, 819041) On this, they said that, if they did not get their daughters married this year they might not get a suitable match later.
('20', 350, 1, 7, 819163) Thus [they said] though some customs may be bad, it is difficult to go against them.
('20', 350, 1, 8, 819248) I told them, in reply, that even if but one single person comes forward to oppose such wicked customs, he will certainly get another to keep him company, and I gave these friends the examples of some Patidars who had waited till their daughters had grown up.
('20', 350, 1, 9, 819507) I told them finally that one who is convinced of the rightness of a certain course will risk anything in following it.
('20', 350, 1, 10, 819626) About a daughter, the utmost risk is that she might remain unmarried till rather late.
('20', 350, 1, 11, 819713) I can see no difficulty at all in this.
('20', 350, 1, 12, 819753) It has been my experience that a wisely educated girl has no difficulty in maintaining self control.
('20', 350, 1, 13, 819854) I told the men of this.
('20', 350, 1, 14, 819878) They took leave of me.
('20', 350, 1, 15, 819901) I do not know what they finally did, but this example shows how strong is the force of custom.
('20', 350, 1, 16, 819996) Until, regardless of its strength, we fight this force of custom with all our energy, we shall not succeed in ending these evil customs which sap the vitality of the people.
('20', 350, 1, 17, 820170) But I have strayed from the question of marriage processions to that of ill paired unions.
('20', 350, 1, 18, 820261) The common man will not experience the same difficulty in getting rid of ostentatious marriage processions as the Patidars do in saving their daughters [from the evil of child marriage].
('20', 350, 1, 19, 820448) If everyone who is sick of such processions introduces reforms immediately where he is himself concerned, without waiting for others, we shall, with very little effort, shake off the hold of this and other suicidal practices of like nature.

('20', 357, 2, 5, 835660) 134. LETTER TO C. F. ANDREWS
('20', 357, 3, 6, 835689) ASHRAM, May 25, 1920
('20', 357, 4, 7, 835710) You have asked me [a] very searching question.
('20', 357, 4, 8, 835757) I have always recognized that there are fundamental differences between you and me on the marriage and the caste question.
('20', 357, 4, 9, 835880) I do not consider marriage to be a necessity in every case.
('20', 357, 4, 10, 835940) From the highest standpoint it is a status lower than that of celibacy but I recognize it to be an absolute necessity in most cases.
('20', 357, 4, 11, 836073) At the same time I would put disciplinary restraints upon the choice of man and woman and just as it would be considered improper for a brother to marry his sister I would make it improper for a person to marry outside his or her group which may be called a caste.
('20', 357, 4, 12, 836338) I would there by make the other men or women free from the attentions of that person.
('20', 357, 4, 13, 836424) And if a person cannot get a suitable match within the limits prescribed for him or her he or she should be satisfied to remain unmarried.
('20', 357, 4, 14, 836563) In other words I do not believe in unbridled licence.
('20', 357, 4, 15, 836617) The vast majority of unions are due merely to physical attraction.
('20', 357, 4, 16, 836684) I would narrow down this circle of attraction.
('20', 357, 4, 17, 836731) So you see that I would be averse to a Brahmin going outside his circle for the choice of a wife; there is no question here of untouchability.
('20', 357, 4, 18, 836874) Caste I consider a useful institution if properly regulated.
('20', 357, 4, 19, 836935) Untouchability is a crime against God and humanity.
('20', 357, 4, 20, 836987) I would purify the former, I would destroy the latter.
('20', 357, 4, 21, 837042) If Manilal fell in love with a pariah girl, I would not quarrel with his choice but I would certainly consider that he had failed to imbibe my teaching.
('20', 357, 4, 22, 837195) I would like him to be satisfied with his own caste division not because he would have any repugnance against the others but because I would like him to exercise self restraint.
('20', 357, 4, 23, 837373) Similarly for the institution of caste.
('20', 357, 4, 24, 837413) In the Ashram we do not observe any caste restrictions , because we are making a new experiment but I would not like a Brahmin to go
('20', 358, 0, 1, 837546) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 359
('20', 358, 1, 2, 837586) beyond his pale, and indulge in dining here, there and everywhere.

('20', 358, 1, 4, 837725) 1 but it proceeds from a sense of discipline.
('20', 358, 1, 5, 837771) Rob the caste of its impurities, and you will find it to be a bulwark of Hinduism and an institution whose roots are embedded deep down in human nature.
('20', 358, 1, 6, 837924) Now for the Khilafat question.

('20', 363, 5, 14, 850130) Mr. Candler has favoured me with an open letter on this quest ion of questions.
('20', 363, 5, 15, 850210) The letter has already appeared in the Press.
('20', 363, 5, 16, 850256) I can appreciate Mr. Candler’s position as I would like him and other Englishmen to appreciate mine and that of hundreds of Hindus who feel as I do.
('20', 363, 5, 17, 850405) Mr. Candler’s letter is an attempt to show that Mr. Llyod George’s pledge 2 is not in any way broken by the peace terms.
('20', 363, 5, 18, 850526) I quite agree with him that Mr. Lloyd George’s words ought not to be torn from their context to support the Mohammedan claim.
('20', 363, 5, 19, 850652) These are Mr. Lloyd George’s words as quoted in the recent Viceregal message :
('20', 363, 6, 20, 850731) Nor are we fighting to destroy Austria Hungary or to deprive Turkey of its capital, or of the rich and renowned lands of Asia Minor and Thrace which are predominantly Turkish in race.

('20', 363, 7, 22, 851046) 1 Sir George Lloyd 2 Made on January 5, 1918
('20', 364, 0, 1, 851091) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 365
('20', 364, 1, 2, 851131) Minister knew in 1918 that the lands referred to by him were ‘predominantly Turkish in race’.
('20', 364, 1, 3, 851225) And if this is the meaning, I venture to suggest that the pledge has been broken in a most barefaced manner, for there is practically nothing left to the Turk of ‘the rich and renowned lands of Asia Minor and Thrace’.
('20', 364, 2, 4, 851443) I have already given my view of the retention of the Sultan in Constantinople.
('20', 364, 2, 5, 851522) It is an insult to the intelligence of man to suggest that ‘the maintenance of the Turkish Empire in the homeland of the Turkish race with its capital at Constantinople’ has been left unimpaired by the terms of the peace.
('20', 364, 2, 6, 851744) This is the other passage from the speech which I presume Mr. Candler wants me to read together with the one already quoted :
('20', 364, 3, 7, 851870) While we do not challenge the maintenance of the Turkish Empirein the homeland of the Turkish race with its capital at Constantinople, the passage between the Mediterranean and the Black Sea being internationalized, Armenia, Mesopotamia, Syria and Palestine are in our judgment entitled to a recognition of their separate national condition.
('20', 364, 3, 8, 852212) Did that mean entire removal of Turkish influence, extinction of Turkish suzerainty and the introduction of European Christian influence under the guise of Mandates?
('20', 364, 3, 9, 852378) Have the Moslems of Arabia, Armenia, Mesopotamia, Syria and Palestine been committed, or is the new arrangement being superimposed upon them by Powers conscious of their own brute strength rather than of justice of their action?
('20', 364, 3, 10, 852607) I for one would nurse by every legitimate means the spirit of independence in the brave Arabs, but I shudder to think what will happen to them under the schemes of exploitation of their country by the greedy capitalists protected as they will be by the mandatory Powers.

('20', 364, 3, 12, 853043) Let there be all the necessary guarantees taken from Turkey about the internal indpendence of the Arabs.
('20', 364, 3, 13, 853148) But to remove that suzerainty, to deprive the Khalif of the wardenship of the holy places is to render Khilafat a mockery which no Mohammedan can possibly look upon with equanimity.

('20', 365, 1, 2, 853706) regarding the Turkish Treaty is based upon the Prime Minister’s pledge”regarding Thrace, Constantinople and Turkish lands in Asia Minor, repeated on February 26 last with deliberation by Mr. Lloyd George”.
('20', 365, 1, 3, 853912) 1 Mr. Roberts holds that the pledge must be treated as a whole, not as binding only regarding Constantinople but also binding as regards Thrace and Asia Minor.
('20', 365, 1, 4, 854072) He describes the pledge as binding upon the nation as a whole and its breach in any part as a gross breach of faith on the part of the British Empire.
('20', 365, 1, 5, 854223) He demands that if there is an unanswerable reply to the charge of breach of faith it ought to be given and adds the Prime Minister may regard his own word lightly if he chooses, but he has no right to break a pledge given on behalf of the nation.

('20', 368, 1, 5, 861945) The Proclamation from which the above extract has been copied was published in December last.
('20', 368, 1, 6, 862039) Thanks to the action of the Government of India and the Provincial Governments, many of those who were undergoing imprisonment at the time have received the benefit of the Royal clemency.

('20', 368, 2, 11, 862597) Mr. Ganesh Damodar Savarkar, the elder of the two, was born in 1879, and received an ordinary education.
('20', 368, 2, 12, 862702) He took a prominent part in the swadeshi movement at Nasik in 1908. He was sentenced to transpor tation for life with confiscation of property under Sections 121, 121A, 124A and 153A on the 9th day of June, 1909, and is now serving his sentence in the Andamans.
('20', 368, 2, 13, 862964) He has therefore had eleven years of imprisonment.
('20', 368, 3, 14, 863015) Section 121 is the famous section which was utilized during the Punjab trials and refers to ‘waging war against the King’.
('20', 368, 3, 15, 863138) The minimum penalty is transportation for life with forfeiture of property.
('20', 368, 3, 16, 863214) 121A is a similar section.
('20', 368, 3, 17, 863241) 124A relates to sedition.
('20', 368, 3, 18, 863267) 153A relates to promotion of enmity between classes ‘by words either spoken or written’ or ‘otherwise’.
('20', 368, 3, 19, 863371) It is clear therefore that all the offences charged against Mr. Savarkar (senior) were of a public nature.

('20', 381, 3, 11, 893581) I have been overwhelmed with public criticism and private advice and even anonymous letters telling me exactly what I should do.
('20', 381, 3, 12, 893710) Some are impatient that I do not advise immediate and extensive non co operation; others tell me what harm I am doing the country by throwing it knowingly in a tempest of violence on either side.

('20', 383, 1, 12, 898366) At the same time I admit that even the violence that did take place on the part of the people and the spirit of lawlessness that was undoubtedly shown in some parts should have remained under check.

('20', 393, 2, 9, 922227) 153. LETTER TO S. R. HIGNELL
('20', 393, 3, 10, 922256) LABURNUM ROAD, BOMBAY, June 12, 1920 DEAR MR. HIGNELL, I have purposely refrained from replying to your letter of the 6th May conveying Mr. Montagu’s message in reply to mycable to him regarding my proposed visit to London on the Khilafat question.
('20', 393, 3, 11, 922505) I have myself given the matter my most anxious thought and have consulted my Musalman friends.
('20', 393, 3, 12, 922600) And I have come to the conclusion that I must not go to London for the purpose intended by Mr. Montagu.
('20', 393, 3, 13, 922704) Nothing would give me greater pleasure than to be able to discuss the general Indian question with Mr. Montagu personally.
('20', 393, 3, 14, 922827) But I feel that I at least must devote for the time being my exclusive attention to the Khilafat question.
('20', 393, 3, 15, 922934) I flatter myself with the belief that mine is the greatest contribution to the preservation of the public peace in India.
('20', 393, 3, 16, 923056) And my withdrawal from it today can be justified only for the purpose of hastening a proper solution of the difficult Khilafat question.
('20', 393, 3, 17, 923193) Mr. Montagu’s message, on the contrary, holds out no such hope if I went to London.
('20', 393, 3, 18, 923277) In the circumstances and at the present juncture, I deem it wiser not to proceed to London unless I am wanted there definitely for the purpose of discussing the Peace Terms with a view to their revision.
('20', 393, 3, 19, 923481) Will you kindly send Mr. Montagu the purport of this letter?
('20', 393, 3, 20, 923542) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('20', 394, 1, 2, 923698) 154. PRESS STATEMENT ON REPATRIATION SCHEME 1
('20', 394, 2, 3, 923744) June 13, 1920 With reference to the approval that seems to have been accorded to the scheme of repatriation, said to have been recommended by the South African Commission 2 and accepted by the Union Government, I would respectfully caution the public against accepting the proposed scheme 3. The public have not the interim report of the Commission.
('20', 394, 2, 4, 924094) We do not know the conditions of repatriation.
('20', 394, 2, 5, 924141) It seems to me therefore that it is most hazardous to venture any opinion at all on a scheme of which we have a most imperfect knowledge.
('20', 394, 2, 6, 924279) Generally, it must be stated that any scheme of State repatriation must be looked upon with the gravest suspicion, especially when the scheme is fathered by those who are uncompromisingly hostile to Indian aspirations.
('20', 394, 2, 7, 924498) The Indians of South Africa are able to remain in that country because of their domicile.
('20', 394, 2, 8, 924588) I very much fear that the proposed scheme will be found to involve forfeiture of domicile against acceptance of repatriation money, that is, passage back to India and possibly a trifling sum as pocket money.
('20', 394, 2, 9, 924796) I am inclined to think that apart from everything else such considerations will be wholly insufficient for giving away a valuable right.
('20', 394, 2, 10, 924933) I would hardly call any such repatriation as purely voluntary.
('20', 394, 2, 11, 924996) This, however, is one of the many objections that may be advanced against the proposed repatriation.
('20', 394, 2, 12, 925097) I have no doubt that the best thing is to suspend judgment till we have the full scheme before us for examination.
('20', 394, 2, 13, 925212) It is to be hoped that the Government of India will take the public fully into its confidence before pronouncing upon the scheme.
('20', 394, 2, 14, 925342) The Hindu, 14 6 1920
('20', 394, 3, 15, 925363) 1 Released from Bombay, in regard to the scheme recommended by the Enquiry Commission in South Africa whose sittings had commenced from March, 1920 2 In its interim report 3India in 1920 says : “The interim report recommended that with a view to encourage the return to India of those Indians who are desirous of repatriation, the Union Government should afford all facilities, including the provision of shipping and the relaxation of restrictions on the export of gold in the form of savings and jewelry.”

('20', 396, 0, 1, 927761) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 397
('20', 396, 1, 2, 927801) 156. THE LAW OF SUFFERING
('20', 396, 2, 3, 927827) No country has ever risen without being purified through the fire of suffering.
('20', 396, 2, 4, 927907) Mother suffers so that her child may live.
('20', 396, 2, 5, 927950) The condition of wheat growing is that the seed grain should perish.
('20', 396, 2, 6, 928019) Life comes out of Death.
('20', 396, 2, 7, 928044) Will India rise out of her slavery without fulfilling this eternal law of purification through suffering?
('20', 396, 3, 8, 928150) If my advisers are right, evidently India will realize her destiny without travail.
('20', 396, 3, 9, 928234) For their chief concern is that the events of April, 1919, should not be repeated.
('20', 396, 3, 10, 928317) They fear non co operation because it would involve the sufferings of many.
('20', 396, 3, 11, 928393) If Hampden had argued thus he would not have withheld payment of ship money, nor would Wat Tyler have raised the standard of revolt.
('20', 396, 3, 12, 928526) English and French histories are replete with instances of men continuing their pursuit of the right irrespective of the amount of suffering involved.
('20', 396, 3, 13, 928677) The actors did not stop to think whether ignorant people would not have involuntarily to suffer.
('20', 396, 3, 14, 928774) Why should we expect to write our history differently?
('20', 396, 3, 15, 928829) It is possible for us, if we would, to learn from the mistakes of our predecessors to do better, but it is impossible to do away with the law of suffering which is the one indispensable condition of our being.
('20', 396, 3, 16, 929039) The way to do better is to avoid, if we can, violence from our side and thus quicken the rate of progress and to introduce greater purity in the methods of suffering.
('20', 396, 3, 17, 929206) We can, if we will, refrain, in our impatience, from bending the wrongdoer to our will by physical force as Sinn Feiners are doing today, or from coercing our neighbours to follow our methods as was done last year by some of us in bringing about hartal.
('20', 396, 3, 18, 929460) Progress is to be measured by the amount of suffering undergone by the sufferer.
('20', 396, 3, 19, 929541) The purer the suffering, the greater is the progress.
('20', 396, 3, 20, 929595) Hence did the sacrifice of Jesus suffice to free a sorrowing world.
('20', 396, 3, 21, 929663) In his onward march he did not count the cost of suffering entailed upon his neighbours, whether it was undergone by them voluntarily or otherwise.
('20', 396, 3, 22, 929811) Thus did the sufferings of a Harishchandra 1
('20', 396, 4, 23, 929856) suffice to re establish the kingdom of truth.
('20', 396, 4, 24, 929902) He must have known that his subjects would suffer involuntarily by his abdication.
('20', 396, 4, 25, 929985) He did not mind because he could not do otherwise than follow truth.
('20', 396, 5, 26, 930054) 1 Legendary King of Ayodhya who held his loyalty to truth above his wife, son, kingdom and wealth.
('20', 396, 5, 27, 930153) Finally, after undergoing countless sufferings, he, his family and his subjects were raised to heavenly bliss.
('20', 397, 0, 1, 930264) THE COLLECED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 398
('20', 397, 1, 2, 930305) I have already stated that I do not deplore the massacre of Jallianwala Bagh so much as I deplore the murders of Englishmen and destruction of property by ourselves.
('20', 397, 1, 3, 930471) The frightfulness at Amritsar drew away public attention from the greater though slower frightfulness at Lahore where attempt was made to emasculate the inhabitants by slow processes.
('20', 397, 1, 4, 930655) But before we rise higher we shall have to undergo such pro cesses many more times till they teach us to take up suffering voluntarily and to find joy in it.
('20', 397, 1, 5, 930813) I am convinced that the Lahorians never deserved the cruel insults that they were subjected to;2 they never hurt a single Englishman; they never destroyed any property.
('20', 397, 1, 6, 930982) But a wilful ruler was determined to crush the spirit of a people just trying to throw off his chafing yoke.
('20', 397, 1, 7, 931091) And if I am told that all this was due to my preaching satyagraha, my answer is that I would preach satyagraha all the more forcibly for that, so long as I have breath left in me, and tell the people that next time they would answer O’Dwyerean insolence not by opening shops by reason of threats of forcible sales but by allowing the tyrant to do his worst and let him sell their all but their unconquerable souls.
('20', 397, 1, 8, 931506) Sages of old mortified the flesh so that the spirit within might be set free, so that their trained bodies might be proof against any injury that might be inflicted on them by tyrants seeking to impose their will on them.
('20', 397, 1, 9, 931728) And if India wishes to revive her ancient wisdom and to avoid the errors of Europe, if India wishes to see the Kingdom of God established on earth instead of that of Satan which has enveloped Europe, then I would urge her sons and daughters not to be deceived by fine phrases, the terrible subtleties that hedge us in, the fears of suffering that India may have to undergo, but to see what is happening today in Europe and from it understand that we must go through the suffering even as Europe has gone through, but not the process of making others suffer.
('20', 397, 1, 10, 932286) Germany wan ted to dominate Europe and the Allies wanted to do likewise by crushing Germany.
('20', 397, 1, 11, 932379) Europe is no better for Germany’s fall.
('20', 397, 1, 12, 932419) The Allies have proved themselves to be just as deceitful, cruel, greedy and selfish as Germany was or would have been.
('20', 397, 1, 13, 932539) Germany would have avoided the sanctimonious humbug that one sees associated with the many dealings of the Allies.
('20', 397, 1, 14, 932654) The miscalculation that I deplored last year was not in connection with the sufferings imposed upon the people, but about the mistakes made by them and violence done by them owing to their not having sufficiently understood the message of satyagraha.
('20', 397, 1, 15, 932905) What then is the meaning of non co operation in terms of the Law of
('20', 398, 0, 1, 932973) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 399
('20', 398, 1, 2, 933013) Suffering?
('20', 398, 1, 3, 933024) We must voluntarily put up with the losses and inconven iences that arise from having to withdraw our support from a Government that is ruling against our will.
('20', 398, 1, 4, 933185) Possession of power and riches is a crime under an unjust government; poverty in that case is a virtue, says Thoreau.
('20', 398, 1, 5, 933303) It may be that in the transition state we may make mistakes; there may be avoidable suffering.
('20', 398, 1, 6, 933398) These things are preferable to national emasculation.
('20', 398, 2, 7, 933452) We must refuse to wait for the wrong to be righted till the wrongdoer has been roused to a sense of his inequity.
('20', 398, 2, 8, 933566) We must not, for fear of ourselves or others having to suffer, remain participators in it.
('20', 398, 2, 9, 933657) But we must combat the wrong by ceasing to assist the wrongdoer directly or indirectly.
('20', 398, 3, 10, 933745) If a father does an injustice, it is the duty of his children to leave the parental roof.
('20', 398, 3, 11, 933835) If the head master of a school conducts his institution on an immoral basis, the pupils must leave the school.
('20', 398, 3, 12, 933946) If the chairman of a corporation is corrupt, the members thereof must wash their hands clean of his corruption by withdrawing from it; even so, if a government does a grave injustice, the subject must withdraw co operation wholly or partially, sufficiently to wean the ruler from his wickedness.
('20', 398, 3, 13, 934242) In each case conceived by me there is an element of suffering whether mental or physical.
('20', 398, 3, 14, 934332) Without such suffering it is not possible to attain freedom.
('20', 398, 4, 15, 934393) Young India, 16 6 1920
('20', 399, 0, 1, 934416) THE COLLECED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 400
('20', 399, 1, 2, 934457) 157. HINDI IN MADRAS
('20', 399, 2, 3, 934478) I have the greatest faith in the Dravidians some day taking up Hindi study seriously.
('20', 399, 2, 4, 934564) If an eighth of the industry that they put in mastering English were to be devoted to learning Hindi, instead of the rest of India remaining a sealed book to them, they will be one with us as never before.
('20', 399, 2, 5, 934770) I know that some would say the argument cuts both ways.
('20', 399, 2, 6, 934826) The Dravidians being in a minority, national economy suggests that they should learn the common language of the rest of India than that the rest should learn Tamil, Telugu, Canarese and Malayalam in order to be able to converse with Dravidian India.
('20', 399, 2, 7, 935076) It is for that reason that Hindi propaganda work of an intense type has been going on in the Madras Presidency for the past eighteen months under the aegis of the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan of Allahabad.
('20', 399, 2, 8, 935276) In response to an appeal by me to the Agraval Marwadi Sammelan held in Bombay last week, the wealthy Marwadis of Bombay and Calcutta present there subscribed on the spot Rs. 50,000 for five years’ Hindi propaganda in Madras Presidency.
('20', 399, 2, 9, 935512) They have once more demonstrated that Hindi work is a speciality of this princely merchant class of India.
('20', 399, 2, 10, 935619) This generous response increases the responsibility of the Sammelan of Allahabad and of those Dravidians who share with me the belief that Madras must take up Hindi for the sake of full national expansion.
('20', 399, 2, 11, 935825) Let no Dravidian think that learning Hindi is at all difficult.
('20', 399, 2, 12, 935889) A little time taken from the recreation hour daily and in a systematic manner will enable an average man to learn Hindi in one year.
('20', 399, 2, 13, 936022) I would venture to suggest, too, that large municipalities might now introduce Hindi as an optional language to be learnt in the municipal schools.
('20', 399, 2, 14, 936170) I can say from experience that Dravidian children take to Hindi in a remarkably easy manner.
('20', 399, 2, 15, 936263) Little does anyone know that almost all the Tamils and the Telugus living in South Africa can carry on an intelligent conversation in Hindi.
('20', 399, 2, 16, 936404) I venture to hope therefore that the young men of Madras will show their appreciation of Marwadi generosity by availing themselves of the facility afforded to them of learning Hindi without payment.
('20', 399, 2, 17, 936603) Young India, 16 6 1920

('20', 400, 5, 26, 938416) There we are concentrating on education, weaving industry and heart culture.
('20', 400, 5, 27, 938493) The family has outgrown the buildings you saw.
('20', 400, 5, 28, 938540) We are living in a cramped condition.
