('20', 403, 1, 2, 941540) 162. DUTY OF SELF SACRIFICE
('20', 403, 2, 3, 941568) They who live on the amrit 1 of what remains after a yajna, 2 attain to eternal Brahma; 3 O Arjuna, those who do no yajna, even this world is not for them, not to speak of the next.
('20', 403, 3, 4, 941750) Narada gave his considered opinion that Parvati 5 should go and do tapasya.
('20', 403, 3, 5, 941826) Her parents liked the idea, for tapasya brings happiness and destroys sin and suffering.
('20', 403, 3, 6, 941915) Tapasya is the basis of all creation.
('20', 403, 3, 7, 941953) They, therefore, desired that Parvati, taking this to heart, should go and do tapasya.
('20', 403, 3, 8, 942040) 6 The term yajna can be interpreted in a number of ways but there is only one meaning acceptable to men of all faiths, and that is, to be ready even to lay down one’s life for true welfare.
('20', 403, 3, 9, 942230) Parvati wanted such a one as Siva as her consort and so was advised to do penance.
('20', 403, 3, 10, 942313) If anyone wants to know what was the penance she did, he should go to the incomparable work of Tulsidas.
('20', 403, 3, 11, 942418) A woman gives birth to children in suffering and sacrifices herself in bringing them up.
('20', 403, 3, 12, 942507) Life comes out of death.
('20', 403, 3, 13, 942532) A seed must disintegrate under earth and perish before it can grow into grain.
('20', 403, 3, 14, 942611) Harishchandra went through endless suffering to honour his word as a man of truth, Jesus put on a crown of thorns to win salvation for his people, allowed his hands and feet to be nailed and suffered agonies before he gave up the ghost.
('20', 403, 3, 15, 942848) This has been the law of yagna from immemorial times.
('20', 403, 3, 16, 942902) Without yajna this earth cannot exist even for a moment.
('20', 403, 3, 17, 942959) Before the Turks could conquer Constantinople, 7 they sacrificed innumerable troops and used the corpses as a bridge.
('20', 403, 3, 18, 943077) I cannot help feeling that we want to advance our country without fulfilling this immutable law of suffering

('20', 404, 1, 2, 943390) which has prevailed in India.
('20', 404, 2, 3, 943420) We want full independence without the sacrifice of a single life.
('20', 404, 2, 4, 943486) We would be happy if we could do without sacrifice of money either.
('20', 404, 2, 5, 943554) A great many people have got frightened of non co operation.
('20', 404, 2, 6, 943615) What must be the reasons?
('20', 404, 2, 7, 943641) I can think of only two: first, that people may have to starve if they give up their jobs and, second, if anyone makes a mistake and the Government resorts to firing, thousands may lose their lives.
('20', 404, 2, 8, 943840) This means that we want a solution of the difficult and important problems of the Khilafat without the least suffering on our part.
('20', 404, 2, 9, 943972) Non co operation is some sort of very easy yajna, it is penance in a small way, requiring a little self sacrifice.
('20', 404, 2, 10, 944087) I would certainly not think of it as any suffering if 20 or 25 thousand, or may be a 100 or 150 thousand, gave up service to secure justice or in order, at any rate, not to be a party to injustice; nay, where the institution in question is well run I would look upon such suffering [by employees] as natural; instead of running away from it, they should welcome it.
('20', 404, 2, 11, 944453) I would not in the least be pained if thousands of men are ruined in the attempt to seek a just solution of a problem like the Khilafat.
('20', 404, 2, 12, 944590) I would look upon it as a test of people’s devotion to dharma.
('20', 404, 2, 13, 944653) I believe that there can be no victory except through such suffering, and also that thousands of men suffering in that way cannot but win.

('20', 404, 4, 20, 945447) Christians, in regarding Jesus as the Saviour, attribute total perfection to him.
('20', 404, 4, 21, 945529) Look ing at the matter in this light, [we see] that we could start non co operation in full force immediately if we knew that there was not the slightest possibility of our being guilty of anything wrong in our agitation regarding the Khilafat or any other issue.

('20', 405, 4, 5, 946398) 163. “WHAT SHOULD I DO?”
('20', 405, 5, 6, 946423) Mrs. Polak has sent me a picture which shows one Mr. Glading, an Englishman of eighty years, spinning wool on a wheel.
('20', 405, 5, 7, 946542) He has taken up this work in his old age by way of recreation.
('20', 405, 5, 8, 946605) The old man cannot spend the whole day talking or reading the Bible; at this age, again, how can he join the games others play at home?
('20', 405, 5, 9, 946741) Moreover, he must have a partner in the game and not everyone can get one.
('20', 405, 5, 10, 946816) So, the old man must have thought of cultivating a useful hobby and chosen the spinning wheel.
('20', 405, 5, 11, 946911) Before I got this picture, a gentleman who had retired from a high post had been to see me.
('20', 405, 5, 12, 947003) He did not know how to spend his time.
('20', 405, 5, 13, 947042) He could not spend the whole day telling his beads.
('20', 405, 5, 14, 947094) He wished to have some philanthropic work.
('20', 405, 5, 15, 947137) He came to me for advice since I have the reputation of being a man engaged in a good many activities.
('20', 405, 5, 16, 947240) I could not think of any better work for him, considering his health, than plying the spinning wheel.
('20', 405, 5, 17, 947342) I politely put it to him that he could spin.
('20', 405, 5, 18, 947387) I am afraid that I failed to make an impression on him.
('20', 405, 5, 19, 947443) Perhaps I lowered myself in his esteem.
('20', 405, 5, 20, 947483) Some believe that spinning is just an activity reserved for women.
('20', 405, 5, 21, 947550) To mention the spinning wheel before men is to make them feel that they are being insulted.
('20', 405, 5, 22, 947642) Not only do I not think this way but I believe, on the contrary, that all work beneficial to society is for both, men and women.
('20', 405, 5, 23, 947771) It is natural, of course, that since women cannot work as hard physically as men and do not as readily go out for work, spinning is regarded as especially their job.
('20', 405, 5, 24, 947937) But cooking is done by men in many families, though ordinarily it is women’s work.
('20', 405, 5, 25, 948020) Similarly, though the spinning wheel may be ordinarily for women, occasionally men also can work on it.
('20', 405, 5, 26, 948124) Many men are trying, at present, to effect improvements in the
('20', 406, 0, 1, 948187) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 20 JULY, 1920 407
('20', 406, 1, 2, 948230) spinning wheel.
('20', 406, 1, 3, 948246) I would, therefore, certainly advise people in the same position as the friend above to start plying the spinning wheel.
('20', 406, 1, 4, 948367) Lawyers and doctors go to clubs and play cards or billiards, but I doubt if they refresh their minds thereby.
('20', 406, 1, 5, 948477) If, on the other hand, they were to stay at home and, sitting in a clean room, work at the spinning wheel, I am sure they would get more innocent pleasure from this work than they ever could from cards.
('20', 406, 1, 6, 948680) Sir John Lubbock 1
('20', 406, 2, 7, 948699) found his rest in turning from one type of useful work to another and his recreation in watching ants at work.
('20', 406, 2, 8, 948810) Lord Salisbury amused himself with experiments in chemistry.
('20', 406, 2, 9, 948871) Gladstone sought relief from his work in the House of Commons by employing himself in splitting logs of wood.
('20', 406, 2, 10, 948981) We stand in need of such recreation more than the British do.
('20', 406, 2, 11, 949043) The country lacks food and clothing, or whatever there is very dear.
('20', 406, 2, 12, 949112) As for milk and ghee, large numbers have to go without them.
('20', 406, 2, 13, 949173) At a time such as this, dharma consists wholly in producing and supplying these two things in enough quantities.
('20', 406, 2, 14, 949286) Not to eat and not to clothe ourselves till we have fed the hungry and clothed the naked is the whole of dayadharma 2 .
('20', 406, 2, 15, 949406) I would, therefore, humbly suggest to all persons in the position of this friend that, if it is not possible for them to do body labour in their spare time by working on farms or in such other ways, they should most certainly get hold of a spinning wheel and spend their time spinning.
('20', 406, 2, 16, 949692) This will safeguard both dharma and material interests.
('20', 406, 3, 17, 949748) No effort on this path is ever wasted
('20', 406, 4, 18, 949786) And no obstacle undoes the progress made;
('20', 406, 5, 19, 949828) Even a little of this dharma
('20', 406, 6, 20, 949857) Saves one from great danger.

('20', 407, 1, 2, 950093) 164. LIVING ON THE PAST
('20', 407, 2, 3, 950117) Editors often have something or other ready at hand to fill space in newspapers.
('20', 407, 2, 4, 950198) In English this is called ‘evergreen’ that is, always fresh.
('20', 407, 2, 5, 950259) You can publish the matter any time.
('20', 407, 2, 6, 950296) I unexpectedly came across something like this in The [Bombay] Chronicle.
('20', 407, 2, 7, 950370) In contains the following information.
('20', 407, 2, 8, 950409) The Hindus invented the decimal system.
('20', 407, 2, 9, 950449) Geometry andAlge bra were first developed in India, and so too Trigonometry.
('20', 407, 2, 10, 950526) The first five hospitals to be built were in India.
('20', 407, 2, 11, 950578) The physicians of ancient Europe used Indian drugs.
('20', 407, 2, 12, 950630) Hindus investigated the anatomy of the human body in the sixth century B. C. and about the same time acquired the art of surgery.
('20', 407, 2, 13, 950760) People in ancient India knew the art of casting iron pillars of the same kind which they make now.
('20', 407, 2, 14, 950859) India specialized in carving caves.
('20', 407, 2, 15, 950895) Alexander, when he invaded India, found republican states in the Punjab and in Sind.
('20', 407, 2, 16, 950980) In ancient India, women enjoyed all those rights for which women of Europe are fighting hard at present.
('20', 407, 2, 17, 951085) Municipalities were in existence in the times of Chandragupta.
('20', 407, 2, 18, 951148) It was the Hindus who perfected the science of grammar.
('20', 407, 2, 19, 951204) The Ramayana and the Mahabharata still remain unrivalled.
('20', 407, 2, 20, 951262) I do not know how far these statements are true, but this I know, that, if the late Justice Ranade were alive today and heard such talk of India’s past glory, he would certainly have asked, ‘So what?’ He used to say that no people could progress by merely dwelling on its past glory.
('20', 407, 2, 21, 951546) If at all we do so, it should be only in order that we may be able to add to it.
('20', 407, 2, 22, 951627) Where is the man who can write the Ramayana today?
('20', 407, 2, 23, 951678) Where are the morals af ancient times?
('20', 407, 2, 24, 951717) Where is the ability of those days?
('20', 407, 2, 25, 951753) And devotion to duty?
('20', 407, 2, 26, 951775) We have added nothing to the drugs discovered thousands of years ago, nor do we even have adequate knowledge about those mentioned in the ancient books.
('20', 407, 2, 27, 951928) We witness the same poverty in respect of all the other gifts mentioned above, borrowing as we do everything from Europe.
('20', 407, 2, 28, 952050) I, at any rate, feel that so long as we have not revived in the present the glory which was ours in the past, wisdom lies in not speaking about it.
('20', 407, 2, 29, 952198) That wealth which has no exchange value, which the world does not recognize as such, brings not credit, but only humiliation and is in the nature of a burden.
('20', 407, 2, 30, 952357) If, as we believe, we had these gifts in ancient times, we ought to be able to
('20', 408, 0, 1, 952436) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 409
('20', 408, 1, 2, 952476) give evidence of them again.
('20', 408, 1, 3, 952505) We are indeed heirs of a brave people, but by confessing at the same time our inability to be worthy of that heritage we shall achieve nothing.
('20', 408, 1, 4, 952649) We shall see hereafter how we can become so worthy.

('20', 408, 2, 6, 952738) 165. NOTES
('20', 408, 3, 7, 952749) Writing about Orissa, Shri Amritlal Thakkar says that he has toured more villages and found that starvation is more widespread than was thought.
('20', 408, 3, 8, 952894) 1 This is so, it seems, because, the means of transport being inadequate and the people comparatively poor, no complaints would be heard from them.
('20', 408, 3, 9, 953042) They live in the conditions they find themselves in, so that these would come to light only if somebody went among them and felt pity for them.
('20', 408, 3, 10, 953186) How shall we ever know the places in which such conditions prevail?
('20', 408, 3, 11, 953254) A newspaper from that place points out that the area being low lying, floods from Central India are always pouring into it.
('20', 408, 3, 12, 953378) Some dams have been built to check these floods, but they are giving way.
('20', 408, 3, 13, 953452) New ones need to be built at some of the places.
('20', 408, 3, 14, 953501) Unless this is done, damage from floods will continue every year.
('20', 408, 3, 15, 953567) To devise measures against this, the newspaper suggests that the Government should call a conference of engineers to obtain their opinion and take the necessary steps.
('20', 408, 3, 16, 953735) We hope that Shri Amritlal Thakkar will, when he has time, inquire also into the question of what should be done to prevent famines and will investigate the causes of the chronic poverty of these unfortunate people.
('20', 408, 3, 17, 953951) The reader will be glad to know that, thanks to the efforts of Amritlal Thakkar and the co operation of Shri Karsandas, the well known Gujarati merchant of Calcutta, a sum of Rs. 18,000 has been collected for famine relief.

('20', 409, 1, 2, 954294) 166. LETTER TO C. F. ANDREWS
('20', 409, 2, 3, 954323) June 20, 1920
('20', 409, 3, 4, 954337) You have been pouring out your heart to me on the Khilafat and other matters 1 whereas I have been unable to reciprocate be cause of the great strain I have been undergoing just now.
('20', 409, 3, 5, 954520) All the same you know that you are ever in my mind.
('20', 409, 3, 6, 954572) I know what spiritual struggles mean for you.
('20', 409, 3, 7, 954618) I hope you are keeping better health.
('20', 409, 3, 8, 954656) You wrote to me that you were very bad after your return from Calcutta.
('20', 409, 4, 9, 954728) I wish you will not concern yourself about my position on the Turkish question i.e., you will depend upon it that I shall do nothing blindly.
('20', 409, 4, 10, 954870) I am committed to nothing on the Turkish question so that upon proof of the immorality of a position being found I could not retrace my steps.
('20', 409, 4, 11, 955013) The unfortunate position in which I find myself is that I thoroughly distrust Lloyd George.
('20', 409, 4, 12, 955105) Somehow or other I distrust the Armenian case as I distrust the Arabian case and I am so prejudiced against the present British diplomacy that I scent the foul hand of the deceitful diplomat in Armenia, Arabia, Mesopotamia, Palestine Syria.
('20', 409, 4, 13, 955346) The position therefore I take up is that as soon as I can remove my prejudice I shall retire from the untenable position I may find myself in.
('20', 409, 4, 14, 955489) I do ask for suzerainty 2 over Armenia, Mesopota mia, Palestine and Syria with proper safeguards.
('20', 409, 4, 15, 955587) You say the safeguards are nothing.
('20', 409, 4, 16, 955623) I do not agree with you.
('20', 409, 4, 17, 955648) If the Allied Powers are themselves insincere and jealous of one another they may mean nothing.
('20', 409, 4, 18, 955744) But if they are sincere, the safeguards can certainly be effective.
('20', 409, 4, 19, 955812) Britain claims suzerainty over the Transvaal, but the Transvaal had no interference with its internal affairs.
('20', 409, 4, 20, 955923) Why should Armenia have to complain if it has full autonomy with a Turkish Resident there?
('20', 409, 4, 21, 956014) If Britain only meant well by Turkey everything could be satisfactorily arranged.
('20', 409, 4, 22, 956096) If Turkey had joined the Allies, could Britain have dispossessed Turkey of Armenia, Arabia or Mesopota mia?
('20', 409, 4, 23, 956204) Would Britain then not have brought about reforms in Turkey by friendly pressure instead of a victor’s dictation?
('20', 409, 4, 24, 956318) The insolence and hypocrisy of the Ministry bolstered up by equal insolence and hypocrisy in the Viceroy’s communique are really insufferable.
('20', 409, 5, 25, 956461) 1Vide Addenda, “Letter to C. F. Andrews”, 25 5 1920.
('20', 409, 6, 26, 956514) 2 Of the Khalif
('20', 410, 0, 1, 956530) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 411
('20', 410, 1, 2, 956570) You consider Mahomed Ali’s representation to be as unclean as the Treaty.

('20', 410, 1, 4, 956790) If you say that the condemnation is not intelligent, is not based on knowledge, but is due to utter distrust of Britain, I should agree with you, but the condemnation is there.
('20', 410, 1, 5, 956967) I do not read news papers as a rule, but look at the enclosed in The Leader.

('20', 410, 1, 13, 957800) If only I could infect India with my belief in the weapons of unadulterated suffering, i.e., self suffering, I would bring down this insolence from its pedestal in a moment and reduce to nothingness the whole of the powder magazine of Europe.
('20', 410, 2, 14, 958043) Shaken as I was by this Peace Treaty, the Hunter Report has taken away all my faith even in the good intentions of the Ministry and the Viceregal Council.
('20', 410, 2, 15, 958198) Nor has Mr. Montagu come well out of the ordeal.

('20', 410, 2, 20, 958631) That however does not alter the situation.
('20', 410, 2, 21, 958674) I would like you to realize with me the enormity of the double crime of the present British administration or make me see my folly and correct myself !

('20', 410, 3, 26, 959023) Not to dine with him by way of self restraint is a virtue.

('20', 412, 4, 10, 961924) 168. LETTER TO VICEROY 3
('20', 412, 5, 11, 961949) June 22, 1920
('20', 412, 6, 12, 961963) TO HIS EXCELLENCY THE RIGHT HON’BLE BARON CHELMSFORD
('20', 412, 7, 13, 962016) P.C., G.M.S.I., G.C.M.G., G.M.I.F. VICEROY AND GOVERNOR GENERAL OF INDIA SIMLA
('20', 412, 8, 14, 962095) YOUR EXCELLENCY, As one who has enjoyed a certain measure of Your Excellency’s confidence and as one who claims to be a devoted well wisher of the British Empire, I owe it to Your Excellency and, through Your Excellency, to His Majesty’s Ministers, to explain my connection with and my conduct in the Khilafat question.
('20', 412, 9, 15, 962415) 1Vide Appendix “Muslim Leaders’ Representation to Viceroy”, 22 6 1920. 2Vide the following item.
('20', 412, 10, 16, 962512) 3 The Turkish Peace Treaty was handed over to the Ottoman Delegation at Paris on May 11, 1920. These terms were published in India on May 14, 1920, along with a message from the Viceroy to the Muslims of India.
('20', 412, 10, 17, 962723) This letter was written consequent upon this message.
('20', 413, 0, 1, 962777) 414 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('20', 413, 1, 2, 962819) At the very earliest stage of the War, even whilst I was in London organizing the Indian Volunteer Ambulance Corps, 1 I began to interest myself in the Khilafat question.
('20', 413, 1, 3, 962990) I perceived how deeply moved the little Mussulman world in London was when Turkey decided to throw in her lot with Germany.
('20', 413, 1, 4, 963114) 2 On my arrival in India in the January of 1915 I found the same anxiousness and earnestness among the Mussulmans with whom I came in contact.
('20', 413, 1, 5, 963257) Their anxiety became intense when the information about the secret treaties 3 leaked out.
('20', 413, 1, 6, 963347) Distrust of British intentions filled their minds and despair took possession of them.
('20', 413, 1, 7, 963434) Even at that moment I advised my Mussulman friends not to give way to despair but to express their fears and their hopes in a disciplined manner.
('20', 413, 1, 8, 963580) It will be admitted that the whole of Mussulman India has behaved in a singularly restrained manner during the past five years, and that the leaders have been able to keep the turbulent sections of their community under complete control.
('20', 413, 2, 9, 963818) The peace Terms 4 and Your Excellency’s defence of them 5 have given the Mussulmans of India a shock from which it will be difficult for them to recover.
('20', 413, 2, 10, 963972) The terms violate Ministerial pledges and utterly disregard Mussulman sentiment.
('20', 413, 2, 11, 964053) I consider that as a staunch Hindu wishing to live on terms of the closest friendship with my Mussulman countrymen, I should be an unworthy son of India if I did not stand by them in their hour of trial.
('20', 413, 2, 12, 964257) In my humble opinion their cause is just.
('20', 413, 2, 13, 964299) They claim that Turkey must not be punished if their sentiment is to be respected.
('20', 413, 2, 14, 964382) Muslim soldiers did not fight to inflict punishment on their own Khalifa or to deprive him or his territories.
('20', 413, 2, 15, 964493) The Mussulman attitude has been consistent throughout these five years.
('20', 413, 3, 16, 964565) My duty to the Empire to which I owe my loyalty requires me to resist the cruel violence that has been done to the Mussulman sentiment.
('20', 413, 4, 17, 964701) So far as I am aware Mussulmans and Hindus have as a whole lost faith in British justice and honour.

('20', 414, 1, 4, 965613) I have not lost faith in such superiority and I am not without hope that somehow or other justice will yet be rendered if we show the requisite capacity for suffering.

('20', 415, 1, 2, 967584) violent eruption, if the people had not had presented to them a form of direct action involving considerable sacrifice and ensuring success, if such a direct action was largely taken up by the public.
('20', 415, 1, 3, 967785) Non co operation was the only dignified and constitutional form of such direct action, for it is the right recognized from times immemorial of the subject to refuse to assist a ruler who misrules.
('20', 415, 1, 4, 967982) At the same time I admit that non co operation practised by the mass of people is attended with grave risks.

('20', 415, 3, 12, 968923) 169. THE NON CO OPERATION COMMITTEE
('20', 415, 4, 13, 968959) There seems to be a great deal of misunderstanding and misconception about the non co operation committee appointed by the Khilafat Committee at Allahabad on the 3rd instant.
('20', 415, 4, 14, 969134) A friend who was present at the meeting writes to say that the committee was formed for the purpose of giving full effect to non co operation and to act in all matters in connection with it as if it was representative of the whole Mussulman population of India even in the matter of making representations to the authorities.
('20', 415, 4, 15, 969460) That this was not the committee’s scope is the purpose of this writing to show.
('20', 415, 5, 16, 969540) 1 Lord Hardinge
('20', 416, 0, 1, 969556) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 417
('20', 416, 1, 2, 969596) As I stated its objects when I invited the formation of the committee, 1 they were to ascertain and enforce the wish of the nation on non co operation.
('20', 416, 1, 3, 969748) Whilst it is a representative body with full powers to act, it cannot be said—it is not intended—to represent all the best and the most influential Mohammedan opinion.
('20', 416, 1, 4, 969916) It does not for instance represent the titled nobility in Islam.
('20', 416, 1, 5, 969981) It is no fault in the committee.
('20', 416, 1, 6, 970014) It has been purposely restricted to those who are able to give their whole time and attention to the work of organized non co operation and in the process of ensuring obedience to instructions, other discipline and non violence.
('20', 416, 1, 7, 970243) It is therefore a committee of workers.
('20', 416, 1, 8, 970283) It is not expected that the whole of the Mussulman India will be equally strong in non co operation.
('20', 416, 1, 9, 970384) Some doubt its efficacy, others consider it to be a milk and water remedy.
('20', 416, 1, 10, 970459) Some dread it as being too strong for India in her present stage; they say she has not developed the measure of sacrifice at present to ensure success.
('20', 416, 1, 11, 970611) The committee does not represent or contain such doubting elements though they may otherwise be much more influential than many Mussulmans who are on the committee.
('20', 416, 1, 12, 970776) It contains those only who have the largest faith in non co operation and who, although they swear by it, yet will not force the pace to the breaking point but will endeavour to carry the nation with its programme, in so far as it is practicable, and who whilst doing so will not themselves be deterred from taking the boldest steps and will seek out those who are prepared to do like wise.
('20', 416, 1, 13, 971167) This committee, therefore, starting without any, has to build its reputation upon its work and upon results it may achieve.
('20', 416, 1, 14, 971291) It will cease to exist if it shows no work or in spite of work shows no results.
('20', 416, 1, 15, 971372) For outsiders it has the least representative capacity.
('20', 416, 1, 16, 971428) Shaukat Ali is an amiable man but a rabid fanatic, carrying no weight with anybody; Hasrat Mohani a useless man who thinks of nothing but swadeshi; Dr. Kitchlew a man of yesterday with no experience of the world outside Amritsar.
('20', 416, 1, 17, 971658) Much the same may be said against the others; I am no doubt a superior person but after all a crank and an interloper at that.
('20', 416, 1, 18, 971785) Any representation signed by it will carry little weight with the outside world in so far as it depends upon the influence of the signatories.
('20', 416, 1, 19, 971928) It does not therefore mean that it will never make representations.
('20', 416, 1, 20, 971996) It certainly will, when swiftness is of the essence or when others for reasons of expediency or otherwise are not prepared to sign representations.
('20', 416, 1, 21, 972144) Indeed, canvassing of signatures to weighty
('20', 416, 2, 22, 972188) 1 Vide “Speech at Khilafat Committee Meeting, Allahabad”, June 3, 1920.
('20', 417, 0, 1, 972260) 418 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('20', 417, 1, 2, 972302) representations will be one of the means of gauging public opinion and testing the spirit of sacrifice among the elite of the land.
('20', 417, 1, 3, 972434) For the masses and for internal work, however, the committee is the most representative.
('20', 417, 1, 4, 972523) It is difficult perhaps to find two men more representative of Mussulman opinion than Shaukat Ali and Hasrat Mohani.
('20', 417, 1, 5, 972640) The others though less known have been chosen for the qualities of strength, perseverance, patience, calmness, truthfulness, courage under difficulty and sacrifice believed to be possessed by them.
('20', 417, 2, 6, 972838) It has been suggested that I am to lead the movement.
('20', 417, 2, 7, 972892) The statement is only partially true.
('20', 417, 2, 8, 972930) I say this not out of humility merely but it is a literal fact.
('20', 417, 2, 9, 972994) If the belief gains ground that I am leading the move ment it may prove fatal to it.
('20', 417, 2, 10, 973079) I am leading the movement in the sense that I am the adviser whose advice is most acceptable today and who has the determination not surpassed by anybody to carry out the programme of non co operation.
('20', 417, 2, 11, 973281) But I do not pretend to represent Mussulman opi nion.
('20', 417, 2, 12, 973335) I can only try to interpret it.
('20', 417, 2, 13, 973367) I could not stand alone and expect to carry the Mussulman masses with me.
('20', 417, 2, 14, 973441) I should be very properly hooted out by a mixed Mussulman audience if I tried to make a point against the best Mussulman opinion in matters of religion.
('20', 417, 2, 15, 973594) But if I were a Muss ulman, I would not mind contesting issues before a Mussulman meeting in the face of heavy odds against me.
('20', 417, 2, 16, 973722) I consider myself to be a sagacious worker and my sagacity means no more and no less than a fine perception of my limitations.
('20', 417, 2, 17, 973849) I hope I never travel beyond my limits.
('20', 417, 2, 18, 973889) Certainly I have never done so consciously.
('20', 417, 2, 19, 973933) It is necessary for every intelligent Mussulman to bear in mind my limitations and the scope of my function.
('20', 417, 2, 20, 974042) Ignorance is likely to prove fatal to the success of the movement.
('20', 417, 2, 21, 974109) My connection with it must not stupefy workers into indolence or indifference.
('20', 417, 2, 22, 974188) My connection should means, if it is to be productive of good results,greater watchfulness, greater sense of responsibility, greater capacity and willingness for work and greater efficiency.
('20', 417, 2, 23, 974379) I can think out plans but execution must ever rest with Mussulman workers.
('20', 417, 2, 24, 974454) The movement must be worked and led by them with the assistance of friends like me but also without if need be.
('20', 417, 2, 25, 974566) I must not be expected to make non co operators; Mussulman leaders alone can make them.
('20', 417, 2, 26, 974654) No amount of sacrifice on my part will produce in the Mussulman world the spirit of non co operation, i.e., sacrifice in a matter of religion.
('20', 417, 2, 27, 974797) The Mussulman leaders will have to show it in their own persons before the masses evolve it.
('20', 418, 0, 1, 974890) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 419
('20', 418, 1, 2, 974930) And now the question why there are no Hindu leaders on the committee is easily answered.
('20', 418, 1, 3, 975019) The supreme committee can only be purely Mussulman.
('20', 418, 1, 4, 975071) My presence, too, I consider as an evil but it is a necessary evil because of my qualifications.
('20', 418, 1, 5, 975168) I have specialized in non co operation.
('20', 418, 1, 6, 975208) I have successfully experimented with it.
('20', 418, 1, 7, 975250) The resolution about non co operation was conceived by me at the conference at Delhi.
('20', 418, 1, 8, 975336) 1 I am on the committee therefore as a specialist and not because I am a Hindu.
('20', 418, 1, 9, 975416) My function is therefore of an adviser merely.
('20', 418, 1, 10, 975463) That I happen to be a staunch Hindu with the conviction that every Hindu should consider it to be his duty to go with the Mussulmans the full length in non co operation, is no doubt an advantage to the committee.
('20', 418, 1, 11, 975676) But that advantage was at its disposal whether I was on it or not.
('20', 418, 1, 12, 975743) Whilst I am considering the Hindu connection with the Khilafat movement, even at the risk of repetition I would like to clear up my own position.
('20', 418, 1, 13, 975889) As I consider the Muslim claim to be intrinsically (as distinguished from religiously) just, I propose to go with them to the extent of fullest non co operation.
('20', 418, 1, 14, 976051) And I consider it to be perfectly con sistent with my loyalty to the British connection.
('20', 418, 1, 15, 976140) But I would not go with the Mussulmans in any campaign of violence.
('20', 418, 1, 16, 976208) I could not help them in promoting, for instance, an invasion of India through Afghanistan or otherwise for the purpose of forcing better peace terms.
('20', 418, 1, 17, 976359) 2 It is, I hold, the duty of every Hindu to resist any inroad on India even for the purpose specified as it is his duty to help his Mussulman brethren to satisfy their just demands by means of non co operation or other form of suffering, no matter how great, so long as it does not involve loss of India’s liberty or inflicting of violence on any person.
('20', 418, 1, 18, 976714) And I have thrown myself whole heartedly into the non co operation movement, if only because I want to prevent any such armed conflict.

('20', 419, 2, 6, 978125) The Leader correspondent says :
('20', 419, 3, 7, 978157) He has since been restored to his position of a Deputy Commissioner of the second grade from which he was degraded and also been invested with powers under Sect.
('20', 419, 3, 8, 978319) 30 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

('20', 419, 3, 10, 978487) The correspondent adds :
('20', 419, 4, 11, 978512) I use both these words deliberately for conveying precisely what they mean.
('20', 419, 4, 12, 978588) I cull a few passages from this illuminating letter to illustrate the meaning of horror and tyranny :
('20', 419, 5, 13, 978690) In private complaints he never takes the statement of the complainant.
('20', 419, 5, 14, 978761) It is taken down by the reader when the court rises and got signed by the magistrate the following day.
('20', 419, 5, 15, 978865) Whether the report (received upon such complaints) is favourable to the complainant or unfavourable to him it is never read by the magistrate, and complaints are dismissed without proper trial.
('20', 419, 5, 16, 979059) This is the fate of private complaints.
('20', 419, 5, 17, 979099) Now, as regards police challans, pleaders for the accused are not allowed to interview undertrial prisoners in police custody.
('20', 419, 5, 18, 979226) They are not allowed to cross examine prosecution witnesses.
('20', 419, 5, 19, 979287) Prosecution witnesses are exa mined with leading questions .
('20', 419, 5, 20, 979348) Thus a whole prosecution story is put into the mouth of police witnesses.
('20', 419, 5, 21, 979422) Witnesses for the defence, though called in, are not allowed to be examined by the defence counsel.
('20', 419, 5, 22, 979522) The accused is silenced if he picks up courage to say anything in defence.
('20', 419, 5, 23, 979597) Any Cantonment servant can write down the name of any citizen of the Cantonment on a chit of paper and ask him to appear the next day in court.
('20', 419, 5, 24, 979741) This is a summons .
('20', 419, 5, 25, 979761) If anyone does not appear in court, who is thus ordered, criminal warrants of arrest are issued against him.
('20', 419, 5, 26, 979870) There is much more of this style in the letter which is worth producing, but I have given enough to illustrate the writer’s meaning.

('20', 421, 6, 19, 984639) 2 Whenever he had had occasion to speak to the Pandit on the subject he had told him that he should make the furtherance of the cause of the University the principal work of his life.

('20', 421, 7, 21, 984922) 1 Who were arrested under the Martial Law and subsequently released under the amnesty announced in the Royal Proclamation of December 23, 1919 2 Malaviya founded the University in 1916, worked on the scheme for a number of years and collected a fund of a crore of rupees to get the University going.

('20', 422, 1, 2, 985262) and devote himself entirely to the cause of the University.
('20', 422, 1, 3, 985322) 1 Bombay had always been famous for the ready manner in which it came to the help of a deserving cause and he had no doubt that Bombay would extend its support to the University with her wonted generosity.

('20', 423, 1, 2, 987237) 173. “IN MEMORIAM”
('20', 423, 2, 3, 987256) Ashad Sud 11, 1976 [June 26, 1920] It is difficult for me to write about Bhai Vrajlal’s death.
('20', 423, 2, 4, 987351) I still cannot forget his figure.
('20', 423, 2, 5, 987385) Not being free from moha yet, I do not find it easy to write objectively.
('20', 423, 2, 6, 987459) I envy his death.
('20', 423, 2, 7, 987477) I look upon him as a fortunate man indeed.
('20', 423, 2, 8, 987520) What better death can we imagine than that of a man who had to receive service from no one, who actually died while serving others?
('20', 423, 2, 9, 987652) When one dies a serene death, with God’s name on his lips, we regard him as one hallowed by good deeds.
('20', 423, 2, 10, 987756) Bhai Vrajlal died doing God’s work.
('20', 423, 2, 11, 987792) 1 I am aware that there is some exaggeration in saying this, but I know him so well that I am sure if he had been asked to choose he would have elected to die at the very hour when he did.
('20', 423, 2, 12, 987981) He was ever devoted to dharma.
('20', 423, 2, 13, 988012) He had let me into the depths of his heart.
('20', 423, 2, 14, 988056) So far as I remember, he asked to be alone with me only once.
('20', 423, 2, 15, 988118) He had on that occasion acquainted me with his deepest feelings and told me of his moral dilemmas as well.
('20', 423, 2, 16, 988225) The Ashram was very dear to him, as he showed through his actions.
('20', 423, 2, 17, 988292) I thought of him as a muni 2 .
('20', 423, 2, 18, 988323) He rarely felt inclined to talk but his face was ever radiant.
('20', 423, 2, 19, 988386) He never looked upon any work as low and used to take the utmost service from his body.
('20', 423, 2, 20, 988474) It is difficult, it would even be a sin, to forget his serene image.
('20', 423, 2, 21, 988543) How should we cherish his memory?
('20', 423, 2, 22, 988577) There is, I think, only one way for us, namely, to emulate his many fine qualities.
('20', 423, 2, 23, 988661) He saw dharma in keeping silent and occupying himself in cheerful service.
('20', 423, 2, 24, 988736) Let us keep him ever living by accepting this dharma and following it ever more firmly and filling our life with his.

('20', 424, 1, 2, 989130) 174. SPEECH ON HUNTER COMMITTEE REPORT 1
('20', 424, 2, 3, 989171) BOMBAY, June 26, 1920 The demands in this resolution go beyond those in the Congress Committee Report.
('20', 424, 2, 4, 989274) The resolution calls for the impeachment of O’Dwyer and his fellow officers.
('20', 424, 2, 5, 989351) The Congress Sub committee did not go so far, though the All India Congress Committee has made this demand.
('20', 424, 2, 6, 989459) My personal view still favours the Sub committee report, but I move this resolution in deference to the wishes of the majority.
('20', 424, 2, 7, 989587) I believe the Hunter Report is a plain, deliberate shielding of the officials in the Punjab.
('20', 424, 2, 8, 989680) If I could have my way, I would bring in a resolution advising non co operation and satyagraha against this, for that is the only way to succeed in our aim.
('20', 424, 2, 9, 989837) I have not come here to make a speech; I speak from the depth of my heart.
('20', 424, 2, 10, 989912) I have not come here to persuade you merely to pass resolutions, but to do many more things.
('20', 424, 2, 11, 990005) If you can get Lord Chelmsford recalled to England, you will have done a far more important thing than hanging O’Dwyer or Dyer.
('20', 424, 2, 12, 990133) The man who is most guilty of slighting public opinion should be the first to be removed.
('20', 424, 2, 13, 990223) The hero of Martial Law, Bosworth Smith, still holds his post.
('20', 424, 2, 14, 990286) The people should aim at having Dyer, O’Dwyer and Lord Chelmsford debarred from holding any post.
('20', 424, 2, 15, 990384) In this resolution, we also ask for the return of fines to the people and compensation for their losses.
('20', 424, 2, 16, 990489) You probably do not know the horror of these fines.
('20', 424, 2, 17, 990541) There is no sense in asking for the dismissal of the officials while these huge fines remain unreturned.
('20', 424, 2, 18, 990646) So long as the Rowlatt Act remains on the Statute book, satyagraha is bound to go on.
('20', 424, 2, 19, 990732) If only the people learn how to use this weapon, all sufferings would end.
('20', 424, 2, 20, 990807) My own faith in satyagraha is unshakable.
('20', 424, 2, 21, 990849) The Punjab injustices still remain unredressed.
('20', 424, 2, 22, 990897) For these injustices, we are as much responsible as the officials.
('20', 424, 2, 23, 990964) Our minimum demands are three : Lord Chelmsford’s recall, return of the fines and the Rowlatt Act to be buried for ever.

('20', 425, 1, 2, 991634) 175. KHILAFAT
('20', 425, 2, 3, 991648) We have taken one step forward on this question, and not an ordinary one at that.
('20', 425, 2, 4, 991730) The Viceroy was served with a notice 1 that he should take our side or else we would not be able to co operate with him in carrying on the government.
('20', 425, 2, 5, 991881) Let us hope that the Viceroy will have wisdom enough to take up the people’s fight.
('20', 425, 2, 6, 991965) The British Empire, however, is not so fortunate as to see such a glorious day.
('20', 425, 2, 7, 992045) Hence, we have no choice but to prepare for non co operation from August 1. The non co operation about which there has been so much talking and which has consumed so much paper and ink is near at hand.
('20', 425, 2, 8, 992247) We must be ready for it in a month’s time.
('20', 425, 2, 9, 992290) The Muslims and Hindus will be put to the test.
('20', 425, 2, 10, 992338) But, at the moment, I wish to say a few words to the Hindus alone.
('20', 425, 2, 11, 992405) Before the Muslims act about the Khilafat, the Hindus need not do anything.
('20', 425, 2, 12, 992481) When, however, the Muslims start non co operation, what should the Hindus do?
('20', 425, 2, 13, 992559) A prominent Hindu gentleman in Allahabad said that for one Muslim resigning his position as Justice of the Peace or throwing up a job, three Hindus will be ready to follow suit.
('20', 425, 2, 14, 992737) They will not have done much thereby.
('20', 425, 2, 15, 992775) Muslims number more than seven crores and Hindus more than twenty two crores; that means there are more than three times as many Hindus as Muslims.
('20', 425, 2, 16, 992923) If there are three Hindus to stand by the side of every single Muslim, both Hindus and Muslims will have made equal sacrifices and to have done this will be evidence of friendship.
('20', 425, 2, 17, 993104) In fact, friendship admits of no arithmetical calculation.
('20', 425, 2, 18, 993163) But this does not mean that a friend may contribute less than his share.
('20', 425, 2, 19, 993236) Friendship means or should mean that, even though paying very much more than one’s share, one should feel that nothing has been paid.
('20', 425, 2, 20, 993370) We have, then, to ask ourselves whether the Hindus will stand by the Muslims; nay, the eyes of the whole world will be fixed on the Hindus for whether the Muslims win or not will depend largely on the attitude of the Hindus.
('20', 425, 2, 21, 993595) If they support the Muslims, there is no doubt that the latter’s sufferings will end the sooner.
('20', 425, 2, 22, 993692) Hindus can avail themselves [of the opportunity] in two ways; one, by making sacrifices in proportion to those of Muslims and, two, by refusing to jump into the positions given up by Muslims.
('20', 425, 2, 23, 993884) The first
('20', 425, 3, 24, 993894) 1 By the Khilafat Committee which met in Allahabad on June 9
('20', 426, 0, 1, 993955) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 427
('20', 426, 1, 2, 993995) means that for every Muslim giving up his job there will be from one to three Hindus doing so.
('20', 426, 1, 3, 994090) If Hindus act in this way, they will have done a great thing.
('20', 426, 1, 4, 994152) The second means that no Hindu will fill the place left vacant by a Muslim and this too will be something great.
('20', 426, 1, 5, 994265) Any Hindu taking up a job given up by a Muslim will have acted as an enemy of the latter and non co operation will become, if not impossible, extremely difficult.
('20', 426, 1, 6, 994428) Thus, the Hindu who cannot do more may at any rate attend their meetings to show his sympathy and refrain from putting obstacles in their way and thus prove that he is not hostile to them.

('20', 426, 4, 9, 994654) 176. LIVING ON THE PAST
('20', 426, 5, 10, 994678) As a son cannot live on his father’s reputation for long, so the people of India cannot maintain their prosperity only on the strength of the glory of ancient India.
('20', 426, 5, 11, 994844) We saw last week that at present there is poverty, not prosperity, in India.
('20', 426, 5, 12, 994921) We have to think over the causes and remedies for this state of affairs.
('20', 426, 5, 13, 994994) Akbar’s successors lost the splendour of the Mogul Empire of his time, because they lost, one by one, Akbar’s qualities of character.
('20', 426, 5, 14, 995128) Jehangir lost one, Shahjehan one more, Aurangzeb more still and his successors lost almost all.
('20', 426, 5, 15, 995224) The result was that they lost the Empire to the British.
('20', 426, 5, 16, 995281) The Indian people in modern times have behaved like Akbar’s successors.
('20', 426, 5, 17, 995353) Not wanting to admit this, we blame the British for everything; we fell because of their cunning, they robbed us of our wealth and left us beggars, we cannot even breathe without their permission; how are we to blame then [we ask]?
('20', 426, 5, 18, 995585) Though there is much exaggeration in this charge, there is also some truth in it.
('20', 426, 5, 19, 995667) What is the cause of the control the British have acquired over us?
('20', 426, 5, 20, 995735) May it not be our own fault?
('20', 426, 5, 21, 995764) Who were the people tempted by the rupees of the East India Company?
('20', 426, 5, 22, 995833) If that Company did business according to its own fashion, does the fault lie with it?
('20', 426, 5, 23, 995920) If a wine merchant sells wine, can the consumer throw the responsibility on him?
('20', 426, 5, 24, 996001) If I pay to the usurer interest equal to the principal, how is that the usurer’s fault?
('20', 426, 5, 25, 996089) I, at any rate, cannot speak ill of him.
('20', 426, 5, 26, 996130) A writer
('20', 427, 0, 1, 996139) 428 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('20', 427, 1, 2, 996181) has said that as long as there are persons who can be deceived, so long will deceivers exist.
('20', 427, 1, 3, 996275) We shall not advance by finding fault with and hating the British.
('20', 427, 1, 4, 996342) As long as we have not got rid of the shortcomings which enabled the British to get a hold here, we shall remain slaves.
('20', 427, 1, 5, 996463) And yet we are always pointing out their faults to the British and will continue to do so.
('20', 427, 1, 6, 996554) This is what the Congress has mainly done.
('20', 427, 1, 7, 996597) Speakers who do this are as numerous as leaves on a tree.
('20', 427, 1, 8, 996655) I believe, therefore, that it will be more fruitful to try and see our own faults than to dwell on those of the British.
('20', 427, 1, 9, 996776) The saying “If we are good, the entire world is good” is not to be lightly brushed aside.
('20', 427, 1, 10, 996866) There is much force in it.
('20', 427, 1, 11, 996893) If we remain upright, nobody will be able to corrupt us.
('20', 427, 1, 12, 996950) It is a principle of medical science that so long as one’s blood is free from impurity, the poisonous air outside can have no effect on it.
('20', 427, 1, 13, 997090) That is why , during an epidemic, some people are attacked while others are not.
('20', 427, 1, 14, 997171) Likewise, had we been incorruptible, the East India Company could have done nothing and at the present time, too, officers like Michael O’Dwyer would have lost their jobs.
('20', 427, 1, 15, 997343) What are our failings, then, because of which we are helpless and cannot stop the profuse flow of wealth from our country, and in virtue of which our children get no milk, three crores of our people get only one meal a day, raids occur in broad daylight in Kheda district, 1 and epidemics like the plague and cholera cannot be eradicated in our country while they can in others?
('20', 427, 1, 16, 997722) How is it that the haughty Sir Michael O’Dwyer and the insolent General Dyer can crush us like so many bugs and the priest in Simla can write unworthy things about us; how is it that an intolerable injustice has been done to us in the Punjab?
('20', 427, 1, 17, 997965) On the Khilafat issue, the British Prime Minister has gone back on his word.
('20', 427, 1, 18, 998042) In both these matters, we seem to feel helpless.
('20', 427, 1, 19, 998091) The reason is our inveterate selfishness, our inability to make sacrifices for the country, our dishonesty, our timidity, our hypocrisy and our ignorance.
('20', 427, 1, 20, 998246) Everybody is selfish, more or less, but we seem to be more selfish than others.
('20', 427, 1, 21, 998326) We make some self sacrifice in family matters, but very little of it for national work.
('20', 427, 1, 22, 998414) Just look at our streets, our cities and our trains..
('20', 427, 1, 23, 998468) In all these, we can see the condition of the country.
('20', 427, 1, 24, 998523) How little attention is paid to the convenience of others in streets, in the town as a whole and in trains?
('20', 427, 1, 25, 998631) We do not hesitate to throw refuse out of our courtyard on to the street; standing in the
('20', 427, 2, 26, 998721) 1Vide “Notes”, 30 5 1920.
('20', 428, 0, 1, 998747) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 429
('20', 428, 1, 2, 998787) balcony, we throw out refuse or spit, without pausing to consider whether we are not inconveniencing the passersby.
('20', 428, 1, 3, 998903) When we are building a house, we take little thought of the inconvenience that may be caused to our neighbours.
('20', 428, 1, 4, 999015) In cities, we keep the tap open and, thinking that it is not our water which flows away, we allow it to run waste.
('20', 428, 1, 5, 999130) The same thing is seen in the trains.

('20', 428, 2, 16, 999877) How many give up a job when necessary, for the sake of the country?
('20', 428, 2, 17, 999945) Where are the men who will reduce their luxuries and adopt simplicity and use the money so saved for the country?
('20', 428, 2, 18, 1000059) If it is necessary for the country’s sake to go to jail, how many will come forward?
('20', 428, 3, 19, 1000144) Our dishonesty is there for all to see.
('20', 428, 3, 20, 1000184) We believe that business can never be carried on honestly.
('20', 428, 3, 21, 1000243) Those who have the chance never refuse a bribe.
('20', 428, 3, 22, 1000291) We have the worst experience of corruption in the railways.

('20', 428, 3, 24, 1000446) Even for securing a railway ticket, we have to use dishonest means or shut one’s eyes to them.
('20', 428, 3, 25, 1000541) The contents of railway parcels which can be opened ever so slightly, if not of those which are wellpacked, are sure to be pilfered.
('20', 428, 4, 26, 1000674) Our hypocrisy is only a little less than that of the British.

('20', 428, 5, 31, 1001062) We are so possessed by the fear of the Government’s armed might that we dare not take any step.
('20', 428, 5, 32, 1001158) And so we submit to force in every matter and allow dacoits to plunder us in broad daylight.
('20', 429, 0, 1, 1001251) 430 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('20', 429, 1, 2, 1001293) What shall I say about our hypocrisy?
('20', 429, 1, 3, 1001331) It has increased in every field.
('20', 429, 1, 4, 1001364) Weakness is always accompanied by hypocrisy.
('20', 429, 1, 5, 1001409) Moreover, where the people want to be upright but cannot be so, hypocrisy will naturally increase; for, if we are not upright, we are anxious to seem so and thus we add another moral weakness to the one which we already possess.
('20', 429, 1, 6, 1001638) Hypocrisy has entered our religion as well, and that so fully that the marks which we put on our forehead, the rosary and things of that kind have ceased to be tokens of piety and become signs of impiety.
('20', 429, 1, 7, 1001843) The origin of all is ignorance, to be sure.
('20', 429, 1, 8, 1001887) It is because we are ignorant of our strength that other weaknesses grow.
('20', 429, 1, 9, 1001961) We doubt the very existence of the atman in us, have to faith in its powers.
('20', 429, 1, 10, 1002038) This ignorance will not disappear merely with education.
('20', 429, 1, 11, 1002095) It can go only with a change in our ways of thinking.
('20', 429, 1, 12, 1002149) Literacy is necessary only to the extent that it develops our thinking power and teaches us to distinguish between good and evil.
('20', 429, 1, 13, 1002279) Hence, so long as we have not given up our selfishness and learnt to be mindful of the interests of others, have not learnt self sacrifice, have not taken refuge in truth, eschewed fear and become brave, shed hypocrisy and banished ignorance, the country will not prosper in any real sense.

('20', 439, 3, 4, 1024797) TURKISH PEACE TERMS 1
('20', 439, 4, 5, 1024819) 1. The frontiers of Turkey will be as already demarcated, and where necessary revised by a Boundary Commission to be created.
('20', 439, 4, 6, 1024945) According to this delimitation Turkey will include the Constantinople sector of Thrace and all the predominantly Turkish areas of Asia Minor.
('20', 439, 5, 7, 1025087) 2. The rights and titles of the Turkish Government in Constantinople will not be affected, but the right to modify this provision is reserved in the event of the failure of Turkey faithfully to fulfil the treaty.
('20', 439, 6, 8, 1025300) 3. A Commission of the Straits will have authority over all waters between the Mediterranean mouth of the Dardanelles, the Black Sea mouth of the Bosphorous, and of the waters within three miles of each of these mouths; also on the shores to such extent as may be necessary.
('20', 439, 6, 9, 1025575) The duty of the Commission will be to ensure freedom of navigation in these waters in peace and war.
('20', 439, 7, 10, 1025676) 4. A scheme of local self government will be drafted for Kurdistan, including provision for the protection of the Assyro Chaldeans and other minorities.
('20', 439, 7, 11, 1025829) The League of Nations will decide later whether Kurdistan should be granted independence of Turkey, if it be proved that separation is desired by the majority of the Kurdish people.
('20', 439, 8, 12, 1026011) 5. Certain portions of Smyrna are formed into a separate unit to be administered by Greece, the suzerainty of Turkey being continued for a period of years till the autonomous State of Smyrna decides its own destiny.
('20', 439, 9, 13, 1026227) 6. With the exception of the Constantinople sector, Eastern Thrace is ceded to Greece, provision being made for the local self government of the town of Adrianople.
('20', 439, 10, 14, 1026392) 7. Certain portions of the Armenian districts of Turkey are added to the existing Armenian Republic, the boundary between Turkey and Armenia in certain districts being referred to the arbitration of the President of the United States, whose decision will be final thereon and on any stipulation regarding the Armenian access to the sea.
('20', 439, 11, 15, 1026729) 8. Syria, Mesopotamia and Palestine are provisionally recognized as independent States, subject to administrative advice and assistance from a Mandatory Power until such time as they are able to stand alone.
('20', 439, 11, 16, 1026937) The man date for Syria has been entrusted to France and those for Mesopotamia and Palestine to Britain.
('20', 439, 12, 17, 1027041) 1 Communicated by the Allies to Turkey and published in India in Gazette of India Extraordinary, dated May 14, 1920
('20', 440, 0, 1, 1027157) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 441
('20', 440, 1, 2, 1027197) mandate for Palestine will include the provision for giving effect to the declaration of November 8, 1918, regarding the establishment of a national home for the Jewish people.
('20', 440, 2, 3, 1027374) 9. The Hedjaz is recognized as a free and independent State.
('20', 440, 2, 4, 1027435) The King of the Hedjaz undertakes to assure free and easy access to Mecca and Medina to Muslim pilgrims of all countries.
('20', 440, 3, 5, 1027557) 10. Turkey relinquishes all rights and titles over Egypt and the Sudan and Cyprus.
('20', 440, 4, 6, 1027640) 11. Turkey recognizes the French protectorate over Morocco and Tunisia.
('20', 440, 5, 7, 1027712) 12. Turkey relinquishes her claims to certain islands in the Aegean.

('20', 440, 12, 17, 1029140) But it is not necessary to detail these in the present statement.

('20', 440, 13, 19, 1029234) 326 329

('20', 441, 1, 2, 1029284) APPENDIX II
('20', 441, 2, 3, 1029296) VICEROY’S MESSAGE TO MUSLIMS OF INDIA 1
('20', 441, 3, 4, 1029336) The decisions of the Supreme Council of the Allies in respect of the peace settlement with Turkey have been made known to the world.
('20', 441, 3, 5, 1029469) They have been reached after the most careful and anxious consideration of representations from the Muslims of all countries, and you have my assurance that before coming to its present decision the Supreme Council has had all possible regard to those representations which have proceeded from the Mohammedan subjects of His Majesty in India.
('20', 441, 3, 6, 1029812) My Government are issuing along with a summary of the peace terms a statement which explains the principal decisions and the reasons for them.
('20', 441, 3, 7, 1029955) These decisions are in full accordance with the high principles which have been applied in the peace settlement with all other Powers lately at war with Britain and her Allies.
('20', 441, 3, 8, 1030132) Nevertheless they include terms which I fear must be painful to all Muslims.
('20', 441, 3, 9, 1030209) The long delays which have protracted your anxiety for over a year although they have been unavoidable, have filled me with regret for your sakes, and now in your hour of trial I desire to send you a message of encouragement and sympathy, which I trust will uphold you.
('20', 441, 3, 10, 1030479) In the day of the Empire’s need you made a splendid response to the call of your King and country, and by so doing you contributed much to the triumph of those ideals of justice and humanity for which the Allies fought.
('20', 441, 3, 11, 1030699) The Empire of which you form a part is now firmly established on these ideals and a great future of political progress and material prosperity is within the grasp of the Muslims of India, who have ever enjoyed under British rule the fullest religious freedom.
('20', 441, 3, 12, 1030959) Before the late disastrous War Great Britain had always maintained the closest ties of friendship with Turkey and I am confident with the conclusion of this new treaty that friendship will quickly take life again and a Turkey regenerate, full of hope and strength, will stand forth in the future as in the past, a pillar of the Islamic faith.
('20', 441, 3, 13, 1031302) This thought will, I trust, strengthen you to accept the peace terms with resignation, courage and fortitude, and to keep your loyalty towards the Crown bright and untarnished as it has been for so many generations.
('20', 441, 4, 14, 1031518) God save the King Emperor !
('20', 441, 5, 15, 1031546) (Sd.) CHELMSFORD

('20', 443, 1, 2, 1032980) APPENDIX IV
('20', 443, 2, 3, 1032992) GOVERNMENT OF INDIA DESPATCH ON HUNTER COMMITTEE REPORT
('20', 443, 3, 4, 1033048) GOVERNMENT OF INDIA HOME DEPARTMENT
('20', 443, 4, 5, 1033084) Political
('20', 443, 5, 6, 1033094) TO THE RIGHT HON’BLE EDWIN MONTAGU HIS MAJESTY’S SECRETARY OF STATE FOR INDIA SIMLA
('20', 443, 6, 7, 1033178) May 3, 1920
('20', 443, 8, 8, 1033190) We submit for your information and for any orders His Majesty’s Government may desire to issue the report which was presented on the 8th March, 1920, by the Disorders Committee, together with our review of the report and our conclusions thereon.
('20', 443, 8, 9, 1033436) In the ordinary course the report would have been published with a resolution of the Government of India in the Home Department, but we consider the subject so important that after discussion with you we have decided that it is best to communicate to you our views and findings on the report for the information of His Majesty’s Government.
('20', 443, 8, 10, 1033777) We desire to add that our views and conclusions are unanimous, except on those points where the dissent of our Hon’ble Colleague, Mr. Shafi, has been expressly indicated.
('20', 443, 8, 11, 1033948) We may also state that our Hon’ble Colleague, Sir George Lowndes, now on leave, concurred in all the conclusions we had reached up to the time of his departure.
('20', 443, 9, 12, 1034109) 2. In Resolution No.
('20', 443, 9, 13, 1034130) 2168, dated the 14th October 1919, the Governor General in Council with the approval of the Secretary of State appointed a Com mittee to investigate the disturbances in Bombay, Delhi and the Punjab, their causes, and the measures taken to cope with them.
('20', 443, 9, 14, 1034385) The Hon’ble Lord Hunter, lately Solicitor General for Scotland and now Senator of the College of Justice in Scotland, was appointed President of the Committee, which consisted of the following Members :
('20', 443, 10, 15, 1034588) (1) The Hon’ble Mr. Justice G. C. Rankin, Judge of the High Court, Calcutta.
('20', 443, 11, 16, 1034665) (2) The Hon’ble Mr. W. F. Rice, C.S.I., I.C.S., Additional Secretary to the Government of India, Home Department.
('20', 443, 12, 17, 1034779) (3) Major General Sir George Barrow, K.C.B., K.C.M.G., I.A., Commanding the Peshawar Division.
('20', 443, 13, 18, 1034874) (4) The Hon’ble Pandit Jagat Narayan, B.A., Member of the Legislative Council of the Lieutenant Governor of the United Provinces.
('20', 444, 0, 1, 1035004) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 445
('20', 444, 1, 2, 1035044) (5) The Hon’ble Mr. Thomas Smith, Member of the Legislative Council of the Lieutenant Governor of the United Provinces.
('20', 444, 2, 3, 1035164) (6) Sir Chimanlal Harilal Setalvad, KT., Advocate of the High Court, Bombay.
('20', 444, 3, 4, 1035241) (7) Sardar Sahibzada Sultan Ahmed Khan, Muntazim ud Doula, M.A., L.L.M., (Cantab.), Bar at Law, Member for Appeals, Gwalior State.
('20', 444, 4, 5, 1035372) The Committee began its sittings on the 29th October, 1919, and after hearing evidence at Delhi, Lahore, Ahmedabad, and Bombay finished its labours in the first week of March 1920, when its report was presented to the Government of India.
('20', 444, 5, 6, 1035611) Before reviewing the findings of the Committee we desire to make some preliminary observations regarding the scope of the enquiry, the procedure followed by the Committee in recording evidence, and the general character of its conclusions.
('20', 444, 6, 7, 1035851) 3. In order to obtain a general view of the character of the disturbances and of the scope of the enquiry it will be useful to explain briefly the relative geographical position of the chief centres of disorder and to refer to a few salient dates which indicate the sequence of events in point of time.
('20', 444, 6, 8, 1036154) It was at Delhi—the Capital of India and from its historical and commercial importance a determing factor of considerable weight in the attitude of the rest of Northern India—that disturbances first occurred on the 30th March.
('20', 444, 6, 9, 1036381) They were of such a character as required the use of the military to restore order and before this was achieved it became necessary to fire twice on the mob.
('20', 444, 6, 10, 1036539) On the 10th April violent rioting took place at Amritsar and Lahore in the Punjab, and at Ahmedabad in the Presidency of Bombay, and distinct unrest manifested itself in a minor degree at places as far distant as Calcutta and Bombay.
('20', 444, 6, 11, 1036773) Lahore is a city of 230,000 inhabitants and the capital of the Punjab.
('20', 444, 6, 12, 1036844) Amritsar, which is 20 miles east of Lahore, is a town of more than 150,000 inhabitants and of great commercial importance.
('20', 444, 6, 13, 1036967) Ahmedabad has a population of roughly 280,000 and is an industrial town where 78 mills are located.
('20', 444, 6, 14, 1037067) The distances respectively of Lahore, Amritsar and Ahmedabad from Delhi are roughly 300, 280 and 540 miles.
('20', 444, 6, 15, 1037175) The situation in the Punjab after the 10th April rapidly deteriorated and Martial Law was proclaimed on the 15th April in the districts of Lahore and Amritsar, and shortly after in three other districts.
('20', 444, 6, 16, 1037379) About two weeks later a thundercloud on the frontier burst and the mobilization of troops for the Afghan war began on the 4th May.
('20', 444, 6, 17, 1037510) This seriously affected the general situation in the Punjab and it was not found possible to withdraw Martial Law from all the districts concerned before the 12th June nor from railway lands till a later date.
('20', 444, 6, 18, 1037720) These were briefly the events which with their causes and consequences formed the subject matter of the Committee’s enquiry.
('20', 444, 7, 19, 1037845) 4. The next point to which the Government of India wish to advert is the
('20', 445, 0, 1, 1037918) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 446
('20', 445, 1, 2, 1037960) decision of the All India Congress Committee to obstain from presenting evidence before the Committee of Enquiry.
('20', 445, 1, 3, 1038074) As explained by Lord Hunter in his letter of the 8th March forwarding the Report of the Committee, all persons desirous of giving evidence were invited to submit their names and addresses, together with a brief memorandum of the points on which they desired to give evidence, and it was left to the Committee to decide what evidence they would hear.
('20', 445, 1, 4, 1038424) Lord Hunter has described the circumstances in which the Congress Committee declined after the 12th November further to assist the Committee of Enquiry by appearing before it and tendering evidence, the offer which the same body made on the 30th December to produce their evidence and reopen the enquiry, and the reasons which led Lord Hunter to reject that offer.
('20', 445, 1, 5, 1038789) We believe that Lord hunter’s account of the matter will convince all reasonable people that his decision was fully justified.
('20', 445, 1, 6, 1038916) The point, however, which we wish to emphasize—and it is one which was present to Lord Hunter’s mind also—is this, that the material placed at the disposal of the Committee and the evidence laid before it covered the whole field of enquiry.
('20', 445, 1, 7, 1039157) The official witnesses fully disclosed all they knew regarding the events in which they had participated and placed before the Committee all correspondence and other documentary evidence which had any bearing on the nature of the outbreak, the suppression of the disturbances, or the administration of Martial Law.
('20', 445, 1, 8, 1039472) It is a matter of regret to Government that this was not supplemented by the additional evidence which the Congress Committee had collected and that the evidence which has since been published by that body has not therefore been subjected to examination by an impartial tribunal.
('20', 445, 1, 9, 1039752) They are doubtful, however, whether it would have made any substantial difference to the general picture placed before the Committee, although it might have thrown further light on particular incidents.
('20', 445, 1, 10, 1039955) With regard to the firing at Jallianwala Bagh, on which the attention of the public both at home and in India has been so largely concentrated since December last, the Committee had the most ample materials for judgment and further evidence would have contributed nothing to their knowledge of the facts.
('20', 445, 2, 11, 1040260) 5. The Committee have now submitted their recommendations in the form of a majority and minority report.
('20', 445, 2, 12, 1040365) The majority report is signed by the President and four members of the Committee, Mr. Justice Rankin, General Barrow, and Messrs Rice and Smith.
('20', 445, 2, 13, 1040510) The minority report is signed by Sir C. H. Setalvad, Pandit Jagat Narayan and Sahibzada Sultan Ahmad Khan.
('20', 445, 2, 14, 1040617) While two reports have been submitted, it is a matter of satisfaction to the Government of India that most of the findings of fact are unanimous and that in spite of differences of opinion as to the conclusions to be deduced thereform there is considerable common ground in this respect also.
('20', 445, 2, 15, 1040910) That common ground covers the whole of the events in Delhi and the Bombay Presidency.
('20', 445, 2, 16, 1040996) It also covers much of the narrative of events and the causes of the disturbances in the Punjab.
('20', 445, 2, 17, 1041093) Nor is the divergence in the Punjab findings altogether basic.
('20', 445, 2, 18, 1041156) It is partly one of degree, partly one of essential difference.
('20', 445, 2, 19, 1041220) Certain measures adopted in the
('20', 446, 0, 1, 1041252) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 447
('20', 446, 1, 2, 1041292) suppression of the disturbances and the administration of Martial Law are condemned in both reports but with varying degrees of severity.
('20', 446, 1, 3, 1041430) This remark applies in particular to the joint condemnation of the firing at Jallianwala Bagh.
('20', 446, 1, 4, 1041525) The most important point on which there is an essential difference of opinion relates to the introduction of Martial Law in the Punjab.
('20', 446, 1, 5, 1041661) While the majority find that a state of rebellion existed, necessitating or justifying the adoption of that measure, the minority consider that the disorders did not amount to rebellion and that the disturbances might have been suppressed and order restored without abrogating the control of the civil authorities or calling in military force save as auxiliary to the civil power.
('20', 446, 2, 6, 1042042) 6. It will be convenient to explain at this stage the arrangement which has been followed in the reports.
('20', 446, 2, 7, 1042148) The first seven chapters of the majority report are devoted to accounts of the disturbances in Delhi, the Bombay Presidency, and the Punjab districts of Amritsar, Lahore, Gujranwala, Gujrat and Lyallpur.
('20', 446, 2, 8, 1042352) In each case the majority briefly review the disturbances and record their findings on the propriety of the measures adopted to check them and to restore order.
('20', 446, 2, 9, 1042513) In Chapter VIII they describe the widespread attacks on communications which have an important bearing on the general nature of the disorders.
('20', 446, 2, 10, 1042656) In Chapter IX they discuss the causes of the disturbances with more particular reference to the Punjab.
('20', 446, 2, 11, 1042760) Chapter X contains a brief description of the stages in the introduction of Martial Law.
('20', 446, 2, 12, 1042849) In Chapter XI the reasons for the introduction and continuance of Martial Law are considered, while Chapter XII is devoted to a criticism of the administration of Martial Law.
('20', 446, 3, 13, 1043025) The minority report follows a somewhat different plan of arrangement.
('20', 446, 3, 14, 1043095) Chapter I sets forth the general extent of the minority’s agreement or disagreement with the findings of the majority.
('20', 446, 3, 15, 1043214) The nature and causes of the disorders are discussed in Chapter II.
('20', 446, 3, 16, 1043282) The justification for the introduction and the continuance of Martial Law in the Punjab is exa mined in Chapter III.
('20', 446, 3, 17, 1043399) Chapter IV is devoted to the firing at Jallianwala Bagh.
('20', 446, 3, 18, 1043456) The admini stration of Martial Law is discussed in Chapter V, the use of armoured trains and aero planes in Chapter VI and the working of the Martial Law courts in Chapter VII.
('20', 446, 4, 19, 1043633) Although it might have been more convenient to review at the outset the findings of the Committee regarding the causes and nature of the disturbances, we are reluctant to depart from the general plan of the majority report, as any such departure would increase the difficulty of comparing its findings with those of the minority.
('20', 446, 4, 20, 1043963) We accordingly propose to examine the report chapter by chapter, to state our conclusions on the findings of the majority and minority, more particularly where these differ, and finally to explain the action which in our judgment should be taken on the report.
('20', 446, 5, 21, 1044224) 7. Chapter I deals with the disturbances at Delhi.
('20', 446, 5, 22, 1044275) The Committee are
('20', 447, 0, 1, 1044293) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 448
('20', 447, 1, 2, 1044335) unanimous in finding that the authorities handled the situation in an adequate and reasonable manner, that there was no provocative or unnecessary display of military force, and that the firing was justified on the three occasions on which it was found necessary to resort to this extreme measure.
('20', 447, 1, 3, 1044633) The actual collisions between the police and mobs are found to be the bye products of the satyagraha movement.
('20', 447, 1, 4, 1044744) The majority recognize that Mr. Gandhi’s visit to Delhi after the first outbreak, if not prevented, would have been a serious embarrassment to the executive authorities there and might well have proved a source of great danger.
('20', 447, 1, 5, 1044972) The minority, while doubtful of the expediency of his exclusion and, while thinking that his presence might have had a beneficial result, do not deny the possibility of developments endangering the public peace.
('20', 447, 1, 6, 1045184) The only criticism passed by the Committee on the measures adopted by the local authorities is that the Deputy Commissioner made a mistake in enrolling a number of leading citizens as special constables, though, as they point out, these persons were not called on to render any services.
('20', 447, 2, 7, 1045472) We accept these conclusions and have perused with satisfaction the commendation which has been bestowed by the Committee on the handling of the situation by the local officers.
('20', 447, 2, 8, 1045649) We do not consider that any blame attaches to the Deputy Commissioner for his appointment of special constables, as he acted in accordance with the established practice.
('20', 447, 2, 9, 1045819) We have, however, decided to address local Governments on the question whether the orders now obtaining on the subject in the various provinces require modification or revision.
('20', 447, 2, 10, 1045997) This is the more necessary as it appears that leading citizens were enrolled as special constables at other disturbed centres besides Delhi.
('20', 447, 3, 11, 1046138) The Government of India consider that the events described in this chapter have an important bearing on the rest of the report, for they were the first fruits of the satyagraha movement, the first collision between the forces of order and the adherents of the passive resistance or civil disobedience movement.
('20', 447, 3, 12, 1046449) The behaviour of the crowd on the 30th March, which rendered it necessary for the military and police to fire on two occasions, cannot be ascribed to any action taken against Mr. Gandhi or local politicians.
('20', 447, 3, 13, 1046657) Such action has been pleaded in excuse of later mob excesses, but the internment order against Mr. Gandhi was not passed till ten days after the first outbreak of disorder at Delhi.
('20', 447, 4, 14, 1046839) 8. Chapter II gives an account of the disturbances in the Bombay Presidency.
('20', 447, 4, 15, 1046916) They were confined to Ahmedabad City and Viramgam in the Ahmedabad district, to Nadiad in the Kaira district, and to Bombay City.
('20', 447, 4, 16, 1047046) Viramgam is a town of 20,000 inhabitants 40 miles distant from Ahmedabad, and Nadiad, which has a population of 30,000, is 29 miles from the same city.
('20', 447, 4, 17, 1047198) By far the most serious outbreak of disorder occurred in Ahmedabad which is the home of Mr. Gandhi and may be described as the birth place of the satyagraha movement.
('20', 447, 4, 18, 1047365) The disturbances began
('20', 448, 0, 1, 1047388) VOL. 20 : 25 MARCH, 1920 JUNE, 1920 449
('20', 448, 1, 2, 1047428) on the 10th April as soon as the people of Ahmedabad heard of the action taken against Mr. Gandhi, and were not finally checked till the 14th, although military assistance was called in from the afternoon of the 10th.
('20', 448, 1, 3, 1047646) It is not necessary to follow the report of the Committee into the details of the disturbances and the measures taken to quell them but it is important to notice that for two days mob law reigned in the city and the excesses committed included two atrocious murders, brutal assaults on Europeans and Govern ment officers, and the total destruction of the courts and other Government buildings.
('20', 448, 1, 4, 1048040) The efforts of the police and the military to protect the city and restore order were not successful till the military commander, with the concurrence of the District magistrate, issued a proclamation on the 12th April warning all people that any gathering of over ten individuals collected at one spot would be fired at, and that any single individual seen outside any house between 7 p.m.
('20', 448, 1, 5, 1048431) and 6 a.m.
('20', 448, 1, 6, 1048442) who did not stop when challenged would be shot.
('20', 448, 1, 7, 1048490) The last occasion on which the troops fired was midday of the 13th April and the Committee find that there was not in fact any firing without warning nor was any person fired on, who was not either rioting or encouraging rioters.
('20', 448, 1, 8, 1048720) The outbreak came to an end abruptly on the 14th April and its cessation is ascribed partly to the effects of this proclamation and partly to the return of Mr. Gandhi who, be it said to his credit, used his influence with the people to assist the authorities in restoring order.
('20', 448, 1, 9, 1048999) During the disturbances telegraph wires were cut at eight places in Ahmedabad and at fourteen places outside, and property to the value of nine lakhs of rupees was destroyed.
('20', 448, 1, 10, 1049174) The number of rounds fired by the armed police and the troops was 748, and the number of ascertained casualties amongst the rioters was 28 killed and 123 wounded.
('20', 448, 1, 11, 1049337) The majority report comments thus on the measures taken to suppress the outbreak : “We are of opinion that the measures taken by the authorities to deal with the disturbances were appropriate.
('20', 448, 1, 12, 1049530) The use of military force was unavoidable and the rioters alone were responsible for the casualties which ensued.
('20', 448, 1, 13, 1049644) The control of the city was in the hands of the military for less than two days and this has been referred to as a period of Martial Law.
('20', 448, 1, 14, 1049782) But beyond maintaining order and issuing the procla mation on the 12th April, the military authorities did not interfere with matters of administration.
('20', 448, 1, 15, 1049935) The so colled Martial Law orders were drastic; but the situation was most serious.
('20', 448, 1, 16, 1050018) The belief that all groups of more than ten men would be fired on without warning did much to restore order, and it appears that this instruction was not in fact literally carried out.
('20', 448, 1, 17, 1050203) We think that the troops behaved with praiseworthy restraint in most trying circumstances, and that the military action taken was not excessive.
('20', 448, 1, 18, 1050348) The Bombay Government have informed us that the behaviour of the military during the period that they were stationed in the city was exemplary.
('20', 448, 1, 19, 1050492) Our investigation leads to the same conclusion.”
